HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Boom Was Real. But So Were Its Mirages.

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
IT may be hard to remember, but less than two years ago Tyco International and Enron were code words in corporate America for something very different than smoke and mirrors. They were, or so it was thought, the antithesis of the dot-com bubble. They made and sold real goods, be they burglar alarms and syringes in Tyco's case or oil and gas in Enron's, and they reported what everybody assumed to be real profits. As part of a wider boom in profits across corporate America, the two companies said they earned almost five times as much in 2000 than they had two years earlier.
 Last week, however, Tyco, a manufacturing conglomerate, joined Enron as a national symbol of corporate scandal. Tyco's chief executive quit on Monday, he was indicted the next day for tax avoidance, and investors sent the stock down to $10, about one-sixth what it had been when the year started. 
 Many people now fear that at least some of the difference between how Tyco performed in 2000 and in 1998 stemmed from how it accounted for its business, rather than how much business it did.
That, combined with the Enron mess and suspicions that other companies are about to join the scandal list, has raised a frightening question that now hangs over the American economy and the world's investment markets: Just how much of the broader New Economy was an illusion after all?
If the profit surge that stretched all the way through the 1990's rested to any significant degree on accounting sleights of hand, the nascent economic recovery of 2002 could be meager. Stocks and the dollar might both start to look overvalued.
Most economists agree that it is highly unlikely that the entire boom of the 90's will eventually be considered a mirage. Still, they say, it is not too early to begin separating the parts of the boom that remain vulnerable to debunking from those that seem solid.
Companies really did make vast new investments in factories and offices. Those did play a role in making businesses more efficient, and such increases in productivity are the ingredients for long-term improvements in living standards, since they let an economy produce the same number of goods with less effort.
The efficiency gains have continued even through the recession of the last year, making unlikely a quick return of the malaise that was common from the mid-70's through the early 90's, when many Americans thought of stagnation as the norm. 
"What's happening now is very serious," said Alice M. Rivlin, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, referring to the accounting questions. "But I don't think it calls into question the boom of the 90's."
The continuing stream of revelations do raise doubts, however, about whether the economy can revert any time soon to the relative bliss of late 90's, which stand as the best economic period in more than 30 years.
Even if they continue to become more efficient, many long-admired companies like General Electric are suddenly facing a newly skeptical audience. They have lost some of their favorite financial-engineering tools, making it more difficult to raise money for new projects and to keep stock prices rising.
These difficulties cannot erase the progress of the late 90's, but they have made that progress less likely to continue. Stocks will not rise, or even keep their current levels, so easily. New investments, and the jobs they create, may not be so common.
Investors are clearly spooked. After dropping by more than 300 points last week, the Dow Jones industrial average is 10 percent below a high it reached after both Sept. 11 and Enron's downfall. The value of the dollar has also been generally declining for weeks, suggesting that the United States economy has lost a little luster in other countries too.
The most tangible fear stems from what is only now being learned about the long profit surge that helped bring about so much of the expansion.
In the final years of the boom, many companies now appear to have overstated their profits, based on the wave of recent restatements and on the inconsistencies between corporate and government statistics.
I T was a classic case of bubble psychology," said Dean Baker, the co-director of the Center for Economic Policy and Research, a liberal group in Washington, who expressed doubts about the sustainability of the good times well before many others. "You had really strong profit growth in '94, '95, '96, '97, and that became the norm."
Executives knew that to keep their company stock prices rising, they had to keep profits growing. They also knew that their pay came largely in the form of stock and that a few dollars difference in the stock price equaled millions of dollars in their bank account.
Some companies, like Tyco, went on an acquisition binge, adding to their earnings by getting larger. Tyco also placed relatively low values on the hard assets of the businesses they were acquiring, thereby helping its own profits, based on current accounting rules, according to some investors. Many other companies classified inconvenient pieces of bad news as one-time events and tried to exclude them from profit numbers.
"We rely on the markets to reward the companies that are doing well and punish those that are not," Ms. Rivlin said. "You have to know the difference, and recently it's been hard to tell the difference."
Of course, the inflated estimates did have some positive effects, pumping money and jobs into the economy. The various bubbles probably helped the unemployment rate fall to its lowest level in 30 years, giving many people important new work experience.
But few aspects of this chain of virtuous events seem likely to be repeated in the current atmosphere. Many people are looking at their 401(k)'s and wondering whether the excesses caused a decade or so of stock-market growth to be compressed into a few years. Companies are reluctant to make new investments because they still have much more capacity to produce goods than they can profitably use. And a falling dollar, which increases the price of imports, could bring an end to the very low inflation of the last few years.
No economic expansion can last forever, of course. With its gains in productivity, however, the recent boom had the potential to create a solid foundation for its successors. But now, it has begun to appear, the widespread inflation of profits -- at Enron and Tyco and also at companies with far fewer problems -- has made that foundation far more wobbly than it once seemed.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Lessons From Enron; 
Greed Is Good, but Only Later

BYLINE:  By CHARLES R. MORRIS; Charles R. Morris is the author of "Money, Greed and Risk: Why Financial Crises and Crashes Happen."

 BODY:
LET's take another look at Enron. Sure, it may have phonied its books, possibly bilked California ratepayers out of billions of dollars, wiped out employees' life savings to manage its stock price, misdirected millions of shareholders' dollars into senior executives' pockets. Though capitalism's apologists hate to admit it, historically that's the way raw markets work.
 Enron was one of the first companies to see that the energy industry was on the brink of tectonic change. Energy is arguably the world's largest business, with annual revenues and investment in the trillions of dollars. It may also be the world's most inefficient business, riddled with subsidies, politics and protection. Local monopolies obstruct technological advances, sheltering expensive, polluting plants behind captive utility commissions. The national electric power grid is often called a creaky disgrace. 
 But the market liberalization process that Enron helped unleash will forever alter the current energy dispensation and replace it with something else, as yet undefined. And in the course of doing so, it will surely waste many, many times more money than California did, and undoubtedly give rise to even more staggering scams than Enron tried to pull off, over and over, probably for at least the next 10 years.
Nevertheless, the past suggests that consumers will ultimately be better off.
Recent examples of market shake-ups are all around. AT&T's technologically retrograde monopoly was known, not so affectionately, as Ma Bell. The centrally switched, one-line-to-a-caller AT&T telecom model has a lot in common with the centralized storage-and-distribution model of the power industry, and faced the same problems of capacity and high cost when communications needs accelerated.
Deconstructing AT&T has hardly gone smoothly. The implosion of the tech-stock bubble is probably best understood as the most recent chapter in the saga of telecom deregulation. Free markets offered vast new opportunities in Internet, wireless, broadband and fiber optics, and this touched off a mad scramble to get in on the bonanza.
Entrepreneurs like Gary Winnick of Global Crossing and Bernard J. Ebbers of WorldCom were able to leverage the public's enthusiasm into vast new network investments. Along the way, they apparently discovered many of the same accounting tricks that were used at Enron. Inevitably, there are thousands of miles of unused fiber and warehouses stuffed with high-tech boxes that were supposed to keep the networks humming. And consumers will probably have to put up with years of confusion about whom to call when phone lines go down.
But who would want to go back to the old ways? The seamless linking of voice and data networks have led to major improvements in business productivity that are stunning even without all the exaggerations. Meanwhile, schoolchildren take Internet access and surfing the Web for granted.
Or consider the revolution in real estate finance. Deregulation turned mortgage finance into a viciously competitive industry, helped cause the great savings and loan debacle and led to the great property bust of the early 1990's.
BUT look at what happened along the way. Independently of all the other factors that brought mortgage rates down, consumers now save more than $20 billion a year in lower mortgage interest and servicing costs, according to the best academic estimates. At the same time, deregulated markets have financed the relocation of what seems like half the country to the Southeast and Southwest. Compared to the gleaming office towers in cities like Charlotte, N.C., and Dallas, with their sprawling mega-malls and wooded apartment complexes, the $150 billion or so loss in the savings and loan wind-down looks like a minor overshoot.
The same applies to Michael Milken's decade of greed. Waste and abuse there was aplenty, but the junk bonds and the raiders they financed helped blow away a corporate old boy network that had proved unable to cope with competitive challenges from Asia and Europe. Without the violent brush-clearing of the 1980's, it is hard to imagine how America could have become the lean, mean, competitive machine that dominated the industrial world of the 1990's.
The important point out of all this is that it takes the excesses of an era like Milken's for markets and regulators to build the structures and rules to accommodate an advance in economic innovation. And so with Enron. Freer energy markets can lead to the kind of market rigging that may have happened in California, or to vast new economic efficiencies. The key is to keep them from running amok.
It has been ever thus. In just 20 years after the close of the Civil War, America laid down 50,000 miles of railroad track -- essentially the entire rail infrastructure that is in place today -- catapulting the United States into industrial leadership of the world. The cleanup that followed, masterminded primarily by J. P. Morgan, led to one of history's first de facto sets of rules for corporate governance and issuance of securities. Many of Morgan's reforms were later incorporated into New Deal securities regulation, yet another great market reform born out of chaos.
The path for market reform in the energy industry is clear. It will be in the direction of freer markets, greater technological diversity, more decentralized generation and active trading (or price discovery, as the professionals call it). Many of those things are happening now. The energy trading market is sufficiently deep that it survived the collapse of Enron with hardly a price ripple. Companies like Caterpillar have been generating their own cheap power for years, removing pressure from the grid, and are reportedly considering making decentralized industrial power generation a major business line. 
Uncharacteristically, Europe is moving even faster than America to break up the old national cartels. Newly freed gas and electricity markets in Britain are reported to save consumers $2 billion a year. There is no stuffing that genie back in the bottle.
Paradoxically, freer energy markets will succeed only under conditions of tight regulation -- but regulations that police the industry's honesty and transparency, with the teeth and the vigilance to swoop in on market spoilers of the Enron variety. And the depredations of the Enrons and their progeny will point the way, finally, to a truly modern energy market regime.

BYLINE:  By Jeremy Pearce 

 BODY:
 The state's bond rating was lowered last week by the Standard & Poor's credit rating agency, from AA-plus to AA. The agency's analysts cited the state's continuing revenue shortage and budget woes. HEADLINE: Investing; 
Ratings for Unrated Farmer Mac Debt Create Confusion

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
ELEVEN days ago, Moody's Investors Service took the unusual step of issuing a news release to clarify that it does not rate Farmer Mac's debt and never has. It also said that Farmer Mac was the largest issuer of unrated debt in the United States, with $3.2 billion outstanding, $2.3 billion coming due within a year.
 Nonetheless, confusion persists. In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Fidelity Investments, which holds Farmer Mac notes in five of its mutual funds, said that the paper had the highest rating, Aaa, even though Farmer Mac has never been rated by a major agency. 
 Fidelity acknowledged last week that the rating was only the assessment of its own researchers, and it said it would provide fuller disclosure in future reports.
On Friday, Bloomberg market terminals also showed Farmer Mac's discount notes as having top ratings from Standard & Poor's and Fitch Ratings. They have neither. Chris Taylor, a spokeswoman for Bloomberg, said the company would look into the problem. 
Part of the confusion stems from Farmer Mac's status as a government-sponsored enterprise. Created by Congress in 1988 to build a secondary market for farm loans, the company, whose official name is the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, reaps various benefits in exchange for carrying out its mission. 
One is the ability to borrow almost as cheaply as the government does because of a perception of government backing that emanates from a single section in its charter. That provision allows the Treasury, in certain circumstances, to provide up to $1.5 billion in loans to Farmer Mac to support the guarantees the company extends on farm loans. 
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which support the secondary market for home mortgages, have similar language in their charters. But they have sought ratings from Moody's to assure investors of their financial strength. In both cases, Moody's has rated the senior debt Aaa.
Farmer Mac, alone among the big government-sponsored enterprises, has never submitted to an outside rating. In a recent conference call with investors, Henry D. Edelman, the company's chief executive, said that it saw no need for one. 
Investors have suggested that the company has been holding out because it might not like the answer. Ratings can cost anywhere from $25,000 to $300,000. But a top rating can pay for itself by lowering borrowing costs, assuring investors that the notes are ultrasafe. 
Jennifer Engle, a Fidelity spokeswoman, said the fund company has assigned an Aaa designation to Farmer Mac's notes based on the research staff's conclusion that the notes were "of equivalent quality."
"We conduct our own research," Ms. Engle said, adding that "the critical component of our rating" is that Farmer Mac is a government-sponsored enterprise. 
To be sure, the $15 million of Farmer Mac paper in the five Fidelity funds amounts to a tiny fraction of their overall holdings. The Puritan fund has the biggest holding, with $8 million of its $20.2 billion invested in Farmer Mac as of Jan. 31.
Ms. Engle said she did not know how many other debentures sprinkled among Fidelity's 323 mutual funds carried ratings that are just internally generated opinions.
Right now, the five Fidelity funds' annual and semiannual reports describe Farmer Mac's medium-term notes as rated Aaa by Moody's. 
A footnote indicates that Standard & Poor's credit ratings are used "in the absence of a rating by Moody's." 
Shareholders have to pull up an entirely different report -- known as the Statement of Additional Information -- to learn that the source of published ratings may be Fidelity's own researchers. That document contains a proviso that "a debt security is considered to be investment grade if it is rated investment grade" by Moody's, Standard & Poor's or Fitch, "or is unrated but considered to be of equivalent quality by FMR," Fidelity's parent. 
"We don't view this as an error," Ms. Engle said. 
But, she added, "there's concern that it's not clear, so we are going to be clarifying the ratings in future shareholder reports." 
In contrast, Fulcrum Trust, a much smaller fund company whose June 2000 filings described its Farmer Mac notes as Aaa, said the information was supplied by a third party, Investors Bank and Trust. Andrew Joseph, a lawyer for Investors Bank, declined to comment. 
In 1990, Treasury officials made a proposal that would have have minimized the chances for such confusion. They advocated that government-sponsored enterprises be required to seek a credit rating to be eligible for government financing. Their plan was never adopted.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Global Partners: One in Hauppauge, One in Tonga

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE 

 BODY:
HIS Royal Highness Crown Prince Tupouto'a of Tonga, dressed in a lightweight double-breasted suit with a decorative pocket square, walked through Globecomm Systems' headquarters in the Hauppauge Industrial Park on Monday, his aides several steps behind.
 Stopping at a conference room, David E. Hershberg, who founded the company in 1994, introduced the prince, who shook hands with half-a-dozen executives and technicians. 
 The prince cedes most royal duties in Tonga, a three-island kingdom in the South Pacific, to his younger brother these days, so that he can concentrate on business ventures and travel. He and two aides, who had arrived in New York on May 26, were driven in a limousine from Manhattan to a hotel in Hauppauge to rest and freshen up before they were whisked away to a reception at Bedell Cellars, in Cutchogue. 
The prince, a son of King Taufa'ahau Tupou, was visiting in his capacity as the chairman of Shoreline Communications, a private Tongan enterprise that last year won the right to compete with the state-owned telecommunications company. Shoreline then chose Globecomm as its partner in a $9 million project that, Mr. Hershberg said, could soon expand throughout the South Pacific.
"Telephone service in Tonga is deplorable," the prince said. "There is substantial room for improvement."
But his new partner has set its sights beyond Tongan telephones. Globecomm says it can provide top-quality data transmission, mostly by satellite, for telephone, Internet and television service, not just on Tonga but on scores of South Pacific islands ranging from Fiji to New Zealand.
In a news release sent out a few days before the prince arrived, Globecomm noted that "as recently as the 1950's, the only link between the kingdom of Tonga and the outside world was a monthly banana boat to New Zealand." The release promised that by July, "Tonga will boast one of the most advanced wireless communications networks in the world."
By all accounts, the key figure behind this transformation is the prince himself. After all, it was the prince who e-mailed Globecomm last year after visiting its Web site.
The prince, who regularly travels around the world on both pleasure and business -- he is currently filming a documentary in Mongolia about farmers who hunt wolves with trained eagles -- said he was in town to meet the people behind the project. 
"Oh, I do like Long Island," he said during his Globecomm tour. "I try to visit often, and I very much like the Hamptons. I stay in a delightful little inn in Quogue. I don't usually get out as far west as we are today, though."
The prince speaks with a decidedly upstairs English accent picked up during his years of schooling in England. Like all visitors to the Globecomm building, he abided by the security policy and dutifully pinned on a badge that identified him as H.R.H. Crown Prince Tupouto'a. 
After a presentation of charts intended to demonstrate Globecomm's technical prowess and rosy future, Mr. Hershberg, the chairman and chief executive, was joined by the company's president, Kenneth A. Miller. They led the royal entourage through more than a dozen rooms, with a demonstration of some sort in most of them. The prince watched attentively as his hosts opened cabinet after cabinet containing control and monitoring equipment and discussed their inner workings in detail.
With a population that is just a shade over 100,000, Tonga is an unlikely business target for a Western technology corporation. But Globecomm, a publicly traded company that does about $100 million a year in sales, has set its sights far beyond balmy Tonga.
"This is really a pilot project for us," Mr. Miller said. "It can show what we can do for other countries through the South Pacific."
On Monday, the emphasis was on showing the prince just how close Tonga was to inaugurating what Globecomm called "state-of-the-art telecommunications." As the prince walked through the building, he was greeted by managers eager to demonstrate how the new technology would improve telephone service, Internet access and television and radio reception. 
Donald M. Gutman, the company's chief technology officer, shook hands with the prince, then began loading a 60-second trailer from a forthcoming Warner Brothers movie onto a desktop computer. As the trailer, a characteristically loud promotion laden with special effects, began, the prince remained on his feet. An aide raced over with a chair borrowed from a nearby desk, and the prince sat down.
The prince watched attentively, then asked, about halfway through: "Is this how it will appear to someone viewing this at home in Tonga?"
Mr. Gutman, looking a little surprised, acknowledged that in fact the trailer would be a little slower to load and the picture would probably not be quite as crisp. 
The prince quickly banished anyone's "King and I" preconceptions and peppered Mr. Gutman with a series of technical questions. Mr. Gutman looked relieved a few moments later when Mr. Hershberg led the group to another room for a demonstration of satellite-based telephone service.
When the tour was well into its second hour, the prince began to look a bit tired. Around noon he asked for a glass of water, and the party took a detour to the executive cafeteria. The prince sat down at a table, opened a pack of Dunhills and lighted one. When Suffolk County's no-smoking regulations were mentioned, the prince held out the pack and said with a smile, "Care for a cigarette?"
He seemed pleased when lunch was announced about 12:30. Regaining his stamina at the table, he was soon regaling his hosts with anecdotes from his travels, providing insights into the India-Pakistan hostilities, reciting a bit of dialogue from "Fiddler on the Roof" and recounting an obscure epigram attributed to Oscar Wilde.
His hosts, naturally enough, were eager to discuss telecommunications.
As a region of mainly undeveloped countries with users separated in some cases by thousands of miles, the South Pacific presents an ideal potential market, said Mr. Miller, Globecomm's president. "It isn't really economically feasible for a traditional phone company to build fiber optic for a relatively small number of users," he said. "For us, it's much easier and less costly to add users to our existing network."
Mr. Hershberg said he hoped the prince's company would take on the role of Globecomm's distributor, bringing in such neighbors as Fiji, Samoa and possibly New Zealand as its customers. That, in turn, would make Globecomm's South Pacific operations that much more profitable.
"The whole point of Monday was to show the prince our capabilities, and let him see the kind of people he's dealing with at Globecomm," Mr. Hershberg said.
And what did the prince think?
"He told me," Mr. Hershberg said, "that he was satisfied."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Prices Are Rising For Second Homes

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
Looking for a vacation home or investment property? Don't expect to find too many bargains.
 The market for second homes appears even stronger than the market for primary residences, and with millions of baby boomers poised to retire over the next couple of decades, prices are likely to climb even more. 
 The National Association of Realtors reported last week that the median price for a second home, new or existing, was $162,000 in 2001, a 27 percent increase from 1999, the last time the trade group surveyed second-home buyers.
The second-home median price was 10 percent higher than the $147,800 median for all homes in the United States last year, the association said.
Sales of second homes, though, were down. About 359,000 were sold last year, off 4.8 percent from the record 377,000 in 1999. "The mild recession in 2001 had a dampening effect on discretionary spending, resulting in a slight pullback," said David Lereah, the chief economist for the group. "Market specialists tell us that by the end of the year, the second-home market turned around and sales began to rise."
Mr. Lereah says buying was spurred by many factors, including low mortgage rates, averaging just under 7 percent, and limited inventory of available property, especially in coastal markets. In addition, he said, many aging baby boomers are investing in real estate rather than Wall Street. They apparently have decided that real estate will offer a better return -- and that they'll enjoy it more anyhow. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: Business; 
A Cloth Man With an Iron Will on Trade Policy

BYLINE:  By JANE TANNER 

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C. 

 BODY:
A FEW months ago, Jim DeMint expected an easy path to a third term in the House from a western section of South Carolina. Instead, he is facing a tough Republican primary on Tuesday. 
 What changed was simple: the textile billionaire Roger Milliken put his considerable weight behind Mr. DeMint's challenger, Phil Bradley, a Greenville real estate broker and former state lawmaker. 
Mr. DeMint's mistake, in Mr. Milliken's view, was a single vote he cast in late December. Minutes before final consideration of a bitterly contested measure to give President Bush expanded trade negotiating authority, Mr. DeMint switched to a yes from a no, providing the swing vote in a 215-214 outcome. Fellow Republicans and Mr. Bush promised him concessions for the textile industry. Most important was a provision that some garments imported from the Caribbean and South America must use American fabrics dyed and printed in the United States -- though the prospects for that concession now appear uncertain. 
Mr. Milliken says he was doubtful from the start about the promised concessions, and he has not softened on that vote on the "fast track" authority. "He betrayed us," he said of the congressman in late May, two days before presiding over a fund-raising event for Mr. Bradley in Spartanburg.
Mr. Milliken, 86, the chairman and chief executive of Milliken & Company, the textile and chemical maker that is the nation's 36th-largest private business, is still an adversary to be reckoned with. Since the 1960's, he has wielded significant influence in Washington.
He is a die-hard traditionalist. His critics even call him an isolationist -- defiantly fighting the tide of trade history and picking as his main battleground the trade deals that have gutted much of the textile industry in the Carolinas and sent hundreds of thousands of jobs overseas. In the process, he has found himself with an unusual mix of bedfellows, from Senator Strom Thurmond and Pat Buchanan to Ralph Nader and a prominent labor leader.
A gathering of his allies "would look like a bar scene in a 'Star Wars' movie," said Jock Nash, Mr. Milliken's longtime Washington lobbyist.
It seems a distinctly quixotic battle. Mr. Milliken, a staunch conservative, is going toe to toe against the Bush administration, most of the nation's business leaders and heavy spending from the retail and apparel lobbies, which were once allies against competition from low-wage countries. His adversaries, though, are not writing him off. 
"Milliken ultimately is going to create a lot of havoc," said Erik Autor, international trade counsel for the National Retail Federation. But, he added, "I don't see how he is going to prevail in the end." 
It will not be for lack of trying. Mr. Milliken has already elevated this Congressional race into an event of national interest. Mr. Bush appears daily in campaign spots for Mr. DeMint and has stumped for him. The president has also dispatched his senior adviser, Karl Rove, to South Carolina. 
Whether Mr. DeMint wins or loses, Mr. Milliken figures that he has managed to shake up lawmakers facing re-election.
HIS efforts in the South Carolina primary are part of a push to defeat the expanded trade authority. Although the measure passed the Senate last month after eight weeks of debate, significant hurdles remain, and a change of one vote in the House could create a snag.
In addition to Mr. Thurmond, Mr. Milliken's longtime allies include another Republican stalwart, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, who has been fighting fast-track authorization.
Mr. Milliken acknowledges that his influence will diminish when the two Republicans retire this year. With import quotas on textiles and apparel set to be removed at the end of 2004, and Chinese goods expected to flood in, pressure on American industry is high. In April, Mr. Milliken formed the American Textile Trade Action Coalition with Bruce Raynor, a textile union leader, and George Schuster, chief executive of Cranston Print Works in Rhode Island, the oldest textile company in the country. 
At stake could be the very heart of the textile industry. Since the enactment of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994, the industry has lost 700,000 jobs. One of the largest American rivals of Milliken & Company in textile manufacturing, Burlington Industries of Greensboro, N.C., filed for bankruptcy protection in November.
Since the end of World War II, when the United States helped Japan set up a strong textile industry, textiles and apparel have been a favorite pawn in global negotiations, said Ellen I. Rosen, a Brandeis University resident scholar. Her book, "Making Sweatshops: The Globalization of the U.S. Apparel Industry," will be published in October. 
Not much has changed. After Sept. 11, in return for cooperation with the American military, Pakistan asked for concessions on textile imports; Mr. Bush granted about a third of the $1 billion it requested. 
Mr. Milliken is skeptical. "I'm totally convinced that the American government told Pakistan, 'Ask for $1 billion, and then we can give you something,' " he said, calling the move an attempt to save face with the textile industry.
Not true, said Grant Aldonas, under secretary of commerce for international trade, who negotiated with the Pakistani government. "What the president did was try to strike a balance between the very real need to support one of our main allies in the war on terrorism and the interest of a lot of hard-working men and women in the American textile industry." 
Industry experts like Ms. Rosen say Mr. Milliken's latest efforts are futile in light of the industry's growing globalization. But Mr. Milliken's coalition is undeterred. Its main goals are to defeat expanded presidential trade power, to bolster enforcement against illegal textiles and clothing shipments and to cut the trade deficit by opening foreign markets to more American goods.
The coalition is promoting a House resolution aimed at forcing other nations to put their tariffs and import charges in line with those of the United States. "If we ship finished fabric to India, there are 40 percent to 80 percent tariffs and charges that keep it out," said Mr. Schuster of Cranston Print Works. "If India ships the same fabric to us, the tariff is 16 percent." 
Mr. Schuster has been criticized because Cranston buys some unfinished textiles from Pakistan and China. But he says the dyeing and finishing done by his United States employees are the real added value. 
Despite Mr. Milliken's conservatism -- he was an important contributor to Mr. Buchanan's 2000 presidential campaign -- many liberals agree with his attempts to thwart the export of jobs to low-wage countries. One of Mr. Milliken's more improbable allies is Mr. Raynor, head of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees. Mr. Raynor first became familiar with the Milliken operations in the early 1980's, when he went to the South to organize unions. Mr. Milliken resisted, and no union has ever operated in his American plants.
In 1982, after a legal battle lasting a quarter-century, Mr. Raynor began overseeing distribution of $5 million in court-ordered back pay to workers from a plant in Darlington, S.C., that Mr. Milliken shut in 1956 -- just days after a union was voted in.
At this point, though, Mr. Raynor is more concerned about saving jobs. He says that while he and Mr. Milliken have had their share of battles, he has not even discussed unionization with him.
Another unlikely partner is Mr. Nader, who accompanied Mr. Milliken in the early 1990's to cultivate allies against the World Trade Organization. Mr. Nash, the Milliken lobbyist, works hand in hand with Lori Wallach, head of Public Citizen's Global Trade Watch, a Nader spinoff that is fighting the fast-track measure. 
Mr. Milliken offers a quick response to anyone baffled by his alliance with Mr. Nader: "They don't know me." Indeed, many people are surprised to learn about this very private billionaire. 
He was a French history major at Yale, and is now a voracious reader who quotes the economic theorists Friedrich List and Adam Smith while tracing the demise of empires like Spain and Britain to their allowing their manufacturing bases to wither. 
He has intense affection for trees and gardens and talks just as passionately about a coral bark Japanese maple in the yard of his modest Spartanburg bungalow as he does about trade issues.
Nina Utne, co-founder of The Utne Reader, praised the Milliken family in the magazine's May issue for environmental sensitivity at its 100,000-acre forest property in Maine. Mr. Milliken's son Roger Jr. runs that operation. (None of the elder Mr. Milliken's three children work directly for the company.) Mr. Milliken would not disclose if the longtime president, Thomas J. Malone, who is 61, would succeed him. Mr. Milliken, in fact, divulges little about the company, whose sales were estimated by Women's Wear Daily at $3.5 billion for last year. 
The Spartanburg headquarters are filled with laboratories that have produced 1,600 patents and allowed the company to branch into chemical products that provide a hedge against textile losses. The company has 65 facilities with about 14,000 employees. 
Seth Milliken, Mr. Milliken's grandfather, was a co-founder of the business in 1865 in New York City. Roger Milliken, born and raised in the city, joined the company in 1941 and took over in 1947. 
Milliken & Company's materials are used in products as varied as automobile upholstery, hotel carpets and the balloons in the Macy's Thanksgiving parade. 
Mr. Milliken said he had never considered taking the company public. He has poured a much of his own money into research and development and invested heavily in employee training, people in the industry say.
Another compelling reason to stay private is to protect trade secrets. "They scrap their used equipment because they don't want competitors to see what they do," says Blanton Godfrey, dean of the textiles college at North Carolina State University.
Mr. Milliken is a micromanager. When he donated money to construct a science building at Wofford College in Spartanburg, he sat in on sessions with the architects. "He'd ask us, 'Where are trash cans located, and how do they get the trash out?' " Ronald Smith, one architect, said. 
On trade, though, Mr. DeMint says Mr. Milliken is out of touch. "My approach has been, 'Hey, what we're doing is not working,' " Mr. DeMint said. "What we need to do is recognize that trade is essential to the American economy. The reality is that just sitting on the sidelines and sniping at an administration that has demonstrated that it will help us is counterproductive." 
Mr. Milliken sees it differently. "DeMint is a nice guy, but DeMint is going to vote for fast track and Bradley is going to vote to save manufacturing jobs. That's the whole difference."

HEADLINE: The World: Home Front; 
Scoring Points While Connecting the Dots

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IT took a few months, but the war on terrorism now seems on the verge of giving America a semblance of wartime politics. 
 Political life had almost gone back to normal. Congressional Democrats had begun a drive to refocus voters on their traditional issues, like Social Security, health care and prescription drug benefits. And President Bush was visiting key electoral states and sounding once again like the "compassionate conservative." 
 But all of that evaporated in a flash with the revelation in May that Mr. Bush had received a C.I.A. briefing in August that terrorists were interested in hijackings.
By last week Capitol Hill was consumed by Congressional hearings and investigations into missed signals by the F.B.I. and C.I.A., and by warnings that America still faced the possibility of devastating attacks.
It's an unfamiliar politics, involving life-or-death questions reminiscent of the cold war, when voters weighed whose finger they wanted on the nuclear button and presidential debates would linger long over questions of arms control and a missile gap. 
Each party has responded uncertainly to this new political landscape. The White House first launched a withering attack on Democrats for asking questions, and suggested that the questioning itself was somehow unpatriotic. Then the president took a new tack and criticized the C.I.A. and F.B.I. 
By Thursday night, in an attempt to overshadow the F.B.I. whistleblower Coleen Rowley's appearance before the Senate, Mr. Bush was on prime time television calling for a vast reorganization of the government, similar to Democratic plans that his administration had been resisting.
Democrats too bobbed and weaved, moving from Watergate-era questions of "what did he know and when did he know it," to less partisan calls for a full examination of the nation's intelligence agencies. Some strategists fretted that their party was deviating from its poll-tested emphasis on domestic issues. But rebellious lawmakers said they could not shrink from the most significant issue of the new era.
"The notion that Democrats shouldn't be talking about world affairs and the war on terrorism is crazy to my way of thinking," said Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat. "If the Democratic Party looks like it is not up to dealing with these grave international issues we're doomed to defeat."
While few strategists were able to say how much security issues would define the 2002 elections, they expected them to be a central theme of 2004, when Mr. Bush's challengers will have to persuade the nation that they have the leadership abilities to handle the terrorist threat. For his part, Mr. Bush will have to show that he met the challenge.
"Terrorism is very much going to be on the next presidential ballot -- who can do a better job at security and who stands for better modernization," said Mark Penn, a Democratic pollster. "No one can run in the next presidential election without having strong profile on these important issues and that will make the election very different from the last election."
No wonder Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader and possible presidential contender, delivered a speech last week setting out the framework of a national security agenda, criticizing the administration for "moving too slowly to develop a homeland defense plan that is tough enough for this new war."
So far polls show that Mr. Bush has the confidence and approval of an overwhelming majority of the country. But strategists of both parties say there are new warning signs of anxiety and discontent in the electorate, with a rising and significant number of Americans now saying the country is on the wrong track.
"It's starting to deteriorate for a lot of reasons," said Carter Eskew, who had been a strategist for Al Gore, " as varied as the states' fiscal conditions, the economy generally but also a sense of real concern that the world is a dangerous place right now."
This erosion of confidence is a warning sign for Mr. Bush since a president's approval rating is usually tied to confidence that the nation is on the right track.
Strategists are waiting to see whether the president's announcement that he wanted a thoroughgoing reorganization of the government to meet the terrorist threat will reassure the public that he is in command. "The way people are going to look at this is did George Bush do the right things in terms of evaluating what had gone wrong and did he take the proper actions?" said David Winston, a Republican pollster. "People say yes. Look at the job approvals."
But some Democrats said Mr. Bush's decision to push a homeland security department was risky, in part because it will be difficult and because he initially resisted just such plans from Capitol Hill. "It's such a flip-flop," said one Democratic strategist. 
Congressional hearings will be going on for weeks, and Republicans as well as Democrats are asking sharp questions about what went wrong before Sept. 11. Part of what makes these hearings interesting is the palpable sense, beyond the usual political jockeying, that this is urgent national business.
"We're in a race with the terrorists to shut them down before they shut us down," said Representative Christopher Shays, the Connecticut Republican who is chairman of a national security subcommittee. "There is nothing normal about what we're dealing with." 
Still, Democratic aides also quietly acknowledge that their party has an interest in probing the performance of an administration that until now faced no criticism of its handling of terrorism.
"Politics works two ways," said one senior Democratic strategist. "You try to fight the fight on your turf, but it's also important to mitigate the strength of the other guys. To the extent that the party is raising questions about the Bush administration's competence that has a real long term payoff."
Democrats said they must move carefully and they face a difficult balancing act. Their party activists are longing for Congressional leaders to be more confrontational with Mr. Bush. But the country at large is not in the mood for any hint that anyone is seeking partisan advantage out of Sept. 11. Thus far, Democrats are simply asking somber questions about what went wrong and how to fix the government.
Republicans say that the president's call for homeland security should help them because it's an issue that plays to their base without alienating independent voters. Moreover, issues of security are usually Republican strengths.
"If I were Democrats I'd be trying to get off this issue as fast as I could," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
But with Congressional hearings just starting, no one knows what will unfold.
"Nobody knows where this is going to go," said Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican."Not just the political consequences but the realistic consequences. What if there is another terrorist attack?"

HEADLINE: Taboo Against Nuclear Arms Is Being Challenged in Japan 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8 

 BODY:
Alarmed by the rising power of China and anxious about the effectiveness of security guarantees from the United States, some of Japan's most powerful politicians have begun to consider breaking with a half-century-old policy of pacifism by acquiring nuclear weapons. 
 In comments that stunned many here, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's top aide told reporters last week that what Japan calls its three non-nuclear principles could soon come under review. 
 "The principles are just like the Constitution," Yasuo Fukuda, the chief cabinet secretary, was quoted as saying. "But in the face of calls to amend the Constitution, the amendment of the principles is also likely."
The Koizumi government was particularly embarrassed by the timing of the controversy. The first news stories about Mr. Fukuda's comments appeared while he was in South Korea attending opening ceremonies of the World Cup, for which Japan is a co-host, and came at the same time as Japan's foreign minister was calling upon India and Pakistan to pledge not to use nuclear weapons against each other. 
Amid a wave of criticism, Mr. Koizumi's government initially denied that the remarks had been made. Then came a belated admission by Mr. Fukuda, who insisted, however, that his comments were not intended to signal a policy shift. 
Mr. Koizumi went even further, saying his government has no intention of obtaining nuclear weapons.
Mr. Fukuda's comments came barely a week after another senior official, the deputy chief cabinet secretary, Shinzo Abe, said publicly that Japan could legally possess nuclear weapons, so long as they were "small." As a result, for many political analysts Mr. Fukuda's words became much more than a gaffe.
In one of his many attempts to explain away his remarks, Mr. Fukuda, one of Japan's most sober and sure-footed political figures, said he was merely trying to get "young reporters" to begin thinking differently about their country's future. 
Despite the denials of an imminent change, remarks like these indicate that a major shift in Japanese security thinking is under way.
Japan's official pacifism is more than a simple policy. Since the country's defeat in World War II with the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki -- the only time atomic weapons have been used in a conflict -- it has been an integral element of the national identity. The three non-nuclear principles -- never to own, produce or allow nuclear weapons on Japanese territory -- were overwhelmingly ratified in a parliamentary vote in 1971, reflecting the strong national consensus on the issue. The principles supplement the explicitly pacifist Constitution, which does not refer directly to nuclear weapons.
The comments by officials in Mr. Koizumi's government, however, come against a backdrop of other recent statements that show an erosion of support for pacifism, at least among the political class. Barely a month ago, an influential opposition leader, Ichiro Ozawa, all but predicted Japan's nuclear armament.
"If China gets too inflated, the Japanese people will become hysterical in response," he said. "We have plenty of plutonium in our nuclear power plants, so it's possible for us to produce 3,000 to 4,000 nuclear warheads."
Mr. Ozawa was pressured to retract his remarks. But then, according to the newspaper Tokyo Shimbun, Tokyo's mayor, Shintaro Ishihara, called Mr. Fukuda to congratulate him for his comments about nuclear weapons. Mr. Ishihara, a nationalist and one of Japan's most popular politicians, is widely seen as a possible successor to Mr. Koizumi.
All this was in telling contrast with the last time a prominent politician entertained such an idea. In October 1999, Shingo Nishimura, then the new vice minister of defense in the cabinet of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, said in an interview that Japan's failure to consider nuclear armament left it open to "rape" by China. 
The chorus of criticism that followed became so shrill that Mr. Nishimura was forced to resign.
"What we are seeing is vastly accelerated change post 9/11," said Robyn Lim, a professor of international relations at Nanzan University, in Nagoya. "Japan has watched how nifty Putin's diplomacy has been, deciding that Russia will cooperate on missile defense with the United States, and the effects of this will be transmitted here through China. China will build up even faster than they might have.
"You have to wonder then," she said, "how long Japan can remain the only non-nuclear power among the major countries in the region?"
The nationalist-leaning Mr. Koizumi came into office just over a year ago promising sweeping economic reforms, which he has largely failed to deliver, earning him unfavorable ratings. But he has used the alarm raised by the Sept. 11 attacks and the hawkish sentiments of Japan's politicians to push through big changes in Japan's defense posture.
Japan's neighbors have always regarded its non-nuclear status with skepticism. Japan spends lavishly on nuclear energy, promoting nuclear fuel enrichment programs that have produced stockpiles of weapons-grade uranium. Japan's space program, meanwhile, has developed rockets that could be converted into missile launchers. Japan's mastery of these two technologies already makes it a "virtual nuclear power," arms control experts say.
Japanese conservatives have long been frustrated by a Constitution that was written by the United States during the postwar occupation, from 1945 to 1952. The Constitution prohibits Japan from having an army or using force to settle disputes. Revising this clause would require a two-thirds majority in both houses of Parliament. Such backing would be difficult to achieve because pacifism enjoys continuing popular support.
Rather than try to revise the Constitution, Mr. Koizumi has simply decided to reinterpret it liberally. With little opposition, he dispatched warships overseas for the first time in the postwar period, to the Indian Ocean in support of the American campaign in Afghanistan. 
This month, he is pushing a bill before Parliament that would give Japan's armed forces much broader powers in an emergency.
"During the 1990's we had almost constant cabinet changes, and you could describe the process as one of drifting or being carried by the currents," said Yasuhiro Nakasone, a former prime minister who has supported a more assertive defensive posture for Japan. "What the Koizumi cabinet has been doing is trying to recover the lost ground."
North Korea, an ally of China, first set off reappraisals of Japan's defense needs when it test fired a ballistic missile over Japan in 1998.
That missile launching also served to renew doubts here about American guarantees of Japanese security under a longstanding mutual defense treaty. Japanese complained bitterly that Washington failed to share its reconnaissance intelligence and gave the country no warning of the North Korean launching.
In response, Japan accelerated development of its own costly spy satellite program, and politicians began discussing the need for something beyond American guarantees to defend their country.
"Simply put, we doubt that the United States would sacrifice Los Angeles for Tokyo," said Taro Kono, a member of Parliament. Mr. Kono does not support nuclear armament, but he is one of a growing number of young Liberal Democratic politicians who favor constitutional reform to allow Japan to defend itself with conventional arms.
Bush administration officials said they did not yet see any substantial shift in Japan. "We see no change in Japan's policy," said Sean McCormack, a spokesman for the National Security Council. "The U.S.-Japan alliance has never been stronger."

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: THE REACTION; 
Hopes and Doubts Over Bush Plan

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Many people in the transportation industry welcome President Bush's proposal to create a cabinet department for domestic security, even though it will certainly be the subject of pitched political battles in Congress.
 Transportation company officials said on Friday that they hoped the creation of a single umbrella department would eliminate the inefficiencies that plague agencies operating at airports, border towns and other points of entry into the United States. But they also remain wary of how effective the department will be, pointing out that it is too early to know how it will function. The department's creation should be carefully monitored, they said. 
 President Bush has suggested placing 22 federal agencies under a new Department of Homeland Security, which would have an initial annual budget of $37.5 billion. The agencies would include the Customs Service, the Secret Service, the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Transportation Security Administration, which is taking over security at airports. Legislators will almost certainly battle over the proposal because Congressional committees and subcommittees have jurisdiction over the various agencies.
But the airline industry, for one, is praising the president's move. Many airline executives said that the federal government is handling airport security with all the delicacy of a grizzly bear. Inefficient searches are driving customers away and slowing operations, they said. The new department could smooth that out and coordinate security efforts by all government agencies operating at airports, including the Customs Service and the I.N.S., the airlines said.
"Bringing these scattered agencies together under one centralized department is a wise decision that I expect will enjoy widespread support," said Michael Wascom, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group in Washington. "More sophisticated coordination, intelligence gathering and information exchange is essential to ensuring true homeland security. The president's plan takes a major step in that direction."
The proposed reorganization will most likely affect airlines, airports, shipping companies and border areas. Federally supervised searches have become customary within the transportation industry, and the efficiency of the procedures has been criticized widely. In some cases, old women are pulled aside to be swiped with magnetometers, baby strollers are run through X-ray machines and airline pilots are asked whether they have access to plane cockpits.
"The Port Authority supports and endorses measures that strengthen security," said Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the three major airports in the New York area, in addition to various bridges and tunnels. "We look forward to reviewing the details of this important initiative."
From January to March, almost 17 million passengers passed through the three airports, and virtually all of those taking departing flights had to go through security. Travelers arriving into the country have to deal with immigration and customs agents.
The United Parcel Service, which handles 12.4 million packages and letters within the country each day, said it intended "to take a thorough look at any legislation that is introduced." The company makes 1,062 domestic flights each day and has 88,000 delivery cars, vans, tractors and motorcycles worldwide. It said it did not have many complaints about the way the government has handled security so far, if only because it has tried to work closely with federal officials after the Sept. 11 attacks.
"We want to make sure there's a streamlined transition between any department or agency," said David A. Bolger, a company spokesman. Mr. Bolger said his company was also waiting to see whether all the responsibilities of the various agencies fell under the proposed department, or only security duties.
Officials at the largest ports in California also praised the president's proposal, saying they hoped that the department will make sure their security concerns are not overshadowed by those of airports. The Coast Guard, which patrols many ports, would fall under the new department. The Port of Long Beach, the country's second-largest cargo container port, said any additional money for security would be welcome. "We're encouraged the president is keeping the issue in the forefront and making sure that ports are part of that mix of what needs to be protected," said Richard D. Steinke, executive director at Long Beach, which moves about 12,000 containers a day.
But more than 120 miles to the south, at the border with Mexico, some Californians wondered whether the new department's creation would result in cumbersome border crossings. That could stifle the economy of nearby towns, they say, where business dropped by up to 90 percent immediately after Sept. 11 because of snail's-pace lines to cross from Mexico. As many as 8 out of 10 businesses along that border depend on the daily flow of Mexicans who come seeking blue jeans, designer clothes and Nike sneakers.
The proposed agency's "chief goal is to keep people out, while our goal is to keep the legal people coming across," said Representative Bob Filner, a San Diego Democrat. "We have trouble getting attention from Washington now. Imagine if we have to deal with Secret Service and the Coast Guard, too."
Business owners near the border say that it does not matter how long the actual wait is, because even the belief that there will be a serpentine line could scare people away. "If people sense they're going to have to wait two hours, they're not even going to make the trip," said Steve Otto, executive director of a business association in San Ysidro, Calif.
But many businesses said it is hard to tell how the new department would affect their day-to-day operations. After all, it is rarely easy to make sense of the intricate workings of the federal government. Those who have toiled within it understand this better than anyone.
"I hope there's follow-through to make this work," said George J. Weise, the federal commissioner of customs from 1993 to 1997. "Hopefully it's more than just rearranging boxes on an organization chart."

BYLINE:  By Nicole Vecchiarelli 

 BODY:

Jennifer Heitler, 25, television producer, Los Angeles

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
Former Crew of Excite Revisits the Bygone Days

BYLINE:  By ERIC HELLWEG 

 BODY:
Joe Kraus does not fidget as much as he used to. His words are often delivered after long, thoughtful pauses, and he has slimmed down since he resigned as senior vice president for content at Excite@Home in April 2000.
 Mr. Kraus, now 30, was one of more than 240 former executives and employees who gathered last Wednesday at the Portofino Grill in Foster City, Calif., for a reunion of Excite.com, as the company was known before its ill-fated merger with At Home in January 1999. Excite.com was once a formidable competitor to Yahoo but became one of the more spectacular flameouts of the dot-com era. 
 "Excite was me, and I was Excite," Mr. Kraus recalled. "It took me a long time to work through that." Mr. Kraus, a company co-founder, arrived at the party in his Jeep Cherokee, which has a license plate reading EXCITE. He was accompanied by his fiancee, Melissa Walia, a former Excite public relations executive. 
Former employees immediately gathered around Mr. Kraus. Hugs were exchanged, and some people proffered baby photos. Mr. Kraus chatted with one former co-worker who was clearly happy to see him but broke off to take a call on his cellphone 30 seconds into their conversation. Cocktail glasses, cellphones and, in some cases, baby bottles cluttered the tables on the waterside deck where Mr. Kraus stood.
Unlike many of the partygoers, some of whom are still searching for jobs, Mr. Kraus was able to cash out of his dot-com shares before the stock collapsed and came away with enough money -- he declines to say how much -- that he does not need to work. Not content to relax, however, he runs DigitalConsumer.org, a nonprofit company that aims to protect consumers' rights. 
The evening held all the potential for combustion: a couple hundred ex-employees, many of whom went down with the ship as Excite@Home filed for bankruptcy in October 2001 amid bitter board infighting. But the theme of the night seemed to be variations of Mr. Kraus's opinion that the Excite years were the best time of their lives.
Brian Murphy, who worked in the company's content division, stood a little farther down the deck, away from the chatter. He said he had not known Mr. Kraus. Nor did he share Mr. Kraus's financial good fortune. Mr. Murphy is now training to be a pastry chef in Oakland while drawing unemployment checks.
"I'm willing to chop vegetables for free, if I can learn about what I really want to do," Mr. Murphy said. "Getting laid off was a perfect opportunity to do that." ERIC HELLWEG

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Political Gridlock Halts Changes in Accounting Law
Six months after the collapse of Enron, the wave of enthusiasm for overhauling the corporate and accounting laws has ebbed and the toughest proposals for change have been thwarted. A consortium of lobbyists, exploiting partisan disagreement in Congress, appears to have killed the most far-reaching proposals, and the jockeying has begun over how to manage that outcome in the fall elections.
 Bills imposing more stringent accounting standards, changing the tax and accounting treatment of employee stock options, and setting tougher conflict-of-interest rules for stock analysts and accounting firms that perform nonauditing consulting services have all fallen victim to political gridlock. Section A. 

Private Effort to Fight Digital Theft
Antifraud companies, like CardCops.com, are part of a growing number of private organizations acting as digital security against thieves. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C7.

A Spokesman With Attitude, Almost
Gary Winnick, left, the chairman of Global Crossing, was said to be enthralled last year with an ad campaign that positioned James Gandolfini, the actor who plays Tony Soprano, as a company spokesman. But the plans were scrapped, in part because executives had concerns about the wiseguy image of a TV character who was under F.B.I. investigation. C3.

Trying to Cash In on Patents
A number of patent boutiques are popping up, hoping to help large companies transfer idle patents into royalties or arrange technology swaps. Royalties from inventions now earn an estimated $150 billion a year, an amount that is expected to climb 30 percent a year for the next five years. Patents. C2.

A Rift Among Webloggers
Five years ago, programmers pioneered Weblogs, or blogs, a form of hyperlinked online journal. Then came war bloggers, people who used Weblogs to vent their anger about the terrorist attacks. These days, many consider Weblogs to be inherently political, something that has angered Weblog veterans. C4.

Fire and Police Try to Market Goods
The annual trade show for marketers looking to license merchandise opens this week in New York. For the first time, the police department and the fire department in New York City will be exhibitors, trying to expand efforts to benefit their charities. Advertising. C11.

Sale of Chip Maker Is Delayed
The sale of Hynix Semiconductor in South Korea will be delayed until the end of the year, a move that was aimed at shoring up support for the ruling party in coming elections. C2.

NBC Was Interested in Letterman
Long before ABC tried to lure David Letterman away from CBS, NBC made a pitch to reclaim the talk show show. C8.

An April Fool's spoof by Harrods has turned into a trans-Atlantic lawsuit. C8.

Making Web Accessible to All
Just as a wall can obstruct a view in the physical world, graphics and page designs on the Web can become barriers for people relying on audio versions or braille. So unless Web designers provide a text equivalent, material can often be inaccessible to those relying on screen readers. New Economy. C4.

Revisiting Wasserman's Vision
Lew Wasserman embraced television at a time when the rest of Hollywood refused to do so. Though he might have had terrible taste in TV and movies, his understanding of technology, particularly as it applied to the distribution, was seemingly without parallel. C8.

HEADLINE: You Kidding Me? How Global Crossing Pursued Tony Soprano 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The F.B.I. is investigating the business practices of both men, leaders who depend on street smarts to run their respective organizations.
 One emerged from a modest Long Island upbringing to become a billionaire investor, the other from a dysfunctional Mafia family to command a New Jersey-based organized crime syndicate. 
 Gary Winnick, the real-life chairman and founder of Global Crossing, and Tony Soprano, the fictional New Jersey mobster of the HBO series "The Sopranos," might have been linked through a national advertising campaign, had things worked out differently.
Mr. Winnick was enthralled early last year with a campaign conceived and developed by a New York advertising agency that positioned James Gandolfini, the actor who plays Tony Soprano, as a tough-speaking spokesman for the communications company Global Crossing, several current and former Global Crossing employees said last week. 
But the plans were scrapped a few months later, as Global Crossing's financial problems were mounting, the advertising budget was cut and other executives at the company concluded that Mafia wiseguy imagery might not be the wisest course.
Global Crossing's accounting practices and business dealings are now under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the F.B.I. Some of its executives, including Mr. Winnick, amassed fortunes before the company's financial collapse resulted in the loss of 12,000 jobs. Creditors of the company, which is now operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, are owed more than $12 billion.
Global Crossing was riding high, however, when Mr. Winnick was presented with the idea of Mr. Gandolfini serving as the company's spokesman at a meeting in March 2001. The campaign, which included mockups of print ads and story boards for commercials, was created by the advertising agency Gotham Inc., a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
Mr. Winnick, who declined to comment for this article, liked the concept so much that he promptly called the producers of "The Sopranos" to inquire about Mr. Gandolfini's availability, said David Archer, the former head of global advertising at Global Crossing.
"They weren't interested, so we continued to pursue it through our agency, Gotham," Mr. Archer said. "We even discussed an offer that combined cash and stock, but it wasn't successful."
Stan Rosenfield, a spokesman for Mr. Gandolfini, said discussions did not evolve beyond a preliminary stage. "There was no offer to refuse," Mr. Rosenfield said. "It probably wasn't something he would have been interested in doing."
The reticence of Mr. Gandolfini's representatives was not the campaign's only obstacle. Several employees at Global Crossing expressed concern over ads that would portray the company, in the words of the campaign's creators, as "opportunistic," "relentless," "fiercely competitive," "street smart" and "ruthlessly efficient."
"Some of us looked at it and said they must be kidding," said Irene Dinolfo, a former marketing executive at Global Crossing. "It conveyed images of negative power and negative associations of Italian-Americans."
F. Stone Roberts, Gotham's chief executive, did not respond to requests for comment.
Rebecca Yeamans, a Global Crossing spokeswoman, said the company's advertising ambitions diminished significantly between January 2001, when the ad budget was set at $30 million, and this past January, when the company made its Chapter 11 filing.
"In early 2001, Global Crossing planned a significant branding and advertising campaign and reviewed plans presented by its advertising agencies," Ms. Yeamans said. "The company's plans were adjusted during the year by the marketing department, based on what they thought was appropriate at the time."
Several of the campaign's slogans had been particularly aggressive. One designed for outdoor venues read, "Speak softly, and carry a big fiber-optic pipe," in reference to the fiber optic cables fortifying Global Crossing's 27-country network. (Actually, the word "big" was embellished with a vulgarism.)
"Wireheads developing technology that kicks butt," proclaimed one television ad that concluded with this tagline: "Yeah. That's how it's done when it's gotta get done."
Nearly all the officials at the company who had worked on the advertising campaign lost their jobs after John J. Legere was named chief executive in October and implemented a series of cost-cutting measures.
Mr. Winnick, meanwhile, who remains chairman of Global Crossing's board, continues to care about public perceptions. He recently replaced Sitrick & Company, a public relations firm in Los Angeles, with Rubenstein Associates, a New York-based crisis management company, to manage his personal image.
Howard Rubenstein, Mr. Winnick's current spokesman, sought to put a positive spin on his client's Sopranos flirtation. "The idea was presented on a story board by the advertising agency," he said. "After some preliminary research on this and many other concepts, it was rejected. In any case, Gary was not the decision maker on any advertising campaign."

HEADLINE: U.N. Hunger Meeting Opens Today, Minus Most Top Leaders 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: ROME, June 9 

 BODY:
Most of the world's top leaders will skip the opening of the United Nations conference on hunger on Monday, undermining hopes that the meeting will resuscitate efforts to dramatically reduce world hunger.
 While dozens of leaders from developing countries have flocked to Rome, including Zimbabwe's shunned president, Robert Mugabe, only the heads of two wealthy Western countries -- Italy and Spain -- are expected to attend. 
 Jacques Diouf, the director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said bitterly before the four-day meeting that this was "a good indication of the political priority that is given to the tragedy of hunger." 
Many affluent countries grouped in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development will be represented by their agriculture ministers, who are expected to resist United Nations demands to pump more cash into the war on hunger.
The Rome summit meeting follows a 1996 event at which delegates vowed to cut the number of hungry people from 840 million to no more than 400 million by 2015. But in the past six years, the number has only dropped to 815 million.
In order to hit the 1996 goal, the F.A.O. is seeking an additional $24 billion a year in agricultural and rural investment. At present, overseas development assistance from wealthier countries totals some $68 billion, of which only $11 billion is earmarked for agriculture. 
The conference is also likely to revive heated debate over the development of genetically modified crops, which is being pushed by the United States but is opposed by non-governmental organizations meeting on the sidelines in Rome.
United States and European Union officials will also come under pressure over the substantial subsidies paid out to their farmers, which the F.A.O. says depress world commodity prices at the expense of third world producers.
The absence this week of top world leaders means that Mr. Mugabe, who has managed to sidestep an European Union travel ban to attend the conference, might steal the limelight. Western governments say Mr. Mugabe is partly responsible for food shortages affecting millions of people in Zimbabwe following the invasion of productive, white-owned farms over the past two years by militants loyal to the president.
The European Union has banned Mr. Mugabe from traveling in its countries because of his treatment of political opponents, but is obliged to make an exception for the food conference because it is under the ausices of the United Nations.
