HEADLINE: Harlem Neighborhood Competes For a Stretch of Riverfront Turf 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The strip of land was once a vibrant waterfront, with a breezy recreational pier that provided an escape from the sweltering streets. In the days before the George Washington Bridge and the Henry Hudson Parkway, it was also an important transportation center, where you could catch a ferry for Northern New Jersey or Coney Island, or board a Hudson River Day Line boat heading for Albany.
 But today, the city-owned property between St. Clair Place and 135th Street, one of the last segments of undeveloped Manhattan shoreline on the Hudson River, is a litter-strewn stretch of asphalt that is used for fishing and as a parking lot for the Fairway Market across the street. 
 Over the years, developments ranging from hotels to housing have been proposed for this piece of waterfront, which is still known as the Harlem Piers even though the piers were torn down long ago. None of the proposals went anywhere. 
These days there are two competing, and largely incompatible, proposals for the piers: one, put together by the city's Economic Development Corporation after years of discussions with the community, would use the waterfront primarily for recreation; the other, being promoted by Representative Charles B. Rangel, the powerful Harlem Democrat, would turn the piers into a tourist-driven entertainment center. Both proposals would restore ferry service.
In recent weeks, Mr. Rangel has been meeting with state and city officials to talk up his vision for the piers, and a slick booklet prepared by the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce and outlining a three-phase development plan for the waterfront has been circulating. Mr. Rangel's chief of staff, Jim Capel, said that the congressman's model was Chicago's Navy Pier, a tourist attraction with rides, restaurants, museums and theaters that was completed in 1995.
Mr. Rangel has said he would like to help finance the project through the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a federal, state and city program in which he plays a key role. The president of the empowerment zone, Terry C. Lane, said the piers should serve as an anchor for economic development in the area. "We will take a leadership role in developing the pier, working closely with E.D.C.," he said. 
Many people in the community say that this scrap of land -- a mere two acres in size -- cannot serve two purposes. "The community wants the area across from 125th Street to look more like a park," said George Goodwill, the chairman of Community Board 9, which represents the neighborhood near the piers. "The community has said that strongly, over and over again,"
In their view, a park would help offset the annoyance of having a sewage treatment plant, waste transfer station and bus depot nearby. (The nearby Riverfront State Park does not compensate for these liabilities, some people say, because it sits on top of the sewage plant.)
"The issue becomes, who is the waterfront being developed for?" said Peggy M. Shepard, the executive director of West Harlem Environmental Action, an advocacy group. "Is it a community benefit, for a community that has been disproportionately affected by pollution by the waterfront, or is it for someone else? Historically, this community has been opposed to the notion that the waterfront is for someone else."
The city's plan for the waterfront is an outgrowth of a process that began in 1999, when the Harlem on the River Committee -- made up of residents, planners, local officials, Ms. Shepard's group and representatives of Columbia University, which owns a number of properties in the area -- met to generate ideas for reviving the piers.
In December, the Economic Development Corporation presented a preliminary master plan -- from the piers to Broadway -- to the community board. Under the plan, the strip along the waterfront would be an esplanade, with piers for fishing, kayaking and ferry boats. It would be maintained with revenues generated by a waterfront restaurant. The plan also calls for retail development under the Riverside Drive viaduct and perhaps the addition of high-tech businesses to the existing small businesses on Broadway.
The other plan, which Mr. Rangel supports, was worked out by the Chamber of Commerce and would include a Mississippi riverboat permanently moored along the piers. The boat, to be operated by Circle Line, would have a restaurant and banquet hall and would be able to accommodate 2,000 people, said the chairman of Circle Line, Karl G. Andren.
Ms. Shepard said that the riverboat proposal was inconsistent with the neighborhood's goals. "This is a very small space," she said. "To have a boat there could detract from kayaking and other recreational pursuits, and cut off views to the waterfront." Mr. Goodwill said there was concern that the boat would ultimately be used for gambling.
Mr. Andren, however, said the riverboat would create jobs. "That would be a unique thing to have up there," he said.
The Chamber of Commerce plan also calls for an elevated viewing platform and a floating stage. (A proposed floating garage for 300 cars has been deleted from the proposal because it is certain to be met with hostility from the community, Mr. Andren said.) 
Less likely to meet with resistance is the Circle Line's proposal to create a stop for excursion and charter boats, in keeping with the piers' historic role. From the late 19th century until the 1930's, the Harlem Piers were a major transportation hub, said Eric K. Washington, the author of "Manhattanville: Old Heart of West Harlem." Ferry boats took families to the Palisades Amusement Park near Fort Lee, N.J. Large steamboats traveled up the Hudson, making stops at 129th Street, Bear Mountain and West Point on the way to Albany and Troy. Smaller paddle-wheel boats took beachgoers to Brooklyn.
The piers and their surroundings were also a thriving industrial area, home to many meatpacking plants. Today, the gritty neighborhood is still zoned for manufacturing, with a few small meatpacking and cleaning businesses operating.
When economic development officials in the Giuliani administration began working on their master plan for the piers, they optimistically announced that waterfront construction would begin this summer. Economic Development Corporation officials in the Bloomberg administration say there is no specific timetable.
According to the preliminary plan, about $20.2 million in public funds would be needed to redevelop the waterfront, with another $4.7 million in private investment. City officials say that given the current budget crisis, more commercial uses than those outlined in the plan may be required to get the project going. In this view, even the Chamber of Commerce proposal may be inadequate, the officials say privately. (The empowerment zone does not invest in private ventures, but it can provide multimillion-dollar loans at below-market rates that lower the developer's risk.)
Public officials are loath to criticize Mr. Rangel, but privately some say that his plan is impractical.
Kevin Corbett, the executive vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's development agency, said the Pataki administration would like to see the area improved. But he suggested that the piers were unlikely to support much commercial development.
"Using the piers to draw people to the waterfront and using the waterfront to draw people to 125th Street makes a lot of sense," he said. "But the majority of economic development would likely be inland."

HEADLINE: Antiterror Fight: Why the Philippines? 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Monday, June 10 

 BODY:
When rebels in the southern Philippines kidnapped an American missionary couple more than a year ago, it was not the first time the Abu Sayyaf group had seized Americans.
 But after Sept. 11 there was a new determination to go after terrorists, and American troops went to the Philippines. 
 Philippine soldiers came upon the rebels late last week, in an encounter that killed one of the American hostages, wounded the other and also killed a Filipino hostage. It looked like the botched ending to one chapter of the American effort against terrorism. 
American and Philippine officials disagree. But the episode raises many questions about the American military role here.
Bracing for criticism, the officials have heaped praise on the operation and the United States military mission here in general.
"This was a successful operation" declared Roilo Golez, national security adviser to the Philippine president. "Enormously successful," said a senior American official.
If Washington does not want to be the world's policeman, this official argued, then it "should find satisfaction" in the fact that the Philippines took responsibility for rescuing the hostages and trying to destroy Abu Sayyaf, a small group that sometimes spouts militant Islamic slogans but is more a criminal gang than anything else. 
Indeed, Manila would not let the United States play a more aggressive military role.
The larger question is why the Bush administration chose the Philippines for its first major military foray after Afghanistan; it sent 1,200 troops, including 160 Special Forces who operated on the island of Basilan, where Abu Sayaf has its base.
The answer ranges from the the desire for a quick victory over terrorism to, more broadly, the wish to reassert American power in Southeast Asia.
The current American-Philippine military exercises are scheduled to end on July 31. But officials from both countries say the mission may be extended, particularly the civic action aspects -- soldiers building schools and roads and carrying out other community projects.
The "world's policeman" concept aptly fits what the American military has been doing in the Philippines for the last four months, in that its campaign was like a police action against a band of criminals who terrorized and kidnapped for profit. 
If the United States is going to go after groups like Abu Sayyaf, whose links to Osama bin Laden are tenuous, the list of further targets is potentially long.
Publicly, the mantra recited by American and Philippine officials was that the American soldiers were here to "train and assist" the Philippine armed forces to combat terrorism. 
Privately, officials on both sides acknowledge that the real purpose was to rescue Martin and Gracia Burnham, the missionary couple, who came from Kansas, and to deal a decisive blow to Abu Sayyaf.
But Mr. Burnham and a third hostage, Ediborah Yap, are dead. Abu Sayyaf has not been wiped out, and its hard-core leaders appear to have escaped.
Leaving Manila today for home, Mrs. Burnham called her abductors "common criminals" and thanked the soldiers, American and Filipino, who she said had "risked and even gave their lives to rescue us."
While brutal, Abu Sayyaf is a relatively small outfit in the world of international terrorism, and its commitment to a militant form of Islam is questionable.
In the early 1990's the group received money from Muhammad Jamal Khalifi, brother-in-law of Osama bin Laden, who channeled money to militant Islamic groups through various aid organizations here.
Also, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the mastermind of the 1993 attack on the World Trade Center, trained some Abu Sayyaf members in explosives.
Abu Sayyaf never had more than several hundred members, though, and by the time the American forces arrived this year, there were fewer than 200 armed guerrillas. Whatever ideology the group once had, American officials say, the members now are basically thugs who kidnap for profit and spend some of the proceeds on arms.
At one time the Philippine military probably used Abu Sayyaf against other Islamic groups to sow discord, Marites Danguilan Vitug and Glenda M. Gloria, investigative journalists, wrote in "Under the Crescent Moon: Rebellion in Mindanao," published in Philippines in 2000. The book is a definitive study of the Muslim rebellion in the Philippines.
The Moro Islamic Liberation Front, which wants an Islamic state on Mindanao, the second-largest island in the Philippines, is far more powerful than Abu Sayyaf. 
It has at least 25,000 members and over the years has wreaked much more havoc on Philippine society and the economy. But it recently began peace negotiations with the government and has never kidnapped Americans.
If Washington's objective is to wipe out the international terrorist organizations that pose a threat to world stability, the Islamic terrorist groups operating in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir would seem to be a higher priority than Abu Sayyaf. 
The members of many of those groups were trained at Al Qaeda camps in Afghanistan, and they have carried out numerous terrorist attacks in India, all but inciting a war.
The Bush administration may have selected Abu Sayyaf because it looked like a chance to win a relatively easy battle early in the war. And for spite, the group was holding Americans hostages and sometimes beheaded its captives.
In a broader sense, the United States may have wanted to strengthen its military presence here, and across Southeast Asia, which declined after the cold war, especially after the American military left two big overseas bases, Clark and Subic, in the Philippines a decade ago. 
Adm. Dennis C. Blair, until recently the commander of American forces in the Pacific, was the architect of the training mission in the Philippines. Like many Asia experts, he expressed concern about the increasing lawlessness in the Philippines, the rise of extremist groups, and a sharp decline in the military's professionalism.
If the United States does extend the military mission, the American Embassy has drawn up a plan to extend the military's civic action program to two small islands.
But historically, it has been easier to get Congress to approve money for big military items than for nation building. The Philippines may offer that lesson once again.

HEADLINE: North Dakotans to Vote On Bank Privacy Rules 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: FARGO, N.D., June 6 

 BODY:
North Dakota voters on Tuesday will be the first in the country to make their own choice about how to regulate financial privacy. A statewide referendum will decide if banks and other financial institutions can continue to share or sell data without obtaining customer permission.
 A disparate coalition seeking tighter privacy restrictions, reaching from labor and the American Civil Liberties Union to a small conservative organization, the Constitution Party, forced the referendum on the ballot. There are unusual allies on the other side, too: the banks and credit unions, which often fight each other on financial regulation. 
 A previous state law required financial institutions to obtain permission before sharing data. But last year the legislature voted for a new system that allows banks and credit unions to sell data. It does not require them to obtain permission. Customers can prevent the distribution of data by objecting. 
The referendum allows voters to keep the new system by voting yes, or to return to the stricter system by voting no. 
As part of a general overhaul of banking laws in 1999, Congress allowed financial institutions to share data without obtaining permission. That law did allow states to impose stricter rules. A handful of states, including Vermont, Alaska and Illinois, have retained strict rules, known as opt-in. 
In a debate here last week, Charlene Nelson, head of the Constitution Party and a group favoring the stricter rules, Protect Our Privacy, made the emotional case for tighter privacy. "If you believe, as I do, that your private information belongs to you, that it is your private property and you have a right to protect it without taking extraordinary measures," she said, "then vote no."
Gov. John Hoeven, a Republican and a former banker, outlined an argument, which he conceded was complicated, for keeping the 2001 law. He said in an interview in Bismarck that the difficulty of attracting business to this remote, cold state, especially the financial businesses that have provided many new jobs, would be further complicated by banking laws that differ from regulations in most of the country.
Privacy advocates in Washington see Tuesday's vote as very important. The A.C.L.U. gave $25,000 this week to help the campaign for stricter privacy rules. Evan Hendricks, editor of the newsletter Privacy Times, said: "It's huge. It's the first time Americans have had a chance to vote" on the issue. If the "no" side wins, he said, "I think it's going to lead to petition drives in other states." 
Paula Bruening of the Center for Democracy and Technology said North Dakota was a leader in an effort spurred by the perception that the federal law "didn't address consumer concerns adequately."
Under the basic federal privacy protections in place in most states, financial institutions send out descriptions of their privacy policies annually and provide customers an opportunity to opt out of having their information shared.
Since the majority of those notices are ignored by customers, the default position, which allows information sharing here and in most states, dominates. As Heidi Heitkamp, a Democratic former attorney general whom Mr. Hoeven defeated in 2000, asked, "Why should every person in North Dakota have to watch their mail with an incredible diligence to protect their privacy rights?"
In the debate here, each side is making its case on what even its opponents concede are rational fears.
North Dakota bankers insist that they do not sell consumer information, and that to do so would immediately lose them customers. State Representative Jim Kasper, who fought the new law in the legislature, recently said at a Rotary lunch in Jamestown Tuesday that he did not believe the state's banks were selling data. But he said he did not want to rely on promises, any more than a bank would loan him money for a car if he said: "Hey, I promise I'll pay the loan. What do I have to sign documents for?"
A poll taken for bankers showed that most North Dakotans trust their own bankers. The state's population of 650,000 makes it possible for managers and tellers to know customers personally. But many voters also know that U.S. Bank, a Minnesota institution that does a lot of business here, paid several million dollars in 2000 to settle lawsuits charging that it violated customers' rights by selling data to telemarketers.
Many who oppose tighter privacy restrictions concede that they do not know for sure that such rules would hurt the state's economy.
But State Senator Deb Mathern, who runs a 2,388-member credit union with $15 million in assets here, said that because "we work very hard to make this an attractive place for business to thrive," no chances should be taken. Even though she got a $25 check in the U.S. Bank settlement, she said, the privacy issue does not trouble her. She argued that very little privacy is left, and that most of the information she has on customers, including loan applicants, could be found elsewhere by determined marketers.
About four months ago, the North Dakota Bankers Association arranged through the Financial Services Coordinating Council, a Washington-based alliance of financial trade associations, to have a poll taken. The poll found that about half the voters opposed the new law, with its looser privacy protections, while about three-tenths favored it and one-fifth were undecided.
But according to defenders of the law who have seen the data, which they would not release, the poll also showed opportunities. It found that North Dakotans feared being isolated economically. That finding led to one widely broadcast television commercial, showing a suddenly advancing wall cutting off the state's boundaries, even slicing through bridges.
The poll also suggested that North Dakotans might distrust banks in general, but not their own bankers. So bank employees have been writing to customers, talking up the issue at work. State Representative Bob Martinson, now the paid chairman of Citizens for North Dakota's Future, closes his debate appearances by saying:
"Go down to your local bank, go down to your local credit union, go down to the person who has helped your son get his first car loan, your daughter get a little extra money for college, the person that has helped you with your checking account when it has been a little off kilter. Ask that person, ask the person you have done business with for the last 10, 15 or 20 years, ask them what they feel about this issue. Then I believe that you will vote yes -- not to make North Dakota an island, not to build a wall around us."
The poll, which has been kept secret here, provided the major outside help for the law's defenders. They see no advantage in tying the issue to the outside banking interests that have been devil figures in North Dakota politics for many years, and indeed led to the creation in 1919 of the North Dakota State Bank, which Governor Hoeven used to head.
For weeks the defenders had the only advertising campaign going, although radio personalities like Ed Schultz, a talk-show host heard statewide, argued hard for "no" votes, to throw out the less restrictive law. Mr. Martinson said he expected the campaign to cost $150,000 or $160,000.
But when the American Civil Liberties Union contributed $25,000, a sum in the same ballpark as the cost of the poll taken for the bankers, Protect Our Privacy began a heavy radio advertising campaign.
"Banks can legally sell your private records without even asking you," one commercial says. "Voting no on Measure 2 cancels Senate Bill 2191 and gives your privacy rights back to you. Protecting your privacy won't build any walls around North Dakota, but it might help you get through supper without a telemarketer trying to sell you something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A North Dakota referendum calls for continuing to let banks share customer information without permission. A commercial in support of the measure shows the state's boundaries being cut off by tightened privacy rules.

HEADLINE: For Jobless, Time and Aid Are Almost Up 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Over the next two weeks, as many as 100,000 jobless New Yorkers will lose their economic lifeline: temporary unemployment benefits.
 Congress created the benefits in March to help unemployed workers who had used up six months of regular state unemployment payments and had not found a job. The federally financed program gave them an additional 13 weeks of benefits. 
 But for the first New Yorkers who signed up for the program -- 100,300, according to federal data -- those 13 weeks are almost up. New York has the largest number of people coming off the rolls but, unlike other economically depressed states, including California, it does not qualify for an additional federal extension that gives the unemployed up to a year of payments. 
The prospect of thousands of unemployed New Yorkers suddenly losing their income is alarming food banks and social service agencies, and concerning economists who track the region. It has caught the attention of some lawmakers in Albany. And it promises to become an issue in the state's gubernatorial race.
But the people most deeply concerned about the loss of benefits are the unemployed themselves, people like Miriam Engstrom of Queens. Mrs. Engstrom, who worked in the Internet division of a financial firm, has been jobless for a year, despite a diligent search and a willingness to take pretty much any job. 
She said that like many of her friends in their 30's, 40's and 50's, she has been living off her savings and unemployment insurance payments, which will run out within weeks.
"We've always saved for a rainy day, but I think this could very well go into next year," she said. "Then what?"
Congress created the unemployment insurance system after the Great Depression, to help people who lost their jobs through no fault of their own. The regular programs are run by each state and financed by taxes on employers; in New York, the unemployed receive a maximum of $405 a week for up to 26 weeks.
But during recessions, Congress has often created a temporary, emergency unemployment insurance program, as it did in March. That program gave 13 weeks of federally financed benefits to the jobless in every state.
In New York, 137,000 people are now enrolled in the temporary plan. A State Department of Labor spokesman, Robert M. Lillpopp, said officials believed that at least some people who signed up for temporary benefits eventually found jobs, but he added that they did not now how many.
Roughly 191,000 people are receiving regular benefits and will be eligible for the temporary program if they exhaust them. Half of the New Yorkers who go on unemployment have been exhausting their benefits this year, according to data from the federal Department of Labor.
Congress also said states could become eligible for 13 more weeks, but only if the number of people receiving unemployment benefits rises sharply and averages 4 percent of the labor force.
In Oregon, which got the second extension, the "insured unemployment rate" is 4.7 percent and the regular unemployment rate has been about 7.8 percent.
In New York State, by contrast, the unemployment rate is 6.1 percent and 3.3 percent of the labor force is receiving unemployment, according to the federal Department of Labor. State officials do not think it will go high enough to qualify for an extension, Mr. Lillpopp said.
Unemployment in New York is heavily concentrated in New York City, where in April the unemployment rate rose to 7.7 percent, after seasonal adjustments. But in the rest of the state, the rate is just 5 percent, significantly below the national average, 6 percent.
Congress is unlikely to come to the rescue of unemployed workers in states that do not qualify for the automatic extension, said Wendell Primus, director of income security for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group. One reason is that in May, the states received $8 billion from the federal unemployment fund, money that could be used to extend benefits.
But New York has spent its share -- $491 million -- to pay for regular benefits and to repay a $189 million federal loan it took out in January when the unemployment fund ran out of money, Mr. Lillpopp said. Any effort to extend benefits at the state level would "immediately undermine the integrity of the U.I. trust fund, which has already been negatively impacted by Sept. 11," he said. 
Employers would also vigorously oppose a state extension, said Matthew Maguire, a spokesman for the Business Council of New York State.
Nevertheless, legislators are working on a bill that would use state money to extend benefits to those who have exhausted the federal program. "We're trying to get our ducks in a line as quickly as possible," said Catherine T. Nolan of Queens, chairwoman of the Assembly's Labor Committee. The legislative session is to end in about a week.
Advocates of a state-financed extension say that New York could spend money now in the fund -- about $800 million -- take out another loan, or enact a temporary tax increase, as Minnesota did. 
"It's a matter of priorities," said Maurice Emsellem, director of public policy at the National Employment Law Project.
Andrew M. Cuomo, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, said on Friday that he supported an extension, and criticized Gov. George E. Pataki for allowing the unemployment fund's reserves to fall to very low levels during the economic boom. "Since being in office, the governor has done nothing less than mismanage the state's unemployment insurance fund, and the consequences are severe," Mr. Cuomo said in a statement. A spokesman for H. Carl McCall, Mr. Cuomo's Democratic rival, did not respond to a request for comment.
In response to Mr. Cuomo's comments, Mr. Lillpopp said: "Andy sat at the right hand of his father as they drove New York's jobless rate up to 7.8 percent, lost hundreds of thousands of jobs and borrowed more than $715 million for the federal U.I. trust fund in the last two years of their administration alone."
History suggests that people who exhaust their emergency benefits during a recession have a hard row to hoe. In the early 1990's, almost a quarter of those whose benefits ran out were unable to find a job within three years, said Walter Corson, who directed a study of emergency benefits by Mathmatica Policy Research Inc. for the federal Department of Labor.
A study done in 1994 by the New York State Department of Labor after the last recession found that about 6 percent of people whose benefits ran out filed for bankruptcy, and 26 percent said they were receiving some kind of public assistance.
That may well happen again, said Mark Levitan, a senior policy analyst for the Community Service Society of New York. "The first safety net, unemployment insurance, is ripping apart," he said. "Next comes the welfare system."
Food pantries are already experiencing a surge in demand from the unemployed, said Lucy Cabrera, president of Food for Survival, the city food bank. "We're worried about what we're going to be seeing in the next few months," she said.
And the presence of so many workers without income could affect the city's economic recovery, said Mark Zandi, chief economist for Economy.com, a firm that specializes in regional studies. "It suggests that the city's economic adjustment still has a way to go, and that the drag on the economy really hasn't been felt yet," he said, adding that he expected the city's unemployment rate to continue to rise for most of the year.
That's bad news for Krystyna Walter, a consulting engineer who just turned 60 and was laid off Nov. 1. Ms. Walter has about nine weeks of temporary benefits left, but said she would like an additional three months to get through the slow summer hiring months.
"Nothing is happening in the city -- this is really scary," she said. "Time is running out extremely fast."

HEADLINE: Wider Military Ties With India Offer U.S. Diplomatic Leverage 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, June 9 

 BODY:
When Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrives here this week, he will have the ear of India's senior political leaders in a way that would have been hard to imagine for most of the past three decades.
 Military cooperation between India and the United States has remarkably quickened since Sept. 11, with a burst of navy, air force and army joint exercises, the revival of American military sales to India and a blur of high-level visits by generals and admirals. 
 The fledgling relationship between American and Indian military leaders will be important to Mr. Rumsfeld in talks intended to put to rest fears of war between India and Pakistan.
"We can hope this translates into some influence and trust, though I don't want to overstate it," a senior American defense official said in an interview on Thursday. "I don't want to predict this guarantees success." 
The American diplomatic efforts yielded their first real gains on Saturday when India welcomed a pledge by Pakistan's military ruler to stop permanently the infiltration of militants into Kashmir. India indicated that it would soon take steps to reduce tensions, but a million troops are still fully mobilized along the border -- a situation likely to persist for months -- and the process of resolving the crisis has just begun.
India has linked the killing of civilians in Kashmir to a Pakistan-backed insurgency there and has presented its confrontation with Pakistan as part of the global campaign against terrorism.
India itself made an unstinting offer of support to the United States after Sept. 11, and Washington responded by ending the sanctions placed on India after its 1998 nuclear tests. With that, the estrangement that prevailed between the world's two largest democracies during the cold war, when India drew close to the Soviet Union and the United States allied with Pakistan, has eased.
India, for decades a champion of nonalignment, seeks warmer ties with the United States in hopes of gaining access to sophisticated military technology and help in dealing with Pakistan.
From the start of President Bush's term, some influential officials in his administration saw India as a potential counterweight to that other Asian behemoth, China, whose growing power was seen as a potential strategic threat.
But since Sept. 11, the priority has been terrorism. The United States is hoping its deeper military and political ties with India will give it some measure of leverage to prevent a war between India and Pakistan that could lead to a nuclear holocaust and would play havoc with the hunt for Al Qaeda in Pakistan.
The military relationship has certainly accelerated in recent months. "We've moved from crawling to walking and we're preparing to run," said an American military official.
American warships have been docking in the Indian cities of Bombay, Cochin and Madras. The first major sale of military equipment to India -- $140 million of artillery-finding radar made by Raytheon -- has been approved by Congress. Aircraft engines, submarine combat systems and helicopter parts are in the pipeline.
In the largest-ever joint ground and air operations, American and Indian paratroopers jumped last month from the same aircraft over the city of Agra. Later this year, for the first time, Indian troops will venture to the United States for exercises in Alaska.
American and Indian naval ships are jointly patrolling the Strait of Malacca to protect commercial shipping, while the number of Indian military officers training in the United States has jumped to 150 this year from 25 in 1998.
A parade of military brass has been marching through each other's capitals. "The current level of military to military cooperation between our nations is unprecedented," Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said upon arriving in New Delhi in February.
Mr. Bush took office determined to bring the United States and India closer together, an undertaking that began under President Bill Clinton. The Bush administration's approach to India was conceived as part of a broader geopolitical strategy in Asia.
Some senior officials saw a close American military relationship with India, a developing, democratic nation of a billion people with a million-member army, as a factor that would give pause to a rising, autocratic China, if not now, then a decade or two down the road when India has become richer and more powerful, American officials say.
By most accounts, Robert D. Blackwill, the American ambassador here and a China expert who taught at Harvard, is a proponent of this school of thought. He has used his contacts in the White House and the Pentagon to speed up United States-India military collaborations. He was a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Bush during the presidential campaign and the boss of the current national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, when both served at the National Security Council under the president's father. Mr. Blackwill declined to comment.
In public remarks, American officials have been careful not to depict the warming relations with India as having anything to do with China for fear of alarming China or offending India.
But the senior American defense official said in the interview on Thursday, "Given our strategy in Asia, the more sober view of China, and Russia no longer being a competitor, there were objective strategic reasons the India-U.S. relationship would improve."
Analysts are more direct. George Perkovich, a South Asia expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said some Pentagon officials see the military relationship with India primarily as a way to make China nervous.
"The joint patrol of the Strait of Malacca is a great example," Mr. Perkovich said. "The administration says it loves India in its own right and is not trying to contain China, but when officials say this, they then mutter under the breath, 'Of course, India is a neighbor of China and if China draws certain conclusions, this is O.K.'
"At this point, it is too early for U.S. military or defense officials to see India as a potential military ally and the Indians themselves don't want an alliance," Mr. Perkovich went on to say. "Americans still regard India as prickly, Indian politics as too volatile and the Indian military as too hamstrung by civilian bureaucracy and technical limitations to be of great current value.
"That said," he added, "the U.S. would probably welcome access to Indian ports or military bases down the road."
India has its own objectives in the relationship. By threatening a war with Pakistan over terrorism that could jeopardize American interests in Pakistan, India has forced American diplomats to say plainly and publicly something they used to say only privately: that Pakistan must stop sponsoring terrorism against India in Kashmir. The United States is now using the weight of its power to exact such a commitment from Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
India also sees American investment, technology and influence as crucial to the realization of its great power aspirations.
"That is the essential engine that drives the U.S.-India military relationship," said Lt. Gen. V. R. Raghavan, a retired director general of military operations in the Indian Army. "India requires technological development, economic development and military growth in terms of technology."
If India had had the radar systems it is acquiring now during its 1999 Kargil war with Pakistan in Kashmir, India could have much more quickly destroyed Pakistani artillery and charged up the mountains to retake the heights, Indian officials say. "Without any doubt whatsoever," Jaswant Singh, India's foreign affairs minister, said in an interview.
India and Pakistan have been fighting over Kashmir since 1947, and the bloody competition drives their military spending higher. This year, India has increased military spending 13 percent, or $1.45 billion, and most of that will go for capital expenses to modernize the military. American companies are now contending for a share.
But India is not going to allow itself to become dependent on American military hardware anytime soon. Its primary supplier was the Soviet Union and is still Russia. The United States, with its ready use of sanctions, is seen as an unreliable supplier. For example, after the 1998 sanctions were imposed, India was unable to get spare parts for its Sea King helicopters.
Mr. Singh said the small-scale American military sales to India were still not much more than "a kind of diplomatic lubricant." The Indian emphasis is on self-reliance.
"It doesn't matter if it is not the best," he said, "but we must have it as our own, as something that we produce for ourselves."
Still, India wants the high-technology weaponry that American companies produce and that the United States has been leery of selling India because of its nuclear program.
"We are looking forward to closer relations both in technology as well as in procurement," India's defense minister, George Fernandes, said in a recent interview.

HEADLINE: 44,650-Acre Deal Guards Land Without Ignoring Economics 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: TUG HILL PLATEAU, N.Y., June 7 

 BODY:
A stretch of this northern New York highlands larger than Manhattan and the Bronx combined will remain forever wild, open to the public for recreation but preserved from development, under an agreement reached by Gov. George E. Pataki, the Nature Conservancy and a timber company.
 The complex $9.1 million deal, to be announced Monday, covers 44,650 often stunning and ecologically important acres between the Adirondacks and Lake Ontario. It is New York's second-largest land preservation pact since the 1980's, and by far the largest outside Adirondack Park. 
 The agreement is a significant step toward conservationists' dream of creating an almost unbroken swath of wilderness across the Great Northern Forest, the mountainous region stretching from northern New York, across much of Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine and into Quebec. Tug Hill Plateau encompasses the westernmost edge of that forest, and the largest part of it west of Maine that remains largely unprotected.
The deal also typifies a trend in wilderness preservation in the last few years, with states and conservation groups moving away from buying tracts outright. Instead, they are blending public and private ownership, paying for the land in some cases, and in others, paying for the right to restrict its use -- a less expensive approach that allows the same number of dollars to cover many more acres.
Learning from conflicts from previous land deals, the state and the Nature Conservancy worked closely with local communities and won their support for the project by accommodating their concerns about hunting rights and economic development in this depressed region. The state will provide a $1.5 million grant to the Tug Hill Commission, a local agency, to develop a plan to manage the property. The northern tradition of hunting camps -- rustic cabins on land that hunters have leased for years from timber companies -- will be preserved. Some logging will continue, protecting an important source of jobs.
Officials say they hope that opening the area to recreation will provide new sources of income. Winter sports enthusiasts regard the plateau, with its extraordinary snowfall and relatively flat terrain, as one of the best places for snowshoeing, cross-country skiing and snowmobiling. It is gaining a reputation as a place for bird-watching, and also hiking and canoeing, in addition to hunting.
Vast quantities of water shape every feature of the landscape across Tug Hill Plateau, in swamps, dense forests, and spectacular river gorges where layered stone walls rise as high as 300 feet. As storms sweep off Lake Ontario, this is the first obstacle they meet, and where they drop 21 feet of snow a year, plus heavy rains in the warmer months.
It is the snowiest place east of the Rockies, and it set a national record in 1997, with more than six feet of snow in 24 hours. All the precipitation supports a profusion of life, from trees to rare freshwater mussels.
"Tug Hill is a unique and wonderful place," said Mr. Pataki, who has made land preservation a priority of his administration.
The plateau first drew conservationists' attention for its glamour fauna like black bears, eagles, ospreys, bobcats, martens (a relative of the mink), the beavers that help create the swamps, and the occasional moose. But the closer they looked, the more they became intrigued by less obvious wildlife.
They found the plateau a breeding ground for a wide range of migratory songbirds that winter in the tropics, including several species of warblers, bobolinks, and the red-eyed vireo, whose persistent six-note call -- "Here I am, where are you?" -- is the background music in many stands of trees. Waterfowl like the black duck, the wood duck, and the great blue heron, with its six-foot wingspan, also thrive here. The swamps and rivers provide homes for many aquatic plants, the eastern pearl shell mussel that lives in rocky stream beds, as well as trout, chub and even salmon in the lower reaches of the rivers.
"It's like a big sponge, soaking up and releasing an enormous amount of water, feeding a huge system of rivers, streams and wetlands," said Henry Tepper, state director of the Nature Conservancy in New York.
Loggers who have made heavy use of the area since the 19th century have profoundly changed the forest. Dividing it with roads, they created invasion routes for raccoons, cats and other predators that raid birds' nests. The logging roads also have provided access for all-terrain vehicles that chew up the earth, and which conservationists hope to banish from the area.
Nothing remains of the old-growth forest that settlers found here, but there are balsam fir, sugar maple and red maple trees, along with red and black spruce, alder and others.
"The bear and moose have mostly been driven out, but as the forest matures, you'll see far more of them here," said Doug Thompson, the Tug Hill-Eastern Lake Ontario project director for the Nature Conservancy. Now, he said, moose appear only in the fall, when young bulls wander widely in search of mates. "This is some of the best moose habitat there is, so a year-round population should get established."
Hancock Timber Resource Group, a subsidiary of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, bought the property six years ago. Under the pact to be announced Monday, which took three years to piece together, GMO Renewable Resources of Boston is buying 30,300 acres, one of a small group of timber companies that specialize in low-intensity logging, harvesting only as much as is replaced by new growth. New York State will buy a conservation easement on that property, limiting logging and prohibiting development.
The Nature Conservancy, with support from other conservation groups, will buy 13,000 acres that include the major swamps and the headwaters of the East Branch of Fish Creek, the Mad River and the Salmon River, which drain into Lake Ontario.
The group will give the state a conservation easement on that property. The state itself will buy 1,350 acres along the corridor of the East Branch of Fish Creek. In all, the state will spend $4.6 million and the Nature Conservancy will spend $4.5 million.
"Not only will the land be protected for future generations, but the majority of it will continue to be a working forest, providing jobs, and it will become a prime recreation area," Mr. Pataki said. "Everybody wins."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tug Hill Plateau includes rivers and wetlands that drain a vast ecosystem to be preserved under an agreement that will allow some logging but restrict development. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times) Map of New York highlights Tug Hill Plateau: An expanse of forest, north of Syracuse, known for its birds and snow. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: U.S. OPEN; 
How They Brought the Open to the People

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
Beginning Thursday, the United States Open, the national championship of the august United States Golf Association, will be contested for the first time on that bastion of the weekend duffer: the publicly owned golf course. Since 1895, the Open has been welcome annually at the country's best and most exclusive private golf clubs, but never at what is known as a muni: a public course owned by a town, a county or a state, where the clubhouse carpet may be threadbare but the door is open to all.
 Golf, however, is seeking a new populism embodied by Tiger Woods, a product of public courses and the most visible golfer ever. So the sport's leadership, opting for symbolism, selected the renowned, if long-neglected, Black Course at Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale, N.Y., a Depression-era public works project. The event has been called the People's Open. 
 Playing the Black, one golfer said upon discovering it for the first time, was like finding a vintage Thunderbird abandoned in the woods. But after a $3 million renovation by the U.S.G.A., the makeover is complete. 
How the 102nd United States Open descended upon the unkempt Bethpage course is a tangled tale, one that curiously centers around a strange but influential cadre of public golf advocates: a rabbi, a stable master's son and a sofa-bed queen.
The saga begins at the Black Course on the unseasonably muggy morning of May 1, 1995, and all of the principals who would launch a seven-year march to golf history were there: Rabbi Marc Gellman, a part-time talk-show host and longtime Bethpage Black patron; David Fay, the executive director of the U.S.G.A., whose trademark bow ties make him appear to be a vested golf pooh-bah when in fact he grew up on an estate as a horse trainer's son; and Bernadette Castro, scion of the Castro Convertible sofa fortune who is New York State's parks commissioner.
On this May day, Fay and a dozen U.S.G.A. staff members had arrived unannounced to play the Black Course, a recognized masterpiece buried under decades of neglect. 
"I have this nutty idea," Fay told his handpicked group. "Maybe you can tell me if I'm crazy."
Fay had hoped to visit the course unceremoniously, proposing originally that someone from the golf association, even himself, sleep in his car overnight, as the average duffer often does, to secure a prized tee time. But when Fay was greeted at the clubhouse door by Gellman, Castro and other state officials, he knew his secret was out.
Gellman had been tipped off to Fay's outing and spilled the beans. A year earlier at the U.S.G.A.'s centennial celebration, it had been Gellman who helped plant the seed that Fay should consider the Black Course as a site for the United States Open.
"The average golfer is not wealthy, and the idea that the national championship was being played every year on courses groomed and reserved for only the rich was outrageous," said Gellman, who along with Msgr. Tom Hartman is host of a cable television program called "God Squad."
While the United States Open has occasionally been held on courses that are open to the public, like Pebble Beach in California and Pinehurst in North Carolina, these are privately owned, lavish resorts where a single round can cost as much as $375 and tee times are frequently reserved for guests at the resorts.
"What I wanted was a way to honor the working-class golfer," Gellman said. "They are the ballast of the ship of golf and deserve their own Open. I call them golf rats, people who get up at four in the morning to get their weekend tee time at the muni. I was a golf rat playing the Black. I just asked David Fay to consider it."
Fay knew of the Black, having played it a handful of times as a teenager growing up in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., about 70 miles from Bethpage. Though Fay now holds a regal position in international golf, he was brought up on municipal courses. His father tended the horses on an estate, and Fay's time on the adjacent private golf course was spent mostly with the maintenance crew.
"Those of us who didn't play the great private courses in the area, Ridgewood or Baltusrol or Winged Foot, well, we had the Black," Fay said. "That was the gold standard of public golf."

A Mixed First Impression
 Gellman had not been the only one pitching the course, one of five at Bethpage. Also occasionally whispering into Fay's ear was Jay Mottola, the executive director of the New York area's Metropolitan Golf Association, who worked on the Tuxedo grounds crew with Fay as a youngster.
Then there was Rees Jones, a member of the first family of golf course architects and labeled the Open Doctor for his work on a number of previous United States Open courses. Jones was a childhood friend of Castro's; their families were friends. Jones went to play the Black Course that day in May 1995, too.
So it was quite the chummy assembly that ventured off the first tee. Things got grumpy in a hurry.
It did not take long for several golfers to find one of the Black Course's mammoth sand traps, the hallmark of the design of the celebrated architect A. W. Tillinghast in 1936. It was one thing to be in a bunker; it was another to find your ball, as Jones did, in a footprint eight inches deep.
"We were all in these traps where it was impossible to get the ball out," Jones said. "Some pretty good players were taking two or three swings and not hitting sand, not hitting a ball."
Once he finally extracted his ball, Jones went looking for a rake to repair the trap. There was none. In other traps, trees and bushes were growing in the sand. The rough was weedy, the fairway grass was occasionally no more than tufts here and there. The greens were uneven. Some tee boxes were half dirt.
Thirty minutes into the flight of fancy he had orchestrated, Fay was aware of the quiet cussing going on around him. Fay said, "I've heard some staffers were mumbling, 'There's no way we're going to host anything here.' "
The Black Course was showing its wear. Situated near the epicenter of Long Island's postwar population boom, the course had attracted 30,000 to 45,000 golfers every year since the late 1940's, twice the number who play on most private courses. Operated on a slim state budget, one harshly slashed during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the Black Course had little irrigation, the staff was spread over the park's five golf courses and maintenance was limited.
Fay bit his tongue until the foursomes reached the fourth hole, which offers a sweeping panorama from tee to green: the 517-yard hole, surrounded by thick trees, offers a dramatic vista incomprehensibly close to the congestion of the Long Island Expressway just four miles from the Bethpage grounds.
"I think right there, some people stared off that fourth tee and said, 'Ah, I get it now,' " Fay said.
By day's end, Fay said there was not a single naysayer to his once far-fetched idea.
Fay met with state officials that afternoon and began hammering out the initial details of an agreement. The course would have to be closed for months, roads rerouted, security and transportation issues resolved and mountains of dirt, sand and sod moved and shaped. The renovations for the course alone would cost nearly $4 million.
Jones had offered his design services free, but he would have to revive and replicate the 66-year-old roots of the Black Course without the original plans, which had been lost. All Jones had was a 1938 aerial photograph of the course.

Little Red Tape
 Driving back to his New Jersey home from Bethpage that day seven years ago, Fay knew it was far from a done deal.
"Look, I grew up as a resident of New York State," he said. "We all know what New York State is like. We would have to deal with people on local, county and state levels. It could have become a political football."
As Gellman said recently: "Enter the unique pressure tactics of Bernadette Castro. She made sure there were few bureaucratic obstacles. And there could have been."
Once the state understood that the U.S.G.A. was serious, Castro and Gov. George E. Pataki pressed the golf association for a commitment. In fact, New York had wanted the 2001 Open, but Fay had to persuade the association's executive board members, most of whom had never heard of Bethpage State Park. The only board member who had played the Black, Eric Gleacher of Manhattan, consistently defended the course.
"The U.S.G.A. is over 100 years old and doesn't move quickly," Fay said. "But this was something long overdue."
What figured to be the biggest hurdle -- who would pay for the renovation -- turned out to be the easiest to negotiate.
"I knew the state couldn't pay for it," Fay said. "Some guy in Syracuse wasn't going to feel warm and fuzzy about the state dumping $3 million into some golf course on Long Island. We had to pay for it."
Fay considered the restoration of the course a service to public golf, and the golf association knew it would still make a multimillion-dollar profit from the 2002 Open at Bethpage. A record number of tickets have already been sold (more than 42,000 each day), and the Open will most likely be the most widely watched television golf event of the year, precisely because it is being contested on a public course.
In 1997, as Castro and Fay were completing their negotiations, Fay had a last, pivotal request. He wanted the state to promise not to raise the economical Black Course greens fees -- $31 on weekdays and $39 on weekends -- for at least three years after the 2002 Open.
"As David said at the time, 'When the circus leaves town, let's return the Black to the regular golfer,' " Castro said. "In all of this, I don't think anyone forgot our first customer: the guy coming up the 18th fairway, lugging his bag, sweaty but smiling after enjoying a treasure of a golf course."
But the regular golfer lugging his bag (no motorized carts are allowed on the Black) will not be returning to the municipal course he remembers from the mid-1990's. Virtually every square foot of the course has been transformed. It began with Jones, with the 1938 aerial photograph in hand, walking the course as he tried to divine the original architect's intent hole by hole.

Unearthing a Jewel
 Sometimes, on his hands and knees, Jones would uncover abandoned traps, seeking their original outline by poking at the grass that had enveloped them. As the park superintendents David Catalano and Craig Currier joined the project, tees were rediscovered and former bends and swales in the fairways unearthed. Jones did it to understand the style, even if every bunker was relocated in some manner.
"This is sacred ground in golf, and what we've done is very much like restoring a great painting," Jones said. "At the Black, there were all those rounds and the soot of 50 years of passing cars. You thoughtfully chip away at layer after layer."
The course was plied with 18 million pounds of sand for its newly sculptured bunkers, hundreds of trees were planted and more than one million square feet of sod laid.
Every tee box was rebuilt and every green refurbished. The weedy rough is now sprouting with blond, gnarly fescue grass. New irrigation lines were dug and nearly 400 sprinkler heads installed.
"I walk the Black Course now and I remember back to when we came here in 1995 and it seems like a dream sequence," said Tom Meeks, the U.S.G.A.'s director of rules and competition. "One day we're here searching for grass on the tees and all of a sudden the U.S. Open is coming here. And the neatest thing is that golfers all over the world will watch on television and say, 'You mean to tell me, I can go play this course?' "
Gellman takes that thought one step further.
"I have this vision of a working-class guy sitting on a couch watching the U.S. Open and he turns to his son or daughter and says, 'Tiger better watch out because I know that putt, and it breaks to the left,' " Gellman said. "That could not have happened in any other U.S. Open ever."
It will likely happen again, though, because of the collective vision that brought the 2002 Open to Bethpage. Torrey Pines, a public course outside San Diego, is in line for the 2008 Open, and the U.S.G.A. anticipates keeping Bethpage Black in its informal rotation of Open courses, an honor once reserved only for the country's pre-eminent private courses.
"I don't see this as a one-and-done deal," Fay said. "What we've done at the Black is too majestic and important. People better be asking when we're coming back."

HEADLINE: The Plan From PEOC 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
To be presidential is to be bold. To be presidential is to plot your surprise in secret, to reverse course with panache, and thereby to bestride the news cycle like a Colossus, asserting leadership in one bodacious swoop. 
 I learned that in the Nixon economic shokku of 1971, when a handful of us met secretly at Camp David, imposed wage and price controls, slammed down the gold window and slapped on a protective tariff. The powerful package turned out to be a historic blunder, but it sure won points for boldness. 
 Here we go again. President Bush had dismissed the prescient proposals of former Senators Gary Hart and Warren Rudman for a conglomeration of homeland security agencies. When put in a bill by Democrat Joe Lieberman, the dramatic plan was brushed off by the Bush-appointed "czar" and all the president's men. 
But meanwhile, down in the bombproof bowels of the White House -- in PEOC, the Presidential Emergency Operations Center, compared to which the Situation Room is like the front lawn -- a little band of ruthless reorganizers, with no constituency but the man a hundred feet up in the Oval Office, huddled over diagrams with little boxes and dotted lines to create what was to be billed as "the most far-reaching modernization of our government since Truman's day." 
The secretaries of State and Defense were kept in the dark lest they blab. The unconsulted Treasury secretary will be remembered as the man who gained a rock star and lost the Secret Service. To the White House staff, far more important than cabinet or congressional or expert input was the element of surprise.
Bold it was, and politically shrewd. Democrats can't complain because the amalgamation of internal protection agencies is what they have been demanding. The press can't kick because it has been deriding the toothlessness of the homeland security "czar." Those who do object will be zapped as protectors of bureaucratic turf or, as the attorney general will charge as November elections draw near, aiders of terrorism.
But set aside the bold-leadership factor, as well as the cleverness of changing the subject from F.B.I.-C.I.A. warfare and the need to stampede Congress into another hasty "U.S.A. Patriot" Act. Consider the substance: is reshuffling a good idea?
Most of it makes sense. For example, the Secret Service comes under Treasury because its original purpose was to combat counterfeiters. Now we have a billion one-dollar coins with an Indian woman on them that nobody uses, and nobody cares if they're counterfeit. Today it's a bodyguard force whose protective mission should be related, as Bush proposes, to that of federal marshals and disaster crews, customs and immigration agents and the Coast Guard.
The questions to be asked by Congressional committees, armed with expert managerial advisers, is: How will this un-scattering be more effective? Unions will holler and lobbyists will defend their Congressional contacts, but as we add a huge new mission of terror prevention, shouldn't we drop old missions, retrain or replace their government work forces and put new oversight in place?
One danger, however, is to fall for the notion, already being discredited in private industry, that bigger is better. This merger-happy administration, weak on antitrust, is tempted to grow fat. Bush claims his proposals are "budget neutral," and we should hold him to that. 
He suggests we strip the Department of Transportation of the Coast Guard and the Transportation Security Administration, assigning them to the new department. Fine; why not distribute the rest of Transportation's activities and do away with that cabinet post, with its attendant superstructure? (Disconnect the D.O.T.!)
Some management-neatness freaks will use Bush's plan to push for a subsequent merger of C.I.A., F.B.I., N.S.A. and military intelligence into a Ministry of the Interior. Better coordination of intelligence is necessary -- and the dismal failure of Congressional oversight calls for the House and Senate to hold their own Intelligence and Judiciary Committee staffs accountable -- but such a concentration of police and surveillance power would be dangerous to our freedoms. 
Here's how to judge the plan bubbling up from PEOC: the reshuffling should increase the puissance of our protection but not the size of our government. Enforcing that discipline calls for boldness on the part of conservatives in Congress.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
. . . Starring The Original Houston Cast

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: HOUSTON 

 BODY:
It has been some time since all the big musicals started on Broadway and then filtered out to the hinterland. Now the trend -- becoming stronger and perhaps permanent -- is for them to open first in cities like this one and then move to New York. 
 Mounting a new musical in New York has become so expensive that producers are loath to take the risk of failure. They prefer to wait until shows are proven at places like Theater Under the Stars in Houston, which has just moved into a dazzling $100-million home designed especially to stage lavish musicals. 
 A new musical called "Some Like It Hot," based on the 1957 film of the same name and starring Tony Curtis, who was also in the film, is having its world premiere here. In October there is to be another first, "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?" Both shows are scheduled to go from Houston to other cities, and then perhaps to Broadway. 
"These days Broadway is doing revivals and leaving the new shows to us," said Frank M. Young, who has headed Theater Under the Stars since it was founded in 1968. "It's all about economics. We can produce a show for one-third of what it costs in New York, and we have other theaters that will partner with us. Shows that we do that are good will be picked up for Broadway."
Mr. Young's plans for "Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?" reflect the pattern that has made Theater Under the Stars one of the country's pre-eminent centers for the production of new musicals.
"We'll do the world premiere, and since I do everything over the top and this new theater allows me to do absolutely anything I can dream up, it will have effects no one has ever seen on Broadway," he said. "It will go on tour in the summer of 2003, and then maybe to New York. It may be a disaster, but I can afford to take that risk. Broadway can't. The costs there are unbelievable, and corporations own most of the big theaters. You don't have a David Merrick who gets a hunch and goes with it and can eat the losses if it doesn't succeed. That era is past and done."
In some senses Mr. Young has emerged as a David Merrick of the provinces. 
He said he regularly received scripts from well-known writers and composers who claim there is no one on Broadway today who is eager to consider new musicals. Each season he presents a mix of world premieres, touring shows and new productions of classics. In January he will open a new "My Fair Lady" that is being billed as the most expensive regional production of this show ever.
"Even if we don't have a hit, we don't lose," Mr. Young said. " 'Jekyll and Hyde' started here, in partnership with two other theaters. It cost $2.1 million to produce, which was $700,000 for each theater. Between the three of us, we have 80,000 subscribers. So 'Jekyll and Hyde' was in the black before the curtain went up." 
He added, "From our three theaters it went national, then to Broadway and then to video." 
Houston is hardly the only city that sends musicals to Broadway. Of shows now playing in New York, "Aida" comes from the Alliance Theater in Atlanta; "Into the Woods" from the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; "The Full Monty" from the Old Globe in San Diego; and "Thoroughly Modern Millie" from the La Jolla Playhouse in Southern California. The next big musical scheduled to open on Broadway, "Hairspray," is coming from the Fifth Avenue Playhouse in Seattle.
The new theater in Houston, called the Hobby Center for the Performing Arts, considerably increases Mr. Young's ability to mount splashy new productions. It has a 2,650-seat hall designed for musicals, with a pit that can accommodate twice as many musicians as most pits on Broadway, a stage that can be removed in whole or part for special effects, and large spaces for dressing rooms and rehearsals. There is also a 500-seat hall that will be used to develop new work as well as for small-scale concerts, spoken-word performances and children's shows.
Theater Under the Stars has come a long way from the days when it presented shows in an auditorium that was also used for rodeos and where some patrons had to sit under plastic sheets to protect them from rain leaking through the roof.
The Walt Disney Company, which has become a major backer of large-scale musicals, has taken a special interest in Theater Under the Stars. One of its biggest hits, "Beauty and the Beast," had its world premiere here in 1993. Two years later it decided to open "Lion King" here, but since the old auditorium did not have special features for such an elaborate show, the premiere was moved to Minneapolis.
That episode shocked city officials and corporate donors into agreeing to build a new hall especially for musicals. Disney's chief executive, Michael Eisner, signaled his interest in producing shows here by flying in for the gala opening on May 18.
Former President George Bush was also in attendance. Kenneth Lay, the fallen chairman of the Houston-based energy giant Enron, was a co-chairman of the committee that organized the gala, but did not appear. Enron pledged $500,000 to the fund-raising drive and delivered $400,000 before it collapsed into bankruptcy.
The new Hobby Center, designed by Robert A. M. Stern, has a soaring glass facade and a high-ceilinged lobby dominated by a colorful wall drawing by Sol LeWitt. It looks daringly modern from outside, but the interior has old-fashioned touches designed to evoke the music halls of bygone days. There are gently curved railings, gold-leaf columns and ceiling panels, private boxes decorated with intricate plaster lattice work and hand-carved wooden ornaments on the walls. 
The ceiling has a dome featuring 2,000 fiber-optic stars that are designed to evoke the open-air origin of Theater Under the Stars.
There is enormous private wealth in this city, despite the collapse of Enron and several other local corporations. When corporate leaders unite behind a project wallets open with remarkable speed.
The city provided just $13 million toward the cost of the Hobby Center, with the rest coming from private sources. Nearly $40 million of the $87 million in private contributions was raised from about 20 donors in the space of a few months. 
"When we were raising money for this building, we were riding an economic boom," said Bud Franks, president and chief executive of the Hobby Center. "Foundations were looking to give money away because of huge increases in portfolio value. But if we were setting out to raise this money today, I think we could still do it. This is such a unique community. The spirit of generosity in the corporate community and the leadership they show is amazing. We raised what I would consider quite a large sum of money, but we have not even scratched the surface of wealth in this community."
The show that will open the new theater, "Some Like It Hot," is typical of what Theater Under the Stars does best. It has appeal based on a beloved and light-hearted film, new songs, imaginative sets and star power in the person of Mr. Curtis. He portrays the aging roue played by Joe E. Brown in the film.
"How privileged I am that 40 years after I was in one of the greatest comedies in movie history, I get to come back in the play," he said during a break in rehearsals. "I don't want to get hokey or metaphysical, but when I look out into this wonderful hall, I feel Sinatra and Lemmon and all the other old guys sitting there. It can't help but pop into my mind."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 14, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An Arts in America article on Tuesday about the development of new musicals in Houston and other cities for tours and perhaps eventually Broadway misidentified the Los Angeles theater that originated the current Broadway production of "Into the Woods." It is the Ahmanson Theater, not the Mark Taper Forum.


GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, Tony Curtis, left, and Timothy Gulan in the musical "Some Like It Hot," the curtain raiser for the new Hobby Center at Theater Under the Stars in Houston. Left, the center's president, Frank Young. (Photographs by Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)(pg. E2)

HEADLINE: Bonds Return to Southeast Asia 

BYLINE:  ByWAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, June 10 

 BODY:
International capital markets are offering Southeast Asian borrowers interest rates so low even Communists can't resist.
 The Socialist Republic of Vietnam, its Communist Party fresh from victory in last month's single-party elections, is now shopping for investment bankers to help it sell up to $500 million in government bonds to global investors later this year. 
 In preparation, it hired Standard & Poor's to rate its creditworthiness and ability to repay; last week, the agency gave Vietnam a BB-, a somewhat speculative rating on a par with Bulgaria and Belize, but above Turkey and Indonesia. That Vietnam is willing and able to borrow American dollars is a sign of how far the country has come since 1986 in opening its economy. 
Sovereign bonds are Wall Street's yardstick for a government's survival: the more confident investors are that a government will be around to pay them back, the less they generally charge to lend the country -- and its companies -- their money by buying bonds. 
On that yardstick, Southeast Asia seems healthier now than it has been in a long time. The difference, or spread, between what Southeast Asian governments have to pay lenders and what the United States Treasury pays has narrowed to levels unseen since the period before the 1997 regional financial crisis.
"To some extent, it's a vote of confidence in these economies -- they've come a long way," said William C. Belchere, head of economics and fixed-income strategy at Merrill Lynch in Singapore.
Attracted by the narrower spreads and the fact that American interest rates are themselves near 40-year lows, Southeast Asian governments and companies are issuing a deluge of new dollar- and euro-denominated bonds, some to refinance old higher-rate debt and some to gear up for the surge in export demand that should come as the United States economy recovers. So far in 2002, nearly $7 billion in such debt has been issued, after a total of a bit over $9 billion for all of last year, according to Barclays Capital. 
The trend began in Singapore and Malaysia, two fairly stable economies where investors, frustrated by poor returns last year in bearish stock markets, could dabble in higher-yielding Asian bonds without losing too much sleep.
Last month, the Malaysian state oil company Petroliam Nasional sold $2.7 billion in 10-year dollar and euro bonds, the biggest corporate Asian bond issue on record outside Japan. Most of the bonds were sold with an interest rate just 1.75 percentage points higher than comparable United States Treasuries.
"They got the appetite right," said Alan Greene, a director and credit analyst at Barclays in Singapore. "There is pent-up demand for Asian paper."
Now the region's riskier issuers are joining in. An Indonesian instant-noodle company, Indofood Sukses Makmur, plans a $200 million bond issue that would be the largest in dollars from Indonesia since the financial crisis. The Thai government is also weighing its first dollar bonds since the crisis.
But economists and analysts like Mr. Belchere and Mr. Greene say the hunger for Asian bonds may not be entirely healthy. Much of the demand, they say, is coming from Southeast Asia's banks, which are hesitant to make new loans while they still have problems with nonperforming old ones; they are buying bonds as an alternative parking place for deposits.
This "domestic bid" is heating up the region's bond markets and pushing down yields, to the point where some foreign investors question whether the low rates on the growing supply of Southeast Asian bonds adequately reflects the region's risks.
The Philippines, for example, has sold more than $2.5 billion in debt this year and plans to issue $1.6 billion more. But the government is falling short of its targets for shrinking its budget deficit, causing the bonds' prices to fall in secondary-market trading and yields to climb.
Mr. Belchere said there was also considerable demand for Asian bonds from investors who worry that global economic recovery may be weaker than expected, a concern that has depressed regional stock markets in recent weeks.
What does this mean for how Vietnam's bonds will be received? In explaining its rating, Standard & Poor's cited Vietnam's high savings rate, low levels of foreign debt and the bright potential for investment and exports in the wake of last year's bilateral trade agreement with the United States.
At the same time, the agency expressed concern about Vietnam's own budget deficit and its banks, which have their own troubles with nonperforming loans. Vietnamese state-owned companies are weak, its tax system is leaky and its monetary policy is too rigid, Standard & Poor's said.
Still, Mr. Greene at Barclays thinks the issue will find plenty of ready buyers, especially from its former enemy, the United States. 
"There's a certain intrigue," he said.
