HEADLINE: A Development Fuels A Debate on Urbanism 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: CHULA VISTA, Calif. 

 BODY:
Otay Ranch would seem to have everything the back-to-the-future movement in American town-planning could ask for: front porches, back alleys, a network of paths, all built around a park with a barn-style community center and little hub called Heritage Towne Center. It's a village, the developers say, not another sea of stucco rising at the urban edge of San Diego. 
 But look again, say the proponents of new-style suburbs, and you see things they have long criticized. Otay Ranch is protected by guarded entrance gates, which limit the kind of random encounters so cherished in older communities. A six-lane road as wide as a freeway leads into the development, making it a challenge to cross the street on foot. Cul de sacs, little different than those in the far exurbs of Los Angeles, fill the development. 
 As the largest single subdivision in California history, Otay Ranch is at the center of a fight among people who plan and build new communities in the fastest-growing states. 
To hear some developers talk, a person would think they would not be caught dead building a traditional suburb, or what is known in shorthand sneer as a csd, for conventional suburban development. They build places where people live in "sustainable communities" around "towne squares," where the three-car garage has been banished.
But just as these developers have seemingly embraced this design style known as New Urbanism, many planners and architects say that the movement has been co-opted and that many of the neo-villages appearing in Southern California, as well as in the exurbs of New Jersey and on the shoreline of the Florida Panhandle, are impostors.
"More and more, we're seeing places where people just take the label of New Urbanism and slap it on a development as a way to get around political or environmental concerns," said Steven Bodzin, spokesman for the Congress for the New Urbanism, a loose-knit group of planners and architects. "It's designed to fool consumers and to fool the political process."
Otay Ranch is a kind of Levittown West, though for a slightly higher income bracket. The houses are affordable, by California standards, ranging from $250,000 to $500,000; the racial mix is diverse, by suburban standards; half the land has been set aside for nature; and homes are selling faster than any other big development in San Diego County. Developers of the 6,000-acre ranch have gone out of their way to distance themselves from the suburbia of old.
"The most visible difference is our village concept, which encourages people to once again meet neighbors, walk to nearby parks, and sit on front porches," the developers proclaim in brochures and on their Web site.
The small, nontraditional parks in the development "are the kind of places where kids go after school to count clouds or play Frisbee until their mom calls them in for dinner," said Kim Kelkenny, executive vice president of Otay Ranch.
One afternoon here in the center of the village, very little front-porch sitting or cloud-counting was evident. But children actually walked home from school, and enough people were out strolling or bike-riding to give the sense that the S.U.V.'s were on a leash.
Still, Otay Ranch is a gated community, one that has many elements heretical to the New Urbanism. 
"The gates resemble New Jersey toll booths and the cul de sacs are wide enough to park a trailer," said Rob Steuteville, editor of New Urban News, who toured the development earlier this year and was highly critical. "It is so over-engineered for traffic that it's just off the charts."
Another critic, a transportation planner from Palo Alto, Calif., Patrick Siegman, said Otay Ranch was an example of an old-style suburb with a few changes that were largely cosmetic. Mr. Siegman called for a process in which developments would have to be certified "to keep the marketers from appropriating New Urbanist language."
Of course, hyperbole is not new to the business of selling real estate. The joke about new developments being named after whatever it is they displace -- Elk View Heights -- is often true. But only recently have marketers started to use the language of New Urbanism, language that was traditionally used against their developments.
It used to be fairly easy to define a New Urbanist development because there just were not that many of them. Nearly 20 years ago, when the town of Seaside was planted as a village-style development on the Florida Panhandle, it was thought to be an anomaly. 
But then the Disney Corporation built a town of its own in Celebration, Fla., and others soon followed.
Now developments that claim to be New Urbanist are finding themselves the object of criticism. For example, Laguna West, a development near Sacramento, was initially hailed as a pioneering example of how to build a community that was not overly dependent on the automobile. But it has since gone through changes that have led critics to label it as classic urban sprawl, though with porches and alleys.
"Laguna West is one of the most pitiful examples of a so-called New Urbanist community that in reality is little different than a 1970's-era development in Los Angeles," said Wendell Cox, a design consultant who has written critically of recent subdivisions.
Mr. Cox pointed to houses with three- and four-car garages, "liberal use of cul de sacs" and the fact that the development pushed the edge of the city into the countryside.
The designer of Laguna West, Peter Calthorpe of Berkeley, Calif., who has been a leading opponent of old-style suburbs, said the project was changed after it was sold in the California recession of the mid-1990's.
"There are compromises," Mr. Calthorpe said, "but all in all I think it's a great success. The reality of America is that some people want three cars."
For some people, though, the compromises go too far.
"I give these developments like Otay Ranch credit for trying something different," Mr. Siegman said. "The problem is when a project takes one or two elements, and leaves out all the others."
Here at Otay Ranch, the main designer, Kent Aden, said he tried to build with narrow streets, fewer cul de sacs and more intentional congestion, but met resistance from buyers and code enforcers. The master plan calls for several villages, each about one square mile, with a school and several small parks, surrounded by arterial highways. Two villages have been built.
"We want congestion inside the villages," Mr. Aden said. "We're trying to break the mold. People aren't necessarily ready for it, and the engineers don't get it yet."
He called the architecture "California heritage," yet lamented that some intersections were too big and busy to walk across and that people seemed to ignore one of his favorite pocket parks.
"But if you compare us to California subdivisions of the 1980's," Mr. Aden said, "we're leaps and bounds ahead of what they did."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Moving South, To the Domain Of the Princes

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WHEN you have spent eight years celebrating the incomparable vitality of New York in a column called The Big City, it is awkward to announce that the column is ending because you are moving out of town. It is especially awkward when the place you are moving to is Washington. 
 In this column, Washington has generally played the role of the Great Satan. It is both the antithesis and the nemesis of New York. My favorite explanation of the New York-Washington relationship, not to mention the history of urban civilization, is the economist Brad DeLong's theory of merchants versus princes. 
 Cities have always been created by merchants, the peaceful deal-makers who flourish under the protection of a relatively hands-off prince. The city becomes cosmopolitan as the merchants import money and talent: entrepreneurs and artisans to create industries; artists and entertainers to serve the new class of patrons.
But the city's growing wealth and glamour eventually attract the age's most ambitious princes. Once these conquerors add the city to their empire, their taxes and decrees drive away the merchants and artists.
Dr. DeLong's theory explains, for instance, why the Renaissance occurred in Florence, an independent city-state run by merchants like Lorenzo de Medici, whose income came chiefly from his family's bank, not taxes. Then, after warrior princes from Spain and France conquered the Italian city-states, merchants created new commercial and cultural hubs in the independent cities of the Low Countries.
Dr. DeLong, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, compared nine regions of Western Europe over the past 1,000 years, and he found that urban populations shrank during periods when cities were consolidated into larger empires. "City growth," he concluded, "has a strong allergy to the presence of strong, centralizing princes."
Dr. DeLong's study did not include New York, but it is easy for a non-economist to spot a similar trend here in the last century. The city's population grew rapidly for the first three decades, doubling to nearly 7 million by 1930. But as Fiorello LaGuardia and Robert Moses consolidated their power and allied themselves with the rising New Deal princes in Washington, the growth slowed, and the population stagnated at 7.8 million from 1950 through 1970. It fell by 800,000 during the 1970's, when Washington's princes were working especially hard to rescue urban America.
Congress's "urban agenda" was scrapped by its Republican princes during the 1980's and 1990's, and Washington's benign neglect coincided with a rebound in New York's population. The merchants gained power, and today one of them is prince. If Michael R. Bloomberg is anything like Lorenzo the Magnificent, the city will prosper.
SO why am I leaving the merchants? Why join the courtiers in Washington? Because the princes make great copy, even if you do not like what they're doing. After ranting at them for so long, it's time to cover the enemy.
It's also time to give the merchants and artists a rest. For eight years I have been haranguing them to stop sending their money to Washington, to stop electing centralizing princes to Capitol Hill and the White House, but New Yorkers have kept voting for national politicians who support higher taxes. My sermons about our tax deficit -- the money New Yorkers lose each year to farmers in the heartland and bureaucrats in Washington -- had exactly zero impact.
This state of affairs used to infuriate me, particularly when I visited Washington in the summer. I would take the Washington Metro, marveling at the quiet ride and the immaculate, air-conditioned stations. Then I would return to Pennsylvania Station and marvel at the sweltering masses on our subway platform.
Actually, I did more than marvel. In my mind, I was screaming at them. What are you people thinking? Can't you see what the princes are doing with your paychecks? They're air-conditioning their subway! I might have looked a bit crazed to my neighbors, but I did at least manage to keep the thoughts to myself. One of the advantages of a column is that you have other opportunities to vent.
This summer I will be calmer, and certainly cooler, when I take the Metro to The Times's bureau in Washington. There may be an occasional moment of treason -- Go ahead, New York, keep sending your money -- but I can't imagine siding with the princes. My heart will stay with the merchants and artists. I'll miss you.

HEADLINE: GOLF; 
Corporate Tents Grow in Popularity at the People's Open

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
As the first publicly owned golf course to play host to the United States Open, Bethpage State Park takes pride in running what some people are calling the "people's open." The reality, of course, is more complicated.
 Golf is the ultimate corporate sport, with its affluent, well-educated fan base, and the United States Golf Association certainly does not mind cashing in at its premier event. 
 A prime example: 78 large corporate tents divided into three minicommunities along Bethpage's Black Course. Corporate giants like Goldman Sachs, AT&T and Citigroup rent the canvas tents for substantial fees and provide food and beverages to ticketed clients, staff and friends.
At the 1995 United States Open, 26 snazzy corporate tents sprawled out over the grounds of Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y.
The number of tents at Bethpage is not only triple that of seven years ago, but it is 24 more than last year, when the Open was played at Southern Hills Country Club in Tulsa, Okla. 
"The space that Bethpage affords us is incredible," said Mimi Griffin, president of MSG Promotions, which oversees the tournament's marketing and corporate hospitality.
The tent cities come complete with names and diverse designs. The tents in Empire Village are arrayed along a straight line along an elevated, carpeted boardwalk. Tillinghast and Liberty Villages are arranged elliptically, with oval boardwalks within. But there is no design feature like the topiary golfers that stood outside the three villages at Shinnecock in 1995. "They looked like Cro-Magnon man," Griffin said.
The blossoming tent business at the tournament brings in substantial revenues to the U.S.G.A., which is charging a top price of $175,000 for the ritziest 40-by-40 foot tent in the Empire Village along the 18th fairway; the least expensive tents cost $85,000 for a 30-by-30 foot tent in the Liberty Village, which, like Tillinghast, is along the first hole. Last year, the four-day rental cost corporations from $75,000 to $150,000. 
Companies pay extra for food, beverages and interior design, which the U.S.G.A. supplies.
While the American economy is not booming, as it was in 1995, there has been no shortage of demand from companies willing to pay as much as it costs to rent a luxury suite in a stadium or an arena in some markets around the country.
Companies like Citigroup and Goldman Sachs are ensconced in Empire; NBC, ESPN and FleetBoston Financial are in Tillinghast; and AT&T, Bear Stearns and Canon U.S.A. will try to rough it in Liberty.
Griffin said the U.S.G.A. has been selling the tents at Bethpage (which have red, white and blue facades) for four years. "We presold them when the economy was still strong," she said. "Had we begun selling them a year ago, we wouldn't have been successful." The sales push is already on for the Open's return to Shinnecock in 2004.
Bethpage had sold out all the tents by March 2001, but about 15 companies later pulled out because of the economy. As recently as March, a company left the fold. 
"But because we're in New York, we were able to replace them," said Griffin, who added that none of the dropouts were caused by the business impact from the Sept. 11 attacks.

HEADLINE: Pataki Says McCall Should Prove Accusation or Apologize 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 13 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today accused H. Carl McCall of stepping beyond the pale of fair political comment when he said that the governor's aides had threatened businesses with the loss of state contracts if they gave to Mr. McCall's campaign. 
 Mr. Pataki, a Republican seeking a third term, said Mr. McCall, the state comptroller and a Democrat running for governor, should either produce proof of the allegations he made on Wednesday or apologize. 
 "I thought those comments were outrageous, and I really think they crossed the line of fair political comment," the governor said at a news conference here. "If that has happened, and I don't believe it has happened, he should come forward and name names, and if he can't come forward and name names and do it now, he should apologize."
The McCall campaign has declined to name names. But Mr. McCall's campaign manager, Allen P. Cappelli, said today that it was the governor who should apologize -- to voters -- for appointing his top fund-raiser, Charles A. Gargano, to oversee the state's economic development agency. Mr. Cappelli also poked fun at Mr. Pataki's outrage.
"To hear the governor's protestations today reminds me of that famous scene from 'Casablanca,' when the police chief, played by Claude Rains, declares that he's 'shocked to learn that gambling has been going on here,' even as he stuffs his pockets with roulette winnings," Mr. Cappelli said.
Mr. McCall made the allegation when a reporter asked him if it had become hard for him to raise money because of the governor's large lead in polls. The comptroller said the polls were irrelevant. Then he said some people had told him that Pataki officials made it clear that they would not get state business if they gave to the McCall campaign.
The comptroller was campaigning on Long Island and in Westchester today. The other Democratic candidate, Andrew M. Cuomo, a former federal housing secretary, took advantage of the dispute to challenge Mr. Pataki and Mr. McCall to agree not to accept donations from people to whom they have awarded contracts. As comptroller, Mr. McCall hires firms to handle the state pension fund's assets, including firms that have given him campaign donations.
Mr. Cuomo told reporters today that, to his knowledge, none of his donors had been intimidated. He also said he believed that Mr. McCall's accusation was accurate. 
"Yesterday, Carl McCall accused Governor Pataki of intimidating donors at the same time Governor Pataki accused Carl McCall of selling access to the pension fund," Mr. Cuomo said in a statement today. "The truth is, they are both right."

HEADLINE: Big Companies Are Looking To Spread Out From Midtown 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A movement among major companies to scatter workers across several locations instead of concentrating them in one place, a trend that began last fall after the attack on the World Trade Center, has spread to some Midtown businesses. 
 The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, which is building an office tower on Madison Avenue near Grand Central Terminal, has decided to reduce its presence there and move some employees to a still-unspecified location downtown, according to several executives of other companies and city officials familiar with the plan. The bank is also looking at Jersey City. 
 Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the giant law firm that moved its offices to Times Square a few years ago, is seeking to rent satellite office space downtown or in Westchester, according to real estate brokers. C.D.C. Capital, a financial services company now at 9 West 57th Street, is also looking downtown and elsewhere. 
"In the post-9/11 world, we're seeing more tenants looking to diversify their operations for security reasons," said Mitchell Konsker, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate company. "At the same time, they're looking at how they can reduce their operating costs."
The spread of the trend to Midtown may prove to be a boon to Lower Manhattan, where dispersion has been the order of the day for eight months. The resulting exodus of thousands of high-paying jobs and even entire companies has sent a shudder through the winding streets of Lower Manhattan, where landlords and city and state officials fear the disintegration of the city's historic financial district.
Morgan Stanley, for instance, has moved hundreds of downtown employees to Jersey City and Times Square, while selling its nearly completed Midtown skyscraper near Rockefeller Center to Lehman Brothers, which abandoned Lower Manhattan altogether. Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield is moving a majority of its downtown employees to a building under construction in Brooklyn, while Marsh & McClennan is building a new tower in Hoboken, N.J. Aon, another insurance company, is heading for Midtown.
Major Midtown companies are now considering multiple locations in order to avoid having their entire operations knocked out by a single catastrophic event. Of course, nearly every company's search list also includes downtown Brooklyn, Long Island City, Westchester and Jersey City, as well as Lower Manhattan.
Midtown law firms like Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells and Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel are considering moving their entire offices from Midtown to downtown -- lured, brokers say, by lower rents and by government grants and tax breaks. Bank of New York, however, plans to move some employees from downtown to Brooklyn, or Jersey City. American International Group, the insurance giant, is also considering moving employees to New Jersey. KPMG, one of the world's largest accounting firms, is close to a deal to move downtown from Midtown.
"These centralization-decentralization patterns run in cycles," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. "New York will benefit from this because it has two or three central business districts, which can meet virtually any need of a large corporation."
Only two years ago, urban corporate campuses were all the rage. Companies saw a benefit to housing all their employees in the same neighborhood. 
Several years ago, the Canadian International Bank of Commerce, which had offices downtown at the World Financial Center, decided to build a 35-story tower at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street. Executives who have been briefed on the bank's plans say it now wants to cut its presence in the new building to 600,000 square feet and look for at least 300,000 square feet downtown or in Jersey City. The move could save it as much as $12 million a year in rent, one downtown executive said.
Mr. Konsker, the broker for the bank, declined to comment on its plans.
Bear Stearns, which has offices at the Metrotech complex in Brooklyn, is even considering moving about 2,000 employees from Brooklyn to Lower Manhattan or Jersey City. But that poses a policy problem for the city, which has long used tax breaks and incentives to encourage companies to move data processing and other departments to Brooklyn or Queens, rather than New Jersey.
After threatening a move to Whippany, N.J., in 1991, Bear Stearns got more than $30 million in incentives from the city to move 1,500 employees to the Metrotech complex. Six years later, the Giuliani administration more than doubled the subsidy, to $75 million, when the bank announced that it would build a 45-story headquarters on Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets.
Several executives say Bear Stearns recently asked the city for even more subsidies to hop back across the East River to Lower Manhattan, a move that some officials say would hurt Brooklyn's economy. The bank, which did not return calls seeking comment, has also looked at alternatives in Jersey City.
But the executives say it is unclear whether Bear Stearns has met its obligations to maintain a certain number of employees in New York to qualify for the tax breaks. Some brokers said the company might be playing another round of corporate poker, in which it threatens to relocate in order to obtain tax breaks, cash incentives from New York and a better deal from its landlord.

HEADLINE: G.M. Beat Ford in Efficiency, A Study of Auto Plants Finds 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 13 

 BODY:
Last year, for the first time since a closely watched study began tracking productivity, General Motors was more efficient than the Ford Motor Company in building cars.
 But both companies, along with DaimlerChrysler, parent of the Chrysler Group, continue to trail Asian competitors in productivity and profitability. The gap remains wide, even though the three major Asian automakers -- Toyota, Honda Motor and Nissan -- slipped a bit last year. 
 According to the study, the Harbour Report, which tracks productivity in North American auto plants, it took G.M. 39.3 hours last year, on average, to form a car body from sheet metal, build the engine and transmission and assemble the vehicle. That number has fallen from 47.1 hours in 1997 and was ahead of the 40.9 hours at Ford. It was the first time since the study began in 1989 that G.M. topped Ford. Such variances are a crucial measure of the drive among automakers for higher efficiency, which leads to greater profitability. 
The report continued G.M.'s streak of encouraging news, coming on the heels of a strong showing last month in an initial-quality survey by J. D. Power & Associates. 
"This shouldn't have happened," said Ron Harbour, president of Harbour & Associates, a consulting and research firm in Troy, Mich., that compiles the annual report from data collected from automakers. Ford's productivity has moved in the opposite direction of G.M.'s, from 36.8 hours a vehicle in 1997 to 40.9 last year, according to the report.
"G.M. passed them by," Mr. Harbour said, adding that he thought Ford grew complacent in the late 1990's.
Since ousting its chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser, last October, Ford's new chief, William Clay Ford Jr., has put in place a turnaround plan and conceded a need to refocus on getting manufacturing systems and quality in order.
"We've said repeatedly that we did lose our focus in some of the basic disciplines," a Ford spokeswoman, Della DiPietro, said.
G.M. was in a more celebratory mood. The company's plant in Oshawa, Ontario, which makes the Chevrolet Impala and Monte Carlo, ranked as the most efficient plant in the report, beating Asian automakers' plants in North America. It was the first time G.M. had won the category. The Oshawa plant turns out a car with 16.8 hours of labor, on average.
"As we continue to improve our quality, more waste pops out of the system," said Gary L. Cowger, the president of G.M.'s North American operations. "We're proud of the gains we've made particularly in the last two years. But we also know we can't rest on our laurels. As we speak, the competition is improving."
The study also pointed out how far the Big Three automakers still have to go to match the productivity levels of Asian competitors. Honda averaged 31.2 hours a vehicle last year while Toyota averaged 31.6 hours. Nissan, which ranks sixth in sales in the United States, led the productivity study for the eight consecutive year, with 29 hours a vehicle. 
"Despite this improved efficiency, G.M. only made $300 per vehicle and the average Japanese automaker made over $1,000 per vehicle last year," said Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. He added that G.M.'s progress on manufacturing efficiency was encouraging but that it would still take years to change perceptions about G.M.'s quality.
"As this business becomes more and more competitive, and it will, you see more intense pricing competition," Mr. Lache said. "The guys making less money than the Japanese today will be making less money in the future." 
Last year, DaimlerChrysler and Ford both lost more than $1,600 a vehicle, while G.M. made $337 a vehicle, according to the Harbour Report. Honda led with profits of $1,661 per vehicle.

HEADLINE: Outlook for Japan Improves, But Households Are Stressed 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 13 

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan slightly upgraded its outlook for the country's economy for a fourth consecutive month today, citing a rebound in exports. But it also warned that the average household was still being pinched.
 The central bank's report for June came after a similar assessment for May. The reports were relatively good news for Japan, the second-largest economy in the world. It has been struggling to emerge from a decade-long slump. 
 "Over all, Japan's economy is projected to stop declining as a whole since an increase in exports and production will lead to an improvement in corporate profits and, in turn, domestic private demand," the Bank of Japan said.
Still, it cautioned that domestic private demand remained weak, and warned that "employment and income conditions of households over all remain severe."
Last week, Japan had its strongest growth in two years, with gross domestic product rising 1.4 percent in the first quarter from the previous quarter. The increase supports the government's view that the downturn is ending.
But the government also said it expected that G.D.P. would be flat for the fiscal year that began in April, compared with a year earlier.
And in a sign that any healing in the economy has so far failed to trickle down to the labor market, Japan's unemployment rate remained unchanged in April, at 5.2 percent, its eighth consecutive month above 5 percent.
The Bank of Japan acknowledged today that recovery was still hampered by high unemployment and the bad loans that are burdening commercial banks.
And while the central bank expects the economy to stop deteriorating, it did not say when the economy might improve.
Many economists say that manufacturing is already showing signs of recovery but that the services sector could lag for months.
"The Bank of Japan is unlikely to declare full recovery until then," said Ryo Hino, an analyst with J. P. Morgan in Tokyo. "But 'when' is the magic question."
A sudden spurt in exports has helped the Japanese economy, and the central bank predicted that domestic industrial production would increase to meet growing demand in the United States and Asia. Still, it said, the "pace of recovery is likely to become somewhat slower in the future than at present."
Critics say that too much reliance on exports will not support stable, long-term growth, in part because manufacturers are increasingly relocating factories to cheaper production sites elsewhere.
Dependence on exports also exposes Japan to the ravages of the global economy.
The Bank of Japan hinted at concern over that today, saying that the outlook for recovery in the United States, in particular, was accompanied "by various uncertain factors," including swinging exchange rates. In recent months, the United States dollar has tumbled against the yen and euro.

HEADLINE: Brazil Tries to Fight 'Wave of Anxiety' on Economy 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13 

 BODY:
The Brazilian government tried today to calm roiling financial markets and bolster its sinking currency by announcing a package of measures meant to restore confidence.
 To reinforce its financial reserves, the government will tap a $10 billion line of credit with the International Monetary Fund, the finance minister, Pedro Malan, said this afternoon at a news conference in Brasilia. At the same time, he said, the government will increase its budget surplus and buy back some of its foreign debt. 
 These steps, he said, are intended to "counter the wave of anxiety" that has assailed Brazil's economy, the largest in Latin America, in recent days, and to show investors that Brazil is "stronger than the turbulence of the present moment." 
That turbulence has been more severe than expected. The value of the Brazilian currency, the real, has fallen 17 percent against the American dollar this year, with most of the loss in the last two weeks. The main stock market index has fallen more than 15 percent since January, and bond yields have shot up nearly 20 percent just this month. The main credit rating agencies have revised downward their outlook on Brazil. 
Much of the market nervousness can be attributed to growing worries about the presidential election to be held in October, a race now led by Luiz Inacio da Silva of the left-wing Workers' Party. Recent polls show Mr. da Silva with the support of more than 40 percent of voters, a lead of more than 2 to 1 over Jose Serra, the handpicked candidate of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. 
Analysts here and on Wall Street fear that if Mr. da Silva is elected, he will renegotiate or even default on Brazil's foreign debt, a stance that his party has endorsed for most of its 20-year history. The analysts also worry that he may abandon other free-market policies, like the privatization of state companies, and fail to fight inflation aggressively.
The jitters of recent days have developed despite statistics showing the economy performing well. Inflation fell to just 0.1 percent last month, for instance. And on Wednesday, Congress secured $1.75 billion in new government revenue by extending a financial transactions tax.
"This is purely political," Edmar Bacha, a leading economist here and a former president of Brazil's national development bank, said of the sagging markets. "If you look at the most recent economic indicators, they are all very good. The economy is growing, and the trade balance is favorable, so the fundamentals are all strong."
Today, investors' initial reaction to the government's announcement was mixed. The real bounced back and regained some lost ground in moderate trading, but the main Sao Paulo stock market index closed down 1.4 percent. 
The $10 billion credit line that Brazil intends to draw on is not a new loan; it was part of a $15 billion package negotiated with the International Monetary Fund last August. Government officials said earlier that they hoped not to have to use the credit line, but the market's sudden skittishness left them little choice.
In addition, the fund has agreed to lower, to $15 billion from $20 billion, the minimum level of foreign reserves that Brazil must keep on hand. If the pressure on the currency continues or intensifies, that change will give Brazil "an important additional space to intervene in the foreign exchange market when we deem it appropriate," Arminio Fraga, the president of the Central Bank, said today.
Both the nature of Brazil's economic problems and the way the fund is responding to them stand in sharp contrast to the situation in neighboring Argentina. Officials there have quarreled with the fund and have been unable to obtain new credit since Argentina's currency and economic collapse six months ago. But Brazil has consistently followed the fund's guidelines, meaning that the fund's own credibility would be damaged if the situation here worsened.
On Wednesday, a senior fund official in Washington, Gerd Hausler, acknowledged that "there are some political uncertainties" in Brazil and that only Brazilians can resolve them. But, he said, "markets agree that the present economic policy of Brazil is largely appropriate."
Arguing that he is not to blame for the current turbulence, Mr. da Silva has accused the government of "fomenting speculation to create panic in Brazilian society." He has criticized market analysts for engaging in "economic terrorism," and he has rejected suggestions that he help assuage investors' doubts by clarifying his positions and policies.
"The only words that console the speculator are those which permit him to continue speculating," he said.
Earlier this month, Mr. da Silva sent one of his closest economic advisers, Aloizio Mercadante, to the United States to meet with market analysts and others. But that move failed to have the desired calming effect, perhaps because until recently Mr. Mercadante advocated a "rupture" with the fund and called on the Brazilian government to withdraw from free trade negotiations with the United States.
Addressing a business group this week, Mr. da Silva argued that the slump was the fault not of his policies but of Brazilian interest rates. Those rates are among the highest in the world, with a benchmark short-term rate of nearly 20 percent; the comparable rate in the United States is 1.75 percent. The high rates, meant to combat inflation, are clearly inhibiting growth. "Either we reduce interest rates or the country atrophies," Mr. da Silva said.
Rates are a concern to borrowers and creditors alike because Brazil's net public debt has now risen to almost 55 percent of its gross domestic product. Mr. Fraga has been criticized in recent days for his decision to exchange long-term debt for much shorter maturities, a step that was intended to appease markets but has added to Brazil's debt burden.
"The root problem is that people are beginning to understand that the high real interest rates and debt have been prolonged for too long," said Christian Stracke, an analyst with Creditsights, a Wall Street research firm. "At some point, something has to give," he said, no matter who wins the election.
Only about 20 percent of Brazil's total public debt of nearly $300 billion is owed to foreigners, but four-fifths of the domestic debt is tied either to foreign exchange rates, mainly the dollar, or to interest rates, making it unusually vulnerable to market swings.
In a conference call last week, Mr. Fraga assured investors that Brazil's debt load would be manageable however the election came out. Today, though, he sought to reduce that burden by announcing that Brazil would buy back at least $3 billion of the $9 billion or so in debts coming due in 2003 and 2004.
"This is a point on the curve that deserves our attention," he said, acknowledging that interest rates have been very high recently. "It lowers our profile and relieves a bit of what is due in the next government, which is always a good thing."

HEADLINE: Senate Debating a U.S. Role In Terror Insurance Coverage 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
The Senate began debate yesterday on insurance legislation that would require the government to pay the vast majority of losses in a terrorist attack, with Democrats and Republicans sharply divided over restrictions on terrorism-related lawsuits.
 In the early evening, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, said the debate would most likely continue into next week. He said he would call for a vote on two amendments this morning. 
 As introduced by Democrats last week, the legislation provides for the government to pay 90 percent of the financial losses in a terrorist attack if they exceed $10 billion. With losses of less than $10 billion, insurance companies would pay a portion based on their market share and would then be reimbursed for 80 percent of additional losses by the government.
Disagreement over limits on terrorism-related lawsuits stalled the insurance measure in the Senate last December, and insurers, bankers and real estate groups that have been lobbying for the insurance bill say they fear that the debate could scuttle the bill. But Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said they were optimistic that a compromise would be reached. 
The Senate Republicans and the Bush administration want to bar victims of terrorism from bringing negligence lawsuits against businesses or the government. 
The Democrats oppose seeking punitive damages from the government but want victims to be able to recover damages from the government for economic losses and pain and suffering; they want no restrictions on suits against businesses.
In the afternoon, the Democrats defeated an amendment that would have prevented lawsuits against American corporations. The vote was 50 to 46.
Angela de Rocha, an aide to Senator Gramm, said that in its current form Republicans thought the legislation left government and businesses open to "predatory lawsuits." 
Even if Congress passed such a bill, she said, "the president will veto it." While urging passage of an insurance bill, President Bush has insisted on limiting lawsuits.
Immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks, the insurers withdrew coverage for terrorism but later resumed writing policies. Those lobbying for government assistance, along with the Bush administration, contend that inadequate amounts of terrorism insurance have been an added strain on an already sluggish economy. At the same time, many insurance brokers and some consumer advocates contend that terrorism insurance is becoming increasingly available and that prices for the coverage are dropping. 
The Consumer Federation of America reiterated yesterday morning its belief that some big buildings, stadiums and other properties in New York and other big cities have not been able to obtain the necessary terrorism coverage. It urged that the legislation be focused specifically on areas where the shortage was most acute to limit the potential cost to taxpayers.
If the Senate passes an insurance bill, it will have to be reconciled with a far different insurance measure adopted by the House last fall. Instead of paying for most of the costs in an attack, the House bill would make loans available to the insurers. But in an interview, Mr. Schumer said he thought the differences could be resolved. "Once we get a Senate bill," he said, "we'll get a bill we can send to the president."

HEADLINE: Traditional Council Elects Karzai as Afghan President 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 13 

 BODY:
In a resounding endorsement of national unity that marked an end to conflict after 23 years, a large majority of delegates at a traditional council elected Hamid Karzai, who has been interim leader for the last six months, to serve the next two years as this country's president.
 It was the first broadly representative election in over 20 years, with delegates from every ethnic group and region, and as such it represents a remarkable watershed in Afghanistan's recent history. 
 Mr. Karzai won 1,295 of 1,575 ballots distributed to delegates, easily defeating his two challengers, one of whom also made Afghan history as the first woman to run for president, just six months after the repressive Taliban fell from power. But it was Mr. Karzai's victory and he was quickly engulfed by enthusiastic supporters and regional leaders surging forward with congratulations. 
His election by a loya jirga, or grand council, a much-honored tribal institution that drew representatives from all regions of Afghanistan, gives him the mandate to lead a transitional administration until general elections in 2004.
"I am proud of you, that you could trust me and that I could win the leadership of the transitional government," he told delegates. "You have laid a very high trust in me." 
The United States, which helped put him in power as part of its war against the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, openly backed his candidacy. The American envoy to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, was on stage offering his congratulations this evening as the results were read inside the vast tent where the loya jirga has been meeting for several days. 
"He became a consensus candidate," said Mr. Khalilzad in an interview after the election. "It looked like he was going to win, and it happens often in Afghan loya jirgas when a victory looks inevitable, then they move towards a consensus."
Mr. Karzai had won over the strongest challengers to his side earlier in the week, securing important endorsements from the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, who ruled out any post for himself, as well as a former president, Burhanuddin Rabbani, and the strong Tajik faction in his own cabinet, including Defense Minister Muhammad Qasim Fahim. Mr. Karzai is an ethnic Pashtun.
A final challenge came when royalists put forward their own candidate for chairman of the loya jirga on Wednesday. But when the chairmanship was won this morning by Ismail Qasimyar, a supporter of Mr. Karzai, it became clear that there was broad support for him.
One of his two opponents in the race was Dr. Massouda Jalal, 35, a medical professor who works for the World Food Program in Kabul. She made an impressive speech advocating a strong central government, police force and national army. She promised to improve education and build up the judiciary, as well as promote adult literacy. About 85 percent of Afghan adults, many of them women, are illiterate. 
"As women we have the right to vote and no one can put pressure on us," she said.
The third candidate, Mir Muhammad Mafouz Nedai, a Kabul company director, spoke urgently of the need to build up the shattered economy. "If a country is holding out its hands for medicines and clothes and these things come from other countries," he said, "then we cannot say we are free."
Dr. Jalal won 171 votes, Mr. Nedai 89, and the remaining ballots were invalid.
Before tackling the enormous challenges of economic and social reconstruction, Mr. Karzai must first try to form a cabinet that will satisfy the powerful regional and factional leaders who gave him support. Additionally, in the coming days he will have to persuade loya jirga delegates to endorse his plan for a new government structure and the people he chooses to run that structure, among them several deputies or vice presidents.
"He's going to be much more confident now," Mr. Khalilzad said of Mr. Karzai. "He has won a landslide and he has the vote of the people. He can choose his own cabinet and put forward his own program."
Yet, Mr. Khalilzad acknowledged, some things will have not changed: there is as yet no national army loyal to the president, and powerful regional leaders remain a strong force.
The 4,500-member international security force deployed in Kabul and its environs will probably stay until June 2004, the deadline for a new constitution and general elections, Western diplomats said. Special Forces helping to train the new Afghan National Army and police force are also to remain in place until then.
Mr. Karzai, who was chosen as interim leader more than six months ago by Afghans gathered for talks in Bonn, Germany, has an inclusive, respectful speaking style that has helped draw regional leaders and some warlords to his side.
His speech to delegates here before the vote, delivered partly in Pashto and partly in Dari, embraced all ethnic groups and factions in Afghanistan. He paid honor, too, to the Islamic guerrillas who fought against the Soviet occupation and then later against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, and remembered the slain leaders of some of these groups, such as the Tajik leader Ahmed Shah Massoud, the Hazara leader Mazari, and the Pashtun leader Abdul Haq, and "all the other Afghan martyrs whose graves lie in the desert marked with only one flag."
He even found something good to say about the first, good intentions of the Taliban, before the movement was subverted by foreign influence and turned against its own people. 
And in comments that will be welcome in this unstable corner of Asia, he promised to forge good relations with Afghanistan's neighbors, despite the interference that experienced from those countries in the last two decades. He was careful to praise Iran and Pakistan for the help they had given to Afghanistan's millions of refugees over the last 23 years of war.
"We give a guarantee to our neighbors that we are not going to take any action against them, because we know what was done to us," he said.
Speeches will continue in the loya jirga over the next two days, which will give Mr. Karzai time to draft his plan of government and choose several deputies or vice presidents, as well as heads of the judiciary and the legislature. 
He is expected to propose that the loya jirga elect over 111 delegates to form a national parliament, made up of representatives from each province and from special groups.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: SUCCESSION; 
6 Men Who Could Be Contenders to Lead the Palestinians if Arafat Goes

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET and JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 13 

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat has remained the Palestinian leader for more than 30 years in part by not cultivating a long-term lieutenant, avoiding a threat to his pre-eminence by dividing up power beneath himself and encouraging rivalries among his top political and security aides. 
 That strategy has also left him without a clear successor. 
 Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has called Mr. Arafat a terrorist and wished him exiled. President Bush has harshly criticized Mr. Arafat, but the United States has so far blocked any Israeli move to harm him. 
Some senior Israeli security officials and Palestinian politicians argue that there is no alternative to Mr. Arafat, who they say would dominate Palestinian affairs in the West Bank and Gaza even from exile. His death, they say, could bring on bloody civil conflict. It could also lead other Palestinian factions outside Mr. Arafat's organization, like the militant movements Islamic Jihad and Hamas, to vie for prominence. 
Despite Mr. Arafat's maneuverings, a varied, experienced group of potential leaders waits in the wings. They include older men who lived decades in exile with Mr. Arafat and younger ones who grew up fighting the Israelis in the West Bank and Gaza and studying Israeli society at close hand. 
If the objection to Mr. Arafat has been his involvement in terrorist activities, few among these leaders -- most of whom have spent years in Israeli jails -- would be exempt from similar charges. But none have Mr. Arafat's combination of international standing, broad constituency, financial resources and the raw power of guns.

Mahmoud Abbas
Lawyer and historian, late 60's
Mahmoud Abbas, who is known as Abu Mazen, has long been known as Mr. Arafat's No. 2. Along with Mr. Arafat, he is one of the few remaining founders of Fatah, first organized in the late 1950's by a group of young Palestinian professionals working in the Persian Gulf. 
In 1980 he was elected to the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization. He is now secretary general, which in the overlapping and somewhat makeshift governing structure makes him the second-ranking Palestinian leader, even though he has no post in the cabinet. 
Regarded as a moderate and pragmatic voice, he played a leading role in encouraging contacts between Palestinians and left-wing Israelis as far back as the 1970's. 
Mr. Abbas was born in 1935 in Safad, a town in Galilee, and became a refugee in Syria in 1948 with the birth of Israel. In addition to a law degree earned in Damascus, he holds a doctorate in history from the Moscow Oriental College; his topic was Zionism. He was an important figure in the negotiations leading up to the Oslo accords and is regarded as having good contacts with both Israelis and Americans.

Marwan Barghouti
Politician, 42
Marwan Barghouti is now the second-most-popular Palestinian leader after Mr. Arafat, according to a recent poll that placed his support at 19 percent, compared to Mr. Arafat's 35 percent. It has not hurt Mr. Barghouti's standing that he is once again in an Israeli prison, having been arrested in April on accusations of masterminding terrorist operations by Mr. Arafat's Fatah movement. 
Until the current conflict, Mr. Barghouti, who is fluent in Hebrew and English, had close ties to Israelis and a growing reputation as an advocate of reconciliation. A wry and subtle man given to blue jeans and leather jackets, he has positioned himself as the common man's alternative to corrupt, aging ministers around Mr. Arafat whose roots in the West Bank are not as deep.
Mr. Barghouti, who is 42, was raised in a West Bank village outside Ramallah and is a member of a large, well-known clan. He logged six years in Israeli prisons, even before his recent arrest, having first been arrested by Israel at 16. 
He was deported in 1978. He returned five years later, became chairman of the student council at Bir Zeit University -- where much later he earned a masters in international relations -- and was then deported again. He returned to the West Bank in 1994 under the Oslo peace accords, winning a seat in the Palestinian Parliament and the office of general secretary of Fatah in the West Bank. 
Mr. Barghouti has always called himself a political leader, not a military one. He has advocated violence only against Israeli settlers and soldiers in the West Bank and Gaza, insisting that once Israel evacuated those territories, the warring peoples could live in peace.

Muhammad Dahlan
Security official, 40
At 40, Muhammad Dahlan is among the youngest of the senior Palestinian leaders. In anticipation of Mr. Arafat's reorganization of his government, he resigned recently as chief of the preventive security forces in Gaza, and is seeking a job as a senior political adviser to Mr. Arafat, which would broaden his portfolio while insulating him from criticism if his old force begins to crack down on Palestinian militants. 
The move is in keeping with Mr. Dahlan's reputation as a sophisticated politician. Mr. Dahlan says he was jailed 10 times by Israel, for a total of six years, but Israeli officials say his jail time was considerably less. 
He was deported in 1987. "The Israelis deported me to Jordan," Mr. Dahlan said in sketching his resume during an interview in November. "The Jordanians deported me to Egypt. The Egyptians deported me to Iraq." 
It may seem paradoxical, but one of Mr. Dahlan's assets is that he has excellent relations with Arab states, and solid ties as well to American and even some Israeli officials. 
Mr. Dahlan speaks English and began studying Hebrew when he returned to Gaza in 1994. Since then, he has struggled to extend his influence beyond Gaza.

Ahmed Qurei
Economic adviser, mid-60's
Ahmed Qurei, better known as Abu Ala, is the speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council and regarded as one of the main authors of the Oslo agreement. 
He was born to a wealthy family in 1937 in Abu Dis, on the Mount of Olives, then an Arab village on the outskirts of Jerusalem. He is regarded by some Palestinians as an aristocrat rather than a revolutionary. Much of his activity has been in the economic sphere, and he has been the mainstay of the Palestinian Economic Council for Development and Reconstruction, the main development agency. 
He joined Fatah, Mr. Arafat's mainstream faction, in 1968 and was director of foreign investment for the Palestine Liberation Organization. 
Mr. Qurei led the Palestinian delegations to the secret negotiations that led to the Oslo agreement in September 1993, and to talks afterward on its implementation. 
He has been critical of corruption in the Palestinian Authority and the cabinet. Under the Basic Law -- passed five years ago but only just signed by Mr. Arafat -- he is officially designated as the person to take over as president of the Palestinian National Authority.

Jibril Rajoub
Security official, 49
Jibril Rajoub, the gravel-voiced, pragmatic chief of preventive security in the West Bank, has for years had the advantage and burden of being one of Israel's favorite Palestinians. Lately this distinction has become a millstone, though Mr. Rajoub retains a strong geographic power base around Hebron, where he grew up. 
First arrested at 15, Mr. Rajoub, who just turned 49, was sentenced to life in prison in 1970 for throwing a grenade at a convoy of soldiers, then released in a prisoner exchange with the P.L.O. He served a total of 17 years in Israeli prisons before being deported to Lebanon in 1988, during the first intifada. 
He became a close lieutenant of Mr. Arafat and spent seven years in exile with him before returning to the West Bank. Mr. Rajoub, who speaks Hebrew and English, has strong ties to American and Israeli security officials, having taken part in trilateral meetings for years. 
But Mr. Rajoub's security compound, paid for at least partly by the United States, was shelled during Israel's incursion into Ramallah in March. Without accusing Mr. Rajoub directly, Israeli officials later claimed to have found disguises linking the office to suicide attacks. 
Mr. Rajoub's popularity has declined in the West Bank, and it is not yet clear what role he might play as Mr. Arafat reorganizes his government in response to American pressure.

Sheik Ahmad Yassin
Hamas's spiritual leader, mid-60's
Sheik Ahmad Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas, the main Islamic fundamendalist organization, is the most charismatic rival to Mr. Arafat functioning outside the framework of the Palestine Liberation Organization. 
Crippled from a childhood injury, he is frail, uses a wheelchair and speaks in a high squeaky voice. 
But his uncompromising denunciations of Israel from his spartan headquarters in Gaza thrill many and inspire suicide bombers. 
Sheik Yassin calls for the recovery of historic Palestine, that is, the abolisment of the State of Israel, and the establishing of an Islamic state. 
His early origins are unclear, but he was born around 1937 and became a refugee in the cramped, squalid Gaza Strip with the birth of Israel in 1948. Although lacking in formal religious education, he was strongly influenced in his youth by Ikhwan -- the radical Muslim Brotherhood founded in Egypt -- and became a compelling preacher. 
He founded the Islamic Center in Gaza in 1973, which soon controlled all religious institutions there. 
In 1991 he was sentenced to life plus 15 years on charges of abetting terrorism, but was released in a prisoner exchange in 1997 for Mossad agents caught in Jordan trying to assassinate a Hamas official by pouring poison in his ear. Sheik Yassin was greeted as a hero on his return to Gaza.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on June 14 about potential successors to Yasir Arafat and one on Aug. 15 about the indictment of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader who is being tried by Israel on murder charges, misstated the history of his arrests and deportation. He was first arrested in 1978 at the age of 19, not 16. He was deported once, in 1987, not twice, and returned to the West Bank in 1994, not 1993. (A reader reported the errors by e-mail on Sept. 2; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

HEADLINE: Battle on Estate Tax: How Two Well-Organized Lobbies Sprang Into Action 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13 

 BODY:
As the Senate moved toward a risky vote on repealing the estate tax; William H. Gates Jr. sat a continent away on Wednesday, trying to work his will on the proceedings.
 One of a group of wealthy Americans who have campaigned to keep the inheritance tax, Mr. Gates, father of the Microsoft mogul, called pivotal senators. From Seattle, he laid out his case for withstanding the Republican-led election year effort to eliminate the tax or put Democrats on record as opposing repeal. 
 "It is a very legitimate claim of society on an accumulation of wealth which would not have occurred without an orderly market, free education and incredible dollars spent on research," said Mr. Gates, 76.
 He said he talked with Senators Jean Carnahan of Missouri and Tim Johnson of South Dakota, two Democrats who will no doubt face tough questions about the tax in their re-election campaigns. Mr. Gates said he doubted that he had much effect. But Mr. Johnson and Mrs. Carnahan were among 44 senators who voted to retain the tax, blocking a business-backed campaign to end it.
 When it became clear on Tuesday that the senate was going to vote on repeal, lobbying turned frantic. Groups on both sides blanketed members with e-mail messages, prompting thousands of telephone calls to senators who were viewed as being in the middle of the debate.
 Although no senator would acknowledge being swayed by such a campaign, repeal opponents said they believed that they helped cement the votes of at least three law-makers who supported the tax cut package last year that started the fight, Mr. Johnson, Mrs. Carnahan and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.
 Repeal advocates say they had successes, as well, in retaining two other Democrats, Ron Wyden of Oregon and Bill Nelson of Florida.
 "Oregon and Florida were our biggest targets," said Marty G. Reiser, a spokesman for Citizens for a Sound Economy, an antitax group. "We generated visits to their offices and a lot of phone calls. Their staffs were certainly aware of our pressure."
 The fight grew out of a wrinkle in the tax cuts last year. Under current law, the value of assets exempt from the estate tax gradually rises until 2010, when it is eliminated for one year. With no change, the tax then reverts to last year's level. Republicans have said permanently eliminating the tax is a defining issue for their party.
 Advocates for repeal included groups like Mr. Reiser's and coalitions that represented some of the biggest business lobbies in town, including the National Federation of Independent Business, the National Association of Manufacturers, automobile dealers, grocery chains, farm groups and even family-held telephone and media companies.
 On the other side were aggressive nonprofit groups allied with some of the most successful makers of profit in America, millionaires and billionaires with a deep-seated philosophical resistance to lifting the tax who formed a group called Responsible Wealth. Besides Mr. Gates, the group included Warren Buffett, George Soros and Ted Turner, among other figures as familiar on Wall Street as on Pennsylvania Avenue.
 Business lobbyists, who knew from the start that they had a uphill fight, said the maneuver by the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, Democrat of South dakota, to bring the issue to the floor unexpectedly on Tuesday cost them.
 "Our effort was grass-roots oriented," said Dirk Van dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors and a leader of the Tax Relief Coalition, which says it has 1,000 members.
 The fight was supposed to have been joined on Wednesday, when another group, Americans for a Fair Estate Tax, an alliance of nonprofit groups and others that oppose the repeal, had planned to release the results of a poll that showed that public opinion favored changing tax but not total repeal.
 At the same time, the federation of independent business was to begin its annual legislative conference, giving hundreds of small business owners a chance to buttonhole their senators in the Capitol corridors. They expected the vote some time before the end of the month.
 Mr. Daschle, running the schedule, had other plans. On Tuesday afternoon, he said that the Senate would start debate a few hours after it had approved a $450 billion increase in the debt limit. He wanted the contrast between the increase in borrowing power and the estimated $740 billion 10-year cost of the repeal to be the backdrop for the floor fight. Stunned, the competing lobbies sprung into action.
 On Wednesday, the lobbying rivals went ahead with their planned events. The repeal opponents had a news conference for the release of their poll and a telephone conference with Mr. Gates. Republican had their event, featuring the manager of a Missouri lumber company worried about holding on to the family business, a clear message to Mr.s Carnahan.
 A critical development was the ability of Senate Democrats to offer competing proposals to the all-out repeal. Mrs. Carnahan joined Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, in offering a plan that would have lifted the value of assets exempt from the tax to $4 million as of next year and granted an unlimited exemption to qualifying heirs.
 Mr. Gates said he did not intend to leave antirepeal lawmakers on their own. "We are certainly going to be helpful to people who this particularly exposes," he said. "The repeal of this tax gives me nightmares."

HEADLINE: End Homelessness? We Need the Will 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Plan to End City Homelessness in 10 Years" (news article, June 13):
 You report that more than 33,800 homeless people are living in New York City homeless shelters today, a population that skyrocketed by 26 percent in the last year alone, and that the city spends close to $1 billion a year on homelessness. 
 Clearly, the short-term, Band-Aid approach to homelessness has failed. 
Solutions must be multifaceted: affordable housing, supportive services tailored to the needs of individuals, living-wage jobs, effective job training and antipoverty efforts. 
Ending homelessness in 10 years is humane, makes economic sense and is achievable. The only missing ingredient is political will.

ROY GAINSBURG
Chmn., Partnership for the Homeless
New York, June 13, 2002

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
FallingConsumer Confidence Helps Send the Dow Lower

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged early yesterday on reports that consumer confidence fell this month and a car bomb exploded outside the United States consulate in Karachi, Pakistan, killing at least 11 people. But investors overcame their initial nervousness and shares rebounded, eliminating almost all of the day's losses.
 But even with the rebound, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at new lows for the year, capping off their fourth consecutive weekly declines. For the week, the Dow lost 1.2 percent and the S.& P. 2 percent. Both are at their lowest point since the Sept. 21 bottom in the wake of Sept. 11. The Nasdaq composite index ended the day barely in the black but fell 2 percent for the week, its fourth consecutive weekly decline. 
 Among the stocks leading the market down were General Motors, Home Depot, Sprint PCS, Qualcomm, Cisco Systems and Dell Computer.
"I don't know if we can say more about the rebound than some investors came in to cover their shorts," said William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics in Boston. He was referring to short sellers, who borrow stock and sell it in hopes that the price will decline. Buying the stock back, in this case, allowed them to lock in their profits. He also said that some investors appeared to be snapping up "what they considered to be bargains."
Some of the market sectors that were doing poorly recently, including multiline insurance companies and diversified financial companies, were leading the rebound yesterday, he said.
"What this means depends on what kind of follow-through there is over the next couple of days," he said.
Combined with a report that industrial production rose just 0.2 percent in May, the data suggested that the economic recovery that is under way may be slower than expected, delaying the hoped-for rebound in corporate earnings. The bombing, along with recent warnings of potential terrorist attacks here, could continue to sap consumer confidence. That could mean consumers would slow their spending, making the recovery even weaker.
Also hanging over the market is investor concern about the manipulation of corporate earnings, the reliability of accounting firms and recent reports of insider trading and tax evasion by leading corporate executives.
The Dow finished down 28.59 points, or 0.3 percent, at 9,474.21, after falling more than 240 points soon after trading began. The S.& P. 500 index was off 2.29 points, or 0.2 percent, at 1,007.27, after dropping almost 30 points. The Nasdaq managed to claw its way back into the black, finishing up 7.88 points, or 0.5 percent, at 1,504.74, after falling 51 points earlier.
At their lows in early trading, the S.& P. 500 index was 16 points away from the low it hit on Sept. 21. The Nasdaq was just 22 points away.
The University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence fell to 90.8 in June from 96.9 in May, the biggest drop since the decline of 9.7 points in September. Industrial production for May rose 0.2 percent, after an increase of 0.3 percent in May. Forecasters had been expecting a 0.3 percent increase.
One sign of investor concern about the slowing of economic growth can be seen in the expectations of when the Federal Reserve will begin raising its short-term interest rate target again. The federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks is now at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent.
The recent betting has been as early as the August meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. But in the last two weeks the yields on these federal funds futures have fallen and it now appears that some investors think the Fed will not act until its meeting on Nov. 6.
Shares of wireless phone companies were among the hardest hit yesterday, after Sprint PCS warned that sales and growth in the number of its wireless customers would fall below analysts' forecasts. Analysts at several brokerage firms including J. P. Morgan and Merrill Lynch lowered their ratings on the sector. Sprint PCS fell more than 26 percent, Triton PCS Holdings, 27 percent, and AT&T Wireless, 9.4 percent.
In the bond market, prices were higher and yields, which move in the opposite direction, lower, as many investors concluded that slower-than-expected growth would put less pressure on interest rates. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note dropped to 4.80 percent from 4.90 percent Thursday, as the price rose 24/32 , to 100 18/32 .

HEADLINE: Baseball? I Got My Ph.D. In It, Thanks; 
To Many Academics, America's Pastime Is More Than a Game

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. 

 BODY:
A sport, a pastime, a diversion, a game. A hobby, a passion, an obsession, a dream. A metaphor, a country of its own, a profession, a statistical mother lode. Baseball is many things to many people, but it is a subject for academic scrutiny to only a few.
 There is an annual conference for this tiny minority, and its 14th incarnation was June 5 to 7 at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum here. Some 70 people attended, including teachers and amateur researchers. But mostly they were scholars from places like New York University, Emory University, the University of Rochester, Union College, Long Island University, Hofstra University and the University of Arkansas. 
 Yes, there is a good-natured sense of "we know people think we're nuts" about them. Many will even acknowledge a shyness (shame is probably too strong a word) over confessing to other academics their adult pursuit of their once boyish or girlish pursuit. 
When Skip McAfee, a nonscholar who has traveled to Cooperstown for each conference from his home in Maryland, quoted President Grover Cleveland in an informal address to the group, he received an appreciative round of laughter and applause.
"What do you think the American people would think about me," Mr. McAfee, the former executive director of the American Society of Horticultural Science, quoted the former president as saying, "if I wasted my time going to a ballgame?"
But all the men and women at the Cooperstown Symposium on Baseball and American Culture were serious enough about baseball's place in American life and history to be drawn by papers on subjects ranging from the advertising industry's use of ballplayers as celebrity product endorsers, to baseball's significance in the works of Ernest Hemingway, to its role in contemporary labor, to its Hollywood filmography and to its history of discrimination. And secretly, or maybe not so secretly, each harbors a belief that this scholarly interest is on the verge of legitimacy, if it isn't already there.
"You still get a condescending attitude from someone whose specialty is supposed to be more serious," said Charles C. Alexander, distinguished professor of history at Ohio University, "but I think we're getting beyond that. I don't think anybody here has to apologize."
Professor Alexander, who has written studies of the Eisenhower presidency and the Ku Klux Klan in addition to biographies of Ty Cobb, Rogers Hornsby and John McGraw and a history of baseball called "Our Game," delivered the keynote address at the conference, which he drew from a chapter in his recently published book, "Breaking the Slump: Baseball in the Depression Era" (Columbia University Press). 
At Ohio, he has been teaching courses on sports and American history since 1980.
"Thirty years ago, I never dreamed I could bite into American history so many ways by writing and teaching baseball history," he said. "What I argue is that baseball history is a lot of other things: immigration, race relations, corporate business, the celebrity phenomenon, the rise of cities, labor history, transportation development, technology development. It was the first big-time sport, the first sport to have an impact on American life, including ballparks as a species of American architecture."
The conference is not, the participants are at pains to point out, about baseball arcana. It does not encourage papers restricted to baseball's insular world. In other words, there are no treatises on the effects of baseball's lowering the pitcher's mound after the 1968 season or statistical analyses of the performances of Duke Snider, Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle to determine once and for all who was New York City's best centerfielder in the 1950's. Nope. That stuff constitutes a whole other discipline called sabermetrics, named after S.A.B.R., the Society for American Baseball Research, an organization founded in 1971 that now claims more than 7,000 members.
Not that the attendees (many are repeaters) aren't interested in such things; the majority of them, of course, were baseball nuts before they were scholars, a circumstance that colored a presentation or two. William M. Simons, for example, a history professor at the State University of New York at Oneonta, used the life of a journeyman major league pitcher who is now, in his 60's, a minor league coach, as a mythical symbol. His bittersweet lecture, "Pitcher at Twilight: Bill Monbouquette and the American Dream," was tinged with personal asides and the ache of Red Sox fandom. 
But much of the conference business was serious-minded in traditional academic style. One paper analyzed the case histories of two ballplayers, Glenn Burke and Billy Bean, who were driven out of the game when it became known that they were homosexual, pointing out that not a single openly gay man has ever played major league baseball.
And not surprisingly, given Jackie Robinson's importance, several presentations focused on race. "He was the biggest issue in integration in the country until court-ordered busing came along," said James Gates, the baseball museum's librarian. 
Doris R. Corbett, a sports sociologist at Howard University, delivered with her colleague Wayne Patterson a paper titled "The Social Significance of Sport and Its Implications for Race and Baseball," which, among other things, raised the issue of racial profiling in the major leagues. They pointed out some statistics that are startling but not easily explainable: that 63.3 percent of major league centerfielders and 36.7 percent of all outfielders are African-American, but that only 3.3 percent of starting catchers and 2 percent of starting pitchers are.
Gregory Bond, a Ph.D. candidate in history at the University of Wisconsin, delivered the first paper of his career: "The Segregation of Professional Baseball in Kansas, 1895-1899," a surprisingly lively account of the travails of the state's black ballplayers, many of them local stars with substantial followings. The paper was drawn from his dissertation, which uses sport as a vehicle to examine American racial attitudes at the turn of the 20th century.
"Most people think baseball was segregated until Jackie Robinson came along in 1947," Mr. Bond said, though, in fact, black athletes played alongside whites on many teams before 1900. "Segregation had to be imposed, and I'll be trying to get at why that was."
It has been nearly half a century since the first Ph.D. dissertation on the game was written at Cornell by Harold Seymour in 1956. The title was "The Rise of Major League Baseball to 1891," and it prefigured his 1960 book, "Baseball: The Early Years" (Oxford University Press), the first baseball volume to be published by an academic press.
By now, 30 to 40 books have been published from papers first presented at the conference, said Alvin L. Hall, who has organized all 14 Cooperstown symposiums. And the way he describes it, it is almost as if there had been a secret baseball academy living within the academy. Before the first conference, he said, he placed a single ad requesting submissions in The Chronicle of Higher Education and was astounded to receive 125 abstracts, 90 percent of them legitimate, many from major universities.
"I went from 'I hope I get enough to hold a conference' to 'I'm going to have to appoint a jury,' " Mr. Hall said.
Most of the academics attending offer courses at their respective schools on subjects like baseball in American history, baseball fiction and the economics of sport.
And as proof of the growing legitimacy of their work, the scholars here cited periodicals like the decade-old Nine: a Journal of Baseball History and Culture, published by the University of Nebraska Press, and The Journal of Sports Economics, which is in its third year. A contributor to that journal, Paul D. Staudohar, a professor of business at California State University at Hayward, is president of the International Association of Sports Economics, which is holding a conference of its own next month at Columbia University.
Here in Cooperstown, Mr. Staudohar, who is also the editor of a volume of baseball short stories, delivered a paper titled "Assessing Outcomes of Baseball Labor Negotiations." (He thinks, by the way, that there may very well be a baseball strike by the end of this season.)
At the very least, the conference makes a pretty good argument that baseball can hold up to the egghead treatment, even if it isn't quite up to being the standard-bearer of human achievement that another of Mr. McAfee's quotables, Tallulah Bankhead, claimed it to be.
"There have been only two geniuses in the world," Mr. McAfee quoted Bankhead as saying. "Willie Mays and Willie Shakespeare."
