LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: Winter's Frustrations Linger On StubbornlyFor U.S. Airline Industry 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Gordon M. Bethune usually struts with enough Texan swagger to stave off the clouds of gloom and doom. He drives a Porsche, rides a Harley and takes spins in the Boeing jets flown by Continental Airlines Inc., which he happens to run.
 But lately, Mr. Bethune has been reduced to throwing up his hands. "We're a stupid industry led by stupid people," he said, his face twisted somewhere between a grimace and a smirk. 
 Mr. Bethune turned Continental from a near-bankrupt airline into the country's most successful full-service carrier. But that is an empty superlative in a profitless industry, and like some other top airline executives, he admits that he is running out of ideas on how to breathe life into the business. 
Still staggered by the Sept. 11 attacks, the airlines are as close to recovery as a comatose patient on an intravenous drip. They lost $2.4 billion in the first quarter of this year and a record $11 billion last year. The biggest carriers need to make deep cuts in labor costs while narrowing the gap between leisure and business fares, experts say. But few people can agree on exactly how to do that.
Everything is up for grabs as executives re-evaluate their operations, from legroom to labor contracts. Some are even calling for retooling the hub-and-spoke route model, which the biggest carriers have developed over the last two decades to feed passengers through transfer points. The giants are looking jealously at the lower-cost operations of Southwest and JetBlue, which do not build their business around fast, easy connections.
So far, though, many of the industry's stabs at resuscitation appear short-sighted.
Airlines that slashed their schedules to save money after Sept. 11 have been furiously adding back flights to gain market share, regardless of whether competitors fly the same routes on the same schedules and at roughly the same prices. Carriers have done nickel-and-dime cost-cutting, removing hot towels and food service, but have yet to address much more serious costs, like labor inefficiencies. Three times in the last two months, carriers have tried -- and failed -- to raise round-trip leisure tickets by $20, and they have yet to overhaul their fare structures to woo back business travelers.
So low have the airlines fallen that they are looking to the government to point the way to salvation, a quarter-century after Washington deregulated the industry.
Executives are carefully watching United Airlines, the second-largest carrier, and US Airways, the sixth largest, as they struggle to win the big labor concessions that the government is demanding if they are to be granted loan guarantees. That backing would come from a $10 billion program set up by Congress after the Sept. 11 attacks.
If those airlines succeed in their negotiations, their competitors almost certainly will set out to roll back their labor costs, too.
"What's broken is that the pricing model reflects a cost model that's not sustainable," said Michael E. Levine, a former airline executive who teaches at Harvard Law School. "The cost model that's not sustainable is not a technological problem, but a problem of fixed commitments like labor contracts and infrastructure contracts. There's nothing wrong that reorganization won't fix. That could take place through renegotiation of contracts, workouts or Chapter 11 bankruptcy."
Of course, the airlines would prefer to avoid bankruptcy court, having had ample experience in it. And they hope that their usually combative unions -- knowing that the industry has hit rock bottom -- will deal with them.
That approach seems to be working at US Airways. The Air Line Pilots Association said Monday that its 4,800 active workers would be willing to give up $400 million a year in wages, benefits and work rule changes, more than two-thirds of the $595 million that executives want. Other labor groups have also offered concessions.
At United, the pilots' union and management reached a tentative agreement yesterday on concessions. Both parties declined to give details. The agreement is still subject to ratification by the union's members and approval by United's board and labor committee. 
"If approved, it will result in significant cost reductions for United while providing our pilots with additional opportunities for participation in United's future growth," said John W. Creighton Jr., the carrier's chief executive.
But other unions have yet to start serious discussions with United executives over the airline's recovery plan.
"When things are bad, the first place they come to is labor," said Robert Roach Jr., the general vice president for transportation at the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 110,000 active airline workers across the country. "But whenever you're in trouble, 9 times out of 10, it's because of mismanagement. We're back in that situation now."
Beyond labor costs, airline managers are re-examining other fundamental aspects of the industry that they now say might be hobbling operations. For example, American Airlines, which popularized the hub-and-spoke system in the 1980's, is looking at whether it should alter its connecting schedules. One idea is to not have so many flights converge and depart at the same time from hub airports like O'Hare International in Chicago and Dallas-Fort Worth International.
"Does it need to be loosened a little bit so that we can achieve reasonable connections and get our costs down so that we provide a product that the customer is willing to pay for?" asked Donald J. Carty, American's chief executive.
At Continental, the fifth-largest carrier, Mr. Bethune said he did not know what more he could do to cut costs without losing the carrier's high levels of worker morale and customer satisfaction.
He has shrunk the fleet from 9 different kinds of aircraft seven years ago to 5. He has invested heavily in regional jets, which are cheaper to buy and operate and make it affordable to feed traffic into Continental's system from smaller airports. The airline has installed self-service check-in kiosks in airports and replaced first-run movies on some flights with older films like "Citizen Kane."
"We did about all we could without compromising the quality of the product and taking the cheese off our pizza," Mr. Bethune said.
But that makes the industry picture even more worrisome, because Continental's recovery remains sluggish. Its revenue per available seat-mile, a standard industry measure, was down 6 to 8 percent last month from a year earlier. It also expects to report a loss this quarter.
A core problem for the industry is that airlines refuse to downsize, with too many carriers flying overlapping routes from the same hubs, experts say. The airlines cut capacity by a fifth after the Sept. 11 attacks and boasted that they would revive along leaner and meaner lines. Instead, they have added back flights until capacity in April was down only 11 percent from the period a year ago, often fighting it out in what Mr. Bethune calls "testosterone wars."
Today, for instance, American Airlines is starting two daily flights between New York and Long Beach, Calif. JetBlue began three flights on the same route last November, added a fourth last week and plans a fifth in October. American said it was strengthening its route structure rather than reacting to JetBlue, but JetBlue executives disagree.
At O'Hare, a knock-down battle between American and United has been unfolding, with the two airlines quickly adding back flights this summer to reach pre-Sept. 11 capacity levels.
"My feeling is there is still too much capacity out there," acknowledged Rono J. Dutta, the president of United. "But when we're adding back, we can't give up market share to others."
Costs are only part of the picture. To regain their health, the airlines need to lure back business travelers, who usually account for about 40 percent of passengers but two-thirds of revenue. During the recent recession, though, businesspeople turned to video-conferencing, trains, cars and discounted plane tickets. Security delays and other post-Sept.11 inconveniences have also kept many away from airports.
Some experts say that the major airlines should look at simpler fare structures like the ones used by Southwest and other no-frills carriers. These airlines usually have only four or five tiers of pricing, as opposed to dozens at the larger carriers, and the walk-up tickets popular with business travelers cost no more than twice advance-purchase fares.
"I think the way things are priced is going to change forever," said James Corridore, the airline analyst at Standard & Poor's. "I think it's more than just a cyclical issue. The cyclical highs are not high enough to offset the cyclical lows. It's not just Sept. 11."
Some carriers are experimenting with advance-purchase fares intended for business travelers, while many have offered deeper discounts to corporate travel departments and small businesses, said Terry Trippler, an airline consultant and fare expert. But the carriers have yet to come up with a fare structure that truly works.
Like virtually all the other problems faced by the airlines, that remains a Gordian knot.
"We need something going for us as an industry," Mr. Bethune said. "We're constantly looking, but it's getting tougher. The tide is pretty heavy."

HEADLINE: Two Reports Show a Faltering Recovery 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14 

 BODY:
Two reports released today showed that consumer confidence had its biggest drop in early June since the terrorist attacks and that industrial production slowed in May as the economic recovery faltered.
 "People had been saying it's just a matter of time before things get better," said James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, which has $75 billion in assets under management. "Well, the lag is too long now." 
 The University of Michigan said its consumer sentiment index fell to 90.8 in June from 96.9 in May. That is the largest decline since a 9.7-point decrease in September. Production at factories, utilities and mines rose 0.2 percent last month after a 0.3 percent gain in April, the Federal Reserve said.
Flagging confidence and production came after a larger-than-expected drop in retail sales last month and add to a picture of slowing growth.
Economists had expected the Michigan index, which is based on a telephone survey of about 500 households, to fall to 96.5, according to the median estimate of 47 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey.
Concerns about the threat of more terrorist attacks and a lack of faith in corporate accountability that has sent stock prices tumbling may prompt consumers to rein in spending and slow the economy's rebound, economists said. That may help explain declines in sales at retailers.
A slowdown in automaking and in utility output contributed to the smaller gain in industrial production last month. Economists had expected a 0.3 percent increase for May.
Still, the increase was the fifth consecutive rise in industrial production, which has not happened in almost two years. Manufacturing is rising because inventories have fallen below levels needed to keep meeting demand. Production of semiconductors and office equipment rose.
A separate report today from the Commerce Department showed that business inventories fell 0.2 percent in April, the 15th consecutive decline. The drop brought inventories to the lowest level in two and a half years.
"Inventory-to-sales ratios are now extremely low," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist for High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "Companies do need to rebuild stocks."
The amount of capacity in use rose last month to 75.5 percent, the highest since September. The plant-use rate fell to an almost 19-year low of 74.4 percent in December and is still well below the average 81.8 percent rate during the record expansion from March 1991 to March 2001.

HEADLINE: By Aiding Needy Filipinos, G.I.'s Could Help Rout the Rebels 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: TABIAWAN, the Philippines 

 BODY:
On the small jungle island of Basilan, success in the fight against terrorism may hinge more on digging wells and building roads than on training Philippine soldiers to shoot straighter and track elusive Muslim militants across rugged terrain.
 For the past four months, the stated mission of 160 American Special Forces soldiers here has been to train Philippine soldiers to fight a dwindling band of Abu Sayyaf rebels who have operated on Basilan. 
 But those American Green Berets, as well as 350 Navy and Marine Corps engineers who arrived here in April, have played an equally important role in mending roads, drilling wells and clearing a 1940's airstrip for cargo planes. This will not only improve life for the 300,000 residents of the island, one of the poorest parts of the Philippines, but may also help dry up popular support for Abu Sayyaf, American and Philippine officials hope. 
"When we leave, the improvements stay," said Brig. Gen. Donald C. Wurster of the Air Force, the commander of American forces here in the southern Philippines. "Our strategy is to enhance the Philippine government's legitimacy. We want to eliminate the seed ground for the next generation of terrorists."
Many projects here stem from a six-week survey conducted after the Special Forces set up headquarters in this village north of Isabela, the island's chief city, in late January. The survey found that government services were provided mostly in the island's few Roman Catholic areas, in the north. The majority Muslim population had been mostly neglected. Few residents had drinking water nearby and, on average, two children a day were dying from contaminated water.
Most schools here were staffed with Christian missionaries. When Abu Sayyaf fighters moved in, the Americans found, one of their first acts was to kill or kidnap the schoolteachers and to behead the landowner who donated property for the school.
American and Philippine officials here say the mere presence of 600 armed American troops and 4,000 Philippine soldiers on this 20-mile-by-30-mile island has forced most of the hard-core Abu Sayyaf fighters to flee to nearby islands.
 Indeed, on June 7, Abu Sayyaf fighters and Philippine troops clashed on Mindanao Island, just north of here. Two hostages held by the terrorists, including an American missionary, Martin Burnham, were killed; his wife, Gracia, was wounded but rescued. 
Until now, the risk of being kidnapped or killed by Abu Sayyaf had dissuaded international aid agencies from operating on Basilan.
"Obviously, investment doesn't go in those conditions, which gets you into a vicious circle, where people remain poor, and they're more easily exploited by these terrorist groups," said Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz, who met here with military commanders this month.
The American military, as it has elsewhere, is reviving the island's moribund economy, buying lumber, gravel, food and other supplies from local businesses, and contracting with widows to wash laundry. Entire families have been involved in delivering the Americans' order for 6,000 truckloads of gravel, in particular.
The assessment by the Special Forces presented a plan that essentially dovetailed social and aid programs with military goals. With the rainy season looming, engineers have been given 60 days to build about 40 miles of roads, bridges and other projects.
General Wurster has asked for $7 million from the Defense and State Departments for medical and other community projects on the island. But even without the new authority or requested financing, Special Forces teams have helped in ways large and small.
In one instance, Green Berets came across a little girl with a fishhook snagged in her leg. Medics cleaned and dressed the injury and took her home to her village. The first aid resulted in a new ally on the island, as the girl's grandfather turned out to be a village leader.

HEADLINE: Two Former Governors Come Off the Bench to Help the YankeeNets' Arena Project 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 14 

 BODY:
The YankeeNets could apparently use someone with the skill of the Nets' assist leader, Jason Kidd, to maintain the momentum of its drive to build an 18,000-seat arena here.
 So the owner of the New Jersey Nets and the New Jersey Devils (as well as the New York Yankees) is getting help from two substitutes, former Govs. Thomas H. Kean and Donald T. DiFrancesco. 
 Just a month ago, Gov. James E. McGreevey gave his blessing to a timetable that would delay the introduction of legislation needed to help finance the arena until substantial progress was made on the redevelopment of the teams' current home, the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands. 
The governor had anticipated that the legislation would pass in October, which seemed to satisfy the YankeeNets in May. But now negotiators for the teams' owner have become anxious, worried that the Newark arena concept has lost support, that the complex will not be ready to open in 2005 and that its costs will climb with the delay.
To meet their schedule, the YankeeNets negotiators calculate, legislation must be enacted by the time lawmakers go home at the end of this month. Otherwise they run the risk of the estimated $355 million cost of the arena increasing by $80 million, they say.
McGreevey administration officials insist they are keeping to their original schedule, using the summer to build support for the plan in Bergen County, which will suffer economically if the teams leave the Meadowlands and the property becomes unused. But they have told YankeeNets officials that the governor will support passage of the legislation this month if the YankeeNets can, on its own, drum up enough votes among Republicans in the Senate.
That is where Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Kean, both Republicans, come in. 
"Waiting until September," Mr. Kean said, "would be a real problem for the YankeeNets as I understand it, and they can't advance additional money without an understanding from the Legislature that they can proceed."
George Zoffinger, one of the governor's top advisers on the arena issue and Meadowlands redevelopment, said, "If they could get five Republican legislators to sign on to move the process now, then all right." Mr. Zoffinger, who is executive director of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which owns the Meadowlands, added, "They have DiFrancesco and Kean working on it, but we are going to be consistent and it has not changed our approach."
But Mr. Kean said, "I think we are within two votes."
He said that he was acting not as an agent for YankeeNets, but in his role as a founder of the Newark Alliance, a group of business and civic leaders who came together three years ago to support development and education projects in the state's largest city. He had enlisted Mr. DiFrancesco in the effort, he said, because of his support of the Newark arena project during his term as governor.
Len Coleman, the chief negotiator for the YankeeNets and former president of Major League Baseball's National League, said the company was jolted into action after realizing in recent weeks how time-consuming the project would be. But equally important, he said, was the need -- after three years of trying to build an arena -- for additional assurances of the state's commitment to the arena, which would be partly financed with state-issued bonds that are secured by sales and income tax revenues generated by the arena and surrounding development. Of the 15 YankeeNets board members, he noted, only three are from New Jersey and likely to show any patience with a long approval process seemingly dictated by the state's politics.
The sense of urgency being pressed by Mr. Coleman, Mr. Kean and others comes at a time when many supporters of the arena feel that pressure for progress has eased with the announcement in May of Mr. McGreevey's timetable. At that time one of the things driving the proposal was the governor's desire to make some announcement helpful to Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, a political ally who was facing a spirited challenge in his bid for re-election.
With Mayor James's re-election and the shift of the McGreevey administration's efforts to meetings with Bergen County interests on the Meadowlands redevelopment, the YankeeNets and its supporters began feeling neglected. They were also troubled by the re-emergence of opposition voices calling for a statewide referendum on any state role in a new sports arena.
Much of what they are doing now is reselling the idea of the arena, repeating projections of its economic benefits, the downsides of not replacing Continental Arena and stressing what Mr. Coleman called the "social importance" of sports teams to the state.
"This is the right thing to do," Mr. Kean said, as he called for elected officials to show leadership on the issue. "If we had made such projects as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, or the Camden Aquarium or even the Continental Airlines Arena subject to what polling said, they never would have been built. My worry is that if this doesn't happen it will be a blow for the city and state, not only economically but psychologically."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 S.& P. 500 and Dow Hit Low for Year in Losing Week
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrials closed at new lows for the year, capping off their fourth consecutive weekly declines. The Dow finished down 28.59 points, or 0.3 percent, at 9,474.21. The S.& P. 500 was off 2.29 points, or 0.2 percent, at 1,007.27. For the week, the Dow lost 1.2 percent and the S.& P. 2 percent. The Nasdaq finished up 7.88 points, or 0.5 percent, at 1,504.74. It fell 2 percent on the week. Page C4.

Citibank Cards Blocked in Gambling
Citibank has joined a handful of other credit card issuers in blocking use of its cards for Internet gambling transactions. The decision came after regulators from New York State told Citibank that it could face criminal prosecution for aiding in the promotion of online gambling, which is illegal in the state. C2.

More Adelphia Deals Are Examined
Investigations into the finances of Adelphia Communications have uncovered additional questionable transactions, according to documents filed with securities regulators. Adelphia has also hired PricewaterhouseCoopers as its new accounting firm. C3.

Tyco's Chairman Denies Inquiry
John F. Fort III, the interim chairman of Tyco International, denied that the company was investigating a transaction he had made as a board member for possible conflicts of interest, and said that an investigation by regulators was confined to L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco's former chief executive. C2.

Agriculture a Diplomatic Concern
Less than one month after President Bush signed the new farm bill, agriculture has leaped from the backwaters of diplomacy to near the top of the list of international complaints against the United States. A3.

Power Traders Deny Manipulation
Avisa, El Paso Electric, the Williams Companies and Portland General, threatened by regulators for not cooperating with an investigation of California power prices, stood by claims that they did not manipulate the state's energy markets. C3.

2 Reports Suggest Slowing Growth
Production at factories, utilities and mines rose 0.2 percent last month after a 0.3 percent gain in April, the Federal Reserve said. The University of Michigan said its consumer sentiment index fell to 90.8 in June from 96.9 in May. That is the largest decline since a 9.7-point decrease in September. The results add to a picture of slowing growth. C4.

Nabors Wins Offshore Approval
Nabors Industries, the onshore oil and gas drilling contractor, said its shareholders had approved a plan to reincorporate the company in Bermuda to reduce its tax bill. C14.

Sprint Shares Fall 18% on Warning
Sprint said customer growth at its wireless unit, the PCS Group, would be 10 percent to 15 percent below forecasts this year because of heightened competition. The news set off an 18 percent decline in Sprint's share price. C4.

Tribe Can Retain Car Dealership
The Mississippi Motor Vehicle Commission voted to dismiss a challenge to a license given the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians for a car dealership in the state. The commission, which granted the license to the tribe in February, said the Indian tribe did not have an unfair advantage. C3.

Jurors in Blockbuster Case Revealed
Two aides to lawyers representing mom-and-pop video stores in their antitrust lawsuit against the video giant Blockbuster were jailed briefly for posting juror names on a Web site. A lawyer for the plaintiff said the posting was an "inadvertent error." C4.

HEADLINE: Raising Farm Subsidies, U.S. Widens International Rift 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14 

 BODY:
Less than one month after President Bush signed the new farm bill, agriculture has leaped from the backwaters of diplomacy to near the top of the list of international complaints against the United States.
 Portrayed by its supporters as a necessary safety net for farmers and by its detractors as an election-year welfare program to win Midwestern votes, the huge increase in subsidies has become an overnight magnet for America-bashing. 
 Javier Solana, Europe's foreign policy chief, declared in Madrid this week that the new American agriculture policy has created the "most profound" division between Europe and the United States, worse than disputes over steel tariffs, the Kyoto environmental treaty or the international criminal court.
In Washington, in an address to Congress, Prime Minister John Howard of Australia said on Wednesday that the only problem between these closest of friends was his country's "intense disappointment" over the $180 billion farm bill. 
In Rome, at a United Nations conference on hunger, developing countries pointed this week to the huge new subsidies to American farmers as one of the biggest obstacles to creating vital opportunities for their own farmers and enabling them to climb out of poverty. 
With Mr. Bush pressing other countries to knock down their trade barriers and expand open markets, his approval of an 80 percent increase in farm subsidies -- with all the advantages that confers on American grain exports -- is viewed as a move in the opposite direction.
Poor countries say the subsidies also work at cross purposes to the administration's avowed desire to reduce poverty and to diminish foreign anger against the United States.
In a private letter to Congressional leaders, a group of countries known as the Cairns Group, which includes Australia, Thailand, Canada, Brazil and Argentina, wrote this month that "the sheer size of the subsidy package will inevitably hurt farmers around the world, particularly in developing countries." 
"The United States should be sending a very different message," wrote Mark Vaile, the group's chairman. 
The heart of the dispute is that by underwriting its largest farmers, the United States is flooding the world market with inexpensive corn, wheat, rice and soybeans, which are sold at half what it costs to produce the grain. That leads to artificially low world prices, which in turn undercut grain produced by farmers in countries that do not give subsidies. The grain market becomes distorted, domestic markets are ruined for producers overseas and their chances of making inroads into foreign markets are reduced.
"Subsidies and other measures applied by the world's richest countries continue to increase exponentially," said Navin Chandarpal, Guyana's minister of agriculture, at the Rome conference. "We continue to be pressured into further opening up our markets, without any regard being paid to the welfare of our farming and rural communities as a whole." 
Development experts agree and say the effects ripple throughout developing economies. "American farm exports drive down prices paid to local farmers, reduce rural family income around the world and push farmers off the land and into overcrowded cities," said Mark Ritchie, president of the Institute for Agriculture Trade Policy, a nonprofit organization in Minneapolis.
However, some developing countries with sufficient foreign reserves prefer to import cheap American food as they build up other sectors of their economy.
Despite the complaints, the new American farm policy also conforms to the current rules of the World Trade Organization. Indeed, the United States is not alone as a wealthy country that gives generous welfare programs to farmers. The 15-nation European Union is notorious for giving lavish subsidies to its seven million farmers. 
In an address in Germany this month, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, defended the farm bill and suggested "respectfully that America-bashing will not promote the E.U.'s enlightened self-interest. 
"When Europeans criticize the recent U.S. farm bill, I wonder how many are even aware that U.S. agricultural tariffs are less than half of the E.U.'s," he said.
Disputes between the world's major economies -- United States, Europe and Japan -- over farm subsidies are nothing new. But the latest American increase, European Union officials say, comes as they are trying to reduce their own payments.
With plans to admit 10 new countries -- including Poland, where nearly one-third of 40 million inhabitants identify themselves as full- or part-time farmers -- the European Union says it must slash expensive programs to support agricultural production and give more money for conservation and rural development.
Critics of the new American policy say that, by giving in to the domestic farm vote, the United States will have a difficult time persuading other countries to open their markets to American agricultural products.
"The American farmers have shot themselves in the foot," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. "The long term growth of U.S. agriculture is clearly in foreign markets, particularly the rapidly growing emerging markets. That requires liberalization and access to those markets. The farm bill undercuts our ability to reach those markets."
During the debate on the farm bill, lawmakers in Congress painted a different picture, arguing that American farmers needed subsidies to remain competitive in the world.
America's main competitors on the global grain markets are not the European Union countries but countries that pay few or no subsidies to farmers and indeed may even tax food exports to earn more government revenue.
During the trade negotiations at Qatar six months ago, members of the World Trade Organization agreed to remove barriers to farm trade.
Mr. Zoellick insists that the United States remains committed to the goals worked out in Qatar. But both the Bush administration and the European Union -- whose dispute over farming is essentially one of their many trade battles over state subsidies -- will be hard pressed to remove the barriers to foreign agricultural products without upsetting their powerful farmers.
"We're all free traders and we're all hypocrites," said Peter L. Scher, specialist on trade negotiations for agriculture in the Clinton administration. "I blame the Europeans as well as the Americans. If we're going to develop these poor countries, we've got to give these nations a chance to develop their own agricultures."

HEADLINE: Tensions on Lebanese Border Cast a Pall Over Peace Effort 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14 

 BODY:
Even as President Bush prepares to issue his new plan for reviving Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a senior Western diplomat warned here today that the increased threat of military action along Israel's border with Lebanon could jeopardize any chance of an international peace conference.
 The diplomat said there were indications of new weapons shipments from Iran to Hezbollah, the militia in southern Lebanon that has ties to both Iran and Syria. He said these included longer-range rockets that could be launched deep into Israeli territory, perhaps within the next several days. The diplomat said such an attack could prompt a severe Israeli reprisal that could include an invasion of Lebanon. 
 But a range of senior Bush administration officials, from the White House to the Pentagon and the State Department, said they were not aware of any such new or immediate threat, while acknowledging that the situation remained volatile and a matter of intense concern.
An Israeli diplomat here confirmed that Israel was concerned about the northern border and that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon had spent considerable time discussing it with Mr. Bush this week. 
"I know that our people have seen indications that there is an intention on the Hezbollah side to act in the short term, and possibly to escalate in comparison with activities that we've seen in recent months," the diplomat said. "If they fired against a population center some sort of missile, Israel I think would have to respond, though I can't be specific about what we would do."
For months, there has been intermittent shelling by Hezbollah and return fire from Israel. On a visit to the region in April, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell took time out to visit Lebanon and Syria to pressure leaders there to crack down on activity by Hezbollah for fear it could prompt a regional war.
American officials said that in the last 36 hours, diplomats in the region had renewed contacts with Lebanese and Syrian officials, urging restraint, especially given the administration's efforts to establish peace.
"Starting with the secretary's visit, we've been underscoring to all the parties the need for maximum restraint along the border area," one senior administration official said this evening. "We don't see much of a difference in patterns of activity. It remains a volatile situation, and the message is, 'Everybody keep cool.' Israelis have expressed their concerns, but the broader reason is that this is the worst possible time of having something ignite up there."
Indeed, Secretary Powell and senior State Department officials held another round of meetings today in preparation for Mr. Bush's expected announcement next week of his plans for reviving political talks and for an international peace conference to address the Middle East crisis.
After meeting with Secretary Powell, the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, told reporters as he left the State Department: "I am afraid again I don't have much to tell you. I think your interest and the talk that you want to hear is not me talking, but what the message and the statement of the president is going to be. And I, like you, am waiting for that."
At the same time, the State Department's top Middle East expert, Assistant Secretary William J. Burns, met with his counterparts from the United Nations, the European Union and Russia to discuss the administration's next steps.
Both American and European officials said the meeting produced strong consensus on the need to move forward simultaneously in efforts to re-establish security, address economic and human needs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and to provide a path for settling the conflict.
One diplomat said that the idea of declaring a provisional Palestinian state whose borders and capital could be determined later was under serious consideration by Mr. Bush, but that he believed no decision had yet been made on that or a host of other points, and that there was some ambivalence about the idea from other nations.
"When you start twisting it, both legally and psychologically, it's very fluffy," the diplomat said.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Reports That Her Husband Made $9.2 Million From Speeches Last Year 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14 

 BODY:
Former President Bill Clinton received $9.2 million in his first year out of office for giving 59 speeches to investment banks, Jewish and Israeli groups, public relations companies, advertising agencies and other organizations, according to a financial disclosure form filed today by his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York.
 In addition, Mrs. Clinton earned $2.8 million last year as part of an $8 million advance for her memoirs. 
 Mr. Clinton has parlayed his public service into an extraordinarily lucrative private life, flying from continent to continent and earning fees as high as $450,000 for a three-day engagement in Tokyo sponsored by the Miki Corporation, a food and cosmetics importer and wholesaler. 
Other presidents have cashed in after leaving office. In 1998, Global Crossing, a telecommunications company that has since gone bankrupt, paid former President George Bush with company stock that grew to be worth $14 million in lieu of an $80,000 fee for a speech. Mr. Bush has also earned large fees for many other speeches, earning millions of dollars. In October 1989, former President Ronald Reagan received a $2 million honorarium for a nine-day trip and speeches in Tokyo.
But Mrs. Clinton's filing, which includes required financial information about her family income, is the first time a former president has specifically enumerated his speaking fees. 
The Clintons were required to disclose only Mr. Clinton's income from honorariums, according to his spokeswoman, and thus other income, from sources like his book deal, is not disclosed. Mr. Clinton's book contract includes an advance of more than $10 million.
The Clintons reported that they paid more than $1.3 million last year in legal fees for themselves and "former staff members," although a spokeswoman declined to say which staff members received help with their legal bills. Over all, the Clintons still owe between $1.75 million and $6.5 million in legal bills, mostly to Williams & Connolly, the Washington law firm that represented Mr. Clinton during his impeachment. 
By far the biggest asset reported in Mrs. Clinton's filing today was accounts at Citibank that contained $5 million to $25 million and generated $100,000 to $1 million in interest income. The family's second-largest asset was a blind trust that contained $1 million to $5 million but lost an undisclosed amount last year.
Ethics watchdogs suggested that the payments to Mr. Clinton could raise concerns.
Scott Harshbarger, the president of Common Cause, remarked: "The former president has a right to earn a living, and he does have legal bills. That said, it is troubling for the spouse of a senator to take in $9 million for nominal work."
Julia Payne, Mr. Clinton's spokeswoman, said that the former president had turned down some speeches because they "may have appeared to be a conflict," and that he and his agent were "very cautious" about the speeches he accepts.
Ms. Payne added: "The paid speaking engagements by the former president are not instances where he goes in and out and makes this kind of money. He delivers a very thoughtful and compelling speech on globalization, and he will also take questions from the audiences."
New York's other senator, Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, listed income of $136,700. His major assets include a thrift savings plan worth $100,000 to $250,000 and deferred compensation of $100,000 to $250,000. He also held mutual funds, an individual retirement account and a United States bond, each worth between $50,000 and $100,000.
According to a summary of other financial disclosure reports compiled by The Associated Press, the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, listed income of $161,200 and major assets that included mutual funds worth $233,000 to $790,000 and bank accounts worth $100,000 to $250,000. He listed no major liabilities. 
The House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, listed income of $186,300 and major assets including a town house, an Illinois opera house and a money market fund, each valued at $100,000 to $250,000. The opera house and town house carry mortgages of $50,000 to $100,000.
The White House this afternoon released copies of financial disclosure forms filed by senior aides to President Bush. 
Karl Rove, the president's senior adviser, reported assets worth $2 million to $4.8 million, and liabilities of $350,000 to $700,000.
Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, reported assets worth $1.1 million to $2.8 million, and no liabilities.

HEADLINE: Along the Fringe 

BYLINE:  By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan, who writes on national issues for The Times, is the author, most recently, of "Lasso the Wind: Away to the New West."

 BODY:
 LONE PATRIOT
The Short Career
of an American Militiaman.
By Jane Kramer.
259 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $25.
 In the annals of American rebels without a clue, it is hard to find a more pathetic group of soldiers of misfortune than the half-dozen or so men in the far northwest corner of the nation who called themselves the Washington State Militia. The Marx Brothers, bumbling through Freedonia, come to mind, but at least they were in on the joke. 
This militia and other units of the so-called patriot movement generated an awful lot of news stories during the middle years of the Clinton administration. They paraded around in surplus cammies, made threats to sheriffs and federal wildlife agents trying to enforce environmental laws and waited for the day that the unseen army of the New World Order would cross the 49th Parallel and take away our right to Mega Gulps and sport utility vehicles.
Up close, they were more Pee-wee Herman than Paul Revere. Had they not been heavily armed, most militia members most likely would have been ignored, left to babble among themselves on bar stools in small Western towns. But a handful of them managed to set off enough bombs, or plot to do the same, that it led some people to believe that a broad national movement was under way. Timothy McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, dabbled in militia culture but never actually joined one. 
A few books in the mid-1990's looked at the more militant and active hate groups that preceded the militia movement. Those people were scary. They were overt Nazis, living in Idaho, Montana, parts of the South and Midwest. They hated Jews, blacks and most elected officials. They held Klan-style cross-burnings, robbed banks and killed people. Most of them have disappeared or are in jail.
By contrast, the militia movement seems like a costume affair for the mildly delusional. Or at least that is the impression that the New Yorker writer Jane Kramer leaves in "Lone Patriot," her well-drawn, superbly reported narrative of the Washington Militia. 
Kramer, who has written The New Yorker's "Letter From Europe" for more than 20 years, may seem like an odd choice to chronicle a far-right beer-belly gang in Whatcom County, Wash., on the Canadian border, about a 90-minute drive north of Seattle. As Kramer says up front in her book, 20 years of living between New York and Paris had put her out of touch with the fringe of her own country. She approaches this subject with fresh eyes, and in a close-up telling of the short, unhappy life of the Washington State Militia she avoids the mistakes of writers who never actually spent much time with these people.
Her subject is John Pitner, a middle-aged unemployed ship painter who called himself the founder, promoter, banker, quartermaster and commander in chief of his own unit of patriots. While his wife brings home the bacon, Pitner frets inside his manufactured home about the usual militia suspects -- Rockefellers, black helicopters and the United Nations -- all while waiting for Armageddon. "He had two lives, the one he had lived and the one he invented, and his real biography seemed to me to be hidden somewhere in the commute he made between them," Kramer writes in a typically lucid dissection of her cast of characters. 
Pitner's comrades came from the folds of western Washington, an assortment of tax protesters, convicted felons and people with too much time on their hands who spent it listening to talk radio. A grandfatherly contractor, an auto mechanic with a propensity for passing bad checks, a tax-dodging veterinarian and a few others were the foot soldiers in Pitner's army. Two of them turned out to be on the government's side -- one a square-jawed agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who posed as a gun dealer, the other a militia regular who turned informant for $25,000.
At meetings they talked about what they would do when the call to battle came, about a government that had lost touch with the Constitution and about bombs and money to pay for dress-up army stuff. Pitner is presented here as a man with profound delusions, but also as a hapless fellow, not entirely unsympathetic. His family history was bleak, and he failed at everything he tried, including a stint in the Army, which led to a court-martial. 
After reading David Brock's book "Blinded by the Right," I was struck that the more bizarre allegations against Bill Clinton that were hatched in chardonnay-sipping salons in the other Washington filtered down to a disgruntled few in a different tax bracket in this Washington: Vince Foster's "murder"; Janet Reno's fealty to the United Nations; the New World Order's plan for global conquest. No matter how twisted the truth, it all added up to these backwoods militiamen. As John Pitner said, "What I was learning fit my paranoia." Pitner also said his brain was zapped, by mysterious forces no doubt connected to the big conspiracy. 
Kramer does a fine job of portraying a group of everyday lost souls looking for something larger to blame for all their troubles. Pitner's rants held them together, for a time, until they turned on one another. "The strangest thing about John's performance was how American he made it, sitting there with his mug of instant coffee and his plate of cookies in the plasterboard parlor of his double-wide manufactured home, sharing a faded flowered couch with a couple of drowsy cats who clearly had no plans for the invasion," she writes.
She has trouble with geography; Chelan County is a long way from the Idaho Panhandle, though she makes it sound closer. And claiming that the anti-environmentalist theorist Ron Arnold "had helped to found the Sierra Club" is even farther from the truth than Chelan is from Idaho. But these are quibbles. 
In the end, Washington Militia members did very little except talk about what they might do. Several members were convicted of conspiracy to make and possess destructive devices, or of possessing and transferring machine guns. Pitner did three years in jail and was released early last year. The militia has officially disbanded. 
Kramer says she never understood what Pitner wanted. But she quotes his sister, Susan, as saying that the saddest part of his militia history was that "the only person who believed him was the F.B.I."

HEADLINE: 'The Last Man With All Known Knowledge' 

BYLINE:  By Sylvia Nasar; Sylvia Nasar, the author of "A Beautiful Mind," teaches financial journalism at Columbia University and is working on a book on 20th-century economic thinkers.

 BODY:
 THE FLY SWATTER
How My Grandfather
Made His Way in the World.
By Nicholas Dawidoff.
Illustrated. 353 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $26.
 BABY boomers still tend to think of the 1950's as orderly, insular and repressed -- as devoid of color as those vintage black-and-white television sitcoms. But it was actually an age of positively unruly, riotous invention.+Everyday life was forever changed by, among other things, the bomb, computers and TV,+and so was the less visible world of ideas. The 50's spurt in American intellectual development was in no small measure the product of+the extraordinary prewar influx of brilliant minds. Scholars fleeing Hitler brought new sophistication to America's premier universities and helped transform the United States virtually overnight into the world leader in disciplines like physics, mathematics and economics.
One particularly exciting mind belonged to Alexander Gerschenkron, the legendary Harvard economist and historian. His colleagues called him "the last man with all known knowledge." But in his captivating memoir, "The Fly Swatter," Nicholas Dawidoff shows that one source of the brilliant insights of "the Great Gerschenkron" into how nations triumph over backwardness was his own personal triumphs over adversity. By retracing his grandfather's tortuous path to Cambridge, Mass., Dawidoff, the author of "The Catcher Was a Spy" and "In the Country of Country," also conveys something of the larger story:+the biggest transfer of intellectual capital in history and its indelible -- and continuing -- impact on American thought.
Before arriving in the United States in 1938, Gerschenkron, who would be called America's "doyen of economic history," was twice exiled. The son of a Jewish tobacco factory manager, he was born in 1904 in Odessa. After the Bolshevik Revolution, Gerschenkron followed his father across the icy steppes to Austria just ahead of Lenin's secret police. In the nearly two decades he spent in Vienna, he fell under the spell of Austrian economics, Social Democracy and the woman who would become his wife, Erica Matschnigg, while making an on-again-off-again living as a factory manager and political organizer. After the Anschluss, Gerschenkron and his family were forced to flee again. This time he skied across the Alps and made his way first to England, where he met up with his wife and daughter, then to California. 
He brought with him a remarkable command of languages and literature, an encyclopedic knowledge of Russian and European history and, last but not least, a deep conviction that freedom was worth fighting for. Too old to be accepted by the Army, he spent the war doing research, moonlighting as a steelworker in a Navy shipyard and, later on, mapping out details of the Marshall Plan at the Federal Reserve. A year after D-Day, he landed at Harvard, where he taught for the next three decades. He died in 1978.
Having reinvented himself twice, he wondered how countries could do the same. Like physicists after Einstein, he was a relativist, writing that "the past changes perpetually with the historian's emphasis, interest and point of view." And in contrast to 19th-century thinkers like Marx who "looked for a determination of the course of human events as ubiquitous and invariant as that of the course of planets," he wrote that his "modest" wish was to find "a historical approach to current problems."
During the cold war, economic development was a very hot topic.+In pursuing his unified theory of industrialization from Edinburgh to the Urals, Gerschenkron upset Marx's notion that "the industrially developed country presents to the less developed country a picture of the latter's future" -- partly by showing that first Germany and later Russia followed the lead of Britain, but not by the same routes or, for that matter, at the same speed.
Gerschenkron had twice fled backward countries, twice made superhuman efforts to catch up. "He had caught up, and the fact that he could do so gave him a sense of optimism about other people's chances," Dawidoff writes. "Yet, as he knew well, things could go the other way." Small wonder, then, that Gerschenkron compared development to a bus that "sometimes comes at odd hours and can be missed."
Development takes place in discontinuous spurts, he concluded, and the more backward a country when a spurt comes, the faster it is likely to grow. Output might consist mostly of heavy machinery rather than consumer products. Consumption might fall rather than rise. Most important, no institutions, whether private capital markets or banks, were absolute prerequisites. In 19th-century Russia, the state had played the role of British stock markets or German banks. Gerschenkron's sweeping history of European industrialization, though criticized in various particulars, has never been superseded. His approach has since proved useful in explaining how Japan and the Pacific Rim economies caught up with the West. And what's more, researchers have found that poor countries and poor regions have generally grown faster than rich ones since World War II.
Gerschenkron's conclusion that the state could promote growth was fashionable in the 50's and 60's among proponents of big government; he was also one of the first scholars in the West to puncture the myth of superior Soviet economic performance. In a virtuoso display of reporting and number crunching (he traveled around the country for months to collect data from companies on various production processes), he demonstrated that standard Soviet production indexes were designed to grossly inflate the rate of growth. What's more, he was among the first Western scholars to argue that the bloated Soviet state was itself a product of backwardness. What characterized the Soviet regime was not Socialism, he wrote in his most celebrated essay, "The Economic Advantages of Backwardness," but rather a "totalitarian dictatorship that has come to dominate the economic processes" and that "actually prevented, or at least delayed, the mental adjustment of the population to the normalcy of a fully industrialized society."
A brilliant+essayist who deployed polemic, humor, ancient Greek, philosophy, novels and poetry with the same ease as statistics, Gerschenkron once published a study of Austrian fiscal policy that an ecstatic reviewer described as a story of "intrigue and backbiting" containing "the necessary ingredient of extramarital affection." However, he never turned his prodigious scholarship into a multivolume opus, possibly, as Dawidoff suggests, because of what he called "his severity to himself, his supreme sense of duty."
Gerschenkron's principal legacy turned out to be his remarkable students -- among them, Paul David, Albert Fishlow, Peter Temin and Deirdre McCloskey -- who carried forward, if not precisely his conceptions, then his exacting yet expansive style of work. For almost a quarter-century, Harvard required its Ph.D. students to take Gerschenkron's yearlong economic history seminar. Short, stocky and notoriously untidy, he nonetheless managed to intimidate his students. "He motivated people," a former student said recently. "He got people to work. No one said, 'Alex gave me this idea.' But they do say, 'I was petrified of him.' "
A showman and ferocious debater, Gerschenkron gave his finest performance during the Vietnam War, after Students for a Democratic Society occupied Harvard's administration building. The refugee who escaped from two totalitarian regimes spoke from the heart when he called on the faculty to defend intellectual freedom: "The university, like all great works of art, is a frail and fragile creation, and unless you do something about it, this wonderful work of art will be destroyed, and the guilt will be yours."
In private, the remote and often+rapierlike Great Gerschenkron let his inner child loose and therefore delighted the children in his life. To his grandson, whose own father was mentally ill -- sick and strange and disappointing" -- he not only conveyed his enthusiasms for baseball, books, boulders and epic battles with flies but also made him feel like "a regular boy." Naturally, Gerschenkron frequently challenged the young Dawidoff, just as he did his students. Gerschenkron often complained about his own "slowness" in reading. Once he timed Nicky Boy, as he called Dawidoff, with a stopwatch while the 12-year-old read Trevelyan's "History of England" a minute at a stretch and quizzed him on what he had just read. Without telling him whether the answers were right or wrong, he repeated the exercise over and over until he suddenly shouted excitedly, "The boy can do it!" And, in "The Fly Swatter," he has.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
National Parks Still Have Space

BYLINE:  By BARRY ESTABROOK; BARRY ESTABROOK is a writer and editor who lives near Boston.

 BODY:
A GROUP of five Tennessee couples had been planning a trip to Ireland in May, but after the Sept. 11 attacks, they decided to tour the American Southwest instead. At the end of a long day of driving, the group entered Thunderbird Lodge in the remote Canyon de Chelly National Monument in Arizona and requested rooms.
 Normally, the response would have been no. As the only hotel within the borders of the national monument, Thunderbird is frequently booked solid. Mary Jones, owner of the lodge, has been known to roll cots into conference rooms to accommodate travelers who would otherwise have to backtrack across 60 miles of mountains and desert to find the nearest Vacancy sign. 
 But this year she was able to take the walk-ins from Tennessee. "Normally people call and make reservations three or four months ahead and we're full," Ms. Jones said. "Now they're just showing up and saying, 'Hey, you got a room?' " 
The Tennessee group was lucky, and arriving before peak vacation season probably helped, too. Though travelers should not expect to walk in and snare prime national-park lodgings this summer, reservations may be available even for those who procrastinate.
According to park officials and operators of visitors' lodgings who were contacted late last month, the overall number of visitors is expected to run even with or slightly higher than last year. Americans are expected to visit the parks rather than travel abroad. But foreign visitors, who typically book far ahead, are also staying closer to home, freeing up rooms in some places.
"There's a sense that there are going to be more visitors this summer than normal," said Gerry Gaumer, a spokesman for the National Park Service in Washington. Last year 280 million visitors went to the parks, a slight decline over the previous three years. But Mr. Gaumer said that even with the increased traffic, there most likely will still be space at the parks' campgrounds. Campsites can be reserved at the park service's Web site, reservations.nps.gov, or by calling (800) 365-2267 for all parks other than Yosemite National Park, where sites can be reserved by calling (800) 436-7275.
Hotels within the parks are managed by independent operators. The largest, Xanterra Parks and Resorts, formerly Amfac, has hotels and other concessions in nine national parks and monuments, including Grand Canyon National Park, Yellowstone National Park, Zion National Park, Mount Rushmore National Memorial and Everglades National Park.

Fewer Tourists From Abroad
"Our European bookings are down 30 or 40 percent, and our Pacific Rim business has nearly gone away," said Judi Lages, vice president of sales and marketing for Xanterra. (The company's Web site, which includes information about reservations, is at www.xanterra.com.)
"But Americans seem to be taking national parks to heart," Ms. Lages said. "Because of that, we are only about 8 or 9 percent behind last year over all and expect to be normal by summer." 
Although space is generally available, demand remains strong for certain popular destinations. There has been no decline in bookings at Bryce National Park, Zion National Park and on the north rim of the Grand Canyon (where extreme fire danger caused officials to ban campfires beginning in mid-May). "These are areas where we don't have a lot of rooms," said Ms. Lages. She advised would-be visitors who find themselves unable to book to keep trying, particularly this summer, because blocks of rooms can become available when wholesalers who deal with European customers cancel bookings, typically one month in advance.
Glacier Park Inc., which operates seven hotels and lodges in and around Glacier National Park, is experiencing a similar trend. "The properties that fill up first are Lake McDonald Lodge and Many Glacier Hotel," said Jan Ek, the company's president and general manager. "If you haven't made your reservations there by now, you probably will have to adjust your dates if you want a room. But our other properties have openings throughout the summer." Information: (406) 756-2444 or www.glacierparkinc.com.
There is also space available at all of the three lodging concessions operated by the Grand Teton Lodge Company, (800) 628-9988; www.gtlc.com. "Normally during the months of July and August we sell out," said Lisa Bishop, director of sales and marketing, who added that bookings were running 6 percent behind last year. "After Sept. 11, we have found that people are booking accommodations a lot closer to the date of travel, 30 to 45 days out, where it used to be 60 or 90." 
Demand is usually strongest for high-end rooms at Jackson Lake Lodge ($220 a night double occupancy) and Jenny Lake Lodge ($429 a night double occupancy, which includes riding, breakfast and a five-course dinner). But this year, Ms. Bishop said, the more economical cabins, tent-cabins and recreational-vehicle sites at the company's Colter Bay Village are selling out first.

More Regional Visitors
Park lodging operators in the East also expect visitors from that region to predominate this summer.
"It's the visitor who only needs one tank of gas to get here," said Clare Wood, executive director of the Bar Harbor Chamber of Commerce, which represents 140 lodging establishments near Acadia National Park in Maine, on the Web at www.barharbor.org. "There's plenty of space available."
Within a day's drive of nearly one-third of the American population, Great Smoky Mountains National Park, with nine million visitors a year, is used by more people than any other national park. "Summer is always crowded here," said Nancy Gray, a park spokeswoman at Great Smoky. "But we still have some vacancies at our campgrounds. If you wait until just before a busy weekend, it might be difficult to secure camping. Otherwise space should be available." Ms. Gray points out that the three main park entrances are at Gatlinburg and Townsend, Tenn., and Cherokee, N.C. To avoid the hurly-burly of the summer crowds, she says, visitors might head for more remote areas like Look Rock in Tennessee, or Fontana, N.C. 
Mr. Gaumer of the National Park Service expects that the busiest parks and monuments this summer will be those that have patriotic connotations. "Places like Yorktown, Valley Forge, Gettysburg," he said.
At Mount Rushmore National Memorial, visits are already up this year by more than 30 percent. "If it continues, it will be a blockbuster summer for tourism in the area," said Mike Pflaum, chief ranger at Mount Rushmore. "But our facilities will be able to handle the influx." 
Although there seem to be plenty of vacant rooms and campsites in the national parks this summer, visitors who want a specific room or site might be well advised to do as the park operators do. "We are going to be heading out on a little trip to the coast to see the redwoods," said Ms. Jones of Thunderbird Lodge. "Everyone had space. But we reserved anyway."
