HEADLINE: Black and White On Long Island: Like Oil and Water 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
A TALL hedge and a street sign are all that separate the homes of Bernard and Della Tomlin in Hempstead and Barton and Laura Midwood in Garden City. The street sign marks the border. But there are plenty of clues that more than just a political boundary separates the two families.
 On the Hempstead side, where the street is called Lafayette Avenue, the road where the Tomlins park their Volvo is cracked and potholed. Mrs. Tomlin said the plows rarely show up after a snowstorm. The Tomlins send two daughters, Dana, 15, and Dawn, 12, to private school for the education Mrs. Tomlin says will increase their odds of getting into college. And if the Tomlins were to sell their Colonial-style house, Mrs. Tomlin said she doubted it would fetch more than $250,000. 
 On the Garden City side, where the street is called Lafayette Street, a heavy tree limb fell the other day, and village workers had it chopped up and carted away in a few hours. A Mercedes is parked in front of the Midwoods' house. The pavement is smooth. Residents flock to the village for its quality schools. Mr. Midwood said he is in contract to sell his home; he declined to reveal the price, but Pat Dickson, a real estate agent with Coach Realtors Fennessy Associates in Garden City, said comparable homes were selling for around $450,000. 
People who have launched a campaign to highlight the racial divisions they say are institutionalized on Long Island say all the distinctions between the Tomlins and the Midwoods are tied to an even more obvious one: The Tomlins are black and the Midwoods are white.
Mrs. Tomlin figures the racial distinction is costly. As an assistant dean of student affairs at Adelphi University in Garden City, she works in the village she and her family would have to struggle to move to, even though it is just paces from her front door. 
"If that sign were moved to the corner," Mrs. Tomlin said of the green-and-white Garden City marker, "my house would increase, what, $150,000, $200,000? My children would then be able to attend a school that I think will prepare them educationally, so that's another $10,000 saved because I send my kids to private school."
The Tomlins and the Midwoods live along one of the more pronounced of the political, social and economic dividing lines that separate the races more thoroughly on the Island than in any other suburb in America, a new report says. The report, issued this month by Erase Racism, a year-old nonprofit group sponsored by the Long Island Community Foundation in Jericho, says 74 percent of the Island's blacks would have to move to be evenly dispersed through the population.
That index of segregation, culled from an analysis of the 2000 federal census by the Lewis Mumford Center for Comparative Urban and Regional Research at SUNY-Albany, was topped in seven cities, including New York, but no other suburban areas.
"Segregation is shorthand for talking about whether people are given access to opportunities," said John Powell, a University of Minnesota law professor and executive director of the Institute on Race and Poverty in that state. He spoke on June 5 at an Islandia conference organized by Erase Racism to call attention to the issue.
The Island's black residents are especially subject to institutional racism, particularly when it comes to housing, Mr. Powell's group said. It pointed to statistics showing that well-to-do blacks were more likely than other minorities to live in low- or moderate-income areas, and Erase Racism said the likely cause was unfair housing practices directed at blacks.
Segregation on Long Island is the result of decades-old discrimination, activists and black residents say, that was flaunted in developments like Levittown, America's pioneering post-World War II suburb, and exacerbated by white flight from once-mixed neighborhoods.
"It's embedded and not overt," said V. Elaine Gross, director of Erase Racism. "It's more subtle, and it doesn't require that people really be intentional about it. All of the stuff that sort of creates the disadvantages for black school children, it's not that someone gets up in the morning and says, 'I'm going to see to it that all the black kids get an inferior education.' That's what makes it so hard to grasp. You don't need an army of bigots for it to be perpetuated."
The segregation trend study that Erase Racism commissioned was released on the heels of another report this month, commissioned by Senator Charles Schumer, showing that blacks on Long Island are at least three times more likely to pay higher interest rates on loans.
Mrs. Tomlin, the Hempstead border homeowner, said segregation on the Island has also been perpetuated by the inability of black homeowners like her family to command top dollar for their houses and trade up to better neighborhoods. "I have Uniondale, Hempstead and Roosevelt to choose from," she said. "Outside of those, I need an extra $250,000."
She noted that Hempstead was much more prosperous decades ago, before the departure of most of its white population. "Money doesn't come back to the neighborhood," she said. "It never returns."
So when the snowplows miss the street in front of her house, Mrs. Tomlin finds herself on the telephone, trying to be a squeaky wheel with Hempstead Village Hall. She seldom gets the grease. "What do you do when you're told time and time again that the money is not there?" she said. "You can be a pest, but when it's not done you stop yelling after awhile."
Speakers at the June 5 conference said they want zoning decisions and other powers more centralized to rupture the jurisdiction lines around the Island's 13 townships, 95 incorporated villages and 126 school districts that they say have penned blacks and other minorities into enclaves.
"On Long Island, there has to be some way of breaking up this fragmentation and creating regional resources," Mr. Powell said, adding that many black communities he has studied around the country have either financial resources or strong governmental representation. But "spatial racism," a term describing institutional racism in land-use policies, has left the Island's minorities without "resources or voice," he asserted.
David Rusk, a consultant on urban and suburban policy who analyzed the Island's segregation issues for the Erase Racism group, held up two Washington suburbs as model communities that have felled the walls around their segregated "little box" communities.
A far lower percentage of blacks -- 41 percent and 38 percent, respectively -- would have to move in Montgomery County, Maryland, and Fairfax County, Virginia, to be evenly dispersed. The counties have centralized school districts and zoning policies requiring developers to reserve 15 percent of new housing for low- and moderate-income families.
Mr. Rusk linked inclusive zoning policies to a strong regional economic identity like those in the Washington suburbs -- now more efficient "big boxes" -- because affordable housing is a magnet for skilled workers. He exhorted Long Island to "do something because you are falling behind. The big boxes are beating you out. Montgomery County is the world capital of biomedical research. Fairfax County is the world capital of the Internet. What is Long Island the world capital of?"
Mr. Rusk's recommendation for Long Island: "I would empower the county governments, through state law, with overall responsibility, working with all the little boxes, to develop an Islandwide land-use and transportation plan, enact Islandwide inclusionary zoning, coordinate economic development initiatives and set up some program of regional tax-based sharing so that some of the wealthier communities put more money into a pot that gets shared out to some of the poorer communities."
Ms. Gross said activists would lobby state and local legislators, making use of the court system if need be, for changes. Ms. Gross said the coalition would question how school district lines are drawn and how they are funded. "The districting lines basically do not allow African-American children in particular to gain access to the kinds of good schools that might be available just next door, because we have so many small little school districts," she said.
Another aim, she said, is to secure funding so Long Island Fair Housing Services, a Bohemia-based watchdog group, can dispatch "more visible and prominent testers" to determine whether real estate agents are steering blacks away from white neighborhoods.
One prong in the strategy that Ms. Gross said would not go overlooked would be arranging public meetings to allay white fears.
"We want to have a better understanding of the there-goes-the-neighborhood mentality," Ms. Gross said. "We know that a lot of what happens in communities is fueled by misconceptions, myths and fears that ordinary citizens have. There needs to be some way of having a dialogue."
Ms. Gross said her group had received positive feedback from Suffolk and Nassau legislators. Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, appeared briefly at the Islandia racism conference and applauded the group for crystallizing an issue that never graduated past casual conversation. Mr. Suozzi took issue with labeling Long Island racist but said he supported stronger regional government in the counties.
But efforts to shift powers from the local municipalities are likely to be met with stiff resistance.
"Many of these villages are almost 100 years old and they were created to get away from the bigger governments that were not giving the services they needed," said Warren Tackenberg, executive director of the Nassau County Village Officials Association. "Village government is still the most responsive and effective government there is. The counties or townships, the bigger governments, haven't proven to us that they're successful in their planning methods."
Some of Long Island's black residents say their isolation from white communities contributes to a sense of doubt about how whites view them when they do mingle. Mrs. Tomlin, the Hempstead resident, said she is "constantly trying to discern what I'm seeing and what I'm feeling. You may say, 'Oh, you're so nice,' but you may just be tolerating me. I think about that all the time."
Veronica Dale, 32, who lives in the predominantly black North Park section of Long Beach, said she wonders why her community does not receive flyers announcing festivals and other Long Beach events. Another recent example was the campaigning of school board candidates at the L.I.R.R. station.
"They did not approach me, and I want to believe that it's because I look young," Ms. Dale said, "but then I watched several black people walk there and they were not approached, either."
Ms. Dale said another instance involved her daughter, Aikea Hassell, 7, when she recently attended a white friend's birthday party. Another white girl pulled the birthday girl away from Aikea. "I didn't know if this was her upbringing, racial comments that her parents make," Ms. Dale said, "or if it just was a kid that didn't want to share her friend with somebody else."
Such uncertainty makes it difficult to speak out, Mrs. Tomlin said. "That says something in itself," she said. "You don't want to rock the boat. As people of color, there's a concern about being too outspoken because you don't know what the repercussions will be."
Richard and Tracy Gaines, a black couple, live on Wellington Street in Hempstead, and their backyard abuts that of a white family on Meadow Street in Garden City. Mr. Gaines said he has nothing to do with the Garden City side, adding that he is irritated by the looks he gets from the Garden City police who pass by when his white coworkers at a clothing distributor in Lake Success come over for barbecue.
His daughter, Shenasiah, 10, said she occasionally talks to children on the other side of the fence. "I think one boy's name is Billy," Shenasiah said. "We talk about how the day was and stuff like that."
Nobody answered the door at that Garden City home, but residents elsewhere along the border with Hempstead said their relations with their black neighbors are cordial.
"We like the fact that we have neighbors in the back who are African-American because we don't want our kids to think it's a white world," said Dane Petersen, 43, a photographer on Meadow Street in Garden City. Mr. Petersen said he sees some of his Garden City neighbors less often than Desmond Gebon, his black neighbor beyond the fence in Hempstead.
Mr. Midwood, who lives next door to the Tomlins, said: "The truth of the matter is the only problems I ever had were with my Garden City neighbors. I never had problems from the Hempstead side because they were all friendly, great people. A few weeks ago some guy from the sanitation department knocks on my door very apologetically to tell me that one of my Garden City neighbors complained because I left my green recycling bucket out six hours longer than I should have."
Mrs. Tomlin said a move to a wealthier and, by inference, white neighborhood would raise a number of uncomfortable questions: "Do you really want to break the barrier? Who are your children going to date? Who are their friends going to be? Will your children be accepted?"
In the end, Mrs. Tomlin decided her goal falls somewhat short of the full integration that activists on the Island want. "It does not matter if it's separate as long as it's equal," she said. "Why can't Garden City and Hempstead have the same success rate in sending their kids to college?"

HEADLINE: IN THE SCHOOLS; 
When the Substitute In Class Is a Parent

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG; This column, about education in Westchester, appears biweekly. E-mail: wested@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DEPENDING on your feelings about parents turned loose in a classroom, the Rye city school district's recent plan to recruit and train parents as substitute teachers in the elementary schools could be considered a brilliant solution to the chronic shortage of substitute teachers -- or a potential nightmare that could create more problems than it solves. 
 Dr. Edward J. Shine, superintendent of the Rye city school district, said that on any given day, the district with 2,566 students needs about 10 to 12 substitutes districtwide , a number comparable to similar districts in the county. That number can double when Rye faculty members are needed to grade standardized tests or participate in professional development programs. 
 "When the economy was booming, we couldn't find anyone available to do subbing," said Dr. Shine. 
Even increasing the daily pay rate to $90 wasn't enticing enough prospects. Rye had tried to tempt parents to consider working as substitutes through a mass mailing during the last school year, but found few takers. Anyone over the age of 18 who passes a criminal background check can be hired as a substitute teacher by a school district. Uncertified substitutes are limited to 40 days in the classroom. Certified teachers, who are working as substitutes, can work without any such limits. The minimum state requirements for being a substitute teacher can be superseded by a school board's and district's own hiring requirements.
This year, the district decided to offer training to substitute teacher candidates, and 55 parents responded to a district solicitation this spring. A dozen mothers were ultimately selected on a first-come-first-served basis for the program.
Before the training was offered, Alison Dye, a mother of three who had been a teacher in the United Kingdom before coming to the United States, wasn't certain how her British training would prepare her for an American classroom. 
"For me, this is the perfect step in," said Mrs. Dye, who had taught home economics to 11- to 18-year-olds in England, and now coaches field hockey here as a volunteer. 
The dozen candidates were given a two-hour training session by two Rye school teachers, focusing on classroom management techniques, district policies regarding student confidentiality issues and how to follow a teacher's lesson plan. The sessions also covered basics like how to collect lunch money and take attendance, and walk children through the hallways to the library or gym. Prospective substitute teachers spent a half-day in a school, essentially shadowing a classroom teacher. Parents were also interviewed by an elementary school principal, and then go through another two-hour training and debriefing session. 
"These are stake holders in our community, who have the safety and best interests of the children at heart," said Jeanette Lees, a third-grade teacher who does some of the training. "This represents an even more formal way for parents to help. We don't expect subs to teach new things, but learning continues and we want our children to be safe and secure. It's a big disruption for kids when their teacher is out. The children rely on structure and routines." 
What about worries that parents who work in the schools will forget that they are district employees and divulge information about one student's attention deficit disorder problem or another's need for extra help in reading while chatting with other mothers at next weekend's soccer game? Or that parents who work as substitutes may try to parlay that role into favored treatment for their own children? 
"We've emphasized strongly to the parents that they are expected to comply with school confidentiality policies," said Dr. Dan McCann, Rye's deputy superintendent. "And we won't place the parents in their child's classroom or even on their grade level." 
While districts often hire parents as uncertified substitutes, this is one of the only district-sponsored programs that seeks and trains parents to fill the slots. For the district, seeking substitutes among parents made sense. "There are many qualified people in our community who are interested in teaching and interested in working in the community," said Dr. McCann. "These are well motivated people who want to contribute. We'll get people who are reliable, and who are close."

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT; 
Auditors Recalculate Delaware Dredging

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
WHEN the Army Corps of Engineers agreed to undertake a controversial plan to deepen the Delaware River's shipping channel, it said the project would save about $40 million a year in transportation costs for the region.
 But after studying the proposal for about a year -- with critics contending that the savings may be less than anticipated and the potential damage to the environment considerable -- Congressional investigators for the General Accounting Office now say the corps vastly overstated the economic benefits. 
 According to the calculations by the investigators, which were made public last week, the project would provide only about half the benefits predicted by the Army Corps of Engineers.
"This is a boondoggle, and it should be dead," said Representative Rob Andrews, a Democrat from Haddon Heights who has long opposed the project, whose cost was estimated at more than $300 million with a completion time of five years. 
The numbers are crucial because the corps is only supposed to undertake projects that provide at least as much economic benefit as they cost in construction. 
The corps is not disputing the criticism. Indeed, it has agreed to suspend work on the dredging plan until a new analysis is complete. It has also agreed to have independent consultants provide the analysis, and to shelve the project if the numbers do not justify it.
The General Accounting Office began its review of the project last year after receiving requests from Representative Andrews as well as New Jersey's two senators. Mr. Andrews has opposed the project in part because engineers planned to dump a large amount of dredged river muck in sites in his South Jersey district. He also said dredging would damage the river's environmental health and provide little economic benefit.
But supporters of the project, led by Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican from Pennsylvania, have vowed to continue to fight for its survival because of what they say is its importance to the economic health of the river ports in and around Philadelphia.
Manuel Stamatakis, chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, said thousands of port-related jobs depended on the deepening project. He said the Congressional investigators were unfairly subjecting the Delaware project to close scrutiny.
"I don't understand why they would single out this project and not look at a much bigger project, such as the one in New York," he said. 
The Delaware project calls for engineers to increase the depth of the 103-mile-long shipping channel from 40 to 45 feet, which supporters say is necessary to accommodate large container ships and oil tankers.
But Congressional investigators questioned whether the increased depth would add substantial business to the Delaware River ports, and opponents point out that the ports have drastically increased revenue in the last several years without deepening the channel.
Environmentalists have said the project would threaten the environmental recovery of the Delaware River. The resurrection of the Delaware, which has seen the return of many threatened animals and plants, is considered one of the success stories of the environmental movement. In their report, the Congressional investigators said most environmental concerns had been properly addressed by the corps.
Some of the errors cited in the report were simple math mistakes. For example, the corps double-counted the economic benefit it expected from reduced costs to oil companies, which would be able to use larger ships on the Delaware. That error led the corps to overstate the annual benefits by $2.6 million, the investigators said. A computer error overstated the project's benefits by another $4.7 million, they also said.
By the time the Congressional investigators finished adjusting for math errors and erroneous assumptions, the project's benefits were reduced from $40 million a year to about $13.3 million.
As a result of the report, the corps has agreed to review its calculations on another 150 projects nationwide. 
Representative Andrews said there was still a possibility that the Delaware River project could survive, although he said "there is an immense burden of proof for the proponents."
He said he would try to ensure that financing for the project is not restored in Congress.
"It is a bad idea, and I can't justify spending $300 million on it," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Army Corps of Engineers wants to to deepen the river for shipping. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Hijacking The Spotlight

BYLINE:  By LUC SANTE; Luc Sante's books include "Low Life" and "The Factory of Facts."

 BODY:
JOHN J. GOTTI was conceivably cited more often in hip-hop lyrics than any other human being, and not just because his name helpfully rhymes with body, karate, Bacardi, Maserati and illuminati. He was New York's bandit king. His sole concession to the sharing of wealth may have been the annual fireworks displays he put on outside the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in Ozone Park, Queens, until they were halted by Mayor Giuliani, but that was hardly the point. 
 In today's free-market culture, a thug does not gain respect by doling out groceries or endowing hospitals. To command death while wearing $2,000 Brioni suits is the dream of the powerless, and Gotti happily embodied that possibility. Just as ingenue boxers of the 1900's assumed the names of their idols, so gangsta rap, the urban soundtrack of the powerless, has spawned a long list of epigones of the Don: Gotti, Young Gotti, D-Gotti, Cell Gotti, Yo Gotti, Lil' Gotti Gambino. . . . 
 John Gotti, who died last week, was, after all, a pure product of the slums: the fifth of 13 children, whose father was unskilled and often unemployed, whose family managed only a lateral move from the South Bronx to East New York, then as now arguably the two bleakest neighborhoods in the city. He became a gang leader, slid out of school, was arrested nine times in eight years for the usual variety of juvenile offenses. 
Every element in this list is familiar from a million dossiers compiled by social workers in the slums of this and other cities. But Mr. Gotti did not wind up eating lead, did not spend his entire youth in prison and did not succumb to dope -- or, for that matter, find religion -- because he caught the eye of an employer for whom his excesses and misdeeds and sociopathic tendencies made excellent resume material.
Unfortunately for those who would follow his example, few milieus in American society possess criminal organizations bound together by the principles of medieval vassalage. Even the one he worked for seems to have slipped; its ownership of judges, juries and prosecutors is at an all-time low.
Mr. Gotti was a star. He may have come up through the ranks, humbly hijacking trucks and working as an enforcer, but after Paul Castellano met the asphalt of East 46th Street in late 1985, Mr. Gotti stepped into the spotlight like an understudy in a musical. In doing so, he was filling a conspicuous vacancy. No mobster had displayed so much panache since Lucky Luciano, who was deported to Italy in 1946. With the possible brief exception of the psychotic Joey Gallo, the intervening years had been dominated by expressionless men in fedoras. Their style had tended to focus on deeds rather than appearances, even if half of them had taken lessons in body language from George Raft.
Mr. Gotti, suddenly if belatedly, invented a kingpin style for the television era. His hair alone was a minor masterpiece; his wardrobe suggested Prohibition splendor with a 1950's Miami Beach palette; his demeanor flickered constantly from amusement to bonhomie to menace. 
Had he mastered the art of the sound bite as well he would have been overpowering, but among the Mob, pithiness apparently went out with Carmine Persico (who, acting as his own lawyer in the 1986 RICO case that sent him and many other prominent capos away, described the proceedings as "a bus tour of Tinseltown"). 
Mr. Gotti wielded language like a two-by-four -- excision of common obscenities would trim his collected utterances by half -- and his most quotable quotes were picked up by concealed microphones.
"La-di da-di, free John Gotti, the king of New York," warbled the Fun-Loving Criminals, a second-string white hip-hop crew, a few years ago. You could buy "Free John" hats and shirts in select locations, and several Web sites were given over to the cause, the guest books of which were dense with condolence messages within a few hours of his death. 
He was a king to many who could not imagine themselves ever achieving a place in society as it is conventionally constituted, and his downfall and improbably long term in solitary only reinforced the notion, oddly enough. His previous ability to buy acquittals had made him an object of admiration, but his inability to do so in 1992 inspired love. 
He was revealed as human, one of us, who had enjoyed a wild ride at the expense of the power elite -- compared to which his own exercise of power could be seen as insurgent, even brave -- and then had been undone by the treachery of Sammy the Bull, an archetypal Judas. He had risen from the dirt of poverty to the plateau of celebrity, a place of fine dining, superb haberdashery, constant presence in the tabloids and power over life and death. Of course he was going to go down. 
Mr. Gotti somehow managed to tap into a tradition, that of the criminal as popular hero, that dates back to peasant societies in the mists of time. By popular reckoning, Dutch Schultz was a killer, Al Capone was a warlord, Carlo Gambino was a remote figure who directed fate with a mere nod of his head; but John Gotti was a bandit.
His life and actions were not much different in substance from theirs, but he possessed charisma and swagger, and he conveyed the very American humbug that because he lived large, you could, too.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Attire that suggested Prohibition splendor. (Associated Press)

PERSON: RUDY GIULIANI (57%) GOTTI, JOHN; SANTE, LUC

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT; 
Trying to Save Energy May Come at a Price

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
With state regulators poised to collect nearly $1 billion from utility customers for energy conservation measures over the next seven years, a recent audit concluded that the plan was flawed and warned that New Jersey might be in danger of wasting much of the money.
 "You should have a long-term plan to measure these things, and they don't," said David Llewellyn Davies, chief executive of Davies Associates, the Maryland-based auditor that conducted the study for the state Board of Public Utilities. "They are sort of winging it at the moment, and they are trying to back into a long-range plan." 
 Moreover, when regulators and the state's power utilities unveiled the program last year, auditors said, they began spending money without clearly identifying the desired results. 
By year's end, the state expects to have spent more than $200 million on programs ranging from rebates for energy-efficient equipment to training for building contractors. Yet in the report, completed in April, auditors recommended that the state more clearly define the goals for each of its energy efficiency programs and scale back or eliminate those not expected to produce long-term results. 
Jeanne M. Fox, president of the Board of Public Utilities, said her staff had already begun to work on long-term plans. "It is a priority for all of us to get a handle on this," said Ms. Fox, who was recently appointed to the board. "I would like to have something in place by early fall."
State legislators created the energy conservation fund when they passed a 1999 measure deregulating the state's electricity market. The clause establishing the conservation fund was one of the most hard-fought sections of the law, with various groups from utilities to environmentalists clashing over how the money should be spent. The arguments tied up the money until last year, when the state reached a compromise solution.
Under the new plan, every ratepayer pays a small fee, called a societal benefits charge, in addition to the bill for the power itself -- some of which goes to the energy conservation fund. Under the deal struck last year, 75 percent of the energy conservation fund will be used to promote more efficient use of power, and 25 percent will support renewable energy sources like solar or wind power.
To get the fund up and running quickly, the state regulators turned to the utilities, which had been administering their own, smaller funds for decades. The utilities, in the past limited to handing out high-efficiency light bulbs or pamphlets on home insulation, were asked to operate more ambitious programs.
But from the beginning, opponents criticized the decision to rely on the utilities to manage the funds.
"It is the fox managing the henhouse," said Jeff Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club. "The people who have the most to gain by not having energy efficiency programs are in charge of it."
The auditors found that the utilities did a good job establishing the programs and ensuring efficiency, but that many of them were modified versions of the utilities' original conservation efforts. Consequently, auditors questioned whether they would achieve the results the board wanted.
Rather, the auditors said that the programs should be aimed at the eventual transformation of the state's energy market so that customers would use less energy because it made economic sense rather than because of state subsidies. "A lot of the programs are not meeting the objectives," Mr. Davies said. "The utilities did a good job, but now you have to get in there and direct them."
The utilities disagreed. One disputed program, for example, trains heating contractors to install energy-efficient equipment to minimize the amount of power used for central air-conditioning. But the auditors criticized the state plan because there were no benchmarks to measure electricity savings or to determine whether the training affected the market for air-conditioning equipment.
Still, Chris Neme, a consultant working on the program, said the training had already shown results.
"The market share for energy-efficient equipment in New Jersey is 30 percent; nationally the average is 4 percent," Mr. Neme said. "New Jersey is way ahead of the national average, largely because of this program."
Frederick A. Lynk, a marketing manager for PSE&G, argued that Mr. Davies's report underestimated the amount of planning that went into the programs. "We had a very short time to get to market with these programs," Mr. Lynk said. "We did a lot of baseline market research about where the markets were, and that market research was an underpinning for the design of these programs."
While Mr. Davies said the auditors did not disagree that many of the individual programs worked well, he noted that the state needed to develop an overall plan to determine which ones should be emphasized.
"If you are going to transform a market, you need a long-term strategy," he said. "And they don't have it, and that is the critical problem."
While the auditors felt the utilities could manage the energy efficiency programs -- with greater involvement by the state Board of Public Utilities -- they said the supervision of renewable energy funds should go to an independent group.
"This is the exploitation of new technologies, and utilities are not known for doing that," he said.
While supporters of the current plan say it has been successful in promoting alternative energies like fuel cells, critics contend that it has not done enough to encourage the use of renewable energy sources.
"The fund has left solar businesses dead in the water," said Lyle K. Rawlings of Advanced Solar Products.
The auditors concluded that the money spent under the current program was unlikely to foster a viable renewable energy industry, and that the current system had spent too much on one technology -- natural-gas-fired fuel cells -- and not enough encourage homeowners to install renewable energy devices.
Ms. Fox said the Board of Public Utilities would examine the plan for renewable energy sources as well as the energy efficiency programs, but that it was too early to call for any changes.
"We are going to look at what structures will work," she said.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW; 
Lost Souls In Search Of Brighter Days

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: MADISON 

 BODY:
"CARNIVAL!" is a musical whose time has come. See it at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival and you may wonder why. 
 You may also wonder what a middling musical like "Carnival!" is doing at the Shakespeare Festival, but that is another matter. Neither a classic musical nor a conventional star vehicle, the place of "Carnival!" in theater lore can be summed up in a name: Gower Champion. Indeed, the musical signaled a new breed of star, one who did not appear onstage but whose presence showed through everything that did. 
 It was 1961 and a new era was dawning on Broadway. The director-choreographer as musical star emerged. Mr. Champion was an early innovator of a new fusion that defined musical theater at its most complete. Production -- not in terms of scenic effects, but vision and concept -- dictated by a masterly touch, overpowered composition. Crashing chandeliers imported from England had yet to arrive. This was Broadway pizazz, genuine, homegrown, first class. 
No other "Carnival!" can be as revelatory. Why the musical is resurfacing, from major showplaces to summer stock, is anybody's guess. It was the season's high point in the terrific Encores! series at New York City Center in February; there is talk of a Broadway revival next year, and the Surflight Theater in Beach Haven opened a "Carnival!" with three Equity cast members last Tuesday. (It runs through June 23.) 
Given the current economic reality, "Carnival" does not need a spectacular production, but it needs something spectacular. New vision, shining talents and grand ingenuity can transform the ordinary into the extraordinary. 
"Carnival!" is about a shoddy circus of lost souls, has-beens and never-was's.At its center, Lili, an innocent 16-year-old orphan, and Paul, a literally, spiritually and psychologically wounded dancer, take two and a half hours of stage time to admit they're in love.
A story about a third-rate troupe of desperate exhibitionists does not call for a third-rate production with desperate performances. Lamentably, in the festival's staging, Lili, on in years, seems moronic or spaced out, but hardly waiflike. When she arrives lugging her suitcase, the keeper of the souvenirs, a bully, calls her "child" and attempts to abuse her. Clearly, myopia is among his impairments. 
Given all the types and degrees of disorders detected here, this woebegone troupe could be transported from their small town "somewhere in France" to the nearest asylum. Given Lili's mindless disruption of the hazardous "leap for life" acrobatic act, eternal wandering seems her rightful destiny. 
The musical depends on Lili's irresistible enchantment. Straightaway, this production is in trouble. 
It doesn't help the vital cause of pathos that Paul's hostility is excessive beyond motivation, his brooding and depression too actorly. To these roles, Kate Dawson and Robert Cuccioli bring considerable vocal resources. Ms. Dawson's silvery soprano enhances Lili's songs, especially the lovely solo, "Mira." 
Mr. Cuccioli's resounding, popular baritone was either restrained for the futile cause of inner turmoil, or the singer had an off night. Either way, Paul's dramatic arias came off as effortfully understated.
Bob Merrill's fitful score shifts from dopiness to lyricism without blend. It is naive to credit it with beauty or cohesiveness. "Humming" is dumb filler; "Her Face," a heart-tugger. 
But even if "I've Got to Find a Reason" may sound treacly, interpretive power could make it heroic, as Brian Stokes Mitchell proved in New York last February. 
Michael Medeiros as Jacquot, assistant puppeteer to Paul, appears to have exclusive rights to charm and musical comedy finesse. Rosalie ("the incomparable") and Marco ("the magnificent") are traditionally annoying, here far more than tradition tolerates.
Because Lili actually believes that puppets are people, it is hard to figure director Bonnie J. Monte's choice of casting actors inside the dummies. Carrot Top is the only hand puppet in the show. 
Ms. Monte's staging and Kelly Garfield's skimpy dances are not seamless.
The festival has produced three musicals under Ms. Monte's leadership. One, "Two Gentlemen of Verona" (1996), was sensational. Now that the theater is New Jersey's first to be awarded $1 million under a new Dodge Foundation Strategic Partnership Grant, perhaps its musical mission can be reevaluated. 
After all, Shakespeare may be the festival's best source for everything.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Cucciolo as Paul and Kate Dawson as Lili in the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's production of "Carnival!" The musical runs through June 30 at the F. M. Kirby Theater in Madison. (Gerry Goodstein)(pg. 11)

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Here A re Your Pills. Do You Want the Seminar?

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds @nytimes.com.

 BODY:
"THE pharmacist will see you now."
 At the Kerr Drug Store in Chapel Hill, N.C., customers can meet with a specially trained pharmacist who will check their cholesterol and suggest how to maintain acceptable levels. Or they can attend a stop-smoking clinic, take a bone-density test, receive information on diabetes or sign up for a course on women's health issues. (And, yes, they can have their prescriptions filled, too.) 
 Kerr is among a small but growing number of drugstores across the country trying to expand the definition of "pharmacy" to include a range of health management services. In this new guise, the pharmacist is no longer just a figure in a white lab coat behind the counter.
Many pharmacists believe that the new role is a natural for them, and consumer groups like the idea, too, because it expands patients' access to health care.
More and more, pharmacists are relinquishing traditional pill-dispensing duties to automation or to off-site centers. With the growth in the number of pharmacy technicians -- 111,000 have been certified since an exam became available in 1995 -- pharmacists can be relieved from routine chores like checking insurance coverage or ordering supplies.
Appointments at doctor's offices can be hard to arrange. But "pharmacies are accessible to people," said Eleni Anagnostiadis, executive director of the National Institute for Standards in Pharmacist Credentialing, which in 1998 began certifying pharmacists who receive extra training in disease management. "Patients see their pharmacist more often than their doctor," she said.
The number of pharmacies offering expanded patient care is still relatively small. The National Association of Chain Drug Stores puts it at about 500 of the 35,000 chain stores. Of the approximately 200,000 licensed pharmacists nationwide, 1,300 are certified to counsel patients on topics like diabetes, asthma, cholesterol management or blood clotting conditions. Thirty-two states allow pharmacists to give flu shots (they generally charge around $15), and pneumonia shots (about $25). 
But as drug therapy becomes more complex, many medical experts agree that it's time for more pharmacists to step out from behind the counter. Many hospitals already include pharmacists in patient management teams. "Doctors don't know enough about medications," said Charles Inlander, president of the People's Medical Society, a consumer advocacy group based in Allentown, Pa. 
Medication is either prescribed or administered in two-thirds of doctors' visits. Last year, 3.3 billion prescriptions were dispensed.
As long as pharmacists don't try to usurp the doctors' primary role in diagnosis and treatment, physicians are guardedly supportive of their entry into patient care. "Pharmacists provide a valuable service," said Dr. Richard Corlin, president of the American Medical Association. "But it's not that of being a junior physician."
Florida is the only state that lets pharmacists prescribe drugs independently, though only a limited number of medications, like certain allergy drugs. An additional 32 states let pharmacists modify medications with the approval of a doctor.
Pharmacists who want to expand their services face other obstacles. For one thing, there aren't enough of them. Chain drugstores reported more than 6,500 pharmacist vacancies in February, and some stores are reducing pharmacy hours because of staff shortages, said Crystal Wright, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.
Insurance reimbursement is an even bigger stumbling block. Health insurers pay pharmacists a dispensing fee for each prescription. They don't generally pay for pharmacists' counseling about drugs or helping patients manage diseases, a function typically handled by doctors. "When you start paying for something, you stimulate a huge amount of business, and much of it is not medically necessary," said Dr. Donald Young, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group representing nearly 300 insurance companies.
Without dependable insurance reimbursement, pharmacies that offer more services piece together revenue through arrangements with employers or individual customers who pay out of pocket, say $15 for a cholesterol test to $75 to $100 for a 45-minute consultation on diabetes.
Right now, just 5 of the 115 Kerr Drug Stores in North Carolina and South Carolina are what the chain calls Enhanced Pharmaceutical Care Centers, with specially trained staff, private counseling rooms and meeting space for groups. The company said it believes that the changes will differentiate it from larger chains and help build customer loyalty, eventually increasing business.
For now, though, "it's a struggle financially" for these care centers, said Mark Gregory, Kerr's director of pharmacy. "Our goal is to break even."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Balancing Act

BYLINE:  By JOHN E. McCORMAC; John E. McCormac is the treasurer of New Jersey.

 BODY:
ON March 26, Governor James E. McGreevey presented a fiscal year 2003 budget that is rooted in two fundamental principles -- fiscal responsibility and fairness.
 The budget proposal achieves fiscal responsibility by controlling spending with an appropriations level at roughly that of fiscal 2002, the first time in many years that such a budgetary accomplishment has been achieved. The budget will reduce the number of state employees, cut overhead costs, and make state government more responsive and less wasteful. 
 The governor's budget achieves fairness by protecting the hard-working families of New Jersey with stable state aid to schools and municipalities and stable property-tax-relief programs for middle-class families, such as the Saver rebates. The budget also increases the Homestead Rebate checks to a maximum of $775 for the elderly and doubles the income eligibility for the Senior Property Tax Freeze Program. Finally, the proposal does not increase personal income tax rates or sales tax rates and maintains critical programs that directly affect our most vulnerable children, families and older citizens. 
Before proposing his own budget for fiscal year 2003, however, Governor McGreevey first had to restore order to a 2002 budget that was badly out of balance. Revenues were over $3 billion down from the original target, and new spending added nearly $500 million more to the shortfall. New Jersey had the worst problem in our history and one of the worst problems in the nation.
With the cooperation between the administration and the State Legislature, the 2002 budget was brought back into balance with $400 million in additional revenues, a $1.9 billion reduction in the remaining budgetary appropriations and the use of $1.2 billion in available surplus balances.
Without any action, the 2003 budget presented a $5.3 billion shortfall because of the continuation of the revenue reduction at $2.4 billion plus another $2.9 billion in statutory growth in appropriations. A determined effort to scrutinize all state spending line by line, division by division and department by department yielded nearly $3 billion in budget cuts for the coming year. Quite simply, we met the challenge of living within our means and held the line on spending.
As we work hard over the next several budgets to restore balance between recurring revenues and recurring appropriations, we are seeking to securitize the state's fiscal benefit from the tobacco industry settlement agreement, which means choosing guaranteed cash now instead of uncertain annual payments.
New Jersey proposes to join with 30 other governmental entities and remove the risks associated with this agreement that could jeopardize the future of this revenue stream. These uncertainties can be manifested in the continued litigation surrounding the tobacco industry in general and the agreement in particular. There is continuing decline in consumption of cigarettes, and the companies that are part of the settlement hold an increasingly smaller part of the market, which will decrease under the agreement.
The decision to securitize these proceeds is sound, and one likely to be considered even in good economic times. Private and institutional investors are more than willing to rely on the tobacco proceeds, so we are transferring those risks from Main Street to Wall Street.
While securitization provides New Jersey with a multiyear fix to its budget woes, it is only a temporary solution. We are seeking such permanent, structural soundness by making changes to the Corporate Business Tax and ensure that we reach in 2003 the original target of $1.823 billion contained in the 2002 budget.
Corporate tax collections have performed the worst of all major revenue sources in 2002 with actual revenues at barely half the original estimate. Left unchecked, corporate taxes would generate fewer real dollars in 2003 than in 1982, without any adjustment for inflation. Out of approximately 200,000 active corporations, roughly 77 percent pay only the statutory minimum of $200 in taxes to New Jersey. A single parent earning $25,000 pays more. The corporate tax as structured entices alternate business types, encourages transfer of ownership to out-of-state and offshore organizations and permits accounting maneuvers that export income and import deductions.
Our Corporate Business Tax reform proposal will eliminate these loopholes and ensure that all companies pay their fair share of taxes to New Jersey, including out-of-state entities that lack a physical presence but profit from their economic presence here. In fact, it will lessen the tax burden for small businesses in our state and level the playing field among and within all industries. Fairness and equity will be restored to our tax code.
New Jersey government remains committed to making investments that build on New Jersey's already strong and diversified economy. We continually build public and private partnerships that encourage new investment, create new jobs and enhance our standing as the most innovative and progressive state in the country for technology, health care, pharmaceutical and financial service industries.
The Wall Street rating agencies are watching, our investors are watching, and most importantly, our eight million citizens are watching. We shall put the state on the road to structural balance between recurring revenues and recurring appropriations. By keeping spending under control, by maintaining our long-term vision for capital expansion and by reforming our corporate tax structure, we have set out on a journey to restore fiscal responsibility and fairness to state finances. The 2003 budget is a giant step toward our achievable destination.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Rhyme but No Reason

BYLINE:  By JOHN J. FARMER Jr.; John J. Farmer Jr., of Stanton Station, was the attorney general of New Jersey Attorney from 1998 through 2001. He previously served as chief counsel to Gov. Christie Whitman.

 BODY:
It's springtime here in Trenton, Gov.
And though you're gone, your name
Is on the new folks' lips each day
 With some new form of blame. 
They've blamed you for each crisis, 
They're awfully glad you're out.
They'd blame you for the Bible's flood
If they hadn't for our drought.
They've blamed you for the deficit
Though New York's is the same.
They've blamed you for recession
But recession barely came.
They've blamed you for the borrowing
On roads and schools and spaces.
They've blamed you for the air we breathe.
They've blamed you with straight faces.
They've railed against indebtedness:
"Beware the interest mounting."
Now they say "securitize"
And hope nobody's counting.
And they're not raising taxes
In the budget, merely "fees,"
And they're not cutting aid,
It's just a "necessary freeze."
They're taxing corporations
But they hope they don't uproot them.
And as for bears they shrug and say,
"Can't live with them, can't shoot them."
They're squeezing aid to colleges
Which'll only raise tuition.
They lack the guts for layoffs
So we're paying for attrition.
The property tax blame you took
Was vicious and unending.
But that's not Trenton's problem,
Now that they're in Trenton spending.
They've frozen aid to urban schools
Without street demonstrations;
No motions filed, no further talk
Of wasted generations.
They've frozen aid to cities,
They've frozen aid to towns.
Our local taxes will go up
Our rebates will come down.
There'll be no cameras in cop cars
But guess what, Gov.? That's fine.
Reform can wait, the reverends say,
"She's gone now; take your time."
The Court is dumb now, so they say
It's filled with her attorneys.
But Handler, Pollock and O'Hern
Were Byrne's, not Bert and Ernie's.
And what of Long and Coleman,
Two career appellate jurists?
Are they dumb too or just not right
For race and gender purists?
They say they'll find a genius
They'll search the high and low
For nominees with "gravitas"
Like non-Colonel Santiago.
And government, they say, will change
Its conduct of affairs.
But things look all too similar
And so the press just stares
As jobs are added or are filled
With friends of union bosses,
While each new problem is addressed
With commissions or task forces.
Is it that you're female?
Is it that you're rich?
Or is it that Republicans
Are bait for every switch?
Yes, it's springtime here in Trenton, Gov.
But some things stay the same --
New grasses bring hay fever
While the asses lay the blame.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Mold Can Be an Insurance Mess for Homeowners

BYLINE:  By DAN MICHALSKI 

 BODY:
FOR the last two months, Bob and Kathy McCord have been suburban refugees. They were forced out of their four-bedroom house in Dallas because of toxic mold, which they say has been festering under the floors and walls since a water pipe burst this spring.
 "The mold got so bad," said Mr. McCord, 52, president of a Web site development company, "that as soon as you walked in that place it burned your eyes and nose." 
 After leaving their house, the McCords spent the first few weeks at a local Summerfield Suites hotel, where they said they met seven other families in similar ordeals. But with the mold removal not yet complete, and negotiations continuing with their insurer over what work still needs to be done, they recently decided to sign a 90-day apartment lease. 
Stories about toxic mold creeping through homes, schools and other buildings, sickening and displacing their occupants, have become more common in recent years, particularly in regions with warm, wet climates, like Florida and parts of Texas and California. 
Of course, mold has always been around. Most of it, though unattractive, is harmless, like the kind you might find growing in the shower stall. But more serious strains of slimy greenish-black fungus have been appearing lately, including Stachybotrys atra, Aspergillus and Penicillium, which produce toxic substances that can cause respiratory problems in some people.
Many scientists believe that today's more tightly sealed, energy-efficient homes are more susceptible to mold growth. They are also looking into the role that powerful air-conditioning systems may play in spreading mold spores throughout a house or building, as well as changes in the formula for some drywall, which some believe may also be a contributing factor in mold growth.
Whatever the reasons, some insurance experts say the problem threatens to become as serious financially as asbestos has been: a potential health hazard that could cost the industry billions of dollars. While the number of claims has risen, so have mold-related lawsuits, driven in part by a few large jury awards of late. (More than 5,000 mold-related lawsuits are pending in state courts against insurers by disgruntled policy holders, according to the Insurance Information Institute in New York.)
No hard data is available, but insurance companies estimate that more than 10,000 families nationwide have been forced out of their homes because of toxic mold the last two years. In Texas alone, insurers paid $1.2 billion in mold claims last year, while a family from the Austin suburb of Dripping Springs won a $32 million judgment against their homeowner insurance company, Farmers Insurance, for mold-related damages to their 22-room house. The judgment included punitive and legal fees as well as about $6 million for repairs, though the state court would not consider the family's medical claims.
Insurers say average bills for most mold claims run from $30,000 to $50,000.
Though taxing for the insurers, the consumer may ultimately have to pay a good part of the price for combatting mold -- through diminished coverage and higher premiums.
Across the country, annual homeowner policy premiums have already risen 7 to 8 percent this year from last year, to around $500, on average, according to Robert P. Hartwig, chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute. He blamed mold claims for a large portion of the increase and said premiums were expected to rise a few more percentage points next year as more claims are expected.
In Texas, which has the nation's highest average homeowners premium -- just under $1,000 a year -- residents can expect premiums to increase, on average, by 40 to 60 percent this year, according to the Texas Department of Insurance. People with previous water damage claims, and mold problems, may face even higher rates.
Some insurers, though, have been trying to get out of mold coverage altogether. Over the last six months, major companies -- from Allstate to Nationwide to State Farm -- have been petitioning state insurance regulatory agencies to let them exclude mold from homeowners policies. So far, 35 states have approved some sort of mold exclusions, like eliminating coverage for water problems caused by a lack of maintenance on the part of homeowners. Louisiana, for example, has eliminated all mold coverage, while North Carolina has put a $5,000 cap on mold-related payouts.
Legislators in some states are trying to add protection for consumers. California recently passed the Toxic Mold Protection Act, which forces insurers to offer mold coverage and mandates that homeowners disclose previous water or mold problems when selling a house. New York is considering similar legislation, while Maryland and New Jersey passed bills this year to study health risks associated with mold.
Last fall, the Texas Department of Insurance allowed carriers to phase out coverage for mold for all new homeowner policies. But in January, it allowed carriers to offer "enhanced water coverage," which essentially sells back the excluded protection, at an average annual cost of $2,000. Under the new policies, Texas homeowners can expect insurers to pay for the actual removal of mold and the replacement of rotted walls, floors, and furniture, but not for testing or the expense of living in a hotel while work is done.
Consumer advocates advise all homeowners to check their policies regularly, understanding fully what is and isn't covered, and to keep abreast of the insurance regulations in their states.
Consumers are learning that it takes vigilance to ensure that mold claims are paid and cleanup work is thorough. In most cases, only "sudden or accidental" discharges of water are covered in claims. 
MARGARET CRUZ, 67, of Bedford, Tex., says she has spent more than two months in negotiations with her insurance company over the cleanup of her home, which was contaminated with mold after a plumbing backup. Now living in a local hotel, she is still unsure about what repairs are covered.
Mr. McCord, whose current homeowner policy still covers certain water damage, said: "It's been a battle every step of the way. You have to follow this thing step by step, inch by inch, if you want it to be handled right."
He said he has had to prove that a burst pipe, not lack of maintenance, was responsible for the water problems in his home and subsequent mold growth. Paul Berry, a spokesman for USAA, the McCords' insurer, said he could not comment directly on their case. He said, however, that his company responds promptly to all mold and water claims and thoroughly investigates them.
Insurers say they have been trying to educate consumers about mold. "What we do is help our customers with a rapid-response team" as soon as water damage is reported to the company, said Ray Baray, another USAA spokesman. "This is a challenge for the entire industry."
But, he added, "there is a lack of standards with mold, and the science just isn't there." 
Obviously, the best way to deal with mold is to stop it early. That means promptly addressing any water problems, by keeping dry all furniture and the areas under carpets, along baseboards and behind appliances. And if you're buying a home, have it inspected for mold.
Most medical experts agree that brief exposure to toxic molds can make eyes itchy but usually does not seriously affect health. Long-term exposure, they say, could lead to respiratory problems.
Consumer groups say that affected homeowners should try to choose their own contractors for the mold cleanup after they file their insurance claims, and they recommend regular testing. If your insurer will not pay for tests, they suggest hiring a testing company on your own. It can be expensive: on-site testing can run $600 to $3,000.
But there are cheaper alternatives. For example, Mold Testing Lab of St. Petersburg, Fla., (www.moldtestinglab.com) says that for $40 it can help you assemble your own test kit out of household materials. Samples are sent to the company's laboratories and results are promised within 24 hours.
Last week, Mr. McCord had his home tested for a third time and, again, it showed unsatisfactory levels of Aspergillus and Penicillium. He and his wife had hoped to reclaim their house this summer, but they are growing more doubtful. 
These days, each time he visits his house to check the cleanup, he dons a $25 biohazard respirator. "We're hoping for the best," he said, "preparing for the worst."

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Looking to Suburbs to Map 9/11's Reach

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton; This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ONE of the many mysteries left in the wake of Sept. 11 is just how hard the attack on the World Trade Center hit New York City's economy. Really hard, obviously.
 But how hard, exactly? And how much of the past year's economic carnage came from the national recession, rather than from the disaster in Lower Manhattan? 
 One place to look for an answer is the suburbs. And particularly the "suburb" that is New York State's second-largest economy: Long Island. 
The New York region is so tightly linked that many economists consider the whole schmear, from Fairfield County in Connecticut down to Staten Island, east to the Hamptons and west well into New Jersey, to be a single economy.
In the past the region has often behaved that way. From 1989 through 1992, New York City lost 9 percent of its jobs; Long Island lost 8 percent; Westchester lost 7 percent; no one was thrilled.
But this time around, things are different. Because while New York City has been suffering, Westchester, Rockland and especially Long Island have been doing pretty darn well, thank you very much.
Want to see some numbers? (If not, feel free to skip the next few paragraphs.) In the 12 months ending in April, New York City lost 107,3000 jobs, a 2.9 percent drop; nationally, the job count was down about 1.1 percent in the same period.
Almost all of the surrounding areas had job gains, particularly Long Island, where the number of jobs actually edged up by more than 8,000, or 0.7 percent. Rockland and Westchester Counties rose 0.2 percent. Unemployment rates show the same pattern. The jobless rate reflects where people live, not where they work, and is almost always higher in the city than anywhere within commuting distance. But it has climbed faster in the city over the last year than in the adjacent areas.
In April, the most recent month for which there is data, the jobless rate in the city was 7.5 percent, up 2.2 points in 12 months. In Westchester, Rockland and on Long Island, unemployment is below 4 percent, and in each place has increased by roughly one percentage point in a year. 
All of this tends to suggest that the crater in New York City's economy was, indeed, caused by terrorists.
To be sure, New York City's economy had started softening well before Sept. 11, and the jobs that disappeared earlier in 2001 cannot be blamed on the calamity.
But, adjusting for seasonal factors, 67,000 jobs vanished during the last quarter of the year, said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and the disruptions of the trade center attack can probably be blamed for most of those losses. During that period, he noted, employment on Long Island was basically stable. 
But he and other economic gurus agree that there are other factors that help account for the differences between the city and the outlying areas.
One, obviously, is size; the city's economy dwarfs those of the northern suburbs, and by some measures is twice as large as the economy of Connecticut. Even Long Island doesn't have half the jobs of the city.
The workers outside the city tend to be wealthier and better educated than those in the five boroughs as a whole, and the places where they work are different, too. For one thing, those places tend to be smaller, said Marc Goloven, an economist at J. P. Morgan. Smaller firms are less likely to have the wholesale layoffs that have afflicted big companies in the city. 
After Long Island's defense industry went into a tailspin in the 1980's, the economy there was transformed to contain a wide diversity of smaller businesses, many of them involved in technology, said Gary E. Huth, the Long Island analyst for the New York State Department of Labor. Other areas of the state now look at Nassau and Suffolk Counties as a model.
Certain businesses that have been slammed by the recession or the economic aftermath of Sept. 11 -- stock brokerages, advertising agencies, garment factories -- are just a lot less important outside the city. "We don't have Broadway," Mr. Huth said. "Some of the reverberations just didn't reach out as far" as Long Island.
Long Island's economy has not been untouched, he added, and unemployed people there are having a tough time. But compared to the city, he said, "In general, things have been better here."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Fares Don't Rise, So Airlines Struggle

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
LAST week, US Airways became the largest airline to apply to the government for loan guarantees, which would help it raise $1 billion for a revamping. 
 Airline stocks fell, continuing a long-term decline. Susan M. Donofrio, the airline analyst at Deutsche Bank, talked last week about the struggling industry. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What is wrong with the airline industry right now?

A. What is working against the industry right now is a lack of fare increases, growing low-fare competition and uncertainties surrounding airport security.

Q. Why have airlines been unable to impose lasting fare increases since Sept. 11?

A. Demand is still very tenuous and highly price-sensitive. As a result, there have been some airlines that have not been willing to go along with fare increases. We also think that from a supply standpoint, although the airlines are doing a very good job of matching supply to demand, that there is still too much capacity out there. Those are the two biggest reasons. And we think the third reason that fare increases haven't been sticking is that consumers are much more price-conscious, which is typical when an economy is in the early stages of a recovery.

Q. Who is helping to keep fares low?

A. These airlines would be AirTran, Alaska and Southwest, just to name a few. They are actually continuing to grow positively year over year because their revenue strategies do tend to thrive in this kind of environment. We also note that new competitor JetBlue is also expected to put pressure on overall air fares.

Q. How big of a problem for airlines is fear of terrorism?

A. Certainly, the fears of terrorism are not helping bring passengers back to the airports. But I also think another reason is the inconsistency with respect to how long it takes to get through an airport. That hassle factor is also keeping people away.

Q. In terms of traffic, where is the industry compared with before Sept. 11?

A. We are still not back where we were pre-9/11. I would say traffic fell off about 30 percent year-over-year right after 9/11. And now traffic is down roughly 15 percent year-over-year.

Q. How serious are airline labor problems?

A. Many of the airlines are purposefully dragging their feet as we await whether United or US Airways are able to get the wage concessions they are currently trying to extract from labor. So we think, as a result, it is going to be a quiet year on the labor front even though we have contracts that are amendable at American, Alaska, Continental and Southwest.

Q. Which airlines are strong and which are weak?

A. America West, United and US Airways have indicated that they are thinking about or have applied for a loan guarantee. We would consider them the weaker players. We think at the other extreme are strong airlines that we think have a healthy liquidity balance and are not likely to need any government assistance. Those major airlines would be American, Continental, Delta, Northwest and Southwest.

Q. Which are the strong smaller airlines?

A. AirTran Airways, Alaska. I also think JetBlue has certainly shown financial strength as well. So those would be the stronger smaller-cap airlines. The weaker ones would be ATA, America West and Vanguard.

Q. Are airline stocks near bottom?

A. We think we are going to continue to see sluggish performance with a downward bias to stock prices because earnings estimates are still falling for the airlines. We also have found that, seasonally, the summertime has not been the best time for airline stocks. So we would anticipate a 10 percent to 15 percent pullback over the summertime in airline stocks.
We think that toward the summer's end is when we will start to see a capacity scaleback. And we think as we head into the fall we are likely to see fare increases, and we believe that will be the catalyst to get this group moving again.

Q. What airline stocks should investors consider buying?

A. They should buy the airlines that are positioned best to outperform once industry revenues begin to recover. On the large-cap side, those airlines would Delta and Continental. On the smaller-cap side, those airlines would be Skywest, Atlantic Coast and Alaska.

Q. What is your longer-term view for airlines?

A. We believe the industry certainly has been dealt a blow with 9/11. But we think that financially it is hurt but not broken.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
You Earned Your Wings, So Return to the Nest

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NO matter how you slice it, the trend of returning to the nest after college is not much fun. For four years, you had autonomy, all-night escapades and the chance to run around the world as if you owned it. Then, one June day, your universe collapses like a warped mortarboard. Health insurance disappears. Loans kick in. With no money and no job, you often have no choice but to go home to your parents.
 I know about this first hand. After receiving a bachelor's degree in communications more than a decade ago, I moved into my parents' home in the Boston suburb where I grew up. Never mind that two years earlier I was hitchhiking my way across Egypt, Israel and Europe and following the Grateful Dead in the United States. Never mind that I'd been living in my own apartment and preparing my own meals. The truth was bitter: I was penniless and jobless, and the country was in a recession. 
 I always saw myself as more of a "balloon" than a "boomerang," a term used to describe offspring who come home after being away. But apparently my balloon was made of lead: I was stuck in that house for almost three years. It was not pretty. 
My mother saw it this way: "It was awful."
That was in 1990, but the world today is much like that one. A poll in March by MonsterTrak, an online job site, found that 60 percent of 1,942 students questioned planned to live at home after graduation. They may have little choice. The 1.2 million college graduates this year will leave school with more debt than ever -- around $20,000, on average, for students with loans, the General Accounting Office says. And they can expect to earn only in the high $20,000's to low $30,000's, on average, compared with the high $30,000's and low $40,000's just two years ago, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the job placement firm. Some experts estimate that new graduates may need up to six months to find jobs in their chosen fields.
New graduates are often afflicted with what I call Benjamin Braddock Syndrome, for the character in "The Graduate": the sense that life will be rather bleak for the foreseeable future. A 1995 study by Barbara Mitchell and Ellen Gee, two sociologists at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia, found that "boomerang" children feel like failures because they have been delayed in reaching their goals. 
Jack Harari, 21, graduated last month from the University of Wisconsin with a degree in television and film. Now he's living in Pleasantville, N.Y., with his parents, but the situation seems far from pleasant. He shares the car with them; if he wants to use it, he wakes up at 8 a.m. and drives his mother to work. He's looking for a job -- ideally in his major -- but knows he probably won't find anything paying close to the $30,000 he thinks he needs to move into Manhattan. (I didn't have the heart to tell him that's not nearly enough.) 
"The issue is, do I live here and save my money and jeopardize my sanity, or do I move out, live off peanuts and maintain my mental health?" he said. While he appreciates everything his parents are doing, and acknowledges that they are all trying to accommodate one another, he resents having to come home. "I feel like I'm younger than I was two weeks ago. A few years ago I was living on my own, traveling around Australia."
Of course, he knows he has it fairly easy, as I did when I lived at home. Not all parents are so generous. 
Cynthia S. Graves, co-author of "Grown-Up Children Who Won't Grow Up" (Prima, 1994) recommends that parents set ground rules, like asking their new roommate to pay rent and charging interest if it's late. Mothers shouldn't fall into maid mode. "Make sure they do their own laundry and buy their own toiletries," she said. "It teaches them good budgeting skills." 
She also advises setting a time limit for their stay, say a year, and kicking them out once it is up. Above all, she said, don't provide cash. "Go buy them groceries if they need it, but don't give them money," she said. "Don't say, 'I can't afford it,' either, because that immediately engages them in a discussion. Just say, 'I'm not comfortable giving you money.' "
Ms. Graves is lucky that she doesn't live in Italy, where her tough-love approach might not fly. In April, a court ruled in favor of Marco Andreoli, 28, who was suing his father for child support. The younger Mr. Andreoli was living with his mother and being supported by his father, who argued that his son had solid work qualifications and access to a $200,000 trust fund. But the courts said the son wasn't responsible for keeping himself if "labor conditions do not satisfy his specific qualifications, his attitudes and his real interests so long as there is a reasonable possibility of satisfying his aspirations within a limited time."
I SUPPOSE it's a good thing that we don't have laws like that here -- most of us might never leave home. The other side of all this, of course, is that many European countries have filial laws, which mean that it's the child's duty to support his parents in their old age. "In the U.S. you don't have to support an elderly parent unless they're destitute," said Laura W. Morgan, a family lawyer at Family Law Consulting in Charlottesville, Va. "In Europe, where families tend to be much closer, the duty is greater." 
Sometimes duty imposes itself on you. As my mother often tells me, she will sell the house in Boston in another few decades, pack up the belongings and move to Manhattan, landing in my home like a Frisbee. It will be up to me to take care of her.
Fair is fair, I guess. Or so she says.
