HEADLINE: Investing; 
Hotels Are Adjusting to a Travel Slump. Are Their Stocks?

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER 

 BODY:
BUSINESSES are still cutting back on employee travel, and hotel profits remain weak. Yet some investors say those are signs to buy hotel chains' shares.
 Michael Rietbrock, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York, said he expects a "powerful" rally in the sector in the first half of next year, precisely because the last year has been so awful. In some ways, he said, the recent slump has helped the industry, by limiting construction of new hotels and by pushing the chains into some serious cost-cutting. 
 That view is not universal among industry experts. Bjorn Hanson, who manages the hospitality consulting unit at PricewaterhouseCoopers, says the companies' share prices, which have generally recovered from their September lows, already reflect that good news. Stock prices of larger hoteliers could go up a little more, he said, but "the risk is, if business travel doesn't recover by year-end, people will become impatient" and prices could plummet. 
Hotel occupancy in the first quarter was 55.6 percent, on average, down from 58.9 percent in the corresponding period last year, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. Room rates have been down each month since September, compared with the year-earlier periods. 
With business travel down, hotels have been offering discounts to vacationers and conventioneers, said Laura Paugh, a vice president of Marriott International in Bethesda, Md. "We watch profit reports from companies like I.B.M. to predict when business travel will come back," she said.
Analysts who expect that business will rebound soon are recommending shares of some of the big chains, like Marriott, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide and Hilton Hotels. 
"The debate is: Do you feel the economic recovery is strong?" said Bernard Winograd, president of Prudential Investment Management in Newark, who is bullish on the lodging stocks. Mr. Winograd added that increases in hotel occupancy levels tend to be tightly correlated with growth in the gross domestic product. "We are fairly optimistic about the economy and so are positive" toward these companies, he said. 
BANKS have not financed much new hotel construction recently, and PricewaterhouseCoopers projects growth of 1 to 2 percent in the number of hotel rooms nationwide each year for the next three years. That compares with 4 percent in 1999, 3 percent in 2000 and 2 percent last year.
Big hotels, meanwhile, have eliminated jobs and consolidated services ranging from reservation centers to laundries. Some hotels have begun changing linens less often for guests staying multiple nights. "Customers are not complaining," said Keith Mills, an analyst at UBS Warburg in New York.
J. Cogan, an analyst at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco, prefers hotel companies that own properties over those, like Marriott, that manage hotels or franchise their brands. Owners, Mr. Cogan contends, will benefit faster when travel resumes. 
He particularly favors Starwood, which generates almost three-fourths of its income through ownership of Sheraton, Westin, W and St. Regis hotels.
Joyce Minor, an analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York, said Starwood's stock is trading at 9.3 times her 2002 estimate for Ebitda -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- a measure of cash flow. Her 12-month price target on the stock is $45, which assumes that it can trade at 10 times her 2003 estimate of Ebitda for a year from now. It now trades at $33.27.
Although Hilton owns only 65 of the 2,015 hotels it controls, those properties are marquee names in big cities and account for 70 percent of its cash flow. In the last four quarters, Hilton's earnings exceeded analysts' expectations, Mr. Cogan said. "Yet it's valued lower than its peers," he added, at less than eight times projected cash flow for 2003.
He has a $20 price target on the stock for the next 12 months. The shares closed on Friday at $13.28.
Ms. Minor favors Marriott. While not a hotel owner, Marriott gains "incentive fees" if hotel profits rise, and it says it expects a 6 percent increase in Marriott-brand hotels both this year and next. She expects its price-to-earnings ratio of 22, based on her 2002 earnings estimate, to reach 26.5 in a year, based on her 2003 earnings estimate. Her 12-month target price is $54; the shares now trade at $38.11.
Mr. Mills at UBS Warburg is not bullish on the industry for the near term, but he has one recommendation: Extended Stay America, based in Spartanburg, S.C. He calls the chain, a low-cost leader, "the Southwest Airlines in the hotel industry." 
The company owns 446 hotels and plans to build 24 more this year, relying mostly on its own cash. Mr. Mills has a 12-month price target of $19 on the stock; it closed on Friday at $15.76.
Ms. Minor acknowledged that hotel occupancy rates had not picked up as quickly as she had hoped and said the stocks are richly priced for now. "We would buy on weakness," she said. 
Mr. Rietbrock said he thinks waiting could be a mistake.
"You may not see it coming," he said, referring to a resurgence of business trips, booked only a few days in advance. "You want to own these stocks."

HEADLINE: Business; 
As the Tech Economy Goes, So Go Special Visas

BYLINE:  By RICK GREEN 

 BODY:
ONE of the last remaining bubbles of the high-technology boom has burst.
 Applications by foreign workers for long-term H-1B work visas plunged by nearly half in the first six months of the government's fiscal year, according to new data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Perhaps more significant, approvals of the visas fell by more than one-third. The H-1B, granted to highly skilled foreigners to help fill jobs when no qualified Americans can be found, has been an important recruiting tool for technology companies. 
 The decline has not, however, quieted critics of the H-1B program, who say it was used during more prosperous times to displace American citizens with foreigners willing to work for less money. Now that companies are laying off workers, the critics contend, there is no reason to import labor. Congress, they say, should lower the ceiling on the number of H-1B visas granted. 
Supporters of the program say the quota should remain the same, because more imported workers will be needed when the economy heats up again.
The H-1B visas, which are work permits good for up to six years, are given to professionals with four-year degrees and specialized skills. They are coveted both by employers and would-be immigrants because the visas are ideally suited for long-term work projects and often serve as a first step toward permanent residence status.
H-1B's were in such short supply a few years ago that employers pressed Congress to raise the ceiling to 115,000 in 1999, from 65,000 the year before. It was raised again, to 195,000, in 2001. But the new cap is unlikely to be reached this year.
Halfway through this fiscal year, only 105,800 applications had been filed for visas covered by the cap, said the I.N.S., down 48 percent from the first six months of fiscal 2001. Approval was given to 44,900, down 38 percent.
"The H-1B numbers have finally caught up with the economy," said Mark D. Shevitz, director of marketing at VisaNow.com, an immigration processing service based in Chicago that tracks I.N.S. data.
In 2000 and 2001, the supply of H-1B visas was exhausted in a matter of months.
The government figures are not complete, focusing only on applicants who count against the annual cap. Not included are certain exempt workers with unique knowledge, such as scientists working at national research institutes. The comparisons were also skewed by a large number of extra applications in 2001 as employers hurried to beat an I.N.S. fee increase.
Nevertheless, it is clear to immigration experts that economic weakness has put a damper on demand for foreign workers. Business is down at many technology companies, which accounted for more than half of all H-1B employees in previous years.
Instead, companies are more likely to hire laid-off United States citizens. For foreigners, that means it is no longer good enough to be merely well-educated. 
"It definitely lessens the demand for the cookie-cutter H-1B," said Daryl R. Buffenstein, general counsel for the American Immigration Lawyers Association in Washington.
Economic weakness or not, said Theresa Cardinal Brown, director of immigration policy at the Chamber of Commerce in Washington, American universities are still not producing enough advanced mathematics and science graduates, so employers must look overseas.
Critics of the H-1B program are not so sure. "You can't convince me there's not a U.S. citizen available," said Representative Tom Tancredo, Republican of Colorado, who introduced a bill in November to roll back the H-1B ceiling to the 1998 level of 65,000. 
Mr. Tancredo and some labor advocates say employers are merely using the visas to import cheaper workers. He pointed to Qwest Communications, based in Denver, which he said had been hiring foreign workers in the last two years even as it was eliminating more than 10,000 jobs.
Chris Hardman, a Qwest spokesman, declined to say how many H-1B workers the company employed, or whether it was hiring new ones. "We hire the most qualified person for the position," he said, adding that Qwest is training American workers to reduce reliance on foreign specialists.
Mr. Tancredo conceded that his bill would probably never come to a vote, but said he hoped to create pressure that would prevent the program from expanding. The ceiling is scheduled to revert to 65,000 in 2004 unless Congress acts sooner.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
The Impossible Demands On America's Airlines

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
FEW American industries have to meet the demands that the public makes of the airlines. People want carriers to operate with the reliability of utilities, providing frequent flights on-time, at low cost and with cozy amenities. But the airlines are also supposed to thrive as businesses in a competitive marketplace, earning enough profits to expand their operations and enrich shareholders. This tightrope act has never been easy to pull off, with big carriers taking financial nosedives and customers growing increasingly disgruntled since deregulation in 1978.
 Yet the public continues to treat the industry as an almost ungainly hybrid of state and private interests, an approach that is highlighted by the government's bailout of the airlines. 
 On Monday, US Airways filed for a $900 million federal loan guarantee as part of a $15 billion aid package put together by Congress last fall. Immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks, the government agreed to give $5 billion, or $18 per resident of the United States, to the faltering industry. Such handouts have raised few eyebrows, though self-sufficiency is one of the paramount mantras of American business. People want assurances that the airlines will keep flying, just as they want water companies to keep providing their resources.
"Transportation is supposed to serve all people," said Alfred E. Kahn, a professor of political economy at Cornell University who oversaw deregulation as president of the Civil Aeronautics Board. "It is crucial to the rest of the economy, like electric power."
Because of that, the government tends to treat the industry like a prodigal child, though critics say such parenting distorts market forces. Even before last fall, when the terrorist attacks led to unprecedented government intervention in both security and financial support, federal officials kept more oversight over the airlines than most other industries. For example, President Bush invoked an arcane labor act twice last year to avert airline strikes; the Justice Department blocked United Airlines' proposed buyout of US Airways in July; and the Transportation Department publishes monthly consumer reports that rate the various carriers.
Deregulation never entirely removed the government's hand from the industry, and in some ways it actually strengthened the perception of the airlines as utilities. Pre-1978 air travel, with its fixed prices, was the accepted domain of the wealthy. After deregulation, prices plummeted because of open competition, and air travel emerged as this country's national mass transit system, as crucial to daily life as highways and subways.
Nothing has done more in recent memory to brand the industry as a public interest than the bailout program. Legislators agreed to enact it just 11 days after the attacks. By contrast, the city of New York, a true public entity, has had to plead and cajole for its billions of dollars in aid.
"We have this feeling in this country, a residual feeling from regulated days, that the airlines have a responsibility to us," said Joe Brancatelli, an advocate of cheaper fares for business travelers. "We should realize these are the kind of people who want to take our money. We never bailed out Enron and we never bailed out Kmart."
Many industry experts say the initial $5 billion cash infusion was a necessary life preserver. But the $10 billion loan guarantee program is another matter, and critics argue that it is propping up businesses that would fail in a completely Darwinian arena. That debate is heating up over the case of US Airways, the country's sixth-largest airline, which lost $269 million last quarter and $2 billion last year.
The carrier is far bigger than any previous applicant. Of the eight airlines that have applied, two have been rejected and one -- America West -- has been approved, getting $380 million last December. The government demanded the option to buy a third of the airline's stock, further blurring the line between public and private domains.
Airlines in this country and abroad have long been regarded as national symbols, and that helps explain why the public did not raise much protest over the taxpayer-financed bailout. Even before the attacks, the American government protected its airlines by limiting terminal slots allotted to foreign carriers and preventing those carriers from flying domestic routes, restrictions common around the world.
"Protectionist attitudes can be very tempting when times are tough, but in fact liberalization would make it easier to cope with tough times," Rod Eddington, chief executive of British Airways, said at a recent luncheon in New York. "Why should we be special?"
IN some ways, the government has supported the airlines more than its own transportation babies, like Amtrak. It has played a more active role in subsidizing airport construction than overhauling crumbling rails. It denied Amtrak $3.2 billion that it requested for security upgrades after Sept. 11, only to take on the costly task of federalizing airport security.
Even in regard to labor issues, the airlines are treated as if they were a vital public interest, often to the chagrin of both management and unions. The Railway Labor Act, a law adopted in 1926 that applies only to the railroad and airline industries, forces workers and management into a collective bargaining process so as not to disrupt service. If talks fail, the National Mediation Board can order both parties into a 30-day "cooling off" period.
After that, workers can still be prevented from striking through an executive order. No other private industry has such an involved labor law intended for the public's interest.
When things go wrong with air travel, customers often complain not only to the airlines, but to the government. "When I complain to my congressmen about the hotel industry, I get a polite letter saying they feel my pain," said Michael E. Levine, a former airline executive who teaches government regulation at Harvard Law School. "Nobody introduces a bill to regulate the hotel industry. But on airlines, they threaten to hold hearings."
Still, in many respects, the airlines do not fit neatly into the role of a utility. The flights of major carriers arrive on-schedule roughly 80 percent of the time, for example, and federal officials do little to enforce better performance. If water appeared only 8 out of 10 times a faucet was turned on, the government would surely take action.

HEADLINE: Bush Doctrine: Lock 'Em Up 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PICKING through conflicting evidence last week, the 12 cloistered jurors in Houston trying to decide whether Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, is guilty of obstruction of justice became the first laboratory in the Bush administration's risky response to the wave of corruption that seems to be engulfing much of corporate America.
 As the jury deliberated, Washington officials held out the case as the model of how to respond -- with quickness and aggressiveness -- to the growing crisis of confidence in business among investors in particular and the public in general. Since the Enron-Andersen scandal broke late last year, the business news pages have been dominated by tales of questionable practices at companies like Global Crossing, Tyco International, Adelphia Communications and ImClone Systems. The market has continued to plunge, and fearful policy makers have decided to stress swift justice -- what some are calling "real time" enforcement -- over the promulgation of new rules. 
 A series of high-profile investigations and cases will yield the desired results, the administration and its appointees believe. A few modest legislative and regulatory proposals, like one last week requiring chief executives to personally certify financial statements, will complete the trick, they say, without the far-reaching legislation and regulation proposed largely by the Democrats. To Republicans, there's no need for stringent proposals to limit the consulting activities of accounting firms, sharper restrictions on stock options issued to executives, broad conflict-of-interest rules for stock analysts or greater access to the courts for stockholders.
At bottom, what separates the Democratic and Republican approaches is a philosophical difference about the role of government and its relationship to the marketplace, as well as a different diagnosis of the root of the problems. The Democrats see the steady stream of corporate failures as a symptom of broad systemic problems. Republicans say it is more a case of a few bad apples, not a fundamentally deformed tree.
"I think people who abuse our trust, we ought to hang them from the very highest branch," Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said in a speech on Thursday. 
Citing "unethical behavior of a few notorious company executives," he added: "These cases are infrequent, but even a few bad cases can poison confidence in our system, which depends on entrusting public company managers with investors' capital. We will never be able to write rules that anticipate every possible subterfuge. Nonetheless, we must take action to restore investor confidence in the accuracy of public company information."
Administration officials like Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's top economic adviser, as well as Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, have warned that some of the more far-reaching proposals by the Democrats would be ineffective, if not downright counterproductive.
The sheer image of executives pleading the Fifth before the klieg lights of Congress, as Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, and Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone, have done, has begun to motivate directors across America to rethink the way they oversee companies, compensate executives and scrutinize accounting practices. 
"The Justice Department realizes that businesses and the financial world don't want any trouble at all with investigators," said E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., a former federal prosecutor who now specializes in white-collar cases. "Even acquittals will not lessen the reaction of corporate America."
BUT some critics in industry and academia question the effectiveness and consistency of this approach. They say that the Justice Department, for instance, has taken a harder line on white-collar cases of late, but that it has also shown considerable leniency in other areas. Most notably, they point to the antitrust case against Microsoft, which was settled by the Bush administration on terms that rival companies and nine states have said were far too lenient.
Equally important, some experts say, tougher enforcement requires more money and more staffing than most agencies now have. To date, the Bush administration has rejected requests from its own officials for additional financing in this area.
In some eyes, the administration's strategy is partially an attempt to distance itself from Enron executives who enjoyed personal ties to senior officials from President Bush on down (as well as to some prominent Democrats).
"When you think back to when this prosecution happened, it may have saved the administration," said Ronald J. Gilson, a specialist in corporate governance at Stanford Law School. "Suddenly, it was the administration's favorite energy guys at Enron and their accountants who were getting rolled. You look tough. You bring in a prosecutor. You set that engine in motion and get a big bang."
Legal experts also wonder whether prosecutions like the one against Andersen, which was Enron's auditor, are going overboard, and whether they are simply blunting more effective reforms. Many experts, for instance, have questioned the societal value of prosecuting Andersen as a firm, instead of individuals, thus hastening the demise of a major accounting firm in a profession that already suffers from being an oligopoly. That strategy also effectively killed the proposed reform measures that Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman brought in to advise Andersen, had hoped would rekindle the firm's onetime image as a model of rectitude and professionalism.
"What have we won by this expensive circus?" asked James D. Cox, an expert on corporate law and accounting at the Duke University School of Law. "What's the just remedy in this case? No one can believe we are better off with a Big Four instead of a Big Five. I certainly feel strongly about going after individuals.
"I'm rather surprised we haven't seen more on the criminal front against Enron," he said. "And we ought to look at the law firms, not to mention some of the investment banking firms. But it's hard to understand the endgame by going after Andersen."
Even before this year's surge in corporate investigations, officials at an array of agencies from the Federal Trade Commission and Federal Communications Commission to the Environmental Protection Agency had vowed to reduce regulations and laws that they have said are too burdensome for companies and the economy. More vigorous enforcement of existing laws would fill any voids, they said.
At the F.C.C., for instance, Michael K. Powell, the chairman, has told Congress of an urgent need to unshackle several industries from rules that have been on the books for decades; he also sought authority to impose stiffer penalties for regulatory violations from companies like the regional telephone companies.
The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Timothy J. Muris, has tried to blunt the move by Democrats for new consumer privacy legislation by expanding the enforcement program under existing consumer laws.
At the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Pitt has said there is little need for most proposed legislation, like restrictions on stock options and new conflict-of-interest laws for analysts and for consultants at accounting firms. The top of his wish list to Congress includes broader authority to bar executives and directors who violate securities laws.
In recent months, though, the landscape has shifted. Deluged with tips of corporate malfeasance -- many uncovered by the collapse of the stock markets over the last two years -- regulators and prosecutors have tried hastily to adjust.
Still, while the rhetoric of deregulation has been recast to avoid sounding too tolerant in a time of investor fear, the basic first principle remains the same. Problems plaguing the markets, officials say, largely reflect the flaws of executives.
"Some of the inadequacies we are seeing are people who are bad and some of what we are seeing is a system that has lost its way," Mr. Pitt said in an interview last week. While he has committed to keeping an open mind about revisions to securities and accounting laws, he has also testified that many Democratic proposals are not necessary and could have unintended and unfortunate consequences.
That stance is no surprise.
"The Republicans have believed that within the framework that has been on the books essentially since 1934, you've got all you need to regulate the markets," said Donald C. Langevoort of Georgetown University, a former S.E.C. official who is an authority on securities and corporate law. "If someone cheats, that's enough," he said. "Nail them. You don't need fancy rules about conflicts of interest, stock options and those kinds of things. That's a way of saying, let's not keep rewriting the rules, layering new responsibilities on companies."
"The broader view," he added, "is that the investor needs not only a sense of protection from bad apples who need to be punished, but that companies must conduct themselves with an eye to more openness. That's the traditional Democratic way of looking at securities law."
Joseph A. Grundfest, a former S.E.C. commissioner now at Stanford Law School, says he and other Republicans think that it is ultimately often less effective to address problems like those now arising by simply rewriting rules.
"If you look at the policy issues, there is a sense that doing things like trying to fix generally accepted accounting principles at the end of the day is a fool's errand," he said. "You will never be able to fix GAAP, just as you can't fix the tax code. There is always some next move."
"If people would just abide by the laws we already have on the books, we would have much more honest markets," he added. "By the same token, if the laws were enforced somewhat differently, we would have more honest markets."
FOR Mr. Grundfest, the model of the new aggressive enforcement beyond Andersen was the action taken by the S.E.C. last month against Edison Schools, the nation's largest commercial operator of public schools.
The case's outcome was foreshadowed earlier this year, as the number of corporate scandals began to explode. Then, Mr. Pitt began to regularly cite a well-known legal decision involving fraudulent financial statements of the Continental Vending Machines Corporation. In a decision by Judge Henry J. Friendly, a prominent appellate judge, a federal appeals court 32 years ago upheld the conviction of three accountants of fraud, even though there was testimony at their trial that they had complied with generally accepted accounting principles.
"Judge Friendly held that if literal compliance with GAAP creates a fraudulent or materially misleading impression in the minds of shareholders, the accountants could, and would, be held criminally liable," Mr. Pitt said approvingly in a speech.
Last month the agency formally revived that principle in its settlement with Edison of accusations that the company had provided inaccurate information about its past revenue and maintained inadequate financial controls. S.E.C. officials said Edison had not violated generally accepted accounting principles and was "in technical compliance" with them. But the commission nonetheless forced Edison to revise the way it reported revenue and hire an internal audit manager because it had failed to disclose that about half its reported revenue never actually reached the company.
"The case shows the qualitative evolution in the types of cases the agency is willing to bring," Mr. Grundfest said. "If you look carefully at the Edison action, had the S.E.C. taken that kind of approach years ago -- the approach that formal compliance with GAAP is insufficient -- and had that message gotten out loud and clear, arguably you could have stopped Enron. Enron is built on the foundation of hypertechnical compliance with GAAP."
A week after the Edison case, the S.E.C. sued Ernst & Young, accusing the firm of violating ethics rules by having a seven-year business partnership with a client, PeopleSoft. Ernst & Young vowed to defend itself, saying its actions "were permissible under the profession's rules and were commonplace" at the time. Ernst & Young disputed the government's accusation that the violations compromised the independence of the auditors, noting in particular that the S.E.C. was unable to find any evidence that the ties between client and accountants had created errors in PeopleSoft's financial statements.
Experts say the Edison, Ernst & Young and Andersen cases reflect the particular zeal of the new era of enforcement. And to the extent that those cases blunt efforts to adopt the toughest rules and regulations, companies and some major accounting firms not in the cross hairs of prosecutors -- and not particularly interested in being shackled by new restrictions -- could not be happier.
"It's the old argument that guns don't kill people, people do," said Mr. Gilson, the law professor. "If I were heading the lobbying coalition against these reforms, I'd be happy about the human sacrifices as the best way to placate these gods. That's the way it works."

HEADLINE: Why Security Must Be Globalized 

BYLINE:  By Shimon Peres; Shimon Peres is deputy prime minister and minister of foreign affairs of Israel.

DATELINE: JERUSALEM 

 BODY:
Security strategy is now becoming globalized, in much the way the world's economy has become globalized. Ever since economies changed from being dependent upon land to being predicated on knowledge and information, the world's political borders have been blurred. 
 Similarly, issues of security are shifting from a world in which nations face certain enemies to one in which threats are of a global nature. From the moment that ballistic missile systems were introduced, ballistic range became a strategic factor no less important than territorial depth. 
 This is particularly true for terrorism that is capable of striking targets at great distances with no prior warning. Because terrorism is global, so must the strategies arrayed against it be global. 
Against the Qaeda network, which is not subordinate to any state or law, the nations of the world have come to understand that in order to protect themselves, collective responsibility is required, on a national, regional and global level. 
This is particularly true in the Middle East, which now faces threats from modern weapons of mass destruction, even as it lags behind in all the benefits from the globalized economy. This part of the world is replete with ballistic missiles, and nations in this region have begun to arm themselves with nonconventional weapons -- chemical, biological and in the future, even nuclear warheads. The presence here of terrorist cells with transnational reach means that their activities in the Middle East are a global danger, rather than just a regional problem.
That is why an international alliance has come together to deal with the Middle East. A "quartet" -- the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations -- has met informally several times in recent months, and may yet establish a formal body. Indeed, President Bush has indicated that he will soon offer a specific plan for reinvigorating the political process to resolve the Mideast crisis. 
The four partners have accepted America's leadership, while the United States has accepted the need for the other three to play key roles. The cold war, which stoked the Middle East conflict, has ended, and the four partners clearly want to avoid having tensions among them rekindled by the current Middle East conflict. Their interest in the region comes not from Arab or Israeli prompting, but rather from their own strategic needs -- a fact neither Israel nor the Arab world can or should ignore. 
The quartet possesses undeniable capabilities, but I am not referring specifically to military power or willingness to dispatch forces to the Middle East. Armies are necessary to win wars or guarantee peace treaties, but an army cannot replace a treaty and cannot be a monitor where no treaty exists. The international partnership can exert influence by extending or denying political and economic aid, and by determining the degree of legitimacy granted to each state or entity -- for example, by adding it to or removing it from the list of those sponsoring terrorism.
Today, Israel has an economy that is half global (the part that continues to operate uninterrupted by national crises) and half national (the part captive to the country's security situation). We will have to get used to the idea that in the realm of strategic defense Israel will also have to operate in a way that is part global and part local. The state must participate in alliances against global threats while using its military to protect itself against its particular enemies.
Globalization of security strategy means that the conflict scenario in the Middle East will no longer involve only two parties, but three: the Israelis, the Palestinians and the quartet of international partners. It also means that Israel needs to reach an understanding with the quartet about our interests. Terrorism now stands in the way of a true peace with the Palestinians and with the Arab states. Every time a Palestinian faction rejects the peace process or carries out a bombing or a shooting, the credibility of the Palestinian side is ruined. Egypt and Jordan entered into peace treaties with Israel, receiving territory and water, without the use of terrorism. The Palestinians had a chance to reach a settlement, but their rejection of the settlement offer at Camp David destroyed trust and good faith.
But perhaps in the context of the quartet of partners, and with President Bush's leadership, we will be able to renew the pursuit of peace as well as defend against new threats. Both sides in the Middle East conflict need assistance to overcome the present political shortcomings from which they're suffering, and for which both peoples are paying a heavy price. If we can return to negotiations, we will be able to establish two states coexisting in peace and capable of moving into the global economy and generating prosperity.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
'Click, Click' Can Be Music to Real Estate Brokers' Ears

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
 If real estate agents were ever worried about being replaced by the Internet, they can relax. If anything, the Internet is bringing them more business, according to a survey of home buyers and sellers released last week by the National Association of Realtors. 
 The survey found that 41 percent of all home buyers went online to search for homes in 2001, up from 18 percent in 1997. At the same time, the percentage of home buyers who used a real estate agent barely budged, declining to 79 percent in 2001 from 82 percent in 1997. People who used the Internet were more likely to use an agent to close the deal (77 percent) than people who relied on other sources of information (64 percent). DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Last-Minute Sizzle Can't Rescue Markets

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market had a furious rally late Friday that erased almost all of the morning's sharp losses. The three major stock indexes still finished down for the week and hit new lows for the year. 
 Investors' concerns from previous weeks continued to hang over the market. 
 A car bomb attack outside the United States Consulate in Karachi, Pakistan, on Friday intensified fears of terrorism. Data showing a sharp drop in consumer confidence in June suggested that the recovery may be weakening. And charges of insider trading against the former chief of ImClone Systems reminded investors of how little trust many have in company executives and auditors these days.
 The negative performers for the week included AT&T, American Express, I2 Technologies, Ciena, the Sprint PCS Group and the CMS Energy Group. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrials finished at 9,474.21, down 1.2 percent, while the Nasdaq composite index closed at 1,504.74, off 2 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 1,007.27, down 2 percent. 
 Bonds rallied, with the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note falling to 4.80 percent from 5.07 percent a week earlier. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
More Black Stock Investors

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
The number of higher-income American blacks who are investing in the stock market has jumped sharply in the last five years, according to a new survey.
 Among people with annual incomes of $50,000 or more, 74 percent of blacks own stocks or stock funds, an increase of 29.8 percentage points over the last five years. 
That compares with 84 percent of whites in the income category, up 3.7 percentage points over the period. 
 Only 46 percent of blacks, compared with 68 percent of whites, expected the economy to improve within a year. Of non-investors, 42 percent of blacks, twice the percentage of whites, said they are likely to begin investing in that period.
Charles Schwab and Ariel Mutual Funds sponsored the survey. The random telephone poll of 500 blacks and whites with incomes of more than $50,000 was conducted in late January and early February by Neuwirth Research Inc.

HEADLINE: Confidence in the Economy, But Not the Market 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "What If Investors Won't Join the Party?" (June 2), which discussed why people aren't coming back to the stock market, despite some positive economic signs: 
 After the dot-com implosion, Sept. 11 and Enron, more people are simply asking themselves: "What's the purpose? What's the point?" The bottom line has always been important in American business, but in the last few decades the bottom line has become everything. 
Whatever happened to a great business idea?
In the new economy, it isn't enough to show a profit for shareholders. If businesses want to lure and hold investors, they need to show why they exist beyond a quarterly financial statement, and prove that their business makes a difference in the quality of people's lives. 
Investors, consumers and even employees don't really hear that message any more from the largest companies in corporate America. This might be why mid-sized and smaller businesses are doing better with investors -- they communicate clearly what they are all about.

SUSAN WEINSCHENK, Ph.D.
Edgar, Wis., June 7

The writer is a business psychologist.

HEADLINE: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; 
Family Bike Rides, Wise Sayings, Snorkeling and a Red Roadster

BYLINE:  These sketches were written by Anthony DePalma, Aaron Donovan, Jan Hoffman, Tarannum Kamlani, Tina Kelley, N. R. Kleinfield, Melena Z. Ryzik and Barbara Stewart. 

 BODY:
PHILIP S. PETTI
Sports Enthusiast
 A basement room in Lt. Philip S. Petti's home in Staten Island was filled with so much sports equipment that it looked like a locker room, complete with a treasured photo of him posing as a pro hockey player. An 18-year veteran of the Fire Department, Lieutenant Petti did play on a department hockey team -- his mother, Catherine, said he joined the team "before he actually knew how to ice skate."
 Though he did eventually learn how to skate -- his daughter, Lauren, now 16, taught him -- he never really learned how to play well. "I saw him play, and you know, he needed work," said his nephew Tim Schlittner. "As much as he loved it, he definitely needed some work." 
 But if Lieutenant Petti, 43, was anything less than content with his hockey skills, it did not stop him. "He had a wonderful disposition," his mother said. "He accepted whatever life handed him. His favorite expression was, 'That's what it is; deal with it.' "
Besides, he was too busy to look for accolades. He continued to coach his church's soccer and baseball teams long after his daughter and his son, Philip, 18, outgrew their cleats. He had to plan for his sister Jacqueline Butt's annual Halloween party -- one year he and his wife, Eileen, went as the Blues Brothers -- and practice the Ed Norton-Ralph Kramden routine he had going with his brother Thomas, also a firefighter.
Their sister Adrian Foran said: "Hugs and humor. When you think of Phil, that's what you think of."

DONALD A. DELAPENHA
Big D, the Daily Biker
 Every weekday at 6:05 p.m., the Delapenha children would stand outside their home in Allendale, N.J., and wait for their father, Donald A. Delapenha, to come back from work. "As soon as they heard the train whistle, they would know, five more minutes," said Mr. Delapenha's wife, Lorraine.
They'd line up with their bikes, waiting for him to take them on their daily ride around the neighborhood. Samantha, 8, and even Robert, 6, rode two-wheelers, and Madison, 2, would sit in a child seat on the back of her father's bike, and off they'd go.
For Mr. Delapenha, getting home from his job as a senior vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in the World Trade Center was often the best part of the day. At work, he was known as Crusher, either because he was an offensive lineman in college or for his 300-yard golf drive; no one knows for sure.
Mr. Delapenha, 37, was a large, stocky guy, who wore shorts "11 months out of the year," his wife said. "He didn't care if it was December, he'd be outside shoveling snow in shorts and a sweatshirt."
His bulk earned him another nickname: Big D. For Christmas, his lifelong friend Gary George gave Mr. Delapenha's children the gift of a star named after their father. "That's what we called it: the Big D," Mr. George said.

SYED ABDUL FATHA
Man of Deep Faith
 Some men cram all the spaces of their hearts with people, places and activities, creating from complexity a fulfilling existence.
Others, like Syed Abdul Fatha, live lives so narrowly focused that other people, places and activities are crowded out. For Mr. Fatha, 54, there were only family and faith.
He was a Muslim who often prayed five times a day according to Muslim practice. He worked at the Pitney Bowes copy center at Aon Insurance in the World Trade Center, and when the work slowed he studied the Koran.
"He was going to buy me a Koran in Spanish because he wanted me to know about his religion," said Beatriz Soto, a co-worker. When Joanna Lewis, new on the job, botched a large copy order, Mr. Fatha stayed calm. "He'd say 'No problem; we just have to do it over again,' " Miss Lewis said.
When Mr. Fatha came to the United States in 1995 he left six children and an ex-wife at home in Bangalore, India. He married an American citizen, but that union also failed.
In Newark, where he lived and worshiped, he met Nauza Umurally, a Muslim woman from Guyana. They were married in a Muslim ceremony in 1998.
Ms. Umurally said Mr. Fatha had planned to become a naturalized citizen. Then he was going to bring his children to America. Mr. Fatha had few friends outside the mosque and few interests outside of prayer. But he had his family, and an intimate relationship with his God. And that, he told others, was enough.

VLADIMIR TOMASEVIC
Payer of Compliments
 Vladimir Tomasevic would find a way to offer a compliment even when a compliment might seem a bit of a stretch. For instance, he always enjoyed the cooking of his wife, Tanja, and for good reason. She cooked well. But like anyone, she had her bad moments.
"One time I oversalted some potatoes that I was baking," she said. "He ate them all, even though I couldn't. He even complimented me on the potatoes. My father was there at the time, and he said, 'You are so lucky.' Another time, it was a new recipe and I put in too much hot pepper. It was really hot. He said, 'It's a bit hot, but it's good.' "
Mr. Tomasevic, 36, lived with his wife in Toronto, and was a vice president for software development at Optus e-Business Solutions. On Sept. 11, he was attending a Risk Waters Group conference on information technology at Windows on the World.
Fond of sports, he played tennis and had recently taken up golf. He did both with his wife. Although he was much better than she was at tennis, he was always patient with her. "He would let me score here and there," she said.
In golf, their abilities matched more closely. "He had a bit of a slice, but my shots were really straight," she said. "He was a bit better, but I was close."

SANAE MORI
Seeker of Adventure
 Ania Kemalow Booth was learning English at Oxford University when she met Sanae (pronounced sa-NYE-uh) Mori, who was a full-time student there. Ms. Mori, who was born in Japan but grew up in the Netherlands, helped Mrs. Booth, who is from Poland, advising her on which college to apply to, which books to read, which courses to take.
Mrs. Booth remembers that when she flew to Poland one December, Ms. Mori met her at the bus station around 5 a.m. to send her off.
"She just wanted to wish me a happy Christmas," Mrs. Booth said. "I was really touched. She gave me a little book, and I thought, 'Wow, I have a friend.' That's something I haven't done for somebody. If I don't have to, I'm not getting up at 5."
They corresponded across the time zones, about renting a car and driving around America, or about Ms. Mori's adventures scuba diving in a Japanese cave. Ms. Mori, who lived in Tokyo, suggested that they visit the Caribbean to go snorkeling.
"It shall be fun!" she wrote. "Someday, someday, perhaps. Keep on dreaming!"
Ms. Mori, 27, worked for Nomura Securities and was attending a conference at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.

ROBERT J. BAIERWALTER
A Man Who Took His Time
 Robert J. Baierwalter thought outside of the box. In high school, he and some friends hoisted a drum set, piece by piece, up to his bedroom so his mother would not know (at least not for a few hours). Decades later, as an account underwriter for FM Global, he liked creating insurance deals his co-workers thought impossible. And when other fathers sped to work early, he stayed home until 8:45 a.m., when Veronica, 14; Richard, 11; and Raymond, 6, left for school.
"He watched their grades like a hawk," said his wife, Laura. "It's a very difficult job, I'm finding out now. He used to ask Veronica every three days, 'What's your math average?' and he was always on the phone with the teachers."
She and his friends remember how Mr. Baierwalter, 44, was always late. "Now that I look back, I see he never rushed for anything," said Debbie Falls, a neighbor. "He enjoyed life. He took his time. He didn't have much time here."
Mr. Baierwalter, who lived in Albertson, N.Y., worked in Norwalk, Conn., but was at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 for a meeting at 8:30 a.m. "It was probably the first time in his life he was on time," Ms. Falls said.

KENNETH BASNICKI
Still an Inspiration
 "It's pretty normal to not listen to what your father has to say," said Erica Basnicki, speaking for herself and other 22-year-olds. "Now it's funny how many times I say, 'Dad always said this.' I actually listen to him more now."
Her father, Kenneth Basnicki, financial marketing director for BEA Systems, was meeting co-workers at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
She remembers how he helped her when her college application was rejected, encouraging her to do some research and write letters. "Nothing else mattered at that moment other than me getting into university, and I did," she said.
Mr. Basnicki, who lived in Toronto, brought that same determination to recreation -- mountain biking, golfing, skiing and snowboarding with his wife, Maureen, and son, Brennan, in addition to his daughter. At 48, he had a group of friends who enjoyed snowboarding together. "We called them the grays on trays," Erica Basnicki said.
Now she hopes to study journalism in New York City. "The best way to honor my dad for me is to not be scared, and to live and go to school in New York," she said. "I know my dad's fighting for me somehow. He'll work his magic, and I'll work my magic over here."

BARBARA KEATING
Contented Grandmother
 Barbara Keating spent 25 years in public service, 10 as executive director of the Big Brothers Big Sisters of South Middlesex, outside Boston. She was widowed almost 20 years ago and survived two occurrences of breast cancer. At 72, she split her time between Cape Cod, Mass., and Palm Springs, Calif., where she drove a red Sebring convertible and went to church every day.
She was someone you would not talk back to, said Paul Keating, one of her five children; she was smart, tough, professional and funny. "The joke was she could always find a restaurant with a good martini," he said. She took hers dry, with two olives.
She planned her year around visits with her 12 grandchildren, in Texas, Massachusetts and California.
A longtime friend, Eunice Maloney, remembers her quiet kindnesses. "She drove people for cancer treatments," she said. "She was always doing something for somebody, but she never said much about it."
Ms. Maloney remembers talking to her about five days before she was killed on American Airlines Flight 11 as she was returning to California from a visit with her East Coast grandchildren.
"She told me she was very happy with her life," Ms. Maloney said. "Later she left me a note that said she was very glad for my friendship. I thought maybe she wouldn't be coming back to the Cape. Little did I know."

ANNE MARIE MARTINO CRAMER
A Modest Leader
 "There was a seven-years difference, yet I looked up to her," Patricia Nilsen said of her younger sister, Anne Marie Martino Cramer. "She was somebody we all looked up to, even my brother. She had a good job, and was a dedicated person. And I wish I could've been more like her.
"My sister was the type of person who never brought attention to herself, she never liked a fuss," she said. "Even as a kid, if she got hurt, if something went wrong, it was no big deal: she'd get up and walk away.
"She just picked up and would just keep going. That's just the way she was."
Jack Leahy, who worked with Ms. Cramer at Fiduciary Trust in the World Trade Center, where she was a tax specialist, said she was difficult to replace. "She was somebody you could confide in when things weren't going well," he said. "She'd support you in any and all decisions you had to make."
Ms. Cramer, 47, who lived with her mother in West Brighton, Staten Island, had a special love for Snoopy. Ms. Nilsen remembers giving her many Snoopy-related items. "She had them in her office," Ms. Nilsen said. "It all went with her."

JEFFREY A. HERSCH
Giver of Maxims
 Nathan Hersch does not remember the first time he heard one of his father's memorable maxims. Maybe they had just returned from Police Athletic League baseball practice. Maybe they were walking the family dog in the neighborhood park across the street. Maybe he was home from school and his father, Jeffrey A. Hersch, an assistant vice president at J. P. Morgan, had come home from work in Manhattan.
Whenever it was, Nathan, who grew up in the family's two-bedroom apartment in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, was probably avoiding his studies. "You have so much potential, why are you wasting it?" his father sometimes asked. "We're not rich enough for you to be stupid."
Nathan Hersch, now 35 and a senior vice president in the human resources department at Citigroup, remembered that his father always said he should work hard in school. The elder Mr. Hersch, who was 53, attended City College for a semester before dropping out to join the Army during the Vietnam War. When he returned, he earned a bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College and later a master's degree in economics.
After 30 years with J. P. Morgan, in 2000 Jeffrey Hersch went to work as an accountant at Cantor Fitzgerald, on the 101st floor of 1 World Trade Center. His wife, Leslie Sue Hersch, said Sept. 11 was his first day back at work after a two-week vacation in Ireland and Scotland. The couple loved to travel, and had been to 28 countries together. "We both figured we'd retire at 59," she said, "and do more traveling."

CELESTE VICTORIA
A Hard Year and a New Job
 The first year of the new millennium was tough for Celeste Victoria, said Dawn Torres, a sister. Shortly after returning home to New York City from Brazil, where she had filmed a documentary on its extremes of poverty and wealth, she was laid off. She was out of work for a year before finally finding a job.
From the time she graduated from New York University, Ms. Victoria, 41, had been earning a good living and supporting Jasmine, her teenage daughter. As a young woman -- tall, very slender, with stately posture and a graceful stride -- she modeled. Later, she worked in journalism and marketing, reporting for radio and NY1 News and producing talk shows for Manhattan cable television.
But she hid her worries, even from her family, Mrs. Torres said. "You could not tell she was going through anything," she said. "We didn't know she couldn't pay the rent and couldn't take care of her daughter the way she wanted to."
Mrs. Torres said her sister continued to dress with flair, hold her head high and behave vivaciously. "She didn't like people to be down," she said. "When she went to a party, she livened people up, livened the atmosphere up."
But last summer, her life took a turn for the better. She found a full-time job with Risk Waters Group, the financial information organization, which was holding a conference on Sept. 11 at Windows on the World. That day, Mrs. Torres said, Ms. Victoria was up early, to be there well before the 9 a.m. starting time.

NEIL J. CUDMORE
Forming Roots
 As a boy, Neil J. Cudmore discovered a hobby that became his lifelong passion. At 8 or 9, he regularly disappeared for hours to the river by his childhood home near Essex, England, to fish. As he grew into an outgoing man, his fishing became an oddly solitary activity for someone who thrived in the company of others.
But it gave Mr. Cudmore, 39, a sales director with the Risk Waters Group, a way to balance an active social life with a gentle sensitivity that helped his friends through their sorrows and joys -- whether making daily calls to a friend going through a painful breakup or giving a first-time father emotional support.
"It was not just that he made a lot of friends, but that he retained them," said Mr. Cudmore's father, James Cudmore. He recalled that at a gathering of his son's friends at a pub near a home he had in Dorset, England, friends from almost every phase of his life and from three continents gathered to share memories of him.
On one of those continents -- in Hong Kong, to be exact -- Neil Cudmore met Dinah Webster, an advertising manager at Risk Waters, who became his fiancee. They bought a house in Port Washington, N.Y., in July 2001 and planned to adopt a child. According to their friend William Rhode, they were putting down roots and finally settling down. "Neil was applying what he wanted for his life to his life," Mr. Rhode said. "He and Dinah really knew how to live passionately, especially in their love for each other."
Ms. Webster and Mr. Cudmore were at a Risk Waters meeting at Windows on the World on Sept. 11.

JAMES M. ROUX
Believer in Simplifying
 The law firm -- Roux & Ghimire of Portland, Me., and Katmandu, Nepal -- was never destined for financial greatness. Although James M. Roux, 42, stoutly described his partner as "the Johnnie Cochran of Katmandu," Mr. Roux himself, a spirited litigator, outdoorsman and windmill-tilter, made impracticality an art form. The firm's rollicking inauguration was held at a club in Manhattan, not Maine, and guests included punk rockers, Mr. Roux's fishing buddies, former girlfriends, a blues-rock band and some Sherpas from Nepal, for whom Mr. Roux designated the evening a benefit.
It was a few years ago when Mr. Roux quit defending corporate clients in asbestos and lead-paint cases to return home to Portland as a small-time general-interest lawyer. He became a magnet for clients like artists, the homeless and the Sherpas.
Dinner chez Roux? He would hand his brother Dave a restaurant menu. Then Mr. Roux, a divorced father of two sons, would attach a fishing reel to a clothesline that stretched from his apartment kitchen window across an alley to the restaurant's back door. Its owner would return the basket full of food -- down payment on legal bills.
On Sept. 11, Mr. Roux was on United Airlines Flight 175, on the first leg of a journey to Roux & Ghimire's Himalayan office.

HEADLINE: Amid Prosperity, Toronto Shows Signs of Fraying 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 14 

 BODY:
A shantytown is swelling on the shores of Lake Ontario, practically in the shadow of Canada's richest banks. The 80 residents have squatted on five acres of undeveloped land that is soaking in mercury and lead.
 Dogs rummage through garbage. Outhouses donated by charities have a stench. There is no running water, save for a single hose shared by everyone, and no electricity. In the winter, people warm themselves over wood stoves. 
 The first baby was born in the shantytown last month, but was taken away by government authorities because the parents used drugs and lived in a shack.
"I don't have a clue how people could live like this in Canada," said a 21-year-old resident named Michael, who gave only his first name. But he himself recently moved into Tent City after losing his welding job. "Rents are just too high in Toronto," he said.
Toronto, Canada's premier city for business and finance, is still considered a model. Like other cities across Canada, it generally managed to escape the urban blight that afflicted industrial cities in the United States in recent decades.
But signs of fraying are becoming evident here, even though Canada's economy is strong, property values are rising and housing construction is booming for the rich and upper middle class.
The poor have been left behind in an otherwise bustling housing market. City officials estimate that 6,000 people are now homeless in Toronto, double the number of a decade ago. Panhandlers have also become more plentiful outside Toronto's fashionable stores and hotels.
Less than 1 percent of Toronto's low-income housing units stand vacant, and apartment rents have risen 35 percent in five years. The number of units that can be rented for $455 a month or less has decreased by nearly two-thirds since 1998, city housing officials say.
At the same time, welfare payments fell -- by 21 percent since 1996 -- because the Ontario provincial government was running deficits and cut spending on things like housing, welfare and transport for austerity.
An influx of immigrants, a relaxing of rent controls and a slashing of federal and provincial public housing budgets all account for the shortage of low-cost housing. While Toronto's chief administrative officer, Shirley Hoy, says, "We've got to fix this because the number of people spilling into the streets is growing," the solution will not come easily.
This city built almost 24,500 units of public housing from 1984 to 1996, but fewer than 100 units in the next five years. The waiting list is long and growing; in shelters, the number of beds is up sixfold in three years, to 4,100, and occupancy is 95 percent.
With 106,000 households in Toronto now spending more than 50 percent of their incomes on rent, families are doubling up in single-family homes or are forced to choose between buying food and medicine or paying the rent.
There is a joke that Toronto is like New York, except it is run by the Swiss. The subways are squeaky clean. Public parks are safe late into the night. But the emergence of Tent City and growing homelessness suggest that the quality of life in Toronto, as in many other Canadian cities, is beginning to fray under financial and demographic strain.
Cuts in federal and provincial funding over the last 10 years have left Toronto and other cities increasingly reliant on property and business taxes to finance crucial services at a time when large companies and the wealthy have been migrating to the suburbs.
Toronto, with a population of 2.5 million, suffers in particular because it must have a balanced budget according to provincial law, and it does not have the right to issue its own bonds. The federal government is encouraging immigration to spur population growth, and that means Toronto and other cities must take on new responsibilities for education, child care, health and housing services -- sometimes in multiple languages.
The signs of stress are growing. With the city 10 years behind in its plans to repair roads and bridges, potholes are more common. The grass is growing higher before it is cut in the parks. There is more litter on the streets. And air quality is declining, as the city sprawls and bus and streetcar service has been cut back, lengthening the lines of people waiting to commute.
"Toronto is at the early stages of erosion as a model city," said Jack Layton, a City Council member and the past president of the Federation of Canadian Municipalities. "The question is, are we going to notice it and do something about it in time?"
The trend in governmental policies may be starting to swing back. The federal government agreed last month to give Toronto and other cities more than $400 million in new housing funds over five years, but Toronto officials say it is a pittance considering the city's needs.
"We have no housing growth strategy to deal with population growth," said Sean Goetz-Gadon, a senior housing official in the Toronto government.
For Jackie Kendell, an ebullient 32-year-old, time has already run out. She is homeless, and she spends her days panhandling, rolling cigarettes and playing with her Rottweiler around her ramshackle shack in Tent City.
A year ago, Ms. Kendell and her boyfriend, Doug, were on welfare, paying $240 a month to rent a tiny apartment in a boarding house. Then came the knock on the door. The house had been sold, and most residents were evicted. Ms. Kendell said that she and her boyfriend could not find an apartment they could afford, and that no homeless shelter would allow them in with their dog.
So they turned to Tent City.
"Our dog is our pride and joy, my life, so there was nowhere else to go," said Ms. Kendell, who admitted to deadening her pains with daily marijuana smoking. "But there is no future here."

HEADLINE: 9/11 Bridged the Racial Divide, New Yorkers Say, Gingerly 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY and DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Daniel Hook knows what it is like to be judged by the color of his skin. It would take no more than a ride on the subway to get the disapproving looks -- the kind that screamed out: stay away.
 Mr. Hook is 25, black and a lifelong resident of Brooklyn. He wears baggy pants and a baseball cap and has a fondness for silver earrings. "Some people wouldn't even look at you," he said. "They didn't have to; you could feel it." 
 But these days, Mr. Hook does not worry about the subways or the people riding them. 
In fact, he seeks them out. Once a week, on a day off from work, he volunteers at New York City Transit, sweeping stations and giving directions.
"People are polite to me," Mr. Hook said while on duty in Jackson Heights, Queens. "My skin color doesn't seem to matter."
According to a recent poll by The New York Times and CBS News, Mr. Hook is among a growing number of New Yorkers who say they have seen a remarkable change in race relations since the Sept. 11 terror attacks at the World Trade Center. People are more tolerant of different ethnic and racial groups, they say, and less likely to overreact to perceived injustices or prejudices. 
"We want to believe the person on the subway next to us is somebody who would've helped us out of a burning tower or would've been willing to give their life for us," said Chris Owens, a former board president of Community School District 13 in Brooklyn. "That's a beautiful thing. That's a powerful thing. That's where people's heads are."
The shift in racial attitudes was noticeable in the first days and weeks following Sept. 11, but then it was seen mostly as the uncertain byproduct of a wounded city. More than nine months later, the change appears to be deeper and less fleeting. Though the widely publicized civility of New Yorkers may have lost some of its sheen, many people say the color lines remain blurred and less intimidating.
Julissa Tineo, who works as a hostess at a Sizzler restaurant in Queens, was struck recently when a middle-aged white woman began complaining about some Spanish-speaking people in the line in front of her. It was as if the woman was living in a different era, Ms. Tineo said.
"The white woman was saying that she didn't understand why these people are in this country," said Ms. Tineo, who moved to New York from the Dominican Republic five years ago. "I just said, 'I am sorry, this is a free country,' and didn't let it bother me. There is so much diversity everywhere, that she really stood out."
For the first time in 14 years, a majority of respondents of all races to the poll said racial relations were generally good in the city. Specifically, the poll found that 53 percent of blacks, 56 percent of Hispanics and 69 percent of whites believed that race relations are generally good. By contrast, just two years ago only 16 percent of black respondents characterized racial relations that way.
The optimism noted in the poll and in dozens of interviews across the city in recent days included some underlying tentativeness. In the interviews, many people said they expected the racial good will to eventually erode, though perhaps not to the same depths of distrust of a decade ago. If there were a high-profile racial incident, along the lines of the police shooting of Amadou Diallo in 1999, some people predicted a racially charged explosion. 
Others worried aloud about other potential threats to the city's nascent racial comity: the campaign for governor, in which H. Carl McCall, who is black, is seeking the Democratic nomination; the city's economic future, in the event of a slow recovery that results in steep cuts in services; and the quality of public education now that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been given control of the city schools.
"In terms of race relations, it is great now, but these things don't last," said Officer Juan Hawkins, a Health Department police officer in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. "It will last until the next idiot comes along and does something stupid."
Down the street, Nathaniel Pinkston, a former city transit worker, said he saw no evidence of improved race relations. He lives in a redbrick house on Cumberland Street bought by his grandparents more than 100 years ago. Mr. Pinkston, who is black, said his new white neighbors don't even talk to him.
"When people move in across from you and they see you here and they don't speak, what does that tell you?" he asked from the stairs leading to his front porch.
That apprehensive undercurrent may be most acute among South Asians and Middle Easterners, many of whom described feeling a new sense of alienation in recent months. Karamat Shah, who moved to New York from Pakistan 20 years ago, said he considers himself a proud American and New Yorker, but has seen a darker side of his adopted home since Sept. 11.
Mr. Shah, who is Muslim, said he has been bothered while buying a hamburger in McDonald's and questioned while riding the subway with one of his two daughters, who wear traditional head scarves. He described the incidents as minor but unsettling. "When you travel in a bus or a subway, there are certain feelings," said Mr. Shah, who lives in Corona, Queens. 
Yet even with one eye fixed on what might be coming around the corner, many New Yorkers described a sense of racial calm seldom experienced in the city. The most obvious and commonly cited cause was Sept. 11, but there were others.
Some people noted the absence of the confrontational style of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was known to push some racially divisive buttons. Officer Hawkins said leaders of all races seemed to be keeping the inflammatory language to a minimum. Others pointed to a better impression of the Police Department and its dealings with minorities. And Mayor Bloomberg, in his first weeks in office, made a concerted effort to reach out to the city's blacks and Hispanics, gestures appreciated in those communities.
"The leader of any organization sets the tone, and if the tone is the right tone, the public will follow," said the Rev. Edward Davis, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of St. Albans in Queens.
Nina Piper, a Jewish mother of three whose eldest son attends Public School 261, a racially mixed school in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, said some people seemed to be making a concerted effort to get along.
"I've tried to be more friendly, more interested in them," she said of the other races and religions at her son's school. "It sounds so patronizing, but I guess I'm warmer."
Although their numbers were smaller, some people insisted there was no going back -- that the city's racial landscape had been permanently altered. Robert Bryan and Coleen Perine were smoking cigarettes during a break from a computer training class on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. Mr. Bryan, who is black, and Ms. Perine, who is white, said younger New Yorkers were at peace with the city's racial and ethnic patchwork.
"It is a generation thing," said Mr. Bryan, 32, who lives in Flatbush. "For my parents' generation, races were more separate. Today you still have a white person and you still have a black person, but we take things more individually. It is not all race."
Ms. Perine, who is 37 and lives in Staten Island, said, "It is the way I grew up; it is what New York has become."
Considering that racial tensions have so often flared up over incidents of police brutality, the poll produced some telling findings about attitudes of New Yorkers toward law enforcement officers. Sixty-six percent of blacks, and 59 percent of Hispanics, said that the police gave white New Yorkers preferential treatment compared to people of other races.
But over all, public approval for the job done by New York's police officers has soared, the poll found. Most strikingly, 50 percent of blacks and 52 percent of Hispanics credited the police with doing a good or excellent job.
In April 2000, by contrast, a mere 12 percent of blacks and 26 percent of Hispanics gave the police such high marks. That poll was taken about a month after four police officers were acquitted in the shooting death of Mr. Diallo.
"I think people don't look at the police as an enemy any more, but as a protector," said Garfield Ricketts, 29, a Jamaican immigrant, as he chewed a piece of sugar cane at a street vendor's stand after a day's work at a nursing home in Harlem. 
"There's a higher regard for law enforcement among young African-Americans," said Willie Green, a manager at the Walt Whitman Houses in Fort Greene. "They're not only crime-busters out to break my back and give me a hard time. And the effort to recruit minorities has had an impact on the way police officers are viewed."
Mr. Owens, the former school board president who sits on the 77th Precinct Community Council in Brooklyn, sounded a more wary note of approval. "I don't think we're any more exempt from potential mistreatment," he said. "We have a new respect for the definition of public service. We don't necessarily believe the cops see us differently, even if we see the cops differently."
But Kevin Pough, 41, an office manager at a midtown Manhattan law firm, said that even if the police still saw him a certain way, they were beginning to treat him differently.
"When I used to go home, it was nothing for me to be stopped, put against a wall, patted down," he said. "Since Diallo, they still stop me -- they stopped me last month, before I moved from Brownsville to Fort Greene -- but it's no more of that attitude like I'm automatically a bad guy, like I'm a criminal. It's not, 'Hey you, get against the damned fence.' "
Mr. Pough seemed torn between savoring his new feelings of comfort and confidence in his city, and apologizing for them.
"Maybe it's just an illusion I'm having, but when I talk to people, they're not looking at me as a black person anymore -- just as this guy who has something to say," he said. "But now we're still singling out Arabs. They're coming under scrutiny, like we were. We're on the other side now, looking out and saying, 'That's the way we were treated,' and we're on the same side as the ones who treated us that way."
Mr. Pough added: "Sometimes I think it's like, how many faces do we wear? When this goes all the way, when we put the terrorists away, are we going to go back to the way we were before?"
