HEADLINE: The Odd Circle Of School Control; 
'Power to the People' in 1960's Is Now Seen as 'Amateur Hour'

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
It was a strange journey. A conservative idea championed by liberals, it was embraced by its enemies and abandoned by its supposed beneficiaries. When it died in disgrace, its last defenders were the philosophical descendants of its original adversaries.
 It was school decentralization, for 33 years the guiding organizational principle of New York City's public schools. Born in the social upheaval of the late 1960's, it was finally ushered toward history's scrap heap last week when the State Legislature gave the mayor control of the school bureaucracy and began a one-year process of abolishing the local school boards in 32 New York City communities. 
 Still, the philosophical story is actually far less tidy than it appears. Decentralization may be a victim less of a disenchantment with its fundamental principles than of the same disillusionment that revolutionized the city's approaches to crime and welfare. In all three areas, the gauzy ethos of the 1960's that included a sometimes naive tolerance and a trust in grass-roots wisdom came up against some intractable human complexities. With a new faith in standards and data-driven results, the public judged decentralization an overall failure. 
"I think the success in fighting crime has made people recognize that government can improve public service when it has the commitment and the resources," said Mitchell L. Moss, Rice professor of urban policy and planning at New York University. "We're now putting authority for the schools in the hands of experts, not in the hands of all kinds of amateurs. Amateur hour is over."
Yet effectiveness has always been the motivation for tinkering with the way schools are governed, however misguided. When the public school system was begun in 1842, it was divided into 17 wards, each run by a powerful board. These were soon dominated by often unlettered immigrant politicians who gave out teacher and principal jobs based less on instructional skills than on connections.
It was the city's conservative business elite that insisted on centralizing power in the hands of bureaucrats and educators. And it was the teachers then too who fought the change, having grown comfortable with the decentralized system, just as 70 years later they would defend centralization, having grown comfortable with that, said Diane Ravitch, a historian of education.
By the 1950's and early 1960's, New York schools seemed to reach what is remembered as a golden age, with a high-quality, merit-selected force of principals and teachers who were turning out hundreds of thousands of well-prepared graduates.
There was one fly in the ointment. The system was not working for poor black and Hispanic children, and activists like Milton A. Galamison and Rhody McCoy insisted that the cause was prejudice, that white principals and teachers had neither the requisite passion nor, in the skewed staff deployment of the day, the experience to teach their children.
The first remedy proposed was not decentralization, but busing. Black children would be shifted to the better white schools. When the heirs of the white immigrants rebelled against that plan, activists in black neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Manhattan demanded community control, known in the lingo of the 1960's as "power to the people." They were supported by patrician liberals like Mayor John V. Lindsay and McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, who were offended by the injustice of failing schools in black and Hispanic neighborhoods. 
"The original vision of community control was not an idea that liberalism normally embraced; it was an S.D.S. kind of idea: destroying the bureaucracy, destroying the professions," said Ms. Ravitch, referring to the radical group Students for a Democratic Society. "The liberal idea is that you raise problem-solving to the highest level, making the solution more equitable. The closer to the neighborhood, the more personal and intense the politics."
But as Kenneth T. Jackson, professor of history at Columbia University and president of the New-York Historical Society, pointed out, despite their battle cries in Ocean Hill-Brownsville, Brooklyn, the stormiest of the three districts set up to test community control, the activists were espousing a distinctively conservative American idea. While in much of the world education is run by a central government -- France has a single education authority; Australia has six -- in America there are 15,000 independent school systems run by local residents.
In Ocean Hill-Brownsville, the largely black school district began firing white, mostly Jewish teachers, and the teachers' union, led by Albert Shanker, went on a series of strikes over two months in 1968. The atmosphere was aggravated by accusations of racism and anti-Semitism. When the dust settled and the State Legislature divided the city into 32 school districts in 1969 and stripped the mayor of power over schools, many thought the union and the politicians had hijacked the new law. It gave the local boards no real power over the selection of teachers and it fragmented the system so much that no one truly ran it.
"What it did was create 32 bureaucracies, and it didn't achieve what its advocates wanted, which was to have decisions made as close to the child as possible," Ms. Ravitch said.
In too many places, the boards soon proved they were not doing the job any better than the centralized board and often did it far worse. People elected to the nine-member local boards often had little knowledge of budget and personnel issues. There was a widespread revolt against professional credentials, and principals and teachers were often chosen because of their race or religion.
The boards, with their control over jobs and contracts, became springboards for political careers. Embarrassments mounted as school board members were accused of sometimes pathetic crimes of petty opportunism like stealing a school's grand piano or forcing principals to hand out campaign literature.
Just as bad, the newly empowered communities soon became indifferent. Turnouts of 5 percent were the norm in board elections. Then in another twist in the strange arc of decentralization, the teachers' union capitalized on the apathy and began floating its own board candidates. It soon became the system's most powerful player, exercising veto power over the choice of chancellors as well local superintendents.
Still, in many districts like District 2 on the East Side of Manhattan or District 26 in northern Queens, decentralization worked as planned, resulting in the election of civic-minded people who were familiar with the desires of residents and put strong principals at the heads of schools, which attracted the best teachers and turned out high-performing students. Frank J. Macchiarola was so impressive as chairman of School Board 22 in the Mill Basin and Manhattan Beach areas of Brooklyn that he was named chancellor.
In the end, legislators in high-functioning districts like State Senator Frank Padavan, a Republican, were the most reluctant to abandon decentralization, but by then middle-class whites, and many blacks, had forsaken the schools for religious and private schools or the suburbs.
When a businessman, Michael R. Bloomberg, took the mayoralty, he realized that what he saw was no way to run a $12 billion enterprise. He could not name his own chancellor, move good principals to the toughest schools or reward good teachers. Other mayors had felt this way too, but this time the black and Hispanic neighborhoods that originally pushed for decentralization were ready to forsake it, and the energized new immigrants now dominating the schools had no stake in it.
"The entire house was a house of cards and they realized how dysfunctional it was to the kids in their neighborhood in an increasingly resegregated school system," said Harvey Robins, the city's director of operations under former Mayor David N. Dinkins. 
Mr. Jackson puts it more stoically. "A lot of times there's an idea where people come to it for the finest of reasons and that it ought to work, but what you think ought to happen doesn't actually happen," he said.

HEADLINE: Experts Wary of G.O.P. Drug Plan 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15 

 BODY:
A Republican plan to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly through private insurers is drawing a skeptical reaction from many health policy experts. The plan, they say, would face problems like those that have plagued Medicare's attempt to encourage the use of health maintenance organizations.
 Private health plans were once seen as Medicare's best hope for controlling costs. In 1998, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that half of all beneficiaries would eventually be in such managed care organizations. But the market has been extremely unstable. Many H.M.O.'s have found federal payments inadequate and pulled out of Medicare, dropping 2.2 million beneficiaries since 1998. 
 The House Ways and Means Committee plans to vote next week on a bill to add drug coverage to Medicare, the largest expansion of the program in its 37-year history. The full House is expected to pass the legislation a week later.
Under the proposal, Medicare would pay subsidies to private entities to offer insurance covering the costs of prescription drugs. Such "drug only" insurance does not exist, and many private insurers doubt whether they could offer it at an affordable price.
"I'm very skeptical that 'drug only' private plans would develop," said Bill Gradison, a former congressman who was president of the Health Insurance Association of America from 1993 to 1998.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, insisted: "We should rely on private sector innovation in delivering the drug benefit. The private sector approach offers the most savings per prescription."
But John C. Rother, policy director of AARP, which represents millions of the elderly, said, "There is a risk of repeating the H.M.O. experience" with any proposal that relies heavily on private entities to provide Medicare drug benefits.
Senator Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan, lamented the exodus of H.M.O.'s from Medicare and asked, "Why in the world would we want to make the same mistakes with the prescription drug benefit?"
About 5.6 million, or 14 percent, of the 40 million Medicare beneficiaries are in private health plans. People dropped from such health plans can go back to Medicare's original fee-for-service program or enroll in another H.M.O., if they can find one. 
Many companies sell insurance to fill gaps in Medicare coverage, but premiums for such Medigap policies have increased rapidly in recent years, and only 3 of the 10 standard policies include drug benefits.
Richard A. Barasch, chairman of Universal American Financial Corporation of Rye Brook, N.Y., which sells Medigap coverage to 400,000 people, said he seriously considered offering a separate insurance product just for drug costs. But after much research, Mr. Barasch said, he concluded that it was not feasible because most of the buyers would be people with high drug expenses.
Under the Republican proposal, insurers and other companies would submit bids to the government, specifying the premiums they proposed to charge for drug coverage. These companies would manage the benefits and would share the risk of financial loss if subscribers' drug costs exceeded expectations.
Asked about such proposals, Mr. Barasch said: "I don't think it's impossible, but the odds are against it."
Participation in the drug plan would be voluntary. But Republicans said the benefits would be so attractive that 95 percent of Medicare beneficiaries, including people with low drug expenses, would sign up.
Richard I. Smith, vice president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a lobby for drug makers, said he believed that Medicare payments to companies offering drug benefits might be more adequate than the payments to H.M.O.'s. Because of "a rigid formula," Mr. Smith said, payments to many H.M.O.'s have grown only 2 percent a year, while costs have increased 10 percent a year.
In the Senate, both parties are working on Medicare drug legislation, but no consensus has formed and no votes have been taken.
The House Republican plan envisions a large role for companies that now manage pharmaceutical benefits for many working families with private insurance. Such companies, including Merck-Medco, Express Scripts and AdvancePCS, negotiate discounts with drug manufacturers and pharmacies. Under the Republican plan, such companies would also assume financial risk, like insurance companies, if they wanted to do business directly with Medicare.
Thomas M. Boudreau, senior vice president and general counsel of Express Scripts, said: "We are not enthusiastic about that approach."
Under the Republican proposal, any company offering prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries would have to be licensed under state law as "a risk-bearing entity" or would have to meet federal standards meant to guarantee financial solvency.
Blair Jackson, a spokesman for AdvancePCS, said: "We are typically paid a fee, generally less than $1, for each claim. But we do not bear financial risk."
H.M.O.'s have long boasted that they hold down health costs, but their ability to do so has been challenged by hospitals and doctors demanding higher payments. Companies managing Medicare benefits would face similar pressures from drugstores.
The National Association of Chain Drug Stores recently sent a bulletin to its members opposing the Republicans' Medicare drug proposal.
Crystal S. Wright, vice president of the association, said: "This could be an economic disaster for community pharmacies. Benefit managers are likely to get even more leverage than they currently have to reduce pharmacy reimbursement."
Under the Republican drug plan, a typical beneficiary would pay premiums of $34 a month, a $250 deductible, 20 percent of drug costs from $251 to $1,000 a year and 50 percent of drug costs from $1,001 to $2,000. Beneficiaries would then be responsible for all drug costs until they had spent a total of $4,500 of their own money. Medicare would cover all drug costs beyond that.
But, House Republicans said, insurers could set different premiums and benefits, so long as the overall value of each drug plan was equivalent to that of the "standard coverage" suggested by the government. 
The Republican plan is part of a bill costing $350 billion over 10 years. A Democratic alternative would offer more extensive benefits, at a much higher cost to the government.

HEADLINE: Do Doctors Really Need to Sleep? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Hospital Accreditor Will Strictly Limit Hours of Residents" (front page, June 13): 
 Complaints by teaching hospitals that limiting the work hours of interns and residents to the equivalent of two full-time jobs will pose an economic burden, while true, are beside the point. Hospitals have exploited residents as cheap labor for decades to their own enormous financial advantage -- ignoring the burden of chronic fatigue and inordinate stress on these young doctors and, more important, threatening the lives of patients.

TIMOTHY B. MCCALL, M.D.
Somerville, Mass., June 14, 2002

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: TRANSPORTATION; 
NEW TRAIN STATION

BYLINE:  By Ronald Smothers 

 BODY:
 Governor McGreevey last week announced plans for a new New Jersey Transit train station in Little Falls at the edge of Montclair State University and along the Midtown Direct line through Montclair, which will travel directly to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. The service, and the station, had been delayed by lawsuits by the town of Montclair over fears of residential displacement and concerns about parking problems. The station will include a six-story parking deck for 1,300 cars when it opens in 2004. At $36 million, It will all be financed by New Jersey Economic Development Authority bonds on land deeded to the state by the university.
 Ronald Smothers

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Indians Are a Wanted Team in Interleague Play

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
This is prime rivals weekend, the weekend on the interleague schedule when geographical or otherwise natural rivals play each other. 
 The Yankees are playing the Mets at Shea Stadium, the White Sox and the Cubs are playing at Wrigley Field, Texas is at Houston, the Canadian teams are in Montreal, the Florida teams in Miami, Kansas City in St. Louis, Anaheim in Los Angeles, Oakland in San Francisco and Pittsburgh in Cincinnati. 
 Pittsburgh and Cincinnati? Interleague rivals? Not only are the Pirates and the Reds in the same league, but they are also in the same division. How does that make them interleague rivals? 
It doesn't, but while other teams are playing interleague games in what, for the most part, are attractive matchups, the Pirates and the Reds are playing just three more of the 18 games they have with each other this season.
Unlike past seasons, neither team is playing its prime rival from the American League, which in both cases is the Cleveland Indians. The Indians like their rivalry with the Reds and do not necessarily see one existing with the Pirates, but from the Pirates' perspective, having the Indians play in Pittsburgh is a big plus.
All three games in a three-game series with the Indians at PNC Park sold out last season. The Pirates sold out only one other three-game series in the first year in their new park. Of the seven games that sold out before the All-Star Game break, three were with the Indians.
In Cincinnati, meanwhile, the Reds experienced a similar attendance boon with the Indians. Their three-game series drew 108,400 fans. The Reds' next largest attendance for three games with the same team was 91,299 for the last three games of a four-game series with the Chicago Cubs. When the Reds played in Cleveland, all three games sold out, making it one of seven three-game series the Indians sold out among 21 three-game series that they played at home. The Pirates did not play in Cleveland last season.
Neither team is playing in Cleveland this season, and the Indians are not playing in Cincinnati or in Pittsburgh. Instead the Indians are playing the Rockies in Colorado and the Arizona Diamondbacks at home, and the Reds and the Pirates have each other.
Katy Feeney, Major League Baseball's scheduling expert, called the Cincinnati-Cleveland-Pittsburgh combination a three-way problem. 
"Pittsburgh considers themselves a prime rival of Cleveland, and Cincinnati considers themselves a prime rival of Cleveland, so it makes it difficult," she said. "Over the last couple years we've tried to figure it out and balance it. This year nobody got them." 
Feeney said the scheduling problems begin with the uneven number of teams in the two leagues and become compounded with the different number of teams in the divisions. Throw in the rotation of divisions this year, and the right mix never emerged.
"You wind up with discrepancies and this is one of them," Feeney said. "I don't want to say it got lost in the shuffle, but it just really didn't work for this year without doing some further imbalancing."
One official said an early schedule had the Pirates and Indians playing. "Then when they tried to work all the numbers," he added, "it didn't work."
Not surprisingly, Feeney heard from officials of all three clubs about what they saw as a gap in the schedule.
"We obviously would very much like to play the Indians," said Dick Freeman, the Pirates' chief operating officer. "I am somewhat sympathetic to the schedule makers. I seldom call. But I did on this one to tell her I was not happy over the fact that we weren't playing them. We were all disappointed. I let Katy know that. I'll be interested to see what happens next year." 
John Allen, the Reds' chief operating officer, said the Indians' absence from the Reds' schedule has not gone unnoticed in Cincinnati. "It's been a topic of conversation on the talk shows," he said. "We're the only natural rivals not playing. We're disappointed by it. We understand that we unfortunately were the odd man out because of the numbers. I've had conversations with Dennis Lehman in Cleveland. They feel the same way as we do. They wish we could have continued it. We both feel strongly and we've expressed our desire to revive it in the future."
Lehman, the Indians' executive vice president for business, said the Indians have had more involvement with the Reds, including a defunct series of preseason exhibition games in Columbus for the Ohio Cup. 
"I guess Pittsburgh would work O.K.," Lehman said, "but from our drawing standpoint, the Reds make more sense. It makes sense to reinstitute that rivalry. Whether it happens I don't know, but John agrees. We'd like to play each other in the future. But clearly either one would be fine."
In the meantime, Lehman said, the Indians are pleased with having the Diamondbacks as a substitute this season. "From an attendance standpoint, it's fine," he said. Allen offered a similar view on the Reds' coming series at home with Seattle and Oakland. "The advance sale is pretty good," he said.
Assuming that the schedule makers could make the numbers work, they could probably make everybody happy by scheduling an Indians-Pirates series in Pittsburgh and home-and-home series for the Indians and the Reds. 
"We're going to try and put them in," Feeney said. "The problem is the three-way. We're looking at different ways, maybe a rotation. That's probably what we'll look at doing. It's a compromise, of course, but nothing works perfectly. The prime rival issue in interleague play is always being discussed."

Castillo a Streak Hitter
Just like that, Luis Castillo became a .300 hitter again. 
It might not have been that simple, but Castillo, the Florida Marlins' second baseman, followed some advice from Bill Robinson, the Marlins' hitting coach, and today has a 30-game hitting streak and a .329 season average.
Castillo was a .300 hitter in 1999 and 2000, reaching .334 the second of those seasons. But then he plunged to .263 last season, stroking 39 fewer hits in two fewer times at bat. As if to show that performance was no fluke, the switch-hitter was hitting .262 this season before beginning his major league-longest streak May 8.
"Earlier in the year he was taking so many pitches that he took third strikes," Manager Jeff Torborg said. "Bill encouraged him to be more aggressive, and he made an adjustment with his front leg from each side of the plate. All of a sudden it came together. He's selective from both sides of the plate but still aggressive. It was just a little adjustment that Bill has made with him and he believes in."
The little adjustment has made for a big difference. Castillo has compiled a .390 average during the streak, the longest in the majors since Vladimir Guerrero of Montreal reached 31 games in 1999.

Irabu Not Fit to Close
From April 24 through May 22, the Texas Rangers' new closer gained saves in 10 successive save opportunities and in 10 of the team's 15 victories. And then? Don't ask.
Manager Jerry Narron has not summoned Hideki Irabu into a game, in the ninth inning or any other inning since June 8. In the six times Irabu pitched before his appearance in the fifth inning against Houston yesterday, he allowed 14 earned runs and gave up 8 home runs in six and a third innings. No surprise that Irabu was the losing pitcher in four of those games.
He allowed three runs in the ninth inning, two on a Joe Randa home run, for a 7-5 Kansas City victory. He gave up consecutive 11th-inning home runs to Carlos Beltran, Mike Sweeney and Randa for a 10-7 Royals victory. Against Anaheim, home runs Brad Fullmer and Tim Salmon hit against him in the ninth tied the score, and Troy Glaus's two-run homer against him in a three-run outburst in the 10th ended the game, 7-5. Finally, Andruw Jones slugged a three-run homer against him in the 10th for a 6-3 Atlanta victory.
After one of those games he said that maybe his body was not fit for the closer's role. That does not say much for his body, because it did not fit the starter's role too well, either.

Balancing Competition
Baseball officials are concerned about competitive balance. Maybe they should follow the example of the National Basketball Association.
"What we've done can certainly work in other sports," David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, said the other day about the league's economic system. "The soft cap allows you to keep your players in place. And the competitive balance is good."
So good the Los Angeles Lakers have won the championship the last three seasons.
Or maybe baseball should copy the National Hockey League, whose championship the Detroit Red Wings have won three of the last six seasons, doing it this year with the league's highest payroll, a reported $65 million. 
They are owned by Michael Ilitch, who as owner of the Detroit Tigers has the major leagues' 18th-highest payroll and is among the so-called low-revenue clubs seeking more of the wealthy teams' revenue so that baseball can improve its competitive balance.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Looking to Suburbs to Map 9/11's Reach

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton

 BODY:
ONE of the many mysteries left in the wake of Sept. 11 is just how hard the attack on the World Trade Center hit New York City's economy. Really hard, obviously.
 But how hard, exactly? And how much of the past year's economic carnage came from the national recession, rather than from the disaster in Lower Manhattan?
 One place to look for an answer is the suburbs. And particularly the "suburb" that is New York State's second-largest economy: Long Island. 
 The New York region is so tightly linked that many economists consider the whole schmear, from Fairfield County in Connecticut down to Staten Island, east to the Hamptons and west well into New Jersey, to be a single economy.
 In the past the region has often behaved that way. From 1989 through 1992, New York City lost 9 percent of its jobs; Long Island lost 8 percent; Westchester lost 7 percent; no one was thrilled.
 But this time around, things are different. Because while New York City has been suffering, Westchester, Rockland and especially Long Island have been doing pretty darn well, thank you very much.
 Want to see some numbers? (If not, feel free to skip the next few paragraphs.) In the 12 months ending in April, New York City lost 107,3000 jobs, a 2.9 percent drop; nationally, the job count was down about 1.1 percent in the same period.
 Almost all of the surrounding areas had job gains, particularly long Island, where the number of jobs actually edged up by more than 8,000 or 0.7 percent. Rockland and Westchester Counties rose 0.2 percent. Unemployment rates show the same pattern. The jobless rate reflects where people live, not where they work, and is almost always higher in the city than anywhere within commuting distance. But it has climbed faster in the city over the last year than in the adjacent areas.
 In April, the most recent month for which there is data, the jobless rate in the city was 7.5 percent, up 2.2 points in 12 months. In Westchester, Rockland and on Long Island, unemployment is below 4 percent, and in each place has increased by roughly one percentage point in a year.
 All of this tends to suggest that the crater in New York City's economy was, indeed, caused by terrorists.
 To be sure, New York City's economy had started softening well before Sept. 11, and the jobs that disappeared earlier in 2001 cannot be blamed on the calamity.
 But, adjusting for seasonal factors, 67,000 jobs vanished during the last quarter of the year, said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and the disruptions of the trade center attack can probably be blamed for most of those losses. During that period, he noted, employment on Long Island was basically stable.
 But he and other economic gurus agree that there are other factors taht help account for the difference between the city and the outlying areas.
 One, obviously, is size; the city's economy dwarfs those of the northern suburbs, and by some measures is twice as large as the economy of Connecticut. Even Long Island doesn't have half the jobs of the city.
 The workers outside the city tend to be wealthier and better educated than those in the five boroughs as a whole, and the places where they work are different, too. For one thing, those places tend to be smaller, said Marc Goloven, an economist at J. P. Morgan. Smaller firms are less likely to have the wholesale layoffs that have afflicted big companies in the city.
 After Long Island's defense industry went into a tailspin in the 1980's, the economy there was transformed to contain a wide diversity of smaller businesses, many of them inolved in technology, said Gary E. Huth, the Long Island analyst for the new York State Department of Labor. Other areas of the state now look at Nassau and Suffolk Counties as a model.
 Certain businesses that have been slammed by the recession or the economic aftermath of Sept. 11 - stock brokerages, advertising agencies, garment factories - are just a lot less important outside the city. "We don't have Broadway," Mr. Huth said. "Some of the reverberations just didn't reach out as far" as Long Island.
 Long Island's economy has not been untouched, he added, and unemployed people there are having a tough time. But compared to the city, he said, "In general, things have been better here."

HEADLINE: He Wrote the Book 

BYLINE:  By Gregg Easterbrook; Gregg Easterbrook is a senior editor for The New Republic, a contributing editor for The Atlantic Monthly and a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution. His next book, "The Here and Now," will be published this fall.

 BODY:
 A GHOST'S MEMOIR
The Making of Alfred P. Sloan's
"My Years With General Motors."
By John McDonald.
202 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The MIT Press. $24.95.
 WHEN corporations are riding high it is well to remember that corporate arrogance is a danger to the public, and also to corporations, on whom arrogance tends to backfire. Insolence at Merrill Lynch, for instance, has just resulted in bad press, big fines and an image dive. Looking back, we see that the chemical industry's attempt to suppress Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" made the industry look worse than the book alone could have. 
There was a similar incidence of corporate arrogance occurring about the time of "Silent Spring," and with a similar blowback: General Motors tried to block publication of "My Years With General Motors," by its former leader and inspiration, Alfred P. Sloan. Ultimately the work became a classic. Like Carson's book, it benefited greatly from corporate arrogance directed against it. 
But though "My Years With General Motors" is now studied at business schools, the story behind the story, as newscasters like to say, has not been told. Sloan's volume was actually written by John McDonald, an editor of Fortune magazine. McDonald spent five years on it, then another five fighting General Motors' suppression. McDonald, who died in 1998, tells the tale in "A Ghost's Memoir," a captivating and revealing chronicle. It is moderately padded with lengthy, 1950's-style business correspondence, and future historians will probably not rush to study these letters. But the book gives a fine account of how one man's persistence resulted in total legal defeat of what was the country's largest corporate entity. Read in conjunction with "My Years With General Motors," it supplies essential understanding of what happens when corporations aim large-bore weapons at their own feet.
McDonald became a leading business writer in the early postwar era, when serious reporting about big business was gaining currency and Fortune was a newsstand colossus. At the time intellectuals shunned business journalism; corporations were to be denounced, not reported on and figured out. McDonald joined Peter Drucker and a few others as intellectuals who found management culture fascinating. McDonald was also a fan of the New York art scene, a friend of the poet Robert Penn Warren and a student of mathematical game theory, but he loved writing about big companies.
Sloan more than anyone else made General Motors happen, pulling it up from one of many competing car brands (Hudson, Reo, Willys) into a company that peaked with more than half of total American automobile sales, plus most of the refrigerator and diesel locomotive markets. Sloan's innovations included offering a full auto line, allowing buyers to trade up as their incomes rose; separating engineering and marketing; insisting that G.M. become one of the first big companies with outside auditing, so that stock buyers would believe its profit claims; tying executive pay to performance; emphasizing styling; and combining car sales with financing.
All seem obvious strategies now, but only because the success of General Motors made them so. Sloan, who ran the company from 1923 till the late 50's, was among the inventors of the modern large corporation. 
McDonald agreed in the late 50's to ghost Sloan's memoir. Though they would spend days on end together, McDonald says he never addressed his subject as anything other than "Mr. Sloan." (Today top managers tell mail clerks to call them Ken or Carly, while awarding themselves pay multiples hundreds of times greater than Sloan would have accepted.) A manuscript was produced, and General Motors sued to block publication. The company proposed an abridged version that Bowdler himself would have found prissy. Sloan, in his 80's, tossed in the towel and signed over his advance to McDonald, thinking that would close the matter. 
McDonald, however, refused to quit. He countersued G.M. He endured pressure from the brass at Time Inc., Fortune's owner, who were terrified that G.M. would pull its advertising. After a prolonged legal and lobbying battle, recounted here, the writer prevailed. Sloan's book was an immediate hit when published in 1964, G.M. heavy-handedness having succeeded in assuring a sensational reception. 
Rereading "My Years With General Motors" today, one strains to discover what caused the corporate reaction. Most of the book is straightforward recitation of management theory. "The function of the Engineering Policy Group in the development of a new model in General Motors is a good example of the work of a policy group" is a typical sentence. 
General Motors must have opposed the book partly because the 50's carried wartime secrecy over into corporate culture; its proposed bowdlerized version of "My Years" deleted even the most harmless specifics. But the company's real problem was that the book defended bigness. G.M. then feared that the Justice Department would sue to break up both its car and locomotive businesses on antitrust grounds. 
In "My Years," Sloan speaks of corporate bigness as the appropriate outcome for whoever makes the best product at the best price. Surely every executive thought the same, but you weren't supposed to say that. Nor were you supposed to say, as Sloan did, that the goal was to best the competition. Sloan even tossed around the world "monopoly" a couple of times, though he anticipated modern economic theory in believing that a true monopoly could never hold because any company making runaway profits or sacking its buyers with poor wares would only draw in competitors who would be its undoing. This is pretty much what occurred when the Big Three later collided with Japanese car makers. 
Perhaps "My Years With General Motors" should hold in the annals of business writing a stature similar to that held by "Advise and Consent" in political writing. "Advise and Consent," published in 1959, shocked readers with depictions of back-room Senate deals and high-pressure lobbying. Sloan's book shocked readers with a premise equally unsurprising now: that corporations organize themselves with the goal of maximizing returns.
John McDonald made a double contribution by putting "Sloan's" book together, then fighting to get it into print.

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: Beware of False Profits 

BYLINE:  By Barry Gewen; Barry Gewen is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:
 REINVENTING THE BAZAAR
A Natural History of Markets.
By John McMillan.
278 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $25.95.
 HERE is the perfect book for the Age of Enron. "Reinventing the Bazaar" doesn't suggest immediate solutions for cleaning up the mess in Texas -- it was written well before the scandal broke -- but it provides a long-term perspective, an intellectual framework, for understanding what went wrong, how we should be thinking about correctives and what a properly functioning market economy should look like.
John McMillan, a professor of economics at Stanford University's Graduate School of Business, is more than a proponent of free markets. He is a celebrant, an enthusiast. He delights in taking us on an economist's tour of the world -- introducing us to the Dutch flower market in Aalsmeer; the centuries-old camel fair of Rajasthan, India; the brave, persistent vendors of Accra and peddlers of Hanoi, who keep coming back despite the brutal efforts of their governments to suppress them.
Markets, McMillan explains, empower people by encouraging autonomous decision making and individual participation;
in the jargon of the moment, they are "proactive." Markets generate productivity and efficiency, allowing resources to flow where they can most usefully be employed. They are flexible in ways that no centrally planned system can match. "For poor countries," McMillan writes, "they offer the most reliable path away from poverty. For affluent countries they are part of what is needed to sustain their living standards."
Put two people together and it won't be long before one of them is figuring out what he can sell to the other. Markets emerge under the most dire conditions. Rwandans living in refugee camps following their genocidal civil war found ways to set up food exchanges and general stores. British prisoners during World War II swapped their Red Cross rations among themselves, using cigarettes as a form of currency. Rembrandt helped create an art market in 17th-century Holland. Mozart entered the marketplace to escape the domination of patrons and maintain his artistic freedom. 
So far, so familiar. But McMillan has another shoe to drop. Markets may arise spontaneously as "the most potent antipoverty engine there is," yet as they develop, becoming more complex, they need rules and structures to perform properly. Sometimes the rules will come from the participants, working together in their common interest. The wholesale diamond trade of New York City is regulated by the Diamond Dealers Club, which sees to it that oral agreements are adhered to. The New York Stock Exchange originated at the end of the 18th century in the closed auctions of 24 brokers who had discovered that free riders attending the daily outdoor auctions on Wall Street were distorting the actual prices of stocks (and undercutting commissions).
The most important, most necessary regulator, however, is the state. Markets achieve their full potential, McMillan insists, only if the government is providing infrastructure. He identifies five conditions that government must guarantee if markets are to flourish: information has to flow freely; people have to be able to trust one another; competition must be assured; property rights must be protected; and side effects like pollution have to be controlled. Without state intervention, markets can scarcely grow beyond primitive face-to-face transactions. The libertarian utopia of complete laissez-faire does not give you prosperity, it gives you Somalia. In 2000, five years after the United Nations had departed, Somalia was a country without a government. No taxes were being collected, and consequently the number of small businesses exploded. Yet the economy has not been a success, and will not become one. Businesses have to dispose of their own garbage, generate their own electricity, find their own sources of water. In the absence of a police force, protection money has to be paid out. Inefficiencies prevail.
McMillan is waging a two-front war here, battling against those who think markets are inherently exploitative and those who think markets can do no wrong. Markets, he writes, are human institutions, with human imperfections. They do not necessarily work well, and they are "too important to be left to the ideologues." Without effective government oversight to assure good corporate market behavior, we can expect two, three, many Enrons. And everyone will suffer as trust declines and investment shrinks. "Countries with stronger investor protections have bigger capital markets," McMillan points out. "The efficacy of the stock market varies with how activist the government is in setting the platform." Ronald Reagan once famously declared, "Government is not the solution to our problem; government is the problem." Ronald Reagan was wrong.
He was wrong because, as McMillan shows, there are no easy answers. Economies are complicated, and the interactions between governments and economies are also complicated. Decisions must be made pragmatically, on a case-by-case basis. "Reinventing the Bazaar" is full of examples. Why, for instance, did Silicon Valley become the center of the computer industry and not Route 128 in Massachusetts? Experts would have predicted the opposite. But Massachusetts had an intellectual property law that prohibited employees from taking the knowledge they had acquired in their current jobs to new jobs. In California, which had no such law, job-hopping was rampant. Individual companies suffered because knowledge they had developed was widely shared. But the industry as a whole prospered. "A subtle aspect of market design, in other words, was a crucial element of Silicon Valley's success." Market design has also been responsible for the effectiveness of the federal government's acid rain program. In 1990, Washington created tradable emissions allowances, permitting companies to buy and sell the right to pollute. The government continued to set pollution standards, but the market would do the work of determining how much sulfur dioxide each individual company would be allowed to emit. Efficient companies sold their allowances and were rewarded; inefficient companies were penalized. And even environmentalists got into the act by buying allowances and withholding them. Most experts, McMillan reports, say emissions allowances have been more successful than any previous program at reducing acid rain.
One of McMillan's most arresting examples concerns AIDS and the pharmaceutical industry. Why shouldn't anti-AIDS medications be dispensed free to third world sufferers too impoverished to pay for them? Moralizers won't like that McMillan performs a cost-benefit analysis while people are dying, but his point is that there are costs no matter which course of action is chosen. Drug companies depend on profits to perform the research that leads to new medication, McMillan observes. No profits, no research, no new drugs. In this case, he concludes, abrogating the companies' patent rights would save lives without greatly affecting profits, since there is such a small market for AIDS drugs in the third world. But, he goes on, there is a grim side to this story. "Letting the poor nations free-ride is of potential benefit only with diseases that strike the affluent countries and have the U.S. and European markets as an inducement to innovation. With tropical diseases, no patents would mean no research." And even with patent protections, unless economists can come up with ways to change the market dynamics of the pharmaceutical industry, the drug companies will spend more on fighting baldness than they do on fighting malaria.
As this example shows, markets can function properly and still produce undesirable results. "The challenge of market design," McMillan states, "is to devise mechanisms, or to allow mechanisms to evolve, that channel the pursuit of profits in a socially productive direction." Ultimately, this is a book about tinkering, a technocrat's plea to all of us to recognize that the big ideas are usually wrong, that the truth is not so much in the details as in the adjustments to the details. For a technocrat, McMillan is a surprisingly accessible writer; he deserves a wider readership than he will probably find (though when it comes to his own specialty of constructing public auctions, he can sound like the dinner guest who goes on talking long after you have stopped listening). Still, McMillan's world is not quite the real world. If he had his way, many of the country's most contentious domestic issues and many of the globe's most pressing economic problems would be handled by locking a bunch of economists in a room and letting them hack away at market designs. He may be right. And he may well get the hearing he deserves at institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. But pragmatism and rationality have never gotten the crowds out of their seats, cheering. In the marketplace that we call the democratic arena, it will surely be the great simplifiers who continue to set the terms of the debate.

COMPANY: W W NORTON & CO INC (91%); ENRON CREDITORS RECOVERY CORP (58%); NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE LLC (50%)

PERSON: GEWEN, BARRY; MCMILLAN, JOHN 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (78%) NEW YORK, USA (92%); TEXAS, USA (92%) UNITED STATES (92%); RWANDA (79%); NETHERLANDS (79%); INDIA (79%)

TITLE: REINVENTING THE BAZAAR (BOOK) 

LOAD-DATE: June 16, 2002 



359 of 709 DOCUMENTS


Copyright 2002 The New York Times Company 
 The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 16, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 52

LENGTH: 4638 words

HEADLINE: Amtrak Must Die 

BYLINE:  By John Tierney; John Tierney, who wrote the Big City column, now works in The Times's Washington bureau.

 BODY:
Before we start on Amtrak, I should confess a longstanding bias. I have been praising trains for as long as I have been speaking. In March 1954, at the age of 11 months, I was on the station platform in Lafayette, Ind., when a train from Chicago suddenly appeared around the bend. The sight and sound of the huge diesel locomotive apparently triggered something in my brain. After my grandmother got off the train, I described her arrival by uttering my first sentence.
 "Gaga choochoo," I said, and went on repeating it for months. The fixation moved on to "The Little Engine That Could" and continued through adulthood. I covered the walls of my apartments with paintings of locomotives and rode trains across America and Canada, over the Andes, around Europe. I developed an appreciation for even the miserable trips, like the one on Amtrak's Crescent that ended in New Orleans with an elderly man declaring that his three years in a Russian prison during the Bolshevik Revolution were never this bad. No matter how often Amtrak disappointed, I kept riding. In the hierarchy of train lovers, I was at least a train buff and maybe even a "rail fan," which is the formal term for the ultimate obsessive. The informal term, coined by railroad workers and now used by the obsessives themselves, is "foamer," as in foaming at the mouth. 
 I sometimes worried that trains were economic dinosaurs. But when the free-marketeer in me suspected Amtrak was a government boondoggle, the foamer said it was only fair to subsidize trains since there was already so much aid going to planes and highways. For a long time, I enthusiastically rode trains but avoided economic analyses of rail travel. My policy toward Amtrak was don't ask, don't tell. 
This year, though, the figures have become hard to ignore. Amtrak is nearly bankrupt, and just threatened to shut down the whole system in July. It has hocked just about everything it owns, including a portion of Pennsylvania Station in New York that was mortgaged last year to cover three months of operating expenses -- the equivalent, critics noted, of mortgaging your house to pay grocery bills. Amtrak's president, George Warrington, abruptly quit in March, shortly after a federal commission recommended to Congress that his railroad be dismantled. One of Warrington's last tasks before quitting was to go before the House Appropriations Committee and renounce his previous promises that Amtrak was on a "glide path" to self-sufficiency. 
"Frankly, Mr. Chairman," he said to Representative Harold Rogers, "we've run out of tools in the toolbox to keep the service together."
Rogers consulted a page of numbers, frowning like a father going over his son's MasterCard bill, until he came to a line with $347.45. That was the amount of money per passenger that Amtrak lost on the Sunset Limited train running from Florida to California. 
"Why," Rogers asked, "is this route still being run?"
A fair question. The previous week I had been contemplating it myself aboard that very train. There is a simple answer, which Amtrak's president provided, but first let me give you a foamer's perspective. 
I picked up the Sunset Limited in Houston, which, like many American cities, has a beautiful train station without any trains. The stately marble terminal built by the Southern Pacific Railroad now serves as the vestibule of a baseball stadium. Train passengers have been shunted to the edge of downtown to a no-man's-land of junkyards and warehouses. The station, which looks like a small-town bus depot, sits beneath freeway ramps. It's not an inspiring place to start a trip, but at least we're not standing in line to have our shoes searched, and there is still nothing like a locomotive for making a grand entrance. 
Boarding the train, I head for one of the two sleepers, the modern version of the Pullman cars that used to be manned by porters known for their "miles of smiles." The porter for my sleeper is not smiling. He barely looks at me as he announces: "You can't use your room. I haven't made it up yet."
I go up to the dome car and watch the receding lights of Houston's skyline. A lounge car on a long-distance train must be the friendliest place in America -- nowhere do you find so many different kinds of people happy to talk to strangers. As midnight approaches, a drunken young guy in an orange T-shirt is dispensing romantic advice.
"I can tell you two still love each other," he says to a 40-ish pair sitting across from him. The woman, an attractive redhead named Catherine, has been explaining that she used to be married to the man next to her, Robbie, and was amazed to run into him on the train.
"No, we're not in love," Catherine says. "I swear to God, I had no idea he would be on this train." Robbie, a handsome guy if you don't mind the shoulder-length gray mane of an aging heavy-metal rocker, disagrees with her.
"Now tell me you don't think about me every day," he says.
"I don't think about you every day," she says. "Just sometimes."
"You're lying."
The drunk persists. "I never saw you before in my life, but I can tell you love each other."
"It would never work," Catherine says to Robbie. "You'll never change."
"There you go again," Robbie says. "You were always giving up on me. Just 'cause I didn't come home didn't mean I was with someone else."
She starts sobbing. He gets up and walks behind her so he can stroke her shoulders. "I never stopped loving you," he says.
She looks up. "You slept with my sister!"
"You slept with her first!" 
An elderly woman nearby looks on in horror as the drunk goes on telling them they're meant for each other.
I retreat to my room, which the attendant has made up, though he left a damp dirty towel on the floor next to the toilet. There's more indifferent service at breakfast. The Transcontinental special, an omelet, is reasonably good, but the staff is unfriendly and unenergetic. When an enormous lake appears outside next to the train in the middle of the desert, I ask a waiter -- who makes this trip twice a week -- what we're looking at. He shrugs.
"I have no idea," he says. "Water."
Up in the dome car, though, the sights are being enthusiastically described by a guide from the National Park Service, which manages this 65,000-acre lake along the Mexican border named the Amistad Reservoir. As the train proceeds west, the guide identifies the varieties of local sagebrush and tells us where a member of Butch Cassidy's gang was killed trying to rob a train. The foamers in the car are blissfully taking pictures and assiduously tracking the train's progress. Two rail buffs from England covetously fondle my G.P.S. receiver, which pinpoints our location to within 50 feet. Its electronic map one-ups their paper map, but then I'm promptly outfoamed by one of them, a composer from London named Henry Lewis, who gives me a CD of railroad songs from his musical revue titled "Brief Encounters on the Penistone Line."
The musical comedy, which has been performed on that line, is the latest of what Lewis calls his "transport revues." One of his most successful, "Joan of Kent," was about an English housewife who hears voices in the supermarket telling her to oppose the new high-speed railroad from London to the Chunnel. "I was sympathetic to her," he says, "but all my subsequent shows have been pro-rail."
The other passengers include some phobics afraid of flying, especially after Sept. 11, but most seem to be here because they like trains. 
"You see stuff you weren't really meant to see," says Catherine Suddarth, the redhead who was arguing with her ex-husband last night. She explains that the train ride is her vacation -- and that he isn't really her ex-husband. "I never saw him before in my life. We made up the marriage as we went along for that other guy's benefit. One of those things you do on a train." Suddarth, a market researcher who lives in Greensboro, N.C., is on a one-week circuit of the country. "It's just a great way to relax and meet people, but you have to be in a certain mind-set. You have to adapt to whatever happens." 
The least happy passengers are the ones paying attention to the timetable. The train keeps slowing down or stopping altogether, generally without explanation. As we cross Arizona Saturday night, we're three hours late, normal for this route. "The problem is that some passengers are on regular time," a mechanic says. "We're on Amtrak time."
Shortly before dawn on Sunday, we come to an especially prolonged halt in the California desert. After a cryptic announcement -- We had an accident" -- rumors circulate in the dining car and the dome car. The foamers have placed us precisely 102 miles southeast of Palm Springs, next to a campground used by young Californians racing all-terrain vehicles on the sand dunes. A passenger reports hearing thumps just after the engineer braked. The thumps are explained by another passenger who has been listening to a police radio: the train ran over someone.
Were kids in dune buggies playing chicken with the locomotive? That theory is popular until we hear that the engineer saw the victim, a young man, lying immobile in the tracks, and that his dune buggy was found parked nearby. Was it suicide? Did he get drunk and pass out? A crowd in the dome car debates the possibilities as police cars come and go and teenagers go on racing their dune buggies alongside the train. One passenger, a veteran who has ridden these dunes himself, hypothesizes that the victim was dead before the train got there. "There are always accidents when guys get drunk at night and go out riding," the veteran says. "Maybe he was killed, and his buddies said: 'Let's move him to the tracks. That way no one can investigate what happened, and his family will collect some money from Amtrak.' " Later, though, the local coroner's office will find no evidence of foul play in the death of Michael Black Jr., a 20-year-old busboy from Chino. 
When the train finally starts moving, three and a half hours after the accident, there's no hope of reaching Los Angeles in time for passengers booked on the train for Northern California and Oregon. To catch up with it, they have to get off at our next stop, Palm Springs, and ride a chartered bus several hundred miles up the coast. It could be worse. A few weeks ago the Sunset Limited was already so late by Tucson that it couldn't get to Los Angeles in time for the start of its return trip, so the train simply turned around in Tucson, leaving the passengers with a 500-mile bus ride to Los Angeles. 
We're nearly eight hours behind schedule when we pull into our penultimate stop, Pomona, but then we suddenly make up so much time that we're only six hours late arriving in Los Angeles. The secret to this miracle is in Amtrak's timetable. It allows two hours and 42 minutes for the 32-mile trip from Pomona into Los Angeles, which actually takes only about 50 minutes. Amtrak routinely pads its timetables this way, and yet one-third of its long-distance trains still arrived late last year. Tony Haswell, who led the passengers' advocacy group that lobbied for Amtrak's creation in 1971, used the Freedom of Information Act to identify the worst train of all: the Sunset Limited, which, in the stretch between New Orleans and Los Angeles, pulled in late more than 70 percent of the time. Haswell refuses to take it anymore, even though the train stops right in his hometown, Tucson. "I have to go to a wedding in Houston," says the man who is hailed as the father of Amtrak, "but I'm going to fly."
Why does Amtrak keep running the Sunset Limited? Because it goes through so many Congressional districts. Amtrak's president acknowledged it himself in his reply at that hearing. 
"We are a creature of the political process," Warrington replied. The Sunset Limited, he explained, is "important to maintaining a fragile political national coalition to support Amtrak."
Amtrak's defenders often say that if Congress would just provide a generous and "secure" source of financing -- ideally a share of the revenue from gasoline taxes -- we'd have trains like the ones overseas. But those railroads are good in large part because they're not sprawling, unwieldy systems like Amtrak. If there were a European version of Amtrak, one centralized monopoly running the continent's trains, it would be pandering to politicians in the Pyrenees and in Ukraine by running a half-empty train from Madrid to Moscow -- and subsidizing it with revenues from the Paris-Lyon trains. 
The Acela, which runs on the Northeast Corridor, is Amtrak's closest thing to a success story, particularly since its airline competition was slowed by security delays. Before Sept. 11, the US Airways and Delta shuttles carried nearly 60 percent of the passengers between New York and Washington; now nearly 60 percent of passengers go by train. But Acela has had more than its share of embarrassing missteps. After a painfully long planning process -- the Acela's debut, in 2000, was three years behind schedule -- Amtrak produced a train that goes nowhere near as fast as its European counterparts. Because of track restrictions and a goof in its construction (it turned out four inches wider than planned, so it can't properly tilt on some curves), the Acela hits its peak speed of 150 m.p.h. for only 18 miles between New York and Boston. While European countries have been laying new high-speed tracks, Amtrak is deferring maintenance on tracks in the Northeast Corridor to subsidize long-distance trains elsewhere.
Europe's national railroads suffer from some of the same problems as Amtrak: meddling politicians, inept management, a bloated central bureaucracy and an unproductive work force protected by powerful unions. (Amtrak's veteran workers receive up to five full years of severance pay if their routes are shut down.) But in Europe the international rivalry has put pressure on the railroads to improve service -- German pride required a high-speed train to match the French TGV. Most foreign railroads are subsidized, but the best ones require much less help than Amtrak, and some, notably in Japan, are private companies providing superb and profitable service. If America really wanted to emulate Europe and Japan, we'd break Amtrak up into smaller railroads run either by regional public agencies or by private companies.
During the past decade, Amtrak's costs have been increasing while airlines and bus companies have been cutting theirs. Train lovers and Amtrak executives love to mention the "hundreds of billions of dollars" of federal money spent on highways and airports and air-traffic control. But virtually all that money comes directly from drivers and airline passengers through taxes on gasoline and plane tickets. While taxpayers provide the average Amtrak rider with a subsidy of 30 cents per mile, the average driver or passenger on a plane or bus gets less than a penny, according to Wendell Cox, a member of the Amtrak Reform Council, overseers appointed by Congress and the president. 
Still, don't trains deserve a subsidy because of all the social and environmental benefits they provide? Don't they ease congestion, save energy and reduce pollution? Not enough to notice. Americans use cars, planes and buses for 99.8 percent of the miles they travel between cities, so the remaining 0.2 percent scarcely matters. Analysts at the Cato Institute calculate that even if Amtrak's trains disappeared from the relatively popular Northeast Corridor lines, there would be no need for extra flights (the air shuttles would simply use bigger planes), and each lane of the New Jersey Turnpike would have to accommodate at most 47 additional cars per hour -- just 2 percent of the lane's capacity.
For most Americans, trains are either unavailable or too inconvenient and expensive compared with planes or buses. Cutting the Sunset Limited might actually result in fewer trucks on the roads because it would be easier to ship freight by rail if Amtrak weren't given priority on the Union Pacific's tracks. What environmental or economic sense does it make to give 170 passengers on the Sunset Limited priority over a freight train that's keeping 500 trucks off the road? 
While Amtrak executives claim they need subsidies to counter the unfair competition from highways, the freight railroads have been operating profitably and gaining market share from trucks during the past decade. American freight railroads have been so successful that their biggest problem is congestion on the tracks. Their executives bitterly resent being forced to let Amtrak use their tracks at discount rates. In addition to complaining about the delays that result, they have been warning that it's dangerous to mix faster passenger trains with freight trains on congested tracks. 
The freight railroads, like the airlines and bus companies, were forced to become more efficient after their industry was deregulated. Would Amtrak's customers also benefit if the federal government stopped trying to control the passenger-train business? Congress could make a clean break by reviving a 19th-century tradition for dealing with failing railroads: liquidation of assets. That's the approach recommended by Joseph Vranich, a former spokesman for Amtrak who became its chief critic with a 1997 book titled "Derailed." He calls the railroad "a halfway house for bad managers." In conjunction with libertarians at the Cato Institute and the Reason Public Policy Institute, Vranich has proposed letting a court sell off Amtrak's assets and consider bids from public organizations, like regional transit agencies or consortiums of states, and also from private companies. Vranich, unlike some of his libertarian allies, doesn't mind the idea of continuing federal subsidies to the new owners of the tracks and trains. "But if we have to subsidize any passenger trains," he says, "let's get our money's worth."
A less radical reform for American trains would be to introduce competition gradually, as the Amtrak Reform Council recommended to Congress. Its plan would turn the Northeast Corridor over to a new public corporation, essentially a regional public agency run by state and federal officials. Amtrak would initially keep operating trains in the Northeast and elsewhere, but within several years, private and public competitors could be allowed to bid for routes.
Some optimists believe that short-distance trains in the Northeast and other densely populated corridors -- Southern California, Florida, parts of the Midwest and Texas -- could cover their operating expenses and possibly generate a profit if they were run by a private company freed of political constraints (like labor contracts dictated by Congress). Not even optimists, though, expect Amtrak's long-distance network to become profitable. Long-distance trains have been losing passengers to planes throughout the world, including Europe. Whatever reform or rescue gets through Congress may well involve shutting down some of the costlier trains, starting with the Sunset Limited. Yet even if the Sunset Limited no longer crosses the Southwest, there may still be solace for train buffs who want to see the desert in style. The new hope, as I discovered on my way home from California, is to reinvent another grand railroad tradition: Fred Harvey and the Harvey Girls.
When you board the American Orient Express, as I did in Los Angeles, the first clue that you're not on Amtrak comes in the lobby of the train station. A line of smiling porters in crisp blue-and-gold uniforms is waiting there, and they will not take no for an answer when they offer to carry your bag. They escort you to the train, a collection of half-century-old Streamliner sleepers and lounge cars with gleaming brass and rich mahogany. The trains were refurbished at a cost of $15 million during the 1980's in the mistaken belief that business travelers wanted a deluxe overnight train between Washington and Chicago. There weren't enough people with both the time and the expense accounts to support a regularly scheduled train. Only after that venture went bust did a new owner find a way to profit from long-distance train travel.
The secret was to go even slower than Amtrak. Our train would take 10 days to get from Los Angeles to Washington. It would meander on little-used tracks -- rare mileage," as foamers call it -- and stop along the way to let the passengers go sightseeing. We were on a "land cruise," a new term in the travel industry, although the concept wouldn't have seemed novel to 19th-century railroaders. The national parks in the West were created in large part because the railroads wanted to sell tickets to sightseers. The first stop on our trip, the Grand Canyon, became a tourist destination thanks to the Santa Fe Railroad. When we got off the train a few steps from the canyon, we were visiting not merely a natural wonder. To historians of the travel industry, to scholars of chain restaurants and hotels, this was the shrine to Fred Harvey, the great patron saint of tourists.
Until Harvey came along in the 1880's, service in the railroad industry was even worse than it is today on Amtrak. When the train stopped to get water for the steam engine, passengers would dash into a shack next to the tracks for a 20-minute meal of greasy, stale, often rancid food. Harvey, a freight agent on the Burlington Railroad, couldn't interest his own railroad in better meals, so he took his vision of a fast-food chain to the Santa Fe, which was then desperate to attract riders. After he took over restaurants along the Santa Fe's route, the railroad prospered with a new advertising slogan, "Meals by Fred Harvey."
To improve service, Harvey trained a crack corps of waitresses called Harvey Girls. At a time when it was said there were "no ladies west of Dodge City and no women west of Albuquerque," Harvey carefully recruited girls of "good character" and housed them in supervised dormitories. Dressed in starched aprons and high collars, they became Western icons of domestic virtue, inspiring a Judy Garland movie ("The Harvey Girls," with its Oscar-winning train song, "On the Atchison, Topeka & the Santa Fe") and a Will Rogers line: "They have kept the West supplied with food and wives." Harvey became renowned for paying his employees well while also terrifying them with surprise inspections. When he died in 1901, his last words to his sons were reported to be, "Don't cut the ham too thin."
After visiting El Tovar Hotel and the rest of Harvey's legacy at the Grand Canyon, I realized he wouldn't last long at Amtrak. The railroad has some wonderfully dedicated workers who love trains, but Amtrak has never figured out what to do with the ones just there for a paycheck. Even after its recent Service Success program sent the entire work force off for weekend training sessions, the ratings of customer satisfaction did not improve. 
But Fred Harvey would feel right at home on the American Orient Express. As we were heading away from the Grand Canyon, we sat down to dinner at tables decorated with flowers and set with china, silver and crystal. The four-course meal was prepared by Warren McLeod, a veteran of Manhattan's best restaurants. (His last job was as poissonier at Alain Ducasse.) His food was consistently great, but the biggest contrast with Amtrak was his attitude. Unlike the dining-car attendants on the Sunset Limited, he did not believe in ordering diners out of the car the minute he was scheduled to be off duty. When some stragglers showed up one morning just as breakfast was supposed to be ending, he immediately announced he'd be open for another hour. When I talked to him later, he couldn't understand my surprise.
"It was just common sense," he said. "Food is available all day long here. If you come to me and say, 'I've got a snacky thing going on,' I'll say, 'Give me 10 minutes, and I'm all over it.' "
The American Orient Express could afford service like this because it had three dozen workers taking care of just 80 passengers, whereas Amtrak had just a dozen or so staff members looking after the 170 passengers on my trip. Still, there isn't that much difference in the cost. The American Orient's basic fare -- covering meals and a shared room with a couch, two bunk beds, a sink and a small cubicle with a toilet -- was $3,990 per passenger, which sounds astronomical compared with the $660 it would cost for similar amenities on the Sunset Limited's transcontinental trip. But then, the trip on the Sunset Limited is only three days, whereas the luxury train keeps you fed and entertained for 11 days. The fare per day per passenger works out to $220 on Amtrak versus $363 on the luxury train, and remember, the fare on the Sunset Limited doesn't cover all of Amtrak's costs. The Sunset Limited loses an average of $115 per day per passenger. When you add that in, the cost per passenger on the Sunset Limited climbs to $335 per day, nearly the same as the fare on the luxury train. 
The American Orient Express is doing so well that it is refurbishing a second train and expanding its itineraries, adding trips through Mexico, the antebellum South, the Canadian Rockies and New England during foliage season. This summer a rival, the Acadian Railway Company, is starting similar trips from New York through Maine and Canada. So far the land-cruise business is still beyond most people's price range and appeals mainly to the elderly, but then that was the condition of the ocean-cruise business a couple of decades ago. Ship operators have since cut costs to attract the middle class as well as younger passengers, and train operators could probably do the same if the heavily subsidized competition from Amtrak didn't make it harder for them to build a larger customer base and achieve economies of scale. If Washington had reacted to the demise of the trans-Atlantic passenger ships by nationalizing ocean liners and subsidizing mediocre service, there'd be a lot fewer private cruise ships plying the waters.
I tried making these arguments to the train buffs on the American Orient Express. We were sitting on what we called the foamers' bench, a round settee, watching the Texas desert through the wraparound windows at the rear of the train. The view couldn't have been lovelier, and we were thrilled to think that this very observation car had once been part of the fabled Twentieth Century Limited, but my companions wanted more. "I love this train, but I want Amtrak too," said Karl Zimmermann, a railroad historian who was one of the lecturers on board. "I like a working train that's taking me from one place to another. I don't want to just have cruises." 
I said it's not fair to have taxpayers subsidize our hobby, but my conviction wavered when the conductor came by and mentioned an upcoming sight. The reason we were pulling into a siding, he said, was to make way for the Sunset Limited, which was coming from the opposite direction on this stretch of single track. 
I dashed to the vestibule and leaned out to watch the distant locomotive approaching. Bracing for the roar, for another gaga choochoo moment, I wondered if this would be the last time I would ever see this train. Was the Sunset Limited going literally and figuratively into the sunset? I was preparing to mourn the end of a tradition as the last car disappeared into the West, but I didn't get the chance. The Sunset Limited ingloriously coasted to a halt right alongside us. 
"They've lost their head-in power," our conductor said. As we pulled out of the siding, the Sunset Limited was still sitting out there in the sagebrush baking in the midday heat. It was not the romantic last glimpse I was hoping for, but maybe that's just as well. Sometimes a foamer needs to see that Amtrak is going nowhere. All it's doing is blocking the tracks.

An article and a headline on Sunday about the conviction of the Arthur Andersen auditing firm on a charge of obstruction of justice and an entry in the News Summary referred incorrectly in some copies to the rationale for the jury's decision.
