HEADLINE: Census Finds Rising Tide, And Many Who Missed Boat 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
If the lingering question about the economic boom of the late 1990's remains how widely or narrowly were the winnings shared, the answer has long been expected to lie in the 2000 census data on income and poverty.
 But as the numbers began rolling out in recent weeks, they struck some people as counterintuitive: Amid the longest peacetime expansion ever, median income actually dropped and poverty rose in a handful of surprising places. 
 Now demographers and economists are using those data and others to piece together a picture of who made a killing, who merely got ahead and who fell behind, and to figure out why a few places widely assumed to have flourished now look as though they did not.
These things are certain. Nationwide, prosperity increased during the decade; incomes rose and poverty in most places declined. And, economists and sociologists say, the gains landed disproportionately in the laps of a small fraction of Americans already exceptionally well off. 
Inequality increased, as it has since the late 1970's, but at a slower rate nationally than in the 1980's, some experts said. Other data suggest, according to one economist, that the percentage of families earning less than $25,000 dropped significantly in the second half of the 1990's.
The fate of people in the middle seems less clear-cut. While the median household income rose in the Northwest, South, Midwest and Southwest, it dropped in parts of the New York metropolitan area, in some other Northeastern cities and in swaths of Southern California.
Many experts suspect immigration helps explain those patterns. As low-wage workers poured in from places like Central America in pursuit of a better life, the midpoint on the income spectrum in some places with large foreign-born populations may have, paradoxically, inched down. At the same time, native-born people moved out -- from the New York region to the Southeast, from Los Angeles to places like Nevada, some demographers say. Though those people may have moved up economically by moving away, their departures may have helped lower the median in the places they left behind.
"You see how the arithmetic works?" asked Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "When you have a lot of people entering from the rest of the world, and many of them enter at the lower rungs of the wage distribution, then you can have a situation where everyone is prospering and the median income is declining."
But immigration is not the only possible explanation. Americans may tend to forget that the decade began with a recession; incomes for many people declined in the early 1990's and poverty increased. In some places, like the New York region, the recovery did not begin until the second half of the decade. Only late in the 1990's did median income catch up and exceed the 1989 levels.
"Between 1989 and 1993, there's a big drop in median income," said Edward N. Wolff, a professor of economics at New York University who specializes in income and wealth inequality. "It wasn't until 1998 that things got back to where they were in 1989. So by 2000, median income was a bit ahead of where it was 10 years ago, but not much."
At the same time, the job base shifted in some places; lower-wage jobs replaced higher-wage ones. When defense spending shrank and aerospace-industry jobs in Southern California dwindled, what took root were jobs in the garment industry and service sector, said Bruce Katz, director of the Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy at Brookings.
"All of us here have been trying to figure out what do these regional variations mean," Mr. Katz said. "How much of it is attributable to the demographic shifts that are happening in these metropolitan areas and how much is attributable to the underlying economy?"
Then there are those who have doubts about the data itself. 
Eric Kober, director of housing, economic and infrastructure planning for the New York City Department of Planning, described as "extremely counterintuitive" the census's finding that the percentage of people in the civilian labor force and the percentage of people employed actually declined nationally and especially in New York City.
Mr. Kober said that the census data for the 25 biggest cities showed that the percentage of people employed tended to drop most in cities with large numbers of foreign-born residents while the rate increased in affluent cities with lower percentages of foreign-born people, like Denver and Columbus, Ohio. 
Mr. Kober suggests that the numbers are wrong. He traces the problem to what he says is a growing unwillingness by people in certain groups to answer the detailed income questions on the census long form. He contends that the data underestimate employment and income in places like Los Angeles and New York City, where median income dropped in four boroughs.
"They may be skewing the national data and accounting for this situation we're seeing, where there is a 50 percent decline in welfare nationally and yet a decline in the percentage of adults working," he said. "It can't be."
On average, median household income rose by nearly $3,000 nationally between the 1990 and 2000 censuses. The states with the biggest increases ranged from Colorado and Oregon to Mississippi. Those with the smallest increases included California, New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia. In Connecticut, on average, median household income dropped.
William H. Frey, a demographer at the University of Michigan, sorts the states roughly into three types: "Mature melting-pot states" with large number of foreign-born who make relatively low wages, like New York and California; "emerging growth states" in the South and West, growing through domestic migration; and "heartland states" attracting few immigrants and losing domestic migrants. 
In the melting-pot states like California, Professor Frey sees a "barbell economy" with growth at the bottom and the top and a thinning out for the group in the middle. In the emerging growth states, like Colorado, incomes were strongly up. In the heartland states, incomes rose moderately as the aging baby boomers who dominate those places moved into their high-earning years.
Even within some states and metropolitan areas, there is considerable variation. In California, median income declines were heavily concentrated in the Los Angeles region, in counties including Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside and San Bernardino. In sharp contrast, there were big increases in median income in counties in the San Francisco Bay area and around Silicon Valley.
In many places with big increases, the gains went disproportionately to people in the top fifth of the income spectrum, according to Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociologist at Queens College who analyzed the census data for The New York Times. People at the top gained the most and people at the middle and bottom gained considerably less.
In San Francisco County, for example, where the median household income rose by $11,854, to $55,221, the income of people in the top fifth of the income spectrum rose by $33,584, to $117,730, Professor Beveridge found. The income of the people in the bottom fifth rose by $3,374, to $21,153. The income of people in the middle rose by $16,961, to $70,470.
"Most of the prosperity has gone into the hands of the rich," said Professor Wolff of N.Y.U., citing his own findings from other data. "The top 20 percent did well in the 90's. And even among that group, it's the top 1 percent that made out like bandits."
He said the pattern was especially pronounced in New York state. Citing city and state statistics, he ascribes the pattern to two things: the high concentration of New Yorkers working in industries like finance that did especially well in the 1990's, and the abundance of others working in low-wage service-sector jobs catering to the first group's needs.
"For every investment banker, you have one or two delivery men to feed them during their long working hours," Professor Wolff said. "So, in a sense, the high-income group in the city also creates this low-income group. It's a sort of symbiotic relationship."
Though it is not possible to draw conclusions about economic and social mobility based on the census data released so far, Jared Bernstein, a senior economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research organization in Washington, said other data he had studied suggested that the rate of movement out of the lowest income categories picked up in the late 1990's.
Comparing the 1980's with the 1990's, he said, "These were both eras wherein economic growth was not shared equally. But in the 1990's, the latter half especially, families were more prosperous throughout the income scale. It didn't reverse the tide of inequality. It just slowed it down, to some degree."

PERSON: Robert Whitehead 

HEADLINE: Robert Whitehead, Who Brought Top Playwrights to Broadway, Dies at 86 

BYLINE:  By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Robert Whitehead, the debonair and distinguished theatrical producer, who refused to let questions of economics take precedence over his artistic standards yet still managed to be a successful businessman, died Saturday at his home in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 86 and also had a home in Manhattan.
 When Broadway celebrated Mr. Whitehead's 80th birthday in 1996, the evening was titled "Mister Class," a reference to "Master Class," the Terrence McNally play that he produced (starring his wife, Zoe Caldwell, as Maria Callas). In Broadway terminology, Mr. Whitehead was considered a class act, the opposite of razzle-dazzle. During his nearly 60 years in show business, he presented some of the 20th century's most important playwrights on Broadway and was a quiet, assertive force, often a mediator and a man with impeccable taste. 
 As Arthur Miller said in his autobiography, "Timebends," Mr. Whitehead was one of "a handful of producers . . . who longed for artistically ambitious and socially interesting plays and could put their money where their mouth was." 
During the last half of the 20th century, Mr. Whitehead's name on a play (often with Roger L. Stevens as his partner) was an assurance of quality, and, unlike so many other producers, Mr. Whitehead dared to take chances. He presented plays by Mr. Miller, Tennessee Williams, Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Carson McCullers, Friedrich Durrenmatt, Jean Anouilh and Robert Bolt, and in most cases he was an integral part of the creative process, involved in everything from the script to the casting to the promotion of the play once it had opened.
With his mustache and carefully combed hair, Mr. Whitehead had the suave look of a 1940's matinee idol (like Douglas Fairbanks Jr. or Errol Flynn), although Williams told him he thought he looked like a riverboat gambler. As he aged, he began to look more like a diplomat, which, of course, was the role that he habitually played offstage in the theater world. 
Mr. Whitehead was born in Montreal on March 3, 1916. His father, William Thomas Whitehead, owned textile mills. His mother, Lena Mary LaBatt Whitehead, an opera singer, came from the family that owned the LaBatt brewery. Mr. Whitehead's cousin, on the LaBatt side, was Hume Cronyn, who was older by five years. The cousins spent summers together and played theater games when they were children. 
"I always had the heroic role," Mr. Cronyn once said, "and he always ended up in the cellar, which was the jail or dungeon." In his 1991 memoir, "A Terrible Liar," Mr. Cronyn praised Mr. Whitehead as "one of the most distinguished and respected theatrical producers in the English-speaking world." He had employed numerous actors, Mr. Cronyn wrote, "but with a gross lack of familial feeling and a marvelous evasiveness, he has always managed to avoid employing me." Tongue in cheek, he said the fruit cellar experience was being held against him. Actually in 1986 Mr. Whitehead was a producer of "The Petition" starring Mr. Cronyn and Jessica Tandy.

Tentatively Choosing a Career
 After attending Trinity College School in Montreal, Mr. Whitehead came to New York to work in the theater without a clear idea about which path to choose. His good looks landed him roles as an actor. Briefly he went to acting school, and in 1938 he began his career at the Barter Theater in Abingdon, Va. He acted, worked as a stage manager and built scenery. As he recalled, "I was haunted by the question of whether I had any talent for any aspect of the theater -- or was this a vagabond escape from responsible activities?" 
With World War II on the horizon, he said, "The hope and excitement of a life in the theater began to seem unproductive, unimportant and selfish." Then he read an essay by Harold Clurman, the director and critic, and it enlarged his respect for the theater as a collaborative, even noble profession. Clurman's words suggesting that theater "must be a vital conversation with society" lifted Mr. Whitehead's spirit and gave him "an understanding and an impetus that have informed my commitment ever since." Ten years later, the two met and eventually worked together on 14 productions, a partnership that helped sustain Broadway as a place for serious drama.
In 1942 Mr. Whitehead enlisted in the American Field Service and became an ambulance driver in North Africa and, later, Italy. Returning to New York after the war, he decided to become a producer, at first in collaboration with Oliver Rea, whom he had met in the United States Army.
During the summer of 1947, while acting with Bert Lahr in "Burlesque" in Marblehead, Mass., he read the Robinson Jeffers version of "Medea" and decided to produce it. That year, when Mr. Whitehead was 31, he took the play to Broadway in a production starring Judith Anderson and John Gielgud. At first, Gielgud had agreed only to direct, but Mr. Whitehead quickly persuaded him also to undertake the role of Jason.
Then, again with Mr. Gielgud (as Raskolnikov, playing opposite Lillian Gish and Dolly Haas), Mr. Whitehead produced a dramatization of Dostoyevsky's "Crime and Punishment." Because both plays were successes, he became known as a man who could make art work in the marketplace. In 1950 he said: "Broadway has the idea that things are either commercial or art. Actually all real art is commercial. I have never seen a really artistic play that failed, unless it was badly done."
In contrast with larger-than-life competitors like David Merrick, Mr. Whitehead did not naturally lend himself to anecdotes, or to controversy. The stories that surrounded him were usually ones of gentle persuasion. For example, there is the case of Carson McCullers's "Member of the Wedding," a modest and wistful play about the awakening of youth. This was the first collaboration between Mr. Whitehead and Clurman as producer and director.
Daringly, he cast Julie Harris, who was 24 and at the beginning of her career, in the central role of the 12-year-old Frankie Addams. One very important role remained open: Berenice, the black cook who was the pillar of this Southern family. Mr. Whitehead decided he wanted Ethel Waters, the blues singer and musical actress.
As the story goes, he tracked her down in a second-rate nightclub in Detroit and returned with her to her room in a boarding house. She said, "Every night I get on my knees by that bed and pray that God will send me a good booking." "Miss Waters," Mr. Whitehead said, "I have a good booking." She hesitated about playing the role because "there is no God in this play." 
Before she accepted the part, she said that instead of singing the Russian lullaby mentioned in the script, she wanted to sing something of her own choice. To an audience of Mr. Whitehead and Ms. Harris, she sang "His Eye Is on the Sparrow." When it was over, Ms. Harris cried, as theatergoers were to do at that moment when the play was on Broadway. That song later became the title of Miss Waters's autobiography. 
The third major role was that of 7-year-old John Henry West. Unable to find a suitable child actor, Mr. Whitehead and Clurman remembered that Fritz de Wilde, an actor in the company (later the stage manager), had a son the correct age. Without previous training, Brandon de Wilde read for the role and was hired.
Although Clurman was the director, he had the audacity to write about the production in "The New Republic," while disclaiming that it was actually a review. In it he credited Mr. Whitehead with believing that it was possible for the play to be a box office success: "Fortunately, there are producers like Robert Whitehead and his associates who are eager to face real theatrical problems because they think of them not primarily in the light of 'investments' but as objects of their love . . . it is only through such love that good theater, and ultimately good business, can be made."
Mr. Whitehead returned the compliment. He said that the director had "set a blazing fire" and that "the actors feel they are embarking on a voyage of danger and magnificence that will bring them into a realm of acting they have never achieved before."

A Five-Star Year
Mr. Whitehead and Clurman worked together on "The Waltz of the Toreadors" (with Ralph Richardson), "Bus Stop" (with Kim Stanley) and "A Touch of the Poet" (with Helen Hayes and Ms. Stanley), among other plays. In 1957, Mr. Whitehead was represented by five plays on Broadway: "Separate Tables," "Orpheus Descending," "The Waltz of the Toreadors," "A Hole in the Head" and "Major Barbara," and only one of them, "A Hole in the Head," could be considered a standard commercial offering.
At other times, he presented Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in "The Visit" by Friedrich Durrenmatt, Katharine Hepburn in "A Matter of Gravity" and "The West Side Waltz" and Paul Scofield in Robert Bolt's "Man for All Seasons" (which won a Tony Award as best play).
After Mr. Whitehead's wife, Virginia, died (in 1965), Mr. Cronyn introduced him to Zoe Caldwell, the Australian actress who was appearing with Mr. Cronyn at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. They were married in 1968. Studiously Mr. Whitehead tried to keep their careers separate, but when he was producing "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," a friend suggested that Ms. Caldwell should play the title role. Ms. Caldwell went on to win a Tony Award as best actress. Years later, he directed her in a revival of "Medea" and in "Lillian," a one-woman play about Lillian Hellman.

Lincoln Center Disappointment
In 1960 Mr. Whitehead and Elia Kazan were named to head the first Lincoln Center theater company. They seemed to be natural choices, Mr. Whitehead as a producer with an instinct for art, Mr. Kazan as a director with a long string of successes. With Clurman as literary adviser, the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater opened in 1964 with "After the Fall," a new play by Arthur Miller, directed by Mr. Kazan and starring Jason Robards. Since construction had not been completed at Lincoln Center, the play was presented in the company's temporary headquarters at the ANTA Washington Square Theater.
Despite all the anticipation -- partly because of the anticipation -- the play proved to be a disappointment, although it did well at the box office. The record did not improve with the subsequent Lincoln Center productions, Eugene O'Neill's "Marco Millions," S. N. Behrman's "But for Whom Charlie," "The Changeling" (Mr. Kazan's first attempt at staging a Jacobean classic) and Mr. Miller's "Incident at Vichy." After one season, and following a clash with George Woods, chairman of the theater's board, Mr. Whitehead and Mr. Kazan found themselves forced to leave their positions.
In his autobiography, "A Life," Mr. Kazan said, "So the effort to set up a repertory theater in New York's Lincoln Center, which had started with a burst of energy and hope, ended with falsehoods and the crunch of disgrace." Leaving Lincoln Center was a major setback for Mr. Whitehead. In the years that followed, he did not speak about it publicly. But he never lost his zest for presenting serious theater, and he was soon back on Broadway.
He continued his collaboration with Mr. Miller, as a producer of "The Price," "The Creation of the World and Other Business," the revival of "Death of a Salesman," starring Dustin Hoffman, and "Broken Glass." He was also one of the producers of Harold Pinter's "No Man's Land" (starring John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson) and "Betrayal" and Tom Stoppard's "Artist Descending a Staircase."
In addition to his wife, he is survived by his sons, Sam, who is a theater critic, and Charlie, who is in theater production. Funeral services will be private.
This month Mr. Whitehead was given a special Tony Award, which he added to the array of honors he had accumulated during his lifetime in the theater.
After the deaths of his rivals David Merrick and Alexander Cohen in 2000, Mr. Whitehead was the last surviving major producer from Broadway's heyday. In an interview in The New York Times, he was asked if producers ever retired. His answer was a definite no. He said, "We always feel there might be another show that will give us that kick."

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of the Broadway producer Robert Whitehead on June 17 misstated the location of Trinity College School, the secondary school he attended. It is in Port Hope, Ontario, not Montreal.

HEADLINE: Company's Ills Further Deflate Buffalo's Hopes 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: BUFFALO 

 BODY:
Finally, for this luck-challenged Rust Belt city, it appeared fortune was shining.
 A big company was not only moving in 1,000 jobs -- after decades of corporate flight -- but it planned to build a 15-story office tower to boot. And not just anywhere, but right on the waterfront, making the building a gleaming catalyst to jump-start the moribund heart of the city. 
 "They were the biggest new player to come to town in years," said Andrew J. Rudnick, president of the Buffalo Niagara Partnership, a business trade group.
As luck would have it, the conquering hero was Adelphia Communications. And as the company, the sixth-largest cable system in the nation, sits in the cross hairs of investigations and tries to fend off bankruptcy, people here have taken to calling the mess "Buffalo's Enron." 
The Securities and Exchange Commission and two federal grand juries are investigating Adelphia after it disclosed off-the-books lending of more than $3 billion to its founder, John J. Rigas, his family and Rigas-controlled companies. Mr. Rigas, whom The Buffalo News in 2001 called the city's "most powerful and effective business leader," and other family members gave up control of the company in May. Analysts say a bankruptcy filing is imminent.
Few people here, apart from Adelphia executives, now believe the $125 million tower will ever be built. Many worry about the hundreds of jobs that Adelphia has already created here, if the company declares bankruptcy and breaks apart. They have given up on Mr. Rigas's dream of turning Buffalo into the second headquarters for his Pennsylvania company.
And, as if to dig the dagger into the city's heart a bit deeper, it happens that the Rigases own the beloved Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League, giving rise to fears in this sports-mad town that the family may have to sell the team to outsiders to help climb out of the financial morass. That, Mayor Anthony M. Masiello said, "would be devastating to the psyche and image of this city."
Civic leaders say they have already lined up unnamed local investors to buy the Sabres if the Rigases have to sell, and N.H.L. officials say they want a team in Buffalo as long as fans keep supporting it. (About 70 percent of season tickets have already been sold for the 2002-03 season.) 
The city's latest bad turn has been greeted here with either a collective shrug -- Buffalo hurting? What else is new? -- or dismay at yet another rut on the long comeback trail from job loss and blight.
"It's one more nail in Buffalo's coffin," said Aaron Platz, 30, a Buffalo resident, alluding to a litany of troubles that includes the layoffs of more than 300 teachers and school administrators in 2001 and a steady decline in population that has left the city with 292,000 people, half of its peak in the 1950's.
Todd Parmington, 45, the chief executive of a wholesale distribution firm, seemed resigned to the city's taking one step forward and two steps back. "It's yet another piece of bad news for an area that I believe has become immune to bad news," he said.
Yet people here seem to have a harder time believing the bad news about the Rigas family. In John Rigas (pronounced RIG-iss), the city believed it had found a savior it could relate to.
The son of Greek immigrants from Wellsville, N.Y., 70 miles south of here, Mr. Rigas, 77, built his cable television empire from scratch, starting in 1952 with a small company in western Pennsylvania that eventually expanded to western New York. It has claimed 5.8 million subscribers in 31 states and Puerto Rico, but recently disclosed financial data suggesting it may have inflated that figure by about 200,000.
The Rigas success story captured the fancy of this city of immigrants and blue-collar workers, and in interviews over the years Mr. Rigas said he always felt a connection to Buffalo, where he attended church in his boyhood. Sabres fans took to the tall, white-haired man who mixed with the everyday folks in the nosebleed seats at the team's arena, across the street from a parking lot where he had proposed the office tower.
Mr. Rigas first bought a stake in the Sabres in 1994 and got controlling interest in the team in July 2000, a month after he reached a deal with the city and state to build the office tower for a regional headquarters in Buffalo, the company's second corporate home after Coudersport, Pa.
Sports fans hoped Mr. Rigas would stabilize the financially precarious Sabres; Adelphia's undisclosed loans include $130 million to a Rigas-controlled partnership that owns the team.
City and state leaders, meanwhile, saw the Adelphia tower as an even bigger boon to western New York, where the decades-long collapse of the manufacturing base has left the region in economic shambles. The Buffalo area, once known for its industrial might, has lost more than half of its factory employment since 1958, dropping to 88,700 industrial jobs today from 194,300 in 1958. 
When the tower project was announced in June 2000, Adelphia promised to create 1,000 new jobs -- and came through with at least 800, deploying them in buildings in and around Buffalo -- to support its expanding fiber optic and cable network. The city and state answered with tax breaks and other incentives, including $50 million the state offered to develop the office tower.
Mayor Masiello called the tower project a "monumental economic development achievement." Gov. George E. Pataki flew in for the announcement and said it would "launch this region's economic renaissance into the 21st century."
These days, despite doubts here and on Wall Street, Adelphia's official stance is that a building is still in the works. "Our short- and long-range plans call for a significant work force based in Buffalo," the company said in a statement.
But that view is not shared by state and city officials. A call to the governor's office was referred to the Empire State Development Agency, whose chairman, Charles A. Gargano, lamented the expected loss of the building, but said, "The governor is strongly committed to ensuring the $50 million remains in Buffalo for economic development initiatives."
Mayor Masiello said waterfront development would continue. Improvements are being made to parks, buildings are being converted to housing, and there are plans for a retail and business center for the Sabres' old arena, now abandoned. The city is also banking heavily on a proposed Indian-run casino downtown, provided a state law adopted last fall stands up to court challenges.
"We are not standing still, holding our breath," the mayor said.
Some Buffalo leaders still hold out hope that another corporate suitor will come calling and deliver the tower. "I see this potential crisis as an opportunity," said Joel A. Giambra, the Erie County executive.
But real estate analysts are skeptical. "There aren't an awful lot of people begging to bring companies, the big ones, in here," said Howard Saperston Jr., a real estate executive here since 1963.
Many Buffalonians weather their city's ups and downs with equal reserves of pride and skepticism. This is why people like Bill Slater, 62, a taxi driver and lifelong resident, can in one breath extol the virtues of his city -- close-knit families, a can-do spirit tested with every winter storm, fine colleges -- and in the next question whether it will ever get better.
Standing on a downtown street where "you can roll bowling balls down here at night and not hit nothing," Mr. Slater said he always had his doubts that Adelphia could turn things around. "My gut feeling is, it's tough to put up a building like that with the city on its heels," he said.
But like so many Buffalonians, he has not given up.
"Someone is going to buy that company and turn it around," he said. "And Buffalo will come out all right. Well, I hope."

A map yesterday with an article about the effect of Adelphia Communications' financial problems on Buffalo, where the company proposed to build an office tower, gave an outdated name for a ballpark near the site. It is Dunn Tire Park, no longer North AmeriCare Park.

HEADLINE: Tourists Discover the Mainstay of Artists and Students: Hostels 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
There is a block in Times Square that Disney never got to. On that block, Osamu Kawahara runs what could be considered a pleasant New York accommodation. It has elegant hardwood floors, lovely interior windows and umbrellas that are given out on the honor system. The rooms are neat and private, and the furniture is shiny.
 To get there, though, one must walk south of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, past an all-night liquor store known for serving customers of all ages, a gaggle of homeless people, a pack of rats and a couple of stinky, smoky garages. Mr. Kawahara runs a hostel, a form of housing that has traditionally served as the temporary home of New York's struggling artists, visiting students and others who consider cheapness an important amenity. And lately, his 16 beds have rarely been empty. 
 The one thing his guests seem to agree attracted them to the hostel, Times Square Beds and Rooms, near Eighth Avenue on West 40th Street, is the price: $38 a night, plus taxes, and a minor assault on the visual and olfactory senses on the way. 
There is little doubt that since the global economic recession began last year, hostels and other hotel alternatives, from apartment swapping to staying with friends and relatives, have become a much more popular way to spend a day, weekend or month in Manhattan. 
"Immediately after Sept. 11 we had about 80 cancellations," Mr. Kawahara said. "Since then, we have seen many more middle-class people and couples who are from Japan or Europe who want to stay in a hostel, even though hotels are offering sharp discounts."
A steady stream of tourists have returned to New York in recent months. But hotel owners estimate that their revenues have not increased at the same pace as the people-per-square-inch on the streets of Times Square, in part because tourists are looking for cheaper alternatives to expensive hotel rooms.
For instance, those in the apartment-swapping business report that more guests are looking to trade with New Yorkers. And at hostels like the Chelsea Star Hostel, where Madonna stayed as a struggling musician in 1981 and 1982, middle-class Europeans are among the largest group of visitors. And some foreign business travelers have been choosing the Union Square Inn, which has cable television and maid service, over the chic W Hotel a few blocks away.
Hotel occupancy in Manhattan in April was 75.6 percent, down 2 percent from the same month last year, according to PFK Consulting. Average room rates in April were $191.75, down 11 percent from a year ago.
According to a survey of 56 hotels conducted by the city's convention and visitor's bureau, NYC & Company, advance booking information suggests that the occupancy rate will be around 72 percent in July, or 1.6 percentage points lower than the same month last year. The survey forecasts occupancy rates of 76.7 percent in August, down 2.4 percentage points from last year. Some of that decrease, tourism officials say, can be attributed to penny-pinching tourists who choose to come but stay in less expensive accommodations.
Support for this argument is mostly anecdotal and comes mainly from hostel owners who say that on average their occupancy levels are at or about 2 to 3 percentage points higher than what they were at this time last year.
Among such occupants are people like William and Robin Korb, of Chippewa Falls, Wis., who stayed this month at the Big Apple Hostel, on West 45th Street near Avenue of the Americas, a stone's throw from the Marriott hotel in Times Square. They were packed in a cramped dormitory-style room with their three daughters, Alex, Gabrielle and Rachel, and two of Rachel's friends and fellow Girl Scouts, Kristina Wolff and Lauren Berg.
On a recent afternoon Big Apple's lobby looked as if it could have been the set for a United Colors of Benetton ad: there was a stylishly dressed student from Japan, a man with dreadlocks and a German woman in bright red pants. The rooms have only bunk beds, guests bring their own linens, maid service is not an option and the only amenity appeared to be a deck on the rear of the place.
Still, Mr. Korb was not shy about his reasons for staying at the hostel: "It was incredible that we could be that close to where everything was happening for that price," he said.
The Korbs paid $33 per person per night, or $1,155 for five nights. A room with a single bed at the nearby Marriott is about $259 a night. Big Apple's self-described front desk guy, Tony Santiago, explains the interest in hostels with a story about a recent customer, "a well-to-do Australian woman" who figured she had saved $300 by staying at the hostel rather than a hotel. "Imagine all the shoes I can buy for $300," he recalled her saying. "And she did buy a lot of shoes," he said. "That is all she was in New York for."
Mr. Santiago said he thought that middle-class American and foreign visitors had finally discovered hostels as the inexpensive alternative to hotels that student travelers have long known them to be.
"Why would you pay so much money to be in Times Square?" he said. "You are not going to find anything for $33 a night in Times Square that is going to be clean and absent of bums and drug addicts."
Hostels are not the only businesses thought be benefiting from more cost-conscious consumers. 
On craigslist.org, a Web site that offers classified-ad listings for several cities, the number of apartments available for swapping in New York has more than doubled, to 54,605 in April 2002, up from 17,583 in August 2001.
Craig Newark, the founder of craigslist.org, said he is seeing about 300 apartment swap postings a week in New York. "For summer, we are on an incline, and it is rising on a very steep climb," he said.
Heidi Dubose, a German immigrant who has lived in New York with her American husband for two decades, has two spacious, furnished one-bedroom apartments in a building on Fulton Street in Lower Manhattan that she rents to out-of-town visitors on vacation or on business. Lately, she said, she has had no trouble filling the apartments, which she rents for $185 to $285 a night, even though they are only blocks from ground zero. 
"People started coming back to the area when the Ritz-Carlton and the Marriott opened," Ms. Dubose said, adding that business is as good as it was last year, which is much better than she expected. "But many people are looking for something that is less expensive and more private - they are willing to give up the amenities of room service and daily cleaning." Similar rooms at the Ritz-Carlton, for example, are running for about $400 a night. 
Whitney Gaylord and a friend decided that they did not want to pay a penny to stay in New York this summer. So they swapped their one-bedroom Paris flat for an apartment in Washington Heights. 
"Money is definitely a factor," she added. "You have to ask yourself, 'Why sublet or stay in a hotel when you can swap for free?' " 
At Times Square Beds and Rooms, Mr. Kawahara said he was so busy he was considering cutting back on advertising and just letting his business grow by word of mouth. Business has been so good, he said, that he has started to limit his patrons only to foreign guests who make advance reservations over the Internet.
"I am surprised," he said. "With the economic troubles and Sept. 11, I thought for sure that this would be a bad year. I am so surprised - but we are actually talking to our landlord about starting another hostel in a building he wants to buy downtown."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many tourists are finding hostels, like the Big Apple Hostel, above, an affordable way to visit New York City. (Mike Nagle/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
2 Agencies Shut Offices As Work Falls Off

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Two agencies are closing offices.
 Arnold Worldwide in Boston is closing its San Francisco office, citing the continued weak advertising economy there. 
 The top two executives of the office -- Jim McGinn, president, and Stu Cooperrider, creative director -- will return to the Arnold headquarters in Boston, in jobs to be determined. 
Work for remaining clients like Gulf Lubricants and Keynote Software will be completed in the next few weeks and then the 17 other employees of the office will be laid off.
The closing of the office, which became part of Arnold when Arnold acquired Ingalls Moranville in 1999, does not affect the offices of sibling agencies like Arnold MPG, for media, and Magnet, for public relations. Arnold, Arnold MPG and Magnet are all units of Havas.
Also, Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, is closing its office in Fort Worth, as a client, the Texas Dairy Queen Operators Council, shifts its account to Loomis in Dallas. Eleven employees are being laid off.
The Fort Worth office became part of Grey in 1998 when Grey acquired the council's agency, Regian & Wilson. At the closing, the office had billings estimated at less than $5 million; its remaining account, Pro-Cuts, is being resigned. Grey continues to handle the worldwide account of International Dairy Queen, part of Berkshire Hathaway, from its Los Angeles and New York offices.

 BODY:
Andersen Verdict Offers Clues for Enron Inquiry
Evidence at the Arthur Andersen trial appears to indicate that a decision promoted by Andrew S. Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer, was crucial in its downfall. Investigators are exploring the matter, as crucial facts in Enron's collapse continue to emerge.
 The jury's Andersen verdict turned solely on the work of Nancy Temple, a lawyer who told a friend that she was taking a job at the accounting firm as a way to get a "balanced life." Section A.

Tyzx, a technology company in Palo Alto, Calif., is working on technology that will give computers the ability to see. C4

A Snapshot of the Nasdaq
Many companies have proclaimed that their annual reports this year disclose more financial information than ever before. But that is not a trend being followed by the Nasdaq, a company that wants to go public. Nasdaq's report, however, does have page after page of photographs, and there is no shortage of slogans. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C2.

Questions Surround Domain Names
A Senate subcommittee is examining whether the organization that manages the Internet's address system is carrying out its mission. The questions that have emerged echoed those of other investigations: how to deal with an entity operating largely in obscurity, mired in bureaucracy and in desperate need of more effective oversight. One Element but Two Patents
A new patent has been issued for an insomnia drug even though the drug is based on a chemical compound covered by another patent. HEADLINE: A Nation in Search of Its Mission 

BYLINE:  By David Gergen; David Gergen is director of the Center for Public Leadership at the Kennedy School at Harvard and editor at large of U.S. News & World Report. He served as a White House adviser to four presidents.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
President Bush deserves praise for proposing to create a new architecture for homeland security, a reversal of his earlier position. And he will win acclaim if -- in reversing his previous hands-off stance on the Middle East conflict -- he settles differences within his team and produces a solid plan for that conflict. Too many presidents in the past have stubbornly clung to their ideas, refusing to adjust to changing circumstances and forcing the country to pay a cruel price. Remember Woodrow Wilson? Hoover? L.B.J.?
 Give credit to Mr. Bush for adaptive leadership. But there is a big challenge that has so far received short shrift and needs a fresh look: the creation of a new sense of purpose in our national life. How can we transform the good will and willingness to sacrifice since Sept. 11 into meaningful and lasting changes in our communities and culture? Nine months after the attacks, our opportunity on that civic front is rapidly slipping away. 
 Most of us have become mere spectators in the war on terrorism. While anxiety about a second strike remains high in big cities along the coasts, I find in travels to the interior of the country that people have generally returned to their daily routines, leaving the struggle to others. The ups and downs of war have become something one follows in the newspapers, just like the stock market. Of course people are rooting for more victories -- indeed, they are rooting for the president, too -- but their level of engagement is low. Some polls show that worries over the economy, education and health care are crowding out concerns about the war.
Now that the debate in Washington has become focused on intelligence failures, most people have become even more disengaged, viewing the bureaucratic restructuring as having very little to do with them. At the same time, there is no call for common sacrifice from either the White House or Congress. As the political columnist Mark Shields points out, this is the first major war since the United States-Mexico war of 1846 that America has fought without having a draft or a tax increase. While more than 3,000 Americans were killed in the Sept. 11 attacks, the rest of us now face little more than inconvenience when we travel. There are no blood drives, no rationing and fewer enlistments in the armed forces than were expected. (Inquiries about military service spiked upward after the attacks, but actual enlistments have remained relatively flat.) 
Our greatest leaders recognized that in order to mobilize support for a long war, they must not only demand common sacrifice but link it to a galvanizing vision of what life would be like after the guns were silenced. Washington could afford to lose more battles than he won because his fellow colonists believed that with victory, they would become a free people. Lincoln sustained support during many a dark moment by kindling dreams of a lasting union and more liberty. In 1941, as war approached, Roosevelt called for universal sacrifice from business, labor and agriculture and laid out his vision of a world with Four Freedoms. His 1944 State of the Union address called for a "second Bill of Rights" for all Americans -- an audacious economic plan that guided the Democratic and some Republican presidents for the next half-century.
Demands for sacrifice and a vision of what can come afterward are fundamental to wartime leadership. Mr. Bush can still demonstrate that leadership by linking present sacrifice with a better future in several ways. He can, for example, roll back his tax cuts and propose that the savings be redirected toward a broad social cause like improving the lives of children. If the war is about securing their safety, after all, why should we not be equally concerned about securing their health and education? Why not seize this moment to make the war about something positive, instead of allowing it to be focused exclusively on how we ward off the negative?
The president obviously cherishes the tax cuts, but along with the string of giveaways in Congress to farmers and others, Washington is sending a clear signal to the public that this war is painless and that we can have a war and life as usual. Not only is this untrue, but it does little credit to Mr. Bush. Only by insisting on the same discipline at home as on the international front will he be able to gain for himself and his political party lasting appeal with the American voters.
He can do even more to invigorate our spirit if he alters direction and embraces universal national service -- setting up programs that ask all eligible young people between 18 and 24 to spend at least a year in civilian or military service. To his credit, Mr. Bush has already started down this road, calling for creation of a USA Freedom Corps, and he continues to call for volunteerism in his public speeches. But a close look at the president's program reveals that it would reach only a tiny fraction of the young. His administration would fund an increase in the Peace Corps from 7,000 to 14,000 participants and an increase in Americorps from 50,000 to 75,000. 
But the census shows that the number of Americans between the ages of 18 and 24 now stands at 27 million. The USA Freedom Corps would enroll less than one half of one percent of these people, a far cry from the level of participation that Americans would willingly support if a bold program were in place.
Today's younger generation is one of the most idealistic in years. On college campuses students began volunteering in record numbers long before Sept. 11. As the Rev. Peter Gomes of Harvard writes in an insightful new book, one can hear a cri de coeur from students today who are asking how "to make a life, and not just a living." A call for universal service would help them find the answer. It would also teach us as a nation, as previous wars have taught us, what we share as Americans.
If he can succeed in the war on terrorism, Mr. Bush will be remembered as a very good president. If he brings peace to the Middle East, he will earn international honor. But if he also creates a new sense of national purpose before this moment fades, he could enter the front ranks of American presidents.

HEADLINE: Common Foe For Musicians And Labels 

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 16 

 BODY:
Four months ago, recording artists were nearly at war with their recording companies, comparing the relationship to that of indentured servants forced to serve corporate bosses concerned mostly with filling their coffers.
 Politics, though, can make friends of even the most ardent foes. 
 In the next few weeks, United States lawmakers are expected to introduce legislation backed by both artists and recording companies who are suddenly joined against what they consider their newest enemy: the radio conglomerates whose practices, they contend, cost them millions of dollars each year.
The bill, which is sponsored by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, will address several issues, including whether to limit consolidation in the radio industry by imposing a cap on the number of stations a company can own. He will also seek to limit the practice of record labels' paying independent promoters to promote new hits to station programmers, something that has gone on for decades, but is now being described as a new form of payola. 
The artists and labels have come together out of necessity, largely an outgrowth of the big problems facing the music business. Sales of new albums have plummeted as consumers have figured out how to access music over the Internet. Artists are demanding more flexible recording contracts and better accounting. At the same time, corporate parents, forced to shore up their own balance sheets, are demanding that record labels cut costs.
"Any time you have changes in the dynamics of an industry, you have an opportunity to rejigger the economic pie," said Carey Sherman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, the Washington lobbying group which represents record companies.
Greg Hessinger, national executive director of the American Federation of Television and Recording Artists, added, "No one wants to be left behind." But what is striking to many is what they consider to be the teapot calling the kettle black: the recording companies, who for the most part have been gobbled up by large global media conglomerates themselves, are attacking the radio industry for its consolidation. The Universal Music Group, for one, a division of Vivendi Universal, has distributed nearly one of every three new albums sold so far this year. And just last week, BMG Music, which is owned by Bertelsmann, announced it was buying the Zomba Music Group, the largest independent record company, which it already owned a stake in.
"Now it's all about synergy and economics of scale," said Michael Bracy, director of government relations for the Future of Music Coalition, a Washington think tank for artist rights.
Some critics say that recording companies lost a big promotional opportunity when they failed to capitalize on the popularity of Internet music early on. Instead, says David Goldberg, vice president and general manager of music for Yahoo.com, record labels treated independent online music concerns as competitors instead of valuable, promotional vehicles. That approach, he said, bolstered the dependence of labels and artists on radio. (The Justice Department is currently investigating the online activities of the recording industry because of antitrust concerns.)
To be sure, radio stations, recording companies and the artists they represent have a complex relationship. In 1996, the federal government lifted the ban on the numbers of radio stations a single entity could own and the industry shifted almost overnight. According to federal records, from March 1996 to March 2001 the number of radio stations increased 7 percent while the number of owners dropped 25 percent. The biggest acquirer was the Clear Channel Communications, based in San Antonio, whose properties have swelled since then to 1,244 radio stations, 36 TV stations and 135 concert venues they either own, operate or have a stake in.
With that came a change in the way recording companies dealt with independent promoters, the agents or middlemen who have flourished since the 1950's and who are hired to pitch new songs to radio programmers.
Independent promoters work like this: Promoters pay a broadcaster or radio station a yearly promotional fee, which allows them to pitch songs on behalf of a label. In return, promoters are given an advance look at the list of new songs added each week. In exchange for that information, a record label can pay a promoter several thousand dollars for each new song added.
Consolidation in the radio industry, though, added a new twist. In the past two years, the radio conglomerates -- including the largest chain, Clear Channel and smaller chains like Radio One -- have designated promoters they want to work with exclusively. (Some executives estimate the recording industry pays independent promoters as much as $200 million a year overall.) Mr. Sherman of the Recording Industry Association said overall promotional costs began to rise dramatically, prompting protests from record executives.
It also made it harder for less-well known acts to get airplay, artist advocates contend. "The focus has gone toward the bean counters and the love of profit," Mr. Bracy added. "But there is a question of what is good for culture."
Kraig Kitchin, president of Premiere Radio Network, a division of Clear Channel, described the situation this way: "I'm not going to tell you our company needs the independent promoter. Record companies do."
He said promoters are less necessary for the stations because, as is the case with his company, program directors collect reams of data and talk among themselves to help make programming decisions not only at one radio station, but countrywide. "That dynamic needs to be taken into account by the labels," he said.
In some ways it already has. A private complaint among record executives (but one they will not say publicly) is that their money is not buying what it used to, that it was easier for a promoter to influence a radio station's playing list when the decision-making by programmers was not so centralized.
"The question," Mr. Sherman said, "is what is the value of the relationship we are trying to capitalize on?"
Not much anymore, according to some in the industry, which is why corporate parents see promotion as a convenient place to trim.
So why then do not recording executives just refuse to pay independent promoters, something they can individually do without Congressional backing? (If they agreed as a group they could run afoul of anti-trust laws.) Many are afraid not to, they say, because they fear retaliation from promoters or radio programmers who could decide to not play new or lesser-known acts.
But as importantly, labels do not trust each other, saying competition is so fierce they will do anything to get what is perceived to be an edge.
"Even if we agree not to do this, someone else will," said one recording executive who asked not to be named. "No one wants to be first. Everyone is in such a huge fit to increase their market share, people will do whatever it takes."
By asking Congress to legislate promotional expenses for them, said another executive, it gets recording executives off the hook. "That way no gets screamed at by their bosses."
Fred Davis, the New York music lawyer whose firm represents bands like Linkin Park and Puddle of Mudd, said the interdependence between radio, musicians and record labels is going to have to be rethought and change with the new pressures in the music business.
"We are all scratching at a declining stream of revenue," he said. "The problem is there is no way to evolve right now unless you totally reinvent the business model."

HEADLINE: Korean Insurers Are Allowed to Expand 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 16 

 BODY:
The South Korean finance ministry announced a sweeping proposal today to allow the country's largest conglomerates, or chaebol, to open insurance firms and build on the ones they already have.
 The ministry said the measures, included in legislation that the National Assembly is expected to adopt in the next few months, would also remove rules that have prevented banks from marketing insurance products. 
 At the same time, in an effort to protect insurance firms and their customers, the bill would impose new limits on the amount of credit they can extend.
The legislation, the first since the basic insurance bill was adopted 25 years ago, seeks to streamline an industry that was hard hit by the economic crisis that swept the region in late 1997. 
The Korea Deposit Insurance Company, an agency of the finance ministry, took over one of the nation's biggest insurers, the Korea Life Insurance Company, at the height of the crisis and is still looking for a buyer.
Although the government has been trying to cut down on the power of the conglomerates that have long dominated the Korean economy, the net effect of the legislation would be to remove restrictions that kept the country's five biggest business groups from expanding on the insurance companies they already own. 
Banking officials described the bill as long overdue considering the size of the industry, which has 22 life and 22 nonlife insurance firms.
The bill would mean that both Hyundai and the LG Ggroup, two of the largest conglomerates, would be free to go into insurance for the first time. Other conglomerates, notably the Samsung group, Korea's largest conglomerate, which includes Samsung Life Insurance, could expand on the kind of insurance they now offer.
Equally important, the bill would answer the frequent complaints of foreign bankers that the government imposes restrictions that make it difficult to operate here.
Under the program, banks could become insurance companies as well, entering a field that was previously closed to them. Banks have been calling for years for the freedom to diversify into insurance, as do firms in the United States and Europe.
The government viewed the legislation as part of an effort to loosen tight restraints on the Korean insurance industry, which potential foreign investors have often described as bogged down in regulations that impede the growth of Korean firms and discourage investors.
The measures are the second overhaul of existing legislation that is giving conglomerates more power than they have ever had in the financial business. The National Assembly has passed a bill that will raise the number of shares that a conglomerate company can own in a bank from 4 percent to 10 percent.
The bill, however, also seeks to reduce the risks of pressure from the conglomerates that would turn insurance companies into financial tools for their own security and enrichment.
The legislation would impose a ceiling of 12 percent of an insurance company's equity on the amount that it can lend to any single creditor and a ceiling of 40 percent of assets on the extent of loans to a group and its subsidiaries. 
Nor could an insurance company buy stocks and bonds in a conglomerate or its subsidiaries with a value above 60 percent of the company's equity.
The commitment of the government in enforcing such rules appeared questionable, however, since none will take effect until 2007 while companies were expected to open insurance companies and build on the ones they have as soon as possible after the bill goes into law, probably in the fall. The rules, when they do take effect, would appear to give a conglomerate huge influence over the fortunes of any insurance firm under its control.
At the same time, the legislation would make it far easier for an insurance company, regardless of who owns it, to go into business and then to profit by investing.
Under the legislation, a company would need no more than 5 billion won, about $4.1 million, to go into business as opposed to the current minimum of 10 billion won. The bill would remove all barriers to an insurance company investing inside Korea and raise the limit on investment abroad from 20 percent to 30 percent of an insurance company's assets.

HEADLINE: Toehold on a Long Trek to Heal India-Pakistan Rift 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 16 

 BODY:
American diplomacy in Pakistan and India this month has produced a tiny victory for each side in the struggle over Kashmir, a toehold on which to proceed. But the car bomb that killed 11 people outside the American Consulate here on Friday made clear that the road to any long-term solution will be difficult and dangerous.
 High-level visits to both countries this month succeeded in pulling them back from the brink of war. They opened the way for tentative steps that could address the roots of their long-running conflict over Kashmir. 
 But a total of one million soldiers remain on alert on both sides of the frontier of the two countries. Shelling and gunfire continue in that disputed Himalayan territory. In a worst-case scenario, both countries have nuclear weapons. 
In Pakistan, Islamic militants who feel betrayed by the government's abandonment of the Taliban in Afghanistan and now by its clampdown in Kashmir are fighting back with the only weapon they have, more violence.
If they can destabilize the government of President Pervez Musharraf in Pakistan or provoke retaliation by India, they could undermine the fragile process begun with the visits of Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage and Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld.
In concrete terms, those visits produced only modest gestures and assurances. But analysts said both sides seemed now to be seeking a way to end the confrontation that, as Mr. Rumsfeld emphasized, is exhausting both of them militarily and economically.
"It could be that this is just a pause in what would be seen as a perpetual crisis in South Asia," said Philip Cohen, a South Asia expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
On the other hand, he said, "Sometimes out of a crisis you get a moment when both sides can move freely.
"Let's hope this is such a moment," he added. "The United States is uniquely placed now, as never in history, to do something."
Its close economic and military relations with both countries have put it in a position to act as an impartial broker, or at least as an honest messenger between them.
The small victories won by each side addressed important concerns. 
India won the support of the United States, as well as other nations, for its position that Pakistan has actively been aiding the infiltration of militants across the border and that General Musharraf could therefore cut them off.
"India has squeezed him and been successful in turning the rest of the world against him," said Pervez Hoodbhoy, a leader in Pakistan's antiwar movement. "So he's really feeling the heat."
As the American officials shuttled back and forth between the capitals, Pakistan gained too. Without any formal declaration, a foreshadowing of the dialogue it had been seeking over Kashmir had begun.
India has ruled out negotiation, saying the subject of Kashmir was already closed. The large portion of Kashmir that it controls, it insists, is part of India and neither Pakistan nor any other country has any role to play there.
But it is precisely this delicate game of message-carrying that opens the possibility of an eventual resolution to a deadlock of counterclaims over mostly Muslim Kashmir that has persisted since Pakistan and India were partitioned in 1947, and has already caused two wars between them.
"If left to themselves, given the personal animosities on both sides, it is hard to imagine Indian and Pakistani leaders getting together and making serious progress," said George Perkovich, a South Asia expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.
Two weeks ago, General Musharraf and Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India were at an international conference in Kazakhstan and refused not only to shake hands but even to look at each other.
Days later, Mr. Armitage visited both leaders and carried statements of their positions back and forth between them.
"This is not mediation," Mr. Perkovich said. "Let's be clear about that. Does a telephone wire mediate? No. It basically carries messages. That's the kind of role the United States can play."
Part of this role will be to assure India that Pakistan is keeping its word to halt infiltration by militant groups over the border into the Indian part of Kashmir. Both countries are considering an American offer to provide technical surveillance that could include motion sensors, satellite images and observation by unmanned aircraft.
If he keeps his pledge to seal the border -- to move from the military to the diplomatic arena -- General Musharraf risks accusations at home that he has betrayed the Kashmir cause.
To survive a domestic backlash, from opposition parties or disaffected military men, he needs to be able to show that he has won concessions from India -- a softening of its military posture and a dialogue on Kashmir. 
A first hint came today that India might relax its alert status along the border. Even though there have been attacks in Kashmir in the last 24 hours that have killed a dozen people, Indian military officials said that for the first time since their Kashmir buildup began in December, some soldiers and officers would be permitted to go on leave.
As both sides maneuver delicately, they both must watch the calendar.
The crucial month is October, when local elections will be held in the Indian portion of Kashmir and national parliamentary elections will be held in Pakistan.
Indian officials have said they do not expect to remove their troops from the border before then, guarding against violence by Pakistan-backed militants bent on disrupting the Kashmir vote.
Analysts said India was determined to complete the election before opening any real dialogue with Pakistan and to use what it expected to be a favorable vote as a bargaining piece.
If war can be averted until then, Kashmir's early snows will be likely to delay it further, making both infiltration and military action difficult and unlikely.
In that case, the next crisis may come as it did this year -- or be averted by a new era of statesmanship -- when the snows melt next spring. 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article on Monday about American efforts to avert war between Pakistan and India misstated the given name of a South Asia expert at the Brookings Institution who commented on the outlook for a solution. He is Stephen P. Cohen, not Philip.

HEADLINE: Powell's Trial Balloon 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Building on an idea from Egypt's Hosni Mubarak, Colin Powell went on Arab television last week to launch a trial balloon. 
 Speaking of "a Palestinian state called Palestine," he said "it may be necessary to have a provisional state, an interim step. . . . something that we can create that is, that can be called a state." This was followed by a six-column headline: "Bush Is Said to Tell Saudis He Will Offer Plan for Creation of a Palestinian State." 
 But when asked about this notion of recognizing a state on West Bank and Gaza land now occupied by Palestinian forces unwilling to control suicide bombers, President Bush's press secretary said only "the president receives advice all the time." 
Here's my advice: Don't step into this trap. It's a lose-lose idea. 
1. Statehood, even if qualified as provisional or interim, confers a degree of sovereignty. That means control of borders, the ability to make treaties, and to import arms from Iraq and by sea from Iran. 
2. Partial statehood would give Arafat control of an airport. A plane loaded with fuel or explosives could hit a major Tel Aviv building within three minutes, too quickly for Israeli jets to scramble. Ritual condemnation would follow. 
3. Any form of statehood would limit Israel's ability to search out bomb factories and arrest terrorist leaders. What is now a tolerable sweep into disputed territory would be denounced in the U.N. as invasion pure and simple. That would trigger European economic boycotts and draw Arab allies into a wider war. 
Why, then, offer Arafat's autocracy this pre-emptive prize? State Department Arabists claim it would show "movement" away from solid Bush support for Israel and, in the still-dovish Shimon Peres's phrase, offer a "political horizon" to Palestinians. But some of us see recognition of an unreformed P.L.O. as offering a taste of triumph to jihadists from Netanya to New York. 
Nobody doubts that statehood will be part of an eventual settlement. That goal provides a powerful incentive for Palestinians to take command of their destiny. But if killing Israeli civilians is rewarded piecemeal, responsible Palestinian leaders will be less likely to fight a civil war being waged against them now by Hamas and the Islamic Jihad -- whose stated goal is to drive Jews out of the Middle East. 
What about Mubarak's "timetable" for full statehood, with a down payment of the 40 percent of the West Bank and Gaza now under Palestinian control, including almost all the Arab population? That is similar to the territorial timetable dreamily agreed to at Oslo, which assumed that regular concessions of land would lead to mutual trust and peace. Instead, Israel's calibrated concessions led to Arafat's insatiable demands and ultimately to war. A timetable for a state of Palestine would become a deadline for Israeli negotiators. 
Why didn't Ariel Sharon, last week in Washington, strongly and publicly oppose it? Maybe because he trusts Bush and underestimates Powell's media savvy; maybe Sharon did not want to appear to be following Likud's recent unequivocal lead against talk of statehood now. I reached him at his farm last night. 
"The Bush administration knows very well our position," the prime minister said. "It is premature now until the full cessation of terror and its incitement, and until there is real reform. I was willing to discuss cease-fire under fire, but I cannot discuss political developments under fire. Many things must happen before that is discussed." 
He wouldn't say what he told Bush on this, but his use of "premature" suggests that once violence subsides and a peace partner emerges, Sharon would be willing to tie the long-term interim agreements he seeks to interim or provisional forms of Palestinian sovereignty. I think statehood should be the deal-closer, and such salami slicing of statehood would be a mistake for the reasons enumerated above, but to strain an old metaphor, it's hard to be more Catholic than the pope. 
A more truculent reaction to Powell's trial balloon of phased statehood comes from Saeb Erekat, Arafat's top negotiator, who demands all or nothing. What if the only statehood Bush offers leaves Israelis at checkpoints between Palestinian cities looking for suicide bombers? He told The New York Times: "I'm afraid that you're going to have a bigger explosion than you're having now."

HEADLINE: How to Split Up the Bipolar F.B.I. 

BYLINE:  By Duncan DeVille; Duncan DeVille, a public service fellow at Harvard's Kennedy School, was an assistant United States attorney in Los Angeles from 1998 to 2001.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
When Robert S. Mueller III, director of the F.B.I., testifies this week before the Congressional intelligence committees, one important question will be whether to move counterterrorism operations out of the bureau. The Congressional leaders who favor doing so are right about the need to break up the F.B.I. But its counterterrorism and counterintelligence work should not be shifted, as some have proposed, into the new Department of Homeland Security envisioned in President Bush's bold proposal. They should go instead to a new, separate office, an American version of Britain's domestic intelligence agency, MI5.
 The F.B.I.'s 28,000 employees are already divided into two disparate branches. The traditional law enforcement agents react to crimes that have already occurred -- for example, bank robberies, kidnappings and organized crime activities. The counterintelligence agents work to disable national security threats -- uncovering Soviet spies in America during the cold war, for example, or finding Qaeda operatives today. 
 Strangely, F.B.I. agents go back and forth between the two branches. Typically a tour of duty is a few years long, yet an agent might find herself chasing terrorists one year and interviewing bank robbers the next.
Further, the counterintelligence wing has long been needlessly hobbled by rules of criminal procedure used in trial courts. Its cases rarely make it to trial; the purpose of its investigations is to gain intelligence that can be used to fight national enemies. Yet this wing's agents are bound by rules that would apply if they were preparing a case for trial: Miranda warnings for detainees, disclosure of confidential informants, disclosure of payments to sources. Some exceptions can be made under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, but getting approval has been difficult, and overly cautious practices are ingrained in F.B.I. counterintelligence agents.
At the same time, the current system poses a threat to civil liberties. When we push the envelope of due process in fighting a war, we also potentially empower the traditional law enforcement wing of the F.B.I. to use these powers in its cases.
Splitting the F.B.I.'s wings could leave the traditional domestic law-enforcement part as the Federal Bureau of Investigation while creating a smaller, more effective way of managing counterintelligence work.
The British agency for domestic intelligence, MI5 (as opposed to MI6 of James Bond fame, which covers foreign intelligence), offers a good model for a new American agency that would assume the F.B.I.'s intelligence functions. MI5 (the official name is the Security Service) is a civilian agency under the authority of the home secretary. It is charged with protecting Britain's national security against terrorism, espionage, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and attacks aimed at crippling the national economy. MI5 has been very effective at infiltrating and weakening foreign saboteurs. In fact, so effective that in 1992 responsibility for leading the intelligence effort against Irish republican terrorism on the British mainland was transferred to it from Scotland Yard and other law-enforcement agencies.
Of course we must be vigilant in making sure that an American domestic intelligence agency is restrained in its powers and operates in line with the civil liberties safeguards that apply to federal law-enforcement agencies now. External oversight by Congress is essential.
Some will argue that the new Department of Homeland Security should house the F.B.I. counterintelligence functions. However, the Department of Justice is a better home for them. The new agency's duties would, after all, still be related closely to law enforcement. Possibly, however, parts of spy agencies like the C.I.A. and the Defense Department intelligence agencies should be folded into the MI5-like agency.
President Bush's bold proposal for the new cabinet department will be hard to get through Congress; this F.B.I. reorganization would step on even more toes. But momentum is growing to fix the F.B.I., and the changes must be substantive. We can learn from the British model.

PERSON: Tim Tompkins 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Dirty Thoughts, Dirtier Bombs and Times Square

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
THERE are many questions to ask Tim Tompkins, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, as he steps out into the clamorous neighborhood, ambling down Broadway, scooting west over to the "New 42nd Street," heading up still-scuzzy Eighth Avenue.
 Let's start with the less scary stuff. Are the prostitutes and petty thieves returning to the district's neon-lit fringes, as some reports suggest? Mr. Tompkins is prepared, armed with police statistics. 
 He hasn't seen any, but security was increased on Eighth Avenue anyway. "Because Times Square is such a high-profile place, there has to be zero tolerance," he says on the way to the area the other morning. "But the reality is that the crime stats are down and they keep going down."
The prospect of sleaze slithering back into Times Square is certainly less frightening than the chilling reminders these days about dirty bombs and how a nuclear device in a suitcase on West 43rd Street could send 20,000 people to kingdom come.
But Mr. Tompkins, 38, doesn't act as if Armageddon is around the corner. Even on this muggy day, he has the unruffled look of a pleasant television anchor, with his neatly groomed hair, pink tie and black suit. He walks briskly.
He has reason to step lively. He's catching a plane in a few hours to Bilbao, Spain, where he was invited by business leaders to talk about the transformation of Times Square.
Mr. Tompkins is the former director of Partnerships for Parks, a group he founded seven years ago to generate community support for neglected parks. He now presides over a district that provides extra security, sanitation and big-time boosterism in an area where you are lucky to find a scrawny tree. The district, which has an annual budget of $5.9 million, includes 5,000 businesses and 500 property owners.
Times Square, he says, "is a crazy, manic version of town square."
He has other good lines: "Times Square is not humanity at its best or its worst but at its most, which is a lot of what New York is. That's what gets sent out to the rest of the world. Times Square is the definition of what New York is."
Isn't that kind of the worry? Should people feel safe here?
"I feel that the honest answer for so many of these issues is unanswerable," says Mr. Tompkins, leaving his visitor unsatisfied -- and apologizing for it. "That's not to say you can't do things, but you also can't kid yourself about the capacity to fully cover every contingency."
Mr. Tompkins began his job in February, becoming the de facto mayor of Times Square. But unlike when the district was created in 1992 to rally against the neighborhood's reputation as a dangerous, seedy place overflowing with peep shows and pornography shops, he faces new quality-of-life challenges after Sept. 11.
Dirty thoughts to dirty bombs. What a difference a decade makes.
"Until a couple of weeks ago, people were talking about eyeball scanners, and now, there's talk about dirty bombs and radiation detection," he says, referring to the headlines at the Broadway newsstands. "Nobody right now has been talking much about anthrax and chemical and biological weapons, but that was the topic du jour. So the key is to be nimble. Part of the nature of my job is to stay on top of whatever issues come up."
He says the district is sending its 50 public safety officers to police antiterrorism workshops, strengthening its neighborhood watch consisting of shopkeepers, property managers and private security guards, and creating an inventory of hidden surveillance cameras, which could lead to their coordinated use against terrorism.
"There are legitimate concerns we need to be sensitive to, but we also need to be as cooperative as possible with any police initiatives to reduce our collective vulnerability," he says.
Mr. Tompkins is known for his adeptness in dealing with different constituencies, but also for being cautious at times. Perhaps that's why he talks so much about things meriting discussion.
YET he gets as animated as a cheerleader when he discusses the possibility of putting public art in temporarily vacant retail spaces and paying more attention to design.
His learning curve isn't huge. From 1993 to 1995 he was the senior project manager on the revitalization of West 42nd Street at the New York City Economic Development Corporation, and in the late 1980's, he worked for the city's Charter Revision Commission.
Growing up in suburban Philadelphia, he knew in eighth grade, while working on the school newspaper, that he would go into public service. His father owned a printing business. His mother raised four children -- he was the youngest.
Since 1986, he has lived mostly in New York. But in the early 1990's, Mr. Tompkins, who is gay, followed his partner to Paris, where he studied French at the Sorbonne, then to Mexico, where Mr. Tompkins was the national editor of The News of Mexico City, an English-language newspaper. He has an M.B.A. from Wharton.
He is now unattached and, he stresses, available, though he shares an apartment with that former boyfriend a few blocks away in Hell's Kitchen. Oh? "All relationships in New York City are fundamentally driven by real estate," he says, laughing.
